The sky still appears moody after a stormy day. A</p><p nitf:lede="true">stately, silvery shape, the 240-tonne Hindenburg airship glides 60m</p><p nitf:lede="true">above New Jersey about 7.21pm. In a six-knot wind, the zeppelin is</p><p nitf:lede="true">attempting its first "high landing". The crew throws the spider</p><p nitf:lede="true">lines out, preparing for mooring. The gigantic ship nearly three</p><p>football fields in length would slowly be winched down . . .</p><p>IF you think you know exactly what happens next, Addison Bain has a</p><p>surprise for you.</p><p>Six decades after the infamous Hindenburg disaster, when 36 of 97</p><p>aboard died in the horrific blaze that halted rigid-airship travel,</p><p>Bain has revealed a stunning new explanation for what started the</p><p>fire.</p><p>Bain, a recently retired engineer and manager of hydrogen programs who</p><p>spent more than 30 years at NASA, recently ended several years of</p><p>scientific sleuthing work for the reason behind the disaster.</p><p>He combed thousands of pages of original testimony and materials at</p><p>four archives in the United States and one in Germany, he interviewed</p><p>survivors and airship experts and, ultimately, tested original</p><p>materials from the model LZ-129 Hindenburg and its contempories.</p><p>Contrary to what investigators ruled at the time, asserts Bain, the</p><p>fire did not start with free hydrogen lit by natural electrical</p><p>discharge or sabotage.</p><p>The hunt for the truth about Hindenburg began in the late 1960s for</p><p>Bain, who was working on a hydrogen safety manual for NASA. Bain</p><p>recalls how he read the literature on hydrogen.</p><p>"Invariably," he says, "the topic of Hindenburg would come up. At</p><p>the time, I didn't think a lot about it."</p><p>Over the years, however, as he continued his NASA work on hydrogen</p><p>systems, the references began to accumulate in his mind.</p><p>"What I was starting to notice was that the authors were</p><p>inconsistent," he says. Hydrogen detractors said the gas was so</p><p>flammable it killed everyone on Hindenburg, which was not true: about</p><p>one-third of those aboard died.</p><p>"On the other hand, hydrogen promoters rubbished safety concerns and</p><p>claimed that those who perished did so only because they jumped from</p><p>the burning airship, which also was not true.</p><p>"I thought, 'wait a minute! Where are they getting their</p><p>information'?"</p><p>Bain had also seen the famous photos of Hindenburg's bright,</p><p>blistering, hot fire and knew that hydrogen did not burn that way.</p><p>A hydrogen fire radiates little heat and is barely visible to the</p><p>unaided eye.</p><p>As a hydrogen expert, he knew that the pure gas does not explode. That</p><p>was enough. He donned a pair of protective gloves, and lost himself in</p><p>decades-old original documents in Washington's National Air and Space</p><p>Museum.</p><p>His research soon became something of a obsession.</p><p>He speculated that, perhaps, some of the airship's materials had</p><p>played a role in ignition. But, maddeningly, he could not find the</p><p>exact formulations used.</p><p>"I had the idea of the problem, but needed enough evidence to back up</p><p>my story," Bain says.</p><p>That was as far as he went, until 1994, when he ran into Space Shuttle</p><p>technician Richard van Treuren, at a conference on hydrogen. Van</p><p>Treuren was a self-avowed "helium head" and member of the airship</p><p>aficionados' group called the Lighter-Than-Air Society, in Akron,</p><p>Ohio.</p><p>Through van Treuren, Bain learnt that pieces of Hindenburg's skin</p><p>still existed. Bain went throughout the US to procure them, also</p><p>spending hundreds of dollars buying original materials, books and</p><p>papers.</p><p>"What I was trying to find out," he says, "was what did they use</p><p>specifically in the coating?"</p><p>Hepburn Walker, who had been stationed at Lakehurst in the early</p><p>1940s, was among those with pieces of Hindenburg. Walker had found</p><p>them in the soil. Another sample, a part of the swastika painted on</p><p>Hindenburg's side, was kept in a safe by Cheryl Gantz, head of the</p><p>Zeppelin Collectors Club in Chicago.</p><p>Materials in hand, Bain headed to NASA's Materials Science Laboratory</p><p>at nearby Kennedy Space Centre. Over the next 14 months, he carefully</p><p>laid out a systematic testing protocol involving about 14 researchers</p><p>who volunteered their spare time to assist in what became known as</p><p>Project H.</p><p>What was in that fabric? An infra-red spectograph and a scanning</p><p>electron microscope provided, respectively, the chemical signatures of</p><p>the organic compounds and elements present.</p><p>A startling variety of highly flammable compounds proved to have been</p><p>added to the cotton fabric base.</p><p>"They used a cellulose acetate of nitrate as a typical doping</p><p>compound, which is flammable to begin with a forest fire is a</p><p>cellulose fire," says Bain.</p><p>"OK, you coat that with cellulose nitrate nitrate is used to make</p><p>gunpowder.</p><p>"And then you put (on) aluminium powder. Now, aluminium powder is a</p><p>fuel used in the solid rocket boosters on the Space Shuttle."</p><p>The wood spacers and fibrous ramie cord used to bind the structure</p><p>together, along with the silk and other fabrics in the ship, also</p><p>would have added to the fuel-rich inferno. Even the duralumin support</p><p>framework of Hindenburg's rigid skeleton was coated with lacquer,</p><p>ostensibly to protect it from moisture.</p><p>In a flame test, a fabric section ignited and burnt readily. The arc</p><p>test, in which 30,000 volts were zapped across a piece of fabric</p><p>several centimetres along, was even more revealing.</p><p>"Poof, it disappeared. The whole thing happened faster than I can</p><p>explain it," Bain says. "I guess the moral of the story is, don't</p><p>paint your airship with rocket fuel."</p><p>However, Bain is quick to point out it is not that the Germans and</p><p>other airship and aircraft makers of the era were simply foolish in</p><p>doping the fabric the way they did. They had a number of technical</p><p>problems to solve using the materials of the time.</p><p>The cotton or linen fabric skin was swabbed with the chemicals to make</p><p>it taut and reduce flutter for aerodynamics, and then painted with the</p><p>reflective red iron oxide and aluminium so the sun's heat would not</p><p>expand the gas in the cells, to help prevent gas escaping.</p><p>"I'm not saying hydrogen didn't contribute to the fire," adds Bain.</p><p>It is, after all, a fuel, he notes and one he is hoping will develop</p><p>into a replacement or supplement to natural gas.</p><p>"But it was a fuel-rich fire already, the hydrogen just added to</p><p>it."</p><p>Decades of speculation about the causes behind the start of the</p><p>zeppelin fire are academic, he says. All have blamed hydrogen, with</p><p>various ideas about how the gas became free and ignited.</p><p>One popular theory has it that a wire punctured a gas cell. Bain finds</p><p>this doubtful.</p><p>"If that happened, it should have occurred during one of the final</p><p>manoeuvres." But, he says, the ship was stationary for four minutes</p><p>before fire was evident.</p><p>What about the possibility of loose hydrogen from the vents? Hydrogen</p><p>was released to help maintain level flight, and others have theorised</p><p>that a valve may have stuck open.</p><p>Bain says Hindenburg had an excellent venting system, with vents</p><p>between cells that measured about 60cm high and 200cm wide.</p><p>If hydrogen accumulated difficult to imagine for the lightest</p><p>element, which has the greatest dispersal rate in the universe why,</p><p>he asks, were none of the fires observed at the vent sites on top of</p><p>the ship?</p><p>What is perhaps most stunning about Bain's research is that what he</p><p>has discovered comes 60 years after some German airship experts</p><p>already knew it. While visiting an archive in Germany, he copied two</p><p>1937 letters, handwritten in German, that had not been seen by earlier</p><p>investigators.</p><p>Their contents were revealed to Bain only after he returned to Florida</p><p>and had them translated. They were written by an electrical engineer</p><p>named Otto Beyerstock, who had incinerated pieces of Hindenburg fabric</p><p>during electrical tests conducted at the behest of the Zeppelin</p><p>company.</p><p>In the notes, Beyerstock testily dismissed the idea that hydrogen</p><p>could have started the fire, stating that it could only have been</p><p>caused by the fabric's flammability in a charged atmosphere.</p><p>"I beg you to kindly inform me about the corrective measures to be</p><p>taken or that have already been taken," Beyerstock wrote to Zeppelin.</p><p>"They knew," Bain says simply.</p><p>But soon after the Hindenburg disaster, and probably because of it,</p><p>the great zeppelins were removed from service.</p><p>None of what Bain has learnt has diminished his admiration for the</p><p>engineering achievement in creating the great airships.</p><p>"With all due respect," he says, "the Germans did a fantastic job.</p><p>"I admire their technology.</p><p>"It was just an unfortunate little flaw, just like the flaw on</p><p>Titanic and the flaw in Challenger," he says, referring to the</p><p>"unsinkable" ship's sulphurous, brittle steel and the Space</p><p>Shuttle's O-ring both of which failed under prevailing weather</p><p>conditions.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4P85-1530-TXN5-R2R4-00000-00Keepers of the watch when the summer heat is on1997-11-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:50:12ZLexisNexisNORTHERN HERALDPg. 4Keepers of the watch when the summer heat is onCOL ALLISON

THE first line of defence against major bushfires throughout the North Shore, Central Coast and Blue Mountains foothills is a tiny observation shed atop a tall tower on a firetrail at Galston, in The Hills district of Sydney.

Staffed by volunteers who usually spot the first wisp of smoke from fires as far afield as Gosford, Frenchs Forest and Katoomba, the Galston fire-tower is likely to be a hotbed of action during the 1997-98 summer.

The fire outlook for the Bush Fire Danger Period - October 1 until March 31, 1998 - appears grim. Up to 99 per cent of NSW bushland has not been burnt for decades. That means there is plenty of fuel, made all the more dangerous by the El Nino effect and recent sweltering temperatures.

Most of the State's 70,000 fire-fighters are readying for the worst, with the Commissioner of the NSW Rural Fire Service, Mr Phil Koperberg, warning: "We must be prepared and vigilant."

On a sobering note, the commissioner said it was not a question of whether we'll have fires; we always have fires. Nor was it a question of how many, although a great number of fires would spread resources and tire out fire crews.

"It's not about the size of individual fires, either, though this increases the work load upon firefighters," he said.

"Principally, it's about how intense the fires will be.

"High temperatures, low humidity and high fuel levels produce high-intensity fires. If strong winds drive these intense fires, then the potential for people and their property to be threatened also intensifies."

Mr Koperberg was keen to remind people that the disastrous fires of January 1994 ravaged just 1 per cent of the NSW land mass. "People forget that much of NSW has not been subject to high-intensity fires for many, many years."

Although it's too early to predict the likely seasonal outcome, dangerous weather conditions and high fuel levels mean that, for 99 per cent of the State, only a spark is required to deliver fires of high intensity.

Most firefighters spoken to by The Northern Herald are fearful of a torrid time ahead, but hopefully not as disastrous as the 16 days of January 1994 when the State was ablaze with 800 fires across 800,000 hectares, many deliberately lit.

Black January resulted in the loss of 208 houses, the deaths of two fire-fighters and one resident directly. A fourth death was indirectly attributable to the fires. In many eyes, we were lucky. It could have been much worse. The USA National Fire Protection Association was predicting a loss of 2,000 NSW homes via its computer modelling.

We've In the event, the Deputy State Coroner, Mr John Hyatt, conducted an exhaustive inquiry into the bushfires. After 12 months of hearings, he recommended the establishment of a Rural Fire Service (formerly the NSW Department of Bush Fire Services) with a single chain of command and a standard set of operational procedures.

The new service was delivered with the proclamation of the Rural Fires Act 1997 on August 31. In summary, the act established the Rural Fire Service and defined its functions. It also set universal standards for safety, training, equipment and procedures across the service.

The act established the responsibilities and accountabilities attached to everyone in the service from the commissioner down, while defining the role of local councils in the service's management. It ensured that all involved in the delivery of fire protection were shielded from legal liability for any task executed in good faith.

Mr Koperberg has hailed what he terms "the new era of fire-fighting in NSW," claiming it will guide the service through the next century.

Meanwhile, a crucial factor in the future management of high-intensity summer bushfires in NSW and elsewhere - understanding just how fires behave - has become the subject of an innovative, six-year study in Western Australia.

Project Vesta involves the expertise of the CSIRO and Western Australia's Department of Land Conservation and Land Management (CALM), and has the backing of the Australasian Fire Authorities Council. The project will also involve scientists from Canada, NSW, South Australia and Victoria.

Vesta aims to build on existing knowledge offire behaviour to develop a standard system topredict accurately the spread and intensity of bushfires. Knowledge gained from the study willhelp determine the hazards in different types offuel and enable more accurate mapping of the threat of wildfires to towns and environment.

The CSIRO's head of Forestry and Forest Products, Dr Glen Kile, said that during the devastating 1994 NSW bushfires the blazes spread much faster that predicted by the standard McArthur Forest Fire Danger Metre, widely used in south-eastern Australia

to predict fire behaviour via fuel, topographical and weather indicators (particularly wind strength).

"The more accurately wildfire behaviour can be predicted, the more effective fire-control measures can be," he said.

Experimental four-hectare plots in various locations will be scientifically torched to measure how the fires' rates of spread are influenced by wind speed and the amount and type of fuel. Some of these sites have not been burnt for two decades and have a massive build-up of leaves and dry twigs - the flash fuels for wildfires.

Detailed measurements of the structure, arrangement and distribution of the various fuel components in the plots have been analysed and recorded by a team of scientists during the past 19 months. Their analyses indicate that a practical system to identify fuel structures can be developed for dry eucalypt forests and woodlands throughout Australia, with likely application overseas.

Back in the Crossland Road fire-tower, at Galston, brigade Captain Bill Lea, 41, a decorated former professional firefighter, and his small team of volunteers stand guard to protect a large slab of Sydney from bushfires.

As smoke billowed from the foot of the Blue Mountains the other day, Captain Lea, Ken Turnidge and Mary Laws - all volunteers - spotted it first from 20 metres above the treetops, raising the alert.

"We've caught quite a few fires. Even in 1994 when one memorable big blaze blew up at Arcadia and set off towards Hornsby, we were able to get crews on the road before it was reported fromelsewhere," Captain Lea said.

This month, the unique tower celebrates its 20th anniversary as an invaluable fire-fighting centre. THE former NSW Electricity Commission left it for the Galston brigade when local power lines were rerouted. The volunteers built a three-metre by three-metre watch-house on top, with a map table in the centre. A telescopic rifle sight is used to pinpoint distant smoke. Weather-reading instruments and radios linked to the fire-control network are solar powered.

From the tower top, the 360-degree view takes in the lower mountains, the Central Coast and most of Sydney's North Shore.

"It's the only one in the northern part of Sydney," Captain Lea said. "There was a tower at Berowra, but it rusted out and another old one at Terry Hills is no longer manned."

The watchtower is only staffed on days of total fire bans, critical periods when fires can spread quickly. There have been amusing moments in such times of tension, such as a year or so ago when the tower volunteers started calling smoke sightings but the smoke kept moving on, quickly.

"It took us a little while to realise it was the 3801 steam train moving up the northern line to Hornsby," Captain Lea laughed. "It gives us the horrors."

While the advantage of fire-towers is their ability to sight smoke long before the hundreds of calls from the public begin rolling in, the problem at Galston is that the crews can't get a second sighting to triangulate the co-ordinates, or pin down the exact distance to fires.

"We can get a rough bearing, but not get the distance, so we need a second tower in the Hills up around Berowra. We're hoping Hornsby Shire Council will do it, but we've got to find a proper site. Transfield has already offered us a good deal on a tower."

There is another problem. Understandably, many volunteers refuse to climb the tower's dizzying heights.

"They start climbing, then chicken out. From then on, they only fight fires from the ground," Captain Lea said. MR Turnidge, a nurseryman, was stuck in the tower one afternoon for many hours during a fierce electrical storm after a southerly struck. He sheltered as lightning bolts crashed all around, the fearsome wind bringing down trees everywhere. He was not deterred.

The Galston Brigade has 12 volunteers, but needs 20 more to fully staff the watchtower. The attrition rate, thanks to everyday jobs pressure, is high, at about 30 per cent a year. So plenty of new recruits are always required.

Potential volunteers can ring Bill Lea during office hours on 9651-4600.

TWO ILLUS Smoke detector . . . Brigade Captain Bill Lea on watch at the Galston fire-tower. Photo by ELIZABETH DOBBIE. Alone amongst the devastation... a householder examines the ruins after the 1995 bushfires.

urn:contentItem:4P8B-H140-TXN5-R1B8-00000-00The heat is on2000-08-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:50:12ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESNews ReviewPg. 38The heat is onMark Riley reports

Australian expertise is playing a vital role in controlling America's bushfire nightmare.

PAUL McBain gets his first look at the latest outbreak of fires as the small car zips down the road alongside the trout-filled Kootenai River.

Small plumes of white smoke rise out of the dense forest of ponderosa pines, feeding into a giant haze that has settled like a blanket over this picturesque tract of the mighty Rocky Mountain Range.

"Geez, they look like they could just go `boom!' at any minute," the NSW State Forest fire officer says with a mixture of wonderment and foreboding.

"Yep," agrees backseat passenger Donnie Strand in his Wild West drawl. "It could rocket up that ridge over there in the next few days ... take out all those trees ... sure would be something to see."

"Sure would. The place to be is up on those hills there," says McBain, motioning across the river to the western edge of the Rockies. "The view from up there would be spectacular."

Anyone overhearing this conversation about the aesthetics of fire could be excused for mistaking these men as pyromaniacs.

Yet, they are among the world's most accomplished fire-fighting strategists, out on a reconnaissance mission at the end of another long day battling America's worst bushfires in more than a century.

Fire is their obsession. They live it, and try not to breathe it. They respect it, sometimes even marvel at its ferocious beauty.

But their objective is to control it. "The fire's just doing what a fire's meant to do," says Strand, his gaze remaining glued to the smoke rising from the mountains in this stunning corner of north-western Montana.

"We've got to try to corral it up into the wilderness where it won't threaten any homes, and let it burn there for a few weeks until the snows come."

Strand is a fire behaviour analyst from neighbouring Washington State. His job is to study the new fires and report back to the central command on what they are likely to do over the ensuing days.

McBain, the fire management officer for the Hunter Region, is one of 82 Australians who have been flown in by the US Government to help co-ordinate the effort against the line of fires that has scorched the American West for the past four months.

Behind the wheel of the car is Paul de Mar, the fire prevention manager for NSW State Forests and team leader of the Australian and New Zealand contingents in this multi-national firefighting force.

"I guess `firefighting' is not quite the term for what we are doing," de Mar says as he turns the car back down the smoke-filled valley towards the central camp.

"It is more `fire management'. You can't hope to put them all out. There are too many of them and they're too big."

There are many lessons to be learnt from the American experience, de Mar says, some good, some not so good.

There has been very little "controlled burning" in American forests over the past 10 years while foresters, environmentalists, loggers and governments have debated the pros and cons of the practice. That has allowed forest "fuels" pine needles, branches and undergrowth to build up to unnatural levels, just waiting for a dry season like this to explode into flames.

"It's part of our European heritage that we think all fire is bad and has to be put out straight away," de Mar says. "But the Aborigines and the American Indians know that forests need fires to keep fuels down and maintain their ecosystems. Believe it or not, fires can be good."

There have been more than 2,000 fires in this part of Montana since mid-July. Few have been good.

The total across the US this year is fast approaching 70,000, a staggering figure that has stretched even this country's massive firefighting resources to breaking point. More than 2.2 million hectares of land has been destroyed in six States, with Montana and neighbouring northern Idaho and Wyoming hit worst.

There is no official cost of damage yet, but the firefighting bill alone is believed to be about $US500 million ($873 million) and growing at a rate of $US16 million a day.

Eleven firefighters have died, dozens of houses have been lost and an area larger than the State of Massachusetts destroyed.

More than 25,000 firefighters are in the field, including two army battalions and another three on the way, protecting dozens of communities threatened by the flames.

The Australians and 11 New Zealanders have been brought in to lend much-needed management-level assistance.

They are being spread across Montana and Idaho, sleeping in tents in mountain camps similar to the one outside the village of Troy, where de Mar, McBain and Strand are headed.

The trio arrive back in time for the nightly planning meeting to discuss strategies for the following day's efforts.

The area they are covering is mostly national forest and wilderness, home to a host of wildlife from grizzly bears and cougars to caribou and deer.

Karel Zebjrlik has been managing a team of 40 firefighters working the flank of a blaze that has been threatening to crawl down the mountain towards a small farming community. "It's pretty hilly where I come from," says Zebjrlik, an operations forester from Wauchope.

"But I've never seen anything like this. These hills go straight up. It just kills you going up and down them all the time."

Dean Anderson, the State Forests regional manager at Bathurst, says he finally got to speak with his wife on the phone. The camp is four hours' drive from the nearest city, Missoula. There are no mobile phone towers in sight and the few land lines are unreliable.

"They made an announcement at my five-year-old's school during assembly the other day that his dad was over in America fighting the big fires," Anderson tells his mates.

"The poor little bloke just burst into tears. He's seen the footage on TV of trees exploding in great bursts of flames and thinks I'm standing underneath them. He thinks I'm going to die."

The firefighters were pleased to find that the American system has a heavy emphasis on safety. The moment the fires even look like getting out of control, all ground crews are withdrawn and air support is called in to water bomb the flames.

There are 18 Australians in this camp, helping to co-ordinate 480 firefighters and control 46 individual fires. They have been working 14-day shifts of anywhere between 12 and 18 hours and will continue to do so for another three weeks. None of them need rocking to sleep at night.

It is below freezing as the next day breaks. The temperature on the mountains will rise to 36 degrees Celsius by mid-afternoon, searing the ridges where the fires are at their worst and slowly baking the firefighters inside their flame-resistant suits.

Montana prides itself on being Big Sky country. It is an expansive State of wide open plains, vast farms, Indian reservations, and "dude ranches" where Wall Street cowboys can fulfil their John Wayne fantasies on horseback and sleep out on the prairies, beneath the stars.

But the big sky has been hardly visible where the Australians have been. To them, it has looked more like Big Smoke country.

Gary Berndt, the commander of operations at the Troy camp, says the Australians have already left a strong impression on their American counterparts with their insight, their willingness and their infectious good humour.

"They are just excellent, well-trained, go-get-'em firefighters," Berndt says.

Berndt is discussing the day's strategy with Roger Armstrong, a typically laconic fire manager with the Department of Conservation and Land Management in Bunbury, Western Australia.

"We call our approach here MIST," says Berndt. "That's Minimum Impact Suppression Tactics, meaning we try to control the fires with the least possible disturbance to the forests, the private lands and the community.

"I guess our equivalent, to put it colloquially," says Anderson, "is `grab it by the throat and bash the snot out of it'."

After the morning briefing, Armstrong heads back up the mountain where a West Australian colleague, Kevin White, is leading a team of 20 Mexican firefighters mopping up the flanks of one of the larger outbreaks.

"I think we've got it fairly secure down here," says White, indicating a fresh fire trail dug by hand between the smouldering trees and a creek dividing the forest from farming land. "But it is going to keep burning up top in the wilderness, particularly if the wind gets up. It's going to shoot over the ridge and head back down the other side. We've got to watch that."

On the other side of that ridge, Paul McBain is working with a local forestry manager, Steve Prieve, marking a new fire break to stop the flames sneaking back into the valley. "We've got to keep it above the houses," McBain says. "You can't beat the fire. You've just got to try and out-think it."

A smile breaks through his dirt-covered face. To the suitably obsessed, fires aren't just spectacular to watch they're smart, too.

ILLUS: Firing line ... damage to Montana is huge.

urn:contentItem:3SJJ-4K70-0048-T0KM-00000-00<published>1997-10-08T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:50:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Features</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>By Margaret Scheikowski, Arts Correspondent</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">By Margaret Scheikowski, Arts Correspondent</p><p nitf:lede="true"> SYDNEY, AAP - Having performed with Riverdance to the wild acclaim of the world, Joanne Doyle has come a long way from when she kept secret her childhood Irish dancing classes.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> In Sydney for a promotional visit before next year's Australian tour, Doyle said the 80 performers loved having the world now appreciate what had always been a passion for them.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> "When I was young it wasn't the coolest thing to do at all," she said in her strong Dublin accent.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> "You didn't tell anyone you were going to Irish dancing, you said you were going to visit your granny or your aunty." Keyword: RIVERDANCE, 952 words.)< < ASIA: HUNT FOR MARCOS GOLD CONTINUES    By Uli Schmetzer of The Chicago Tribune<br/></p><p>BATAC, Philippines, KRT - Those who believe in ghosts and restless souls swear the corpse of Ferdinand Marcos wears a wan smile these days as Swiss banks, US courts, treasure hunters and private detectives battle over billions of dollars in gold and gems the Filipino dictator is supposed to have stashed away - somewhere.</p><p> He is said to change expression often, usually when he is pleased or displeased with the ups and downs of his family or when the power company cuts off electricity to his mausoleum because the clan has failed to pay the bill again.</p><p>(Keyword: PHIL MARCOS, 1352 words.)< MID: REVERSAL OF FORTUNES FOR RADICAL ISLAMIC GROUP    By Laura King of the Associated Press<br/></p><p> GAZA CITY, Gaza Strip, Oct 7 AP - For the radical Islamic group Hamas, the past few days have been satisfying.</p><p> Fate and politics have served up an extraordinary series of events, any one of which would probably have been high on a Hamas wish list. The net effect: more power, more prestige - and the clout to demand a greater role in Palestinian policymaking.</p><p>(Keyword: MIDEAST HAMAS, 821 words.)< UK: CASH REGISTERS RING A KNELL FOR DIANA    By Sue Leeman<br/></p><p> LONDON, AP - Adored in life, marketed in death.</p><p> Barely six weeks after Princess Diana hurtled to her death in a Paris car wreck, the race is in full swing to market - and milk - her memory, with wares ranging from glossy picture books to memorial coins to less-than-tasteful stickers reading "Bye Bye Di".</p><p>(Keyword: DIANA MERCHANDISING, 707 words.)< CHN: HONG KONG REAL ESTATE AGENTS IN FEEDING FRENZY    By Silvia Cavallini (with photo HK102)<br/></p><p>HONG KONG, AP - Michelle Liu had put her one-year-old daughter to bed and was about to turn in at 11pm when the doorbell rang.</p><p> Opening the door a crack, she heard the cheery voice of a real estate agent named Chen, offering her 10 million Hong Kong dollars ($ A1.77 million) in cash for her Kowloon apartment.</p><p>(Keyword: HK PROPERTY, 654 words.)< IRE: FOUR WOMEN RUNNING HARD FOR IRISH PRESIDENCY    By Fawn Vrazo<br/></p><p> BIRR, Ireland, KRT - If hanging out with 60,000 farming fans in a 20-hectare field of mud does not sound terribly appealing, then Ireland's national ploughing championships are not for you. But four women in boots - W.I.B. - wouldn't dream of passing them up.</p><p> Mary McAleese, Adi Roche, Mary Banotti and "Dana", a Catholic pop singer currently living in Alabama, all pulled on their rubber wellies and pressed the flesh of thousands of voters' hands last week as they made separate pilgrimages to the big annual ploughing event in this little town known jokingly as Ireland's coldest spot.</p><p>(Keyword: IRELAND PRESIDENCY, 1325 words.)< CHN: PRAGMATISM STILL REIGNS IN HONG KONG    By Liz Sly of The Chicago Tribune<br/></p><p>HONG KONG, Oct 8 KRT - The neon kitsch of the new Chinese Foreign Ministry building, glowing green and orange amid the sedate high-rises of a wealthy residential district, is one of the more glaring reminders that Hong Kong has a new sovereign.</p><p> To most Hong Kong residents and international observers, it has come as a pleasant surprise that there haven't been too many of those reminders in the first 100 days of Chinese rule.</p><p>(Keyword: HK CHINA, 1235 words.)< EUR: GREENPEACE SUFFERS FROM GLOBAL COOLING OF INTEREST    By Mike Corder<br/></p><p> AMSTERDAM, AP - For 26 years, Greenpeace activists have scaled barbed-wire fences ringing nuclear plants, handcuffed themselves to oil rigs and set out on the high seas in rafts to take on whalers.</p><p> Now that the environmental group has come of age - with offices in every corner of the globe and a multi-million dollar budget - there are signs it is suffering from a global cooling of interest.</p><p>(Keyword: DUTCHGREENPEACE, 680 words.)< EUR: ROMANIA A LAND OBSESSED WITH SPIES    By Alison Smale<br/></p><p>BUCHAREST, AP - Most people know that speed, paparazzi and a drunk driver contributed to the car crash that killed Princess Diana.</p><p> Except Romanians, who just don't buy it.</p><p>(Keyword: ROMANIA CONSPIRACY, 919 words.)< ASIA: RICKSHAWS LOSE OUT AS LIFE SPEEDS UP IN INDIA    By M.R. Narayan Swamy<br/></p><p> NEW DELHI, AFP - Cycle rickshaws - the poor man's taxi - are losing out as life speeds up in India.</p><p> Green activists argue the age-old mode of transport is the answer to growing vehicular pollution. But the police - and the middle classes, looking to travel fast behind the wheel of their imported cars - do not agree.</p><p>(Keyword: INDIA RICKSHAW, 588 words.)< US: DAM-BUILDERS FIND BUSINESS TOUGH IN GREENER ENVIRONMENT    By Michelle Boorstein (with photo NY309)<br/></p><p>NEW YORK, AP - The US dam-building industry - bedevilled by growing environmental opposition, and faced with the fact that American rivers are already crowded with dams - has virtually closed up shop in its home country.</p><p> Founded nearly a century ago by one of the builders of the Hoover Dam, the engineering company of Mead and Hunt is about as American as American dam-building gets.</p><p>(Keyword: US DAM, 1075 words.)< US: SHANIA TWAIN A COUNTRY-STYLE FEMINIST    By Jim Patterson (with photo NS201)<br/></p><p> NASHVILLE, Tennessee, AP - It's great to be a girl, says country singer Shania Twain.</p><p> As an idol of young American women, the Canadian singer preaches her own brand of feminism. In her videos and songs, Twain keeps making the point that a beautiful woman can be strong and smart.</p><p>(Keyword: US SHANIA TWAIN, 564 words.)< US: THELONIUS MONK III HONOURS HIS FATHER    By Charles J. Gans (with photos NY347)<br/></p><p>NEW YORK, AP - His father was anointed "the high priest of modern jazz" but Thelonious Sphere Monk III was never pressured to become a disciple.</p><p> "I had a very strong relationship with my father," said T.S. Monk, as the 47-year-old son of the legendary jazz pianist and composer calls himself. "He gave me his name but then he said, 'You're not required to do anything but be my son'."</p><p>(Keyword: US THELONIUS MONK, 879 words.)< EUR: CROAT-RUN FACTORY TYPIFIES BOSNIAN ECONOMIC DIVIDE    By Judith Ingram<br/></p><p> MOSTAR, Bosnia-Herzegovina, AP - The chequerboard flag of Croatia flies over Mostar's aluminum factory, and the Bosnian Croat army has a post next door. The message is clear: the plant - and its profits - are in Croat hands. Local Muslims aren't welcome.</p><p> The factory is a symbol of all that is wrong with the Muslim-Croat federation that was supposed to run half of Bosnia under the Dayton peace accord.</p><p>(Keyword: BOSNIA FACTORY, 905 words.)< TEN: NOAH BUILDS COACHING SUCCESS ON YOGA AND PYSCHOLOGY    By Bert Lauwers<br/></p><p> DEN BOSCH, Netherlands, Oct 8 Reuter - Seven years after quitting as a player, Yannick Noah has applied a delicate blend of yoga and psychology to become one of the world's most successful coaches.</p><p> The former world number three, winner of an emotional French Open in 1983, took France to Davis Cup triumphs in 1991 and again last year.</p><p>(Keyword: TENNIS NOAH, 631 words.)< HAZE, CURRENCY WOES DETRACT FROM SOUTHEAST ASIAN GAMES    By Martin Abbugao<br/></p><p>JAKARTA, Oct 8 AFP - Athletes and officials began arriving here today for the 1997 Southeast Asian Games, armed with devalued currencies and surgical masks to combat smog as environmental and financial crises threatened to take the shine off the event.</p><p> from Saturday, hoping that a forest-fire haze from embarassed hosts and defending overall champion Indonesia will not blow into town and spoil the party.</p><p>(Keyword: GAMES SEASIA, 767 words.)</p><p> < PEOPLE AND PLACES    STORIES OF PEOPLE AND PLACES AROUND THE WORLD:<br/></p><p> CHINA YAK</p><p>(Keyword: PEOPLE AND PLACES, 1570 words.)< THAT'S SHOW BUSINESS!    A ROUNDUP OF REPORTS FROM HE WORLD OF SHOW BUSINESS:<br/></p><p> US LOCKLEAR</p><p>(Keyword: SHOWBIZ, 1489 words.)< TODAY IN HISTORY: OCT 10    By AAP and agencies<br/></p><p> Today is Friday, October 10, the 283rd day of 1997. There are 82 days left in the year.</p><p>(Keyword: HISTORY, 965 words.)<    AAP gr<br/></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1997</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3SJJ-4K70-0048-T0KM-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-24</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="1461"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1997 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:4PGY-WRH0-TXN5-R0BF-00000-00FOREST OF DEATH1993-11-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:50:12ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 15FOREST OF DEATHFrom FRANK WALKER in Bowral

THE birds don't sing in Belanglo State Forest any more ... an eerie silence has fallen over the rugged bushland, which will be known forever as the backpacker killing fields.

It makes the skin crawl to walk the trails of this creepy place, taking the same path that the killer, or killers, of seven young backpackers must have taken as he delivered them to their appointment with death.

No birds fly from the stringy-bark gum trees; no animals scurry away in the bushes. Something is terribly wrong here.

To get into the forest the killer would have had to drive through several kilometres of felled pine forest that looks like a wasteland.

It's clear the killer knows this forest well. Perhaps he chose it for its macabre names on orienteering maps such as Executioner's Drop, Sick Man, Ugly Man, Knapsack Gully and Miner's Despair.

The only sounds in this place come from the largest police operation Australia has ever seen as more than 300 police scour the forest for more remains, and dozens of detectives hunt for clues.

It's clear the killer knows the forest well as it's easy to get lost in the maze of firetrails and rugged bush tracks that shoot off in every direction, some simply petering out at dead-ends before fading into the spindly scrub.

It was at four such spots that the backpacker killer snuffed out seven young lives, six of them in frenzied knife attacks. Some blows were so hard they snapped bones and left scars found on the skeletons years later.

From the bodies found so far - and police fear there are more in the forest- it appears the killer's sick mind has concocted a chilling ritual, played out time and again over the past three years.

His first known victims were Melbourne teenagers Deborah Everist and James Gibson, both 19. They were last seen alive on December 29, 1989, at a backpackers' hostel in Surry Hills. They planned to hitchhike north to a festival at Nimbin.

Two weeks later, Gibson's bag was found at Galston Gorge, near Hornsby, slashed and with the name labels cut off. The two were reported missing on January 15 and a week later Gibson's camera was handed in by someone who had found it at the gorge.

Almost three years later, on October 1 this year, a bushwalker stumbled across their skeletal remains at Belanglo.

They were 1km from where the first pair of hitchhikers were found dead 12 months before - 22-year-old British backpackers Joanne Walters and Caroline Clarke.

They were the last known victims of the killer. They disappeared in April, 1992, and were last seen hitchhiking at Bulli Pass. Reported sightings of them at Bowral were discounted by police last week. In both cases, the couples were found about 100 metres apart.

The four bodies were laid out as though for a sick ritual. Animals had disturbed some of the bones, but it appears in each case the killer had laid their hands behind their backs.

In each case, the killer had flayed into them with a knife, stabbing them repeatedly. The only difference - and police say this is crucial - is that Caroline Clarke had been shot several times through the head with a .22 rifle. It was, one said, as if she had been used for target practice.

The bodies of Clarke and Walters were placed under a rock ledge and loosely covered with sticks and brush.

But Gibson and Everist were placed in what appeared to be a bizarre bush coffin. Both lay beside a log, with branches and sticks laid over them like a tent.

It appears some people may have had picnics over the years, not knowing they were just metres from the graves. The charred remains of campfires were found near several of the bodies and it is possible, police said, the killer may have camped there himself.

Four weeks after the discovery of the Melbourne couple's bodies, police found the remains of Simone Schmidl, 21, a backpacker from Regensburg in Germany. Her body was 5km from the first two killing sites and she was laid out in almost identical fashion.

Schmidl was last seen alive in January, 1991, as she left Sydney to hitchhike to Melbourne to meet her mother, who was flying in from Germany. She never made it.

Again, her body was laid out as if for a ritual presentation - face down, arms and legs stretched out, and covered with bush.

Then, last Thursday, police found what they expected - the sixth and seventh victims - missing German backpacker Gabor Neugebauer, 21, and his girlfriend, Anja Habschied, 20. They were last seen alive on Boxing Day 1991, leaving a Kings Cross backpackers' hostel to hitch to Darwin via Adelaide.

Again, the bodies were face down. They were 80 metres apart. Again, they were covered in a bush coffin. This time, their bodies were separated by a trail.

Again, there were signs somebody had visited the spot in the past few years. There were signs of a picnic and somebody had chopped wood just metres away from Habschied's body.

Officially, police say they are only certain that Walters and Clarke were alive when they were taken into the forest. But all indications are that the other victims were also brought to their execution alive.

Speculation is high that the victims were drugged and then driven into the forest. One theory is that the killer attacked one victim while they were still drugged or unconscious and then used the other for sport.

Superintendent Clive Small, officer in charge of the operation, said the placing of the bodies followed a deliberate pattern. They are all about 40 metres from a fire trail or tracks on the fringe of the pine forest.

Police believe the killer is likely to be a local who knows Belanglo well and always returns there, like a wolf to its lair.

Some experts believe the killer subconsciously wants the bodies found, perhaps to act out some imagined ritual.

Could the killer be laying the bodies out in a pattern that could only be seen on a map or from a helicopter, perhaps that of a box or a satanic sign?As four of the victims disappeared around Christmas, perhaps it was some sort of bizarre Christmas "present" left near a forest of Christmas trees?

The only things the victims had in common were that they all disappeared on school holidays and while hitchhiking. They were healthy, fit, attractive young people. Several of the women had striking resemblances to each other.

Police are combing through hundreds of other missing persons reports, some going back to the mid-1970s, to see if there is any sign they too could have fallen victim to the backpacker killer.

Police are also examining unsolved murders of several other hitchhikers. In September 1991 Dianne Pennachio disapppeared from Bungendore. Her body was found two months later in Tallganda State Forest, near Queanbeyan where she lived, in a similar condition to those found in Belanglo 120km away. Her body was 10 metres off a forest fire trail, face down and covered in loose scrub. She had been sexually assaulted before being knifed to death. It has been impossible to tell if the Belanglo bodies had been sexually assaulted.

The manhunt for the killer is now national, with Supt Small's taskforce examining several unsolved killings of hitchhikers in other States, especially in Queensland where several hitchhikers disappeared and were murdered in the 70s and 80s.

So far it appears the backpacker killer has not struck since April 1992. There may have been periods before when he lay dormant.

It may be the killer has found a new dumping ground since the bodies of the British backpackers were found in September last year. It may also be the killer's rest time is coming to an end and he is ready to strike again.

Two Illus: WORST FEARS REALISED: The grave site of German backpacker Anja Habschied. Pictures: SIMON ALEKNA Forest of death'DELIBERATE PATTERN': Supt Clive Small.

urn:contentItem:4P7G-Y0H0-TXN5-S3B9-00000-00`Circle' shows Stalin through devotee's eyes1993-09-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:50:12ZLexisNexisGREEN GUIDENew ReleasesPg. 16`Circle' shows Stalin through devotee's eyesADRIAN MARTIN

WATCH out for the blurb on the cover of The Inner Circle (M, First Release): "a powerful and epic love story in the tradition of Doctor Zhivago!". This true account of the man employed by the Kremlin as Josef Stalin's personal movie projectionist is certainly powerful, but it is anything but romantic or uplifting. Indeed, like many of director Andrei Konchalovsky's previous films, it is profoundly unsettling.

Konchalovsky's main theme is the mass psychology of Stalinism in Russia from the 1930s to the 1950s. He takes a completely opposite tack to the recent video release Stalin, starring Robert Duvall.

Instead of showing the leader as a monster and the people as oppressed victims, he offers us a hero, Ivan Sanshin (Tom Hulce), who is wildly enamored of "the Master", seeing him as a benevolent savior. The film delves fearlessly into the irrational passion underlying Ivan's (and a nation's) fervent ideological belief.

Outside the paranoid labyrinth of the Kremlin, we follow the course of Ivan's marriage to Anastasia (Lolita Davidovich). Once Ivan unflinchingly avows that he loves Stalin more than he loves her, the film plunges these characters into a horrendous erotic nightmare involving the sinister KGB chief Beria (Bob Hoskins). As in Konchalovsky's Maria's Lovers, the traumas of political history are seen to cause gross sexual dysfunctions in intimate life.

The Inner Circle is, in the most unrestrained and complex way, a melodrama. Whether Konchalovsky's characters are heading for salvation or damnation, they are driven, obsessed, unmoored. The actors (especially Hulce) give performances that border on the grotesque _ yet this is of a piece with the overall melodramatic style. Constantly alternating moments of crushingly dull alienation and frantic, desperate emotion, the film ensures that there is no neat reassurance or resolution for the viewer. No wonder this fine, often brilliant movie escaped a proper cinema release.

ARTICLE 99 (M, Columbia-TriStar), by contrast, offers a slick and simplistic treatment of a divisive social issue. Directed by Howard Deutch (Pretty In Pink) and scripted by Ron Cutler, the film dramatises the plight of Vietnam veterans faced with a bureaucratic ruling that effectively denies their rightful claim to medical aid.

While full of colorful sidebar characters in wheelchairs or sick beds, the story concentrates on two doctors: a righteous rebel (Ray Liotta) who has for years flaunted hospital rulings, and an incoming rookie (Kiefer Sutherland) who would rather go by the book. Before building to an extravagant inmates-and-staff-versus-police-state finale, the film finds space in its jittery mosaic for romantic sub-plots involving Kathy Baker and Lea Thompson.

Although the material is handled with undoubted skill by Deutch, the final result is gratingly superficial and forgettable. Whenever the film gets anywhere near the wasteful tragedy of death through official negligence, it speeds off into supposedly riotous scenes that desperately imitate similar set-pieces in MASH or Good Morning, Vietnam. And when it reaches the ultimate political crunch, the movie opts for commonsense consensus rather than actually daring to challenge the established system.

Loaded Weapon 1 (PG, Roadshow) is a National Lampoon production that religiously follows the formula of broad, comic pastiche introduced by Flying High 13 years ago. A popular movie genre is sent-up as if by wisecracking 12-year-olds high on `Mad' magazine: all elements of the original are derided whether they deserve it or not, and not even the corniest gag or pun is excluded. Meanwhile, familiar actors from film or TV join in the fun either by mugging outrageously or playing everything with an absurdly straight face.

The target here is essentially the buddy cop action films of recent years, with the Lethal Weapon movies, obviously enough, serving as prime material. But there are also fleeting excursions into the neighboring thriller genre for parodies of Basic Instinct and The Silence of the Lambs. For some reason, there's even a Wayne's World take-off included. Emilio Estevez hams, Samuel L. Jackson stays cool, and many stars make cameos at varying degrees of comic conviction.

FROM here onwards, it's a week of telemovies and more telemovies.

Obsessed (M, Roadshow) is a rather engaging vehicle for Shannen Doherty of 90210 fame, casting her in a role reminiscent of the heroine in Clint Eastwood's Play Misty For Me. Doherty becomes wildly involved with a man 40 years her senior (William Devane, doing his Jack Nicholson mannerisms). If the soft focus love scenes between these two aren't freaky enough for you, Doherty's subsequent description of their relationship as "spiritual" and "beyond sex" surely clinches the unnatural horror of it all.

This woman, you see, is obsessed. In movie logic, this means that she wants by any means necessary to possess her "free spirit" of a guy, moving into his pad without asking, bothering him with phone messages day and night when she paranoiacally suspects infidelity and, eventually, taking to highly demonstrative acts of vengeful passion when he tries to end the affair. It's a gripping tale, less for its psychological insight than for the fact that the crazy femme fatale is far more admirable than the dour daddy-substitute.

Lethal Error (PG, Applause) was originally titled Mother's Day, which more suitably fits its unusual premise. For it is less a thriller about a young man (Malcolm-Jamal Warner from The Cosby Show) wrongly accused of murder and drug dealing than a domestic melodrama detailing the loving faith and perseverance of his mother (Denise Nicholas).

Just as The Inner Circle reworks elements from Hitchcock's Notorious, this film is enlivened by its borrowing of a major premise from The Wrong Man.

VIDEO watchers know that Bram Stoker's Dracula is soon on its way, if only because of the flurry of releases trying to hitch a ride on this promotional tidal wave before it hits shore: last week the Roger Corman production Dracula Rising, and now a version of Mary Shelley's Frankenstein (PG, Roadshow) starring Patrick Bergin as the mad scientist and Randy Quaid as the pathos-ridden monster.

Producer-director-adapter David Wickes is a specialist in stuffy period dramas that have a sensational element, such as Jekyll & Hyde and Jack the Ripper (both starring Michael Caine). Here, the horrific and cruel elements of the Frankenstein story are downplayed in favor of mildly philosophical soliloquies on science or art, and curt observations on the frailty of civilised society. Wrapping the tale in a framing narration set in the Arctic, Wickes emphasises the doppelganger link between Bergin and Quaid, but generates few sparks, either of a visceral or intellectual nature.

FIRESTORM: 72 Hours in Oakland (M, Entcorp) is, like most disaster movies, essentially a soap opera, which is not in itself an insult.

Characters of many different persuasions _ black, white, Asian, crippled, discontent _ are introduced in bland vignettes while, unbeknown to them all, a forest fire leaps into being. The spectacular, prolonged blaze that ensues guarantees that each person must learn to let go of their unfinished business and start anew _ or cling to the past and perish. LeVar Burton (from Star Trek: The Next Generation) and Jill Clayburgh star in this pretty dull soap, overly punctuated by clumsy TV zooms into burning tree branches.

A re-release, very far from telemovie land, deserves special mention: Wim Wenders' 1977 film The American Friend (PG, Entcorp). Adapted, like Hitchcock's Strangers on a Train, from a novel by Patricia Highsmith, it circles the strange and ambiguous relationship between a quiet picture framer (Bruno Ganz) and an underworld hitman (Dennis Hopper). Although the plot has all the narrative and moral elements of a thriller, Wenders abstracts the proceedings into a disquieting, attenuated mood piece. The performances, like the extraordinary visual compositions, are hypnotic, intricate and uncanny in their emotional effect.

Photos Dennis Hopper is an underworld hitman in an ambiguous relationship with a quiet picture framer (Bruno Ganz) in `The American Friend'; Ivan Sanshin (Tom Hulce) pauses before a bust of Lenin in KGB headquarters in `The Inner Circle'

urn:contentItem:4P0N-K0W0-TXN5-S2P2-00000-00LETTERS2003-12-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:50:12ZLexisNexisINSIGHTLettersPg. 8LETTERS

The first step for Point Nepean

The Mornington Peninsula branch of the National Trust congratulates the Melbourne family that anonymously donated $10 million, and which will ensure the new Point Nepean Community Trust keeps the site in public hands in perpetuity, protected from inappropriate subdivision and development.

We are extremely pleased that the four major principles of the master plan developed by the local community reference group will be upheld and implemented - integrated management, public access, no private residential development and the preservation

of heritage values.

Point Nepean is a unique, multi-layered site of national importance, embracing both natural and built environments, ancient Aboriginal and more recent European uses, and the cultural memory of countless numbers of indigenous people, quarantined migrants, armed forces, refugees and visitors. We are recommending the immediate inclusion of the whole of Point Nepean on the new federal Australian heritage list as an iconic place of this very old - and very young - country.

Peter Holloway, president, Mornington Peninsula Branch, National Trust of Australia (Victoria)

And thanks to the fighters

Congratulations and salutations are the order of the day. But in the euphoria of the announcement that keeps Point Nepean in public hands, let's never forget the victory belongs to the tireless efforts of hundreds of people who gave their time, expertise and hard work to save this most precious natural and historical icon.

Let's not forget, either, that the Federal Government and its cronies were more than willing to let our land pass into the hands of private developers and were popping champagne corks just months ago. It was the tenacity of the community that refused to give in that kept the issue alive.

It appears Flinders MP Greg Hunt was worried about his seat - he had good reason to be. The wave of community concern was enormous and would have drowned him. But now he has been thrown a lifebuoy.

As we accept the anonymous (and excruciatingly well-timed) $10 million dollar gift, let us look very carefully at the processes put in place by the Government in the establishment of a trust. Let us make sure that the trust truly represents the community passion for the point.

Jane Barrington, Portsea

What guarantee?

The good news is that Point Nepean won't be going to the developers. The bad news is what guarantee do we have that the issue hasn't been put on the backburner? If the Howard Government is re-elected and runs true to form, it will be back on the market. Why wait five years before handing Point Nepean to Victoria when no such delay applied to the similar heritage site in Sydney?

Maybe Howard should reassure Victorians by saying it will "never, ever" be sold. I'm sure that will set our minds at ease, just like his words on the GST, Medicare and the children overboard.

Geoff McQuinn, Morwell

An election loser

When Mark Latham announced Labor would give Point Nepean back to Victoria if it won next year's federal election (The Age, 11/12), I thought it would put the cat among the pigeons.

It did not take long for the Liberal Party's backroom boys to realise they were on a large loser, so they corrected their mistake very quickly. I wonder how long the $10 million offer has been on the table. Was it before Latham made his announcement?

Neville Wright, Kilcunda

Release all the detainees

The spirit of Christmas, as well as ordinary compassion, demands action to end the continuing horror of the refugees. So many Australians feel diminished and ashamed, and call for intervention by the minister on humanitarian grounds. If there are no terrorists among the hundreds of refugees still behind barbed wire, their continued detention offends against many of the very principles that most Australians uphold and take pride in, best summed up in the basic principle of a "fair go".

The women and children (94 in detention centres in Australia, 90 in Nauru) have not committed any crime. They should be released immediately, subject to any appropriate conditions. If any refugees cannot physically be returned to their homeland (parts of Afghanistan, for instance, seems as dangerous as ever), they should not be imprisoned indefinitely but released while their applications are reconsidered. Many would make very good Aussie citizens.

Let us press for a Christmas gesture that would make us proud to be Australians.

Sir Rupert Hamer (former premier of Victoria), Kew

Don't listen to the minister

Immigration Minister Amanda Vanstone tells us that the demonstrators on Nauru are not our problem. They are economic migrants, she says. How does she know this if she hasn't heard their stories? The vast majority of Afghan asylum seekers assessed onshore were found to be genuine refugees. So why are all the people on Nauru economic migrants, and not genuine refugees like their countrymen? Surely they were fleeing their country for the same reasons.

Minister Vanstone, you might fool some of the people some of the time by your smears. But not all of us are that gullible.

Ann de Hugard, Castlemaine

Not much insight

Surely this story on the $7000 first homebuyers grant to the rich and famous (The Age, 19/12) is small-minded thinking by small-minded people. Million-dollar houses attract about $100,000 GST, less the grant, with $93,000 going to the Government. A $300,000 house attracts $30,000 GST, less the grant, with $23,000 going to the Government. It costs more to police it.

If this is the extent of the Productivity Commission's research, somebody help us. House costs are inflated by excessive state taxes, expensive dirt and the four/five bedroom mansions that couples think they must have to keep the children they can't afford to have.

John Lord, East Brighton

Capital gains is the problem

Negative gearing has existed for a long time, but the 50 per cent capital gains tax discount was brought in by the Federal Government only in September 1999. Since then, house prices have risen by an enormous amount.

It is the interaction of the two that provides the opportunity for investors to reduce their tax burden. Negative gearing is used to convert income from rental property into capital gain on the value of property. It was always likely that the 50 per cent capital gains tax discount would lead to tax minimisation by the conversion of income into capital gain. The Government was warned of that before it introduced the capital gains tax changes.

There is no justification for capital gain to be taxed at a lower rate than ordinary income. The 50 per cent discount is unfair, and largely benefits high-income earners. It should be abolished, and the capital gains tax regime that existed before September 1999 should be restored.

Gavin Porter, Sunbury

ENTER challenge

A suggested alternative headline to your article (The Age, 18/12) on the VCE results: "Western and northern metropolitan schools achieve best VET options." It is about time the assumption that ENTER scores are the only measure of success is challenged.

Kate Rhodes, executive officer, Banyule Nillumbik Local Learning and Employment Network, Lower Plenty

Board reforms 1

Lucy Abbott of Hamilton (16/12) makes a valid point in her criticism about the throwaway line by Andrew Slutzkin of the Rural Doctors Association that hospital boards without doctors are "essentially good at organising the chook raffle each year" (The Age, 15/12).

However, Lucy Abbott, Hamilton is a rural city with a larger pool of able citizens willing to commit to the huge amount of unpaid time and effort that being a member of a hospital board and its multiple committees entails. Smaller towns such as Cohuna or Rochester or Terang have a much smaller number of available citizens, some of whom may be already on other community boards of management.

By the time Health Minister Bronwyn Pike eliminates doctors, nurses, lawyers and "tinkers and tailors" with alleged conflict of interest and warns off others, "the chook raffle" looks the best option.

When is the Bracks Government going to similarly "reform" the 15-member boards of state schools, which have five teachers (employees of the Education Department) as full-voting members?

Dr Peter W. Graham, Cohuna

Board reforms 2

Well done, Andrew Slutzkin, for your criticism of the new policy to ban doctors from appointments to the hospital management boards. We agree this is another step to remove the autonomy of local boards. Surely it is up to boards to approve or disapprove of doctors being members.

However, we disagree that boards without doctors are only "good for organising the chock raffle". We are country GPs and until this policy change, have been members of boards for more than 10 years. We have worked with many people from diverse backgrounds with great skills in essential areas such as planning, finance, legal issues and personnel management. At board meetings, we all recognise these strengths and have the utmost respect for each other's knowledge. This has led to a very successful hospital with a fine track record.

Rural communities are proud of their hospitals - let them choose who should serve on their board.

Drs David Iser and Philip Worboys, Foster

Air-con is not the answer

Another record power consumption day for Victoria (The Age, 18/12). Every hour at 8500 megawatts peak power output releases about 10.2 million kilograms of carbon dioxide to the atmosphere. For the day, something approaching 100 million kilograms were released just for Victoria.

Hot conditions combined with extensive marketing are driving air-conditioner sales like never before. This is leading to even higher carbon dioxide emissions which, as now generally agreed, are causing the hotter conditions. We are in a self-amplifying loop.

The solution is not in air-conditioners but in properly designed houses and buildings. Unfortunately, with no incentives, it is far easier and cheaper to install an air-conditioner into a poorly designed and insulated building - witness the new city apartments and ever increasing sprawl of new houses with little regard for heating or cooling.

Matthew Harrison, Elwood

Armchair view of the fires

In dismissing broad-scale fuel reduction burning, Gavan McFadzean (Opinion, 15/12) demonstrates a knowledge of forest fire that appears to be limited to boiling a billy. How or why fires get into national parks is irrelevant, whilst McFadzean's use of historical comparisons of fire severity are invalid in view of the different social circumstances and today's advanced technological fire-fighting methods. What is important is the ability to minimise the threat to forests and the community by reducing fuels and being able to respond to bushfires.

Contrary to McFadzen's assertions, the timber industry has sought only to maintain access to Victoria's forests, but its exclusion from the minority of areas where it is still permitted to operate would remove the only substantial source of non-government funding as well as much of the motivation to maintain vehicular access, conduct hazard reduction activities, and maintain workforces capable of fighting bushfires.

McFadzen's denial of the importance of these activities is based on an idealistic view of forests separated from human disturbance. Perhaps if he and other armchair critics spent a summer working among the heat, smoke and flames they would appreciate their critical importance.

Mark Poynter, Doncaster East

CARTOON by PETTY

urn:contentItem:459J-F2D0-0197-T01F-00000-00<published>1996-09-28T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:50:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>A HOBART LANDMARK AT THE CROSSROADS</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>DE CESARE JODI</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">D AVID Bedford remembers well the day that death struck the Royal Tasmanian Botanical Gardens. "I was devastated," said Dr Bedford, the gardens' director. "It feels pretty awful to be the director of a dying gardens. It really does." A HOBART LANDMARK AT THE It was Autumn 1995. A canoe bark birch had died suddenly.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"Being autumn, leaves fall off anyway, but the leaves fell off just a bit too quickly," Dr Bedford said.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"The staff noticed it and said: 'that's not autumn, that's death.' " Armillaria had caught hold. Described as an underground bushfire, the deadly fungal disease has spread to 10% of the gardens and threatens the survival of the Tasmanian icon.</p><p>Dr Bedford is now a man on a mission, but his opponent _ the horticultural equivalent of cancer _ is ominous.</p><p>Armillaria has the experts baffled. Like cancer, there is no cure. All you can do is chop out the affected areas and hope for the best.</p><p>The severity of the infection has shocked garden staff.</p><p>Many trees have already been killed by the infestation.</p><p>First detected in the gardens in 1994 in one tree in an isolated area of the main lawn, staff mistakenly thought quick action had halted its spread.</p><p>"We thought we had it under control," Dr Bedford said. "What we didn't know was that there was another much larger site in the gardens that had it." Dr Bedford was so fearful of the aggressive disease that one of the first questions he asked garden staff upon his appointment in October 1993 was: where is the armillaria and phytophthora (another root rot disease)?</p><p>"I was expecting to find it, but I was not expecting to find that it covered such a large extent of the gardens," he said. "I was devastated because it is a very major problem.</p><p>"It spreads in roots under the ground, and in a small thickly-planted gardens like this where the roots intersect, it just keeps going.</p><p>"My experience of armillaria in the past had been like a spot fire, a spot infection. One tree would die and it wouldn't affect the trees around it. It was sad, but it wasn't an absolute disaster. But what I found here was so different because it was trees going one after the other.</p><p>"Here it's reached that forest fire stage where it's wiping out everything in its path.</p><p>"Unless we can find a way to stop the fungus, we will eventually lose the gardens _ the whole lot. It's as basic as that." For the staff who have cared for the plants for years, the outbreak is having a strong personal impact. Some say the death of a tree is like the death of an old friend.</p><p>"It concerns me greatly because although I know we have done all that is humanly possible, it does give you a somewhat fatalistic feeling," Dr Bedford said.</p><p>"You say 'what am I directing here _ the death of the gardens or living gardens?' It's lovely being part of a botanic gardens normally because you are a part of life, of ongoing life. This massive death and potential for even more is depressing.</p><p>"I don't think people really appreciate just how serious it is because the gardens look so good on the surface." The Mercury Save the Gardens Appeal will be officially launched at the gardens' Tulip Festival tomorrow.</p><p>With the fight ahead huge and expensive, Dr Bedford sees the appeal as the difference between life and death.</p><p>Money raised will be used to employ a plant protection officer and a team of experts to tackle the disease, start an extensive research and mapping program, and develop a long-term proactive strategy for the health of the gardens.</p><p>"We would be able to start fighting it on a number of fronts at once," Dr Bedford said. "At the moment we can only do one at a time.</p><p>"We would excavate the centres of infection that we knew of and dig trenches to quarantine areas, so we knew we had a chance of keeping the disease out of other sections.</p><p>"If money was no object, we would have laboratory facilities and dedicated scientific and technical staff. We could start looking at factors to inhibit the growth of the fungus.</p><p>"I can see ways to go that we cannot possibly do without the resources. We don't know the whole answer, but if we had the resources we could make a start." So far, gardens staff have tried several methods to contain the outbreak.</p><p>A 150-year-old cork oak, said to be the oldest, biggest and best in Australia, has had infected roots severed _ costing $50,000 so far.</p><p>While it appears healthy at the moment, staff say it's a matter of "wait and see".</p><p>The stumps of other infected trees have been fumigated with a chemical. While scientific literature says this method should work, it hasn't at the Royal Tasmanian Botanical Gardens. Management is seeking approval to use stronger concentrations of the chemical.</p><p>Elsewhere, stakes have been driven into the ground to map the extent of the armillaria fungus, dying when they touch an infected root.</p><p>Little else can be done without further funding.</p><p>"Money can help because we have to do something about it _ we can't just say 'we've got this disease and we're going to die'," Dr Bedford said.</p><p>"Instead of focusing on the death, we can focus on life.</p><p>"We believe we can protect the gardens from diseases if we have the resources. Yes, we will lose trees _ there are trees that are already infected that can't be saved _ but if we get the money we can work to stop that going any further.</p><p>"If we don't get the money we will lose the gardens. There will be nothing here.</p><p>"This is an opportunity for the community to do their bit. They say they love the gardens, this is their chance to show it." And the gardens are certainly worth saving.</p><p>Established in 1818, they are the second oldest in Australia and recognised as the nation's best cool climate gardens.</p><p>The most visited site in Tasmania, it attracted 330,000 people last year and is worth more than $5 million to the economy annually.</p><p>Tourists who visit the botanical gardens stay one day longer in Tasmania than those who don't visit the gardens, each spending an extra $600 in the state.</p><p>An integral part of Tasmania's heritage and beauty, it is home to more than 6000 exotic and native plant species and has had an unbroken history of convict labour since 1818.</p><p>"We are a core part of the Tasmanian tourism offering," Dr Bedford said.</p><p>"And in a cultural sense, botanical gardens are the spirit of a place. It's because of the peace, the serenity, the beauty of the incredible plant diversity. We re-create that feeling of nature, of the natural beauty of the world." His vision of the ideal gardens is to establish annex sites throughout the state (the Tasmanian botanical gardens is believed to be the only one in Australia without annexes), a visitor centre, active horticultural research and conservation programs, strong education programs and proactive disease management.</p><p>He says one of the saddest moments in the gardens' recent history was the loss of its scientific heart, the herbarium, to the Museum and Art Gallery several years ago.</p><p>With a PhD in botany from the University of Sydney, Dr Bedford came to the Royal Tasmanian Botanical Gardens after 13 years at Sydney gardens.</p><p>He is not backwards in coming forward when it comes to defending the gardens, fighting for funding, and chewing politicians' ears.</p><p>"I care very deeply about the gardens and their role in society," he said.</p><p>"I think it's only appropriate that the director of a botanic gardens makes it clear just how important a place like this is.</p><p>"It would be a big error on my part or the part of any director to sit quietly by and watch their gardens decline or die." And although, like cancer, there is no cure for armillaria, Dr Bedford says the community should not feel helpless.</p><p>"Some people who have cancer can live for many years and be happy and healthy," he said, "and the same goes for these gardens. We may never fully eradicate armillaria, but if we work on it we'll be able to keep our botanic gardens going nonetheless. That's what I am convinced of."</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source
