urn:contentItem:5572-PPH1-F0J6-J06D-00000-00REAR WINDOW1996-03-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:50:12ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 47REAR WINDOWEdited by Andrew Main

FLAG OF DISTRESS

FORGET the crumbling of the Berlin Wall, the collapse of the Soviet Union and the opening of a McDonald's franchise in Beijing. We can now produce documentary proof that socialism is over.

The Melbourne headquarters of the once-mighty Builders Labourers Federation supremo and prominent Maoist, Norm Gallagher, is to be converted into a hairdressing salon.

Yesterday the Construction Forestry Mining and Energy Union - which gained control of the deregistered BLF's assets last year after a protracted court case - sent the renovators into the famous building at 11 Lygon Street, Carlton. Down came Gallagher's tattered Eureka Stockade flag along with its barbed wire-encircled flagpole.

The wire was apparently a legacy of BLF-Australian Workers Union demarcation disputes in the 1970s when the wags from the AWU made a practice of stealing the trusty ensign.

Former Gallagher lieutenant turned whistle-blower, Victorian Trades Hall Council industrial officer Brian Boyd, was on hand to souvenir the flag.

WILD ABOUT RUPERT

OPTUS Vision boss Geoff Cousins returned to work yesterday fighting fit after a week bushwalking in the Tasmanian wilderness, which caused him to miss Rupert Murdoch in Sydney last week.

But Cousins was particularly cranky about comments made about him by Murdoch, whose Super League continues to flounder in the courts.

Murdoch told one of his News Ltd papers on the weekend that Cousins, who is on the board of Kerry Packer's Publishing and Broadcasting Ltd, was "a Packer man in every way" and implied that Packer had influence on Optus Vision beyond PBL's 5 per cent stake.

"To suggest that I am 'a Packer man in every way' calls into question my ability to discharge my fiduciary duties to all shareholders of Optus Vision, and I regard those comments by Mr Murdoch as misleading and defamatory," Mr Cousins said in a statement.

DIGGING THE DIRT

THE Health Department of Western Australia is running its first ever "fly survey" amid rising concerns over infestations of the blood-sucking stable fly in the Gingin Shire, north of Perth. Media hacks who get involved cannot say they haven't been warned. "As part of the survey, participants will be collecting fly maggot samples from a range of potential breeding sites. Media are welcome in the field," say the organisers.

HAPPY TO BE HOME

WAS the new boss of AMP's Retail Financial Services, Ray Greenshields, protesting just slightly too much when yesterday he insisted, "I didn't have to have my arm twisted" in order to come back to Australia?

As AMP's man in London, he was responsible for establishing its global investment operation, called AMP Asset Management.

After accumulating a pool of $40 billion from worldwide investors over the past five years, it could be seen as a bit of a comedown to be charged with firing up AMP's mums and dads division back home. But he insists he lined up with competitors both inside and out of AMP for the job. He takes over from Phil Twyman, who resigned last September. Greenshields protege Tony Watson takes over in London.

WHAT A CARVE UP!

AN ANTI-RAT drive in Shenzen, China, has apparently backfired due to the high market rates being paid for rat tails, AFP reports. Apparently the plan to kill 150,000 rats, with five yuan (90c) payable per rat's tail, caused an outbreak of rat tail docking rather than rat elimination. One street cleaner who set eight rat traps in sewers said he caught 52 rats but only 10 of them had tails.

PRU'S VALUE FOR MONEY

WITH one bound they were free. Well, a bit anyway.

Michael Milne's home-shopping group, International Media Management, has done a deal with Prudential Asset Management Asia Ltd and other investors that will see IMM's interest in unlisted group The Value Network cut from 59 per cent to 7.4 per cent.

In exchange for control, Prudential will inject "approximately $30 million in equity capital", as a statement from IMM to the ASX put it yesterday.

Good news for TVN's creditors, who had been getting used to the idea that payment was a long way off. One creditor told us he had been paid 15 per cent of money owing yesterday with a promise of full payment within two to four weeks, subject to FIRB approval.

But only average news for IMM shareholders, since the 59 per cent stake in TVN is understood to be IMM's sole asset of any significance.

So now IMM, which has been suspended for a week at its own request, has a market capitalisation of $8.19 million and 7.4 per cent of TVN, which imputes a value of more than $100 million for TVN.

TVN will have to throw in an awful lot of steak knives to reach that sort of value.

A LOT TO DIGEST

PROOF that Melbourne has become a can-do city like Sydney: many members of Melbourne's business community are forking out $150 a head for a breakfast on Friday, the day before the State election, to raise money for Open Family, a charity for street kids.

The breakfast will take place at Max's Restaurant at The Hyatt where IBIS's Phil Ruthven and BRW's Bob Gottliebsen will be peering into the crystal ball.

Guests will get "politics, elections, consumer and business confidence, the economy, soft and hard industries, interest rates, and the Asia Pacific and global outlook - plus prospects of corporate profitability". Which suggests they might not have to worry about lunch.

OFF TO BALI - AND PROBABLY TAX DEDUCTIBLE, TOO

LAWYERS who plan to attend July's Australian Lawyers Conference in Bali are set for an excruciating work load.

They arrive on Saturday (evening at leisure), spend Sunday at leisure preparing for the gruelling opening ceremony and reception; attend meetings on Monday, and even more meetings on Tuesday - before breaking for the tennis tournament and buffet in the gardens of the Bali Hyatt Sanur.

After all that exercise, Wednesday will be is spent at leisure before more meetings on Thursday and again on Friday. On Saturday, they rest up for their late-night return flight.

The organisers, Creative Conference Management of Glebe, NSW, explain that the conference "provides practitioners with an excellent opportunity to compensate their spouses or families for the disruption caused by the demands of their busy professional lives and for those accompanying them to be actively involved in the program at all levels".

DICTATORS' VIEWS

A SYDNEY survey reveals that 44.7 per cent of bosses believe in the glass ceiling.

Alectus Personnel surveyed 1,200 bosses nationwide and found some enlightened attitudes: 11.2 per cent didn't think their secretaries were paid enough, 37.1 per cent said there was no carer development for secretaries in place; only 9.3 per cent of their secretaries were expected to provide tea and coffee.

From our experience, we don't believe the bit about the daily cuppa and can only ask why, if the bosses reckon their secretaries are underpaid, they cannot fix it?

$900M'S NOT HALF BAD FOR A BIT OF SPECULATION

THE Taiwan, Hong Kong and China rumour mills went into overdrive when a wire service reported the newly engorged BTR plc - still digesting BTR Nylex - was considering selling its part-owned petrochemical operations in Taiwan.

There had been speculation after Alan Jackson's successor in London, Ian Strachan, signalled the group was looking seriously at its non-core assets in the light of its aim to be a major industrial, manufacturing and engineering group. BTR had already sold its Slazenger sporting goods operation, among others, and the admittedly (by BTR) "little and lonely" petrochemical operations looked like the next course.

The speculative embers flared into a forest fire when BTR Australia chief executive Philip Aiken made an appearance in Taiwan - for an unrelated reason.

As with all good rumours, there was even a fancy price mentioned, this time $US900 million. "That'd be great. I'd sell it tomorrow for $US900 million," Aiken said yesterday. End of rumour.

SWITCHED SIDES

BANKWEST chief Warwick Kent, once an expatriate Sydneysider, has gone native in Western Australia now.

Defending to Melbourne brokers the exclusion of eastern staters in the recent hugely oversubscribed BankWest listing, he spoke in terms of the lesser of two evils: it was better to exclude easterners than westerners in a process when someone had to dip out. "I could never have lived in Perth again if I had let in east-coasters at the expense of west-coasters," he admitted.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

' Anaconda Nickel is the last train to heaven when it comes to nickel '

- extract from a letter from an Anaconda fan who feels the company has been misrepresented by brokers and the press.

urn:contentItem:4593-BY10-0197-D4TT-00000-00<published>1996-02-24T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:50:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>CRUNCHING THE NUMBERS</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>STORY: DAVID GAZARD</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">The Budget has been the dominant election issue but do Australians</p><p nitf:lede="true">really understand or care about the fiscal bottom line?</p><p nitf:lede="true">FOREIGNERS visiting Australia could easily be forgiven for thinking</p><p nitf:lede="true">the nation was full of budding economists. As the election campaign</p><p nitf:lede="true">enters its last week, much of the political fisticuffs have centred on</p><p nitf:lede="true">such issues as the Budget deficit, forward estimates and Treasury</p><p nitf:lede="true">costings. Voters have been forced to endure a deluge of economic</p><p nitf:lede="true">argument on the merits of each side's big spending promises and</p><p nitf:lede="true">whether they can responsibly pay for them. They've had to grapple with</p><p nitf:lede="true">such heady subjects as the starting point for the 1996-97 Budget</p><p nitf:lede="true">deficit, the forecast headline inflation rate and falling growth</p><p nitf:lede="true">impact on the Budget's bottom line.</p><p>These intricate budgetary details, and others, have been enough to</p><p>make the average merchant banker's head spin let alone the average</p><p>voter. A street poll will quickly reveal besieged voters in many seats</p><p>cannot even name their candidates or sitting member without trying to</p><p>make sense of the finer points of budgetary number crunching.</p><p>So will five weeks of carping about the size of the starting point of</p><p>the underlying deficit win any votes? Or has the in-depth economic</p><p>debate been a massive turn-off for the average voter, who may not know</p><p> or care about the difference between the current account deficit,</p><p>the Budget deficit and foreign debt?</p><p>A political hornets' nest has been stirred up over whether the major</p><p>parties will be able to keep the Commonwealth out of the red whichever</p><p>one wins government on March 2. The avalanche of election promises</p><p>from Labor and the Coalition has kept the economic boffins of both</p><p>parties burning the midnight oil in an attempt to find holes in their</p><p>opponent's spending pledges.</p><p>To date, the Coalition has announced a whopping $6.3 billion of</p><p>campaign promises over three years, funded by a controversial $6.3</p><p>billion spending-cuts program and about $2.6 billion of revenue</p><p>measures. The big-ticket pledges include a $2.7 billion family tax</p><p>package, $1 billion in private health incentives, $400 million in</p><p>capital gains tax breaks and $195 million for Pacific Hwy funding. The</p><p>Opposition Leader, Mr Howard, has also released a raft of lesser</p><p>spending items designed to stimulate small business. On a separate</p><p>spending sheet, the Coalition says it will privatise one-third of</p><p>national telecommunications carrier Telstra for about $8 billion, with</p><p>$1 billion used for an environmental package.</p><p>On the other side of the political ledger, Labor has unveiled its own</p><p>ambitious $3 billion package of spending measures. Labor's big</p><p>spending priorities will see the Government outlay close to $1 billion</p><p>over three years on health, $439 million on an innovation package and</p><p>$347 million on the environment. To fund the program, Labor says it</p><p>will raise $2.4 billion in three years from simply closing a tax</p><p>loophole applying to 100 of the country's richest people. A clampdown</p><p>on a research and development tax concession will yield another $727</p><p>million.</p><p>Since the campaign began, the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, has</p><p>consistently argued the Coalition's brand of pork-barrelling politics</p><p>will reward Australia with an enormous deficit. But Mr Howard has hit</p><p>back, claiming his promises are based on the Government's budgetary</p><p>projection of an underlying surplus in the 1996-97 financial year.</p><p>MR Howard has argued that if the Coalition's promises are unable to be</p><p>kept, it will be because Labor has refused to reveal how far it has</p><p>allowed Australia to slip back into deficit. If the latest Government</p><p>projections are correct, he says the Coalition will return a surplus</p><p>next financial year and keep all its promises, including no new taxes</p><p>or tax hikes.</p><p>The fiscal debate reached a new high this week when the Finance</p><p>Minister, Mr Beazley, told his department to cost the Coalition's</p><p>promises. Mr Beazley assured voters a huge $3 billion hole existed in</p><p>Mr Howard's $6.3 billion pledges. An outraged Opposition claimed</p><p>caretaker conventions dictated departments be non-partisan during</p><p>campaigns. And Mr Howard wanted to know why couldn't the Finance</p><p>Department produce updated Budget projections under Labor if it was</p><p>able to run its calculators over Coalition spending promises. This</p><p>would clear up all the confusion about where Australia was heading</p><p>fiscally and allow for responsible spending pledges, he told</p><p>reporters.</p><p>But many believe the wrangling over the size of the deficit which</p><p>has received enormous media coverage has left most Australians</p><p>behind. And economists with a good understanding of the political</p><p>arena say the in-depth fiscal debate has done little to lift community</p><p>knowledge.</p><p>EXPERTS say an economically literate electorate would have been</p><p>outraged at signs the Government was sinking back into the red late</p><p>last year. When the Treasurer, Mr Willis, released the mid-year review</p><p>of the Budget in December it showed only an unexpected, early State</p><p>debt repayment from Victoria kept the Commonwealth from sinking back</p><p>into deficit.</p><p>This raises an important question: why has the issue remained so</p><p>visible if it has already slipped past a bewildered voter?</p><p>The answer, according to both parties, is simple. It's all about</p><p>credibility.</p><p>The detail of the economic debate may have gone above the heads of the</p><p>average voter but there is one side of economics they understand well</p><p> interest rates. Voters are aware of the nexus between high</p><p>government spending, high mortgages and taxes. The more government red</p><p>ink, the less likely a cut in rates or a fall in taxes. That puts a</p><p>whole new onus on the believability of grand political spending by</p><p>both parties. And both, predictably, insist they can deliver.</p><p>But Labor Party pollsters believe they have identified a wide streak</p><p>of disbelief in the community when it comes to the economic vision</p><p>espoused by Mr Howard. And the ALP strategists have determined the</p><p>best way to get that message across is to constantly put the blowtorch</p><p>on the Coalition's promises.</p><p>"The average person does understand Budget deficits and interest</p><p>rates," one senior ALP adviser says. "And the Coalition for months</p><p>has been making such a big deal about delivering a Budget surplus. We</p><p>knew they were up against it."</p><p>The ALP believes the fiscal debate had been kept alive because the</p><p>Keating Government wanted to keep tabs on all the spending promises</p><p>the Coalition made from the outset.</p><p>But the Coalition contends it has been the impetus behind the fueling</p><p>of the fiscal forest fire. And Liberal Party strategists are adamant</p><p>the ALP has left itself wide open to attacks on credibility after a</p><p>series of broken tax and privatisation promises.</p><p>"Labor and Paul Keating have a serious credibility problem when it</p><p>comes to taxes, jobs and the Budget," says its director, Mr Andrew</p><p>Robb. "They won't throw open the books so they have something to hide</p><p>there."</p><p>The Democrats offer a different view but credibility still forms the</p><p>centrepiece of its perspective. Leader Senator Kernot says the</p><p>community has become disinterested and lost in a haze of cynicism</p><p>because both parties embarked on such an audacious park-barrelling</p><p>exercise four weeks ago.</p><p>EARLY in the campaign, Senator Kernot said the party which made the</p><p>least spending pledges would win on March 2. It was her belief the</p><p>more parties promised, the less they were believed. If that axiom</p><p>proves correct, Mr Howard's team can look forward to another term</p><p>warming the Opposition benches in the House of Representatives.</p><p>But Mr Sol Leibovic, of the polling organisation Newspoll, says voters</p><p>do not necessarily want to understand the debate, they only want to</p><p>know the leader of their choice can. "I really believe people would</p><p>like to vote for the side they think has the best vision and is going</p><p>to do the best job for the country," he says. "I think the</p><p>Australian electorate actually wants the leadership of the party to</p><p>know where to take the country, to know the detail. They want to feel</p><p>confident that those in charge do know the detail."</p><p>By continuing to kick the economic debate along, both sides are</p><p>attempting to deliver that confidence and deliver the king-hit which</p><p>will see them win next Saturday, he says. From that perspective,</p><p>polling shows more voters trust Mr Howard, although Mr Keating's firm</p><p>leadership style has gone down well.</p><p>"Either side can win," predicts Mr Leibovic. "I think it will come</p><p>down to the last couple of days. It wouldn't surprise me if the</p><p>Coalition won easily (but) it wouldn't surprise me if Labor won."</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:44DT-W970-015G-Y391-00000-00<published>2001-06-16T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:50:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FEATURES; Pg. 27</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>A hole in the HEART</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Don Petersen</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">A year after the fatal Childers backpacker hostel fire a stark reminder still haunts a rural community in mourning, writes Don Petersen</p><p nitf:lede="true">"There is no memorial. We need something that is beautiful, not something dark and charred, something to help us remember who those children were, not how they died." - Jenny Lloyd-Morgan, psychologist</p><p nitf:lede="true">"It's a black hole that has a stranglehold on people's emotions, on the town's ability to move on." - Bill Trevor, Childers mayor</p><p nitf:lede="true">"Thirty years a social worker and you would think I'd know better. But I can't look at that building now. I walk past it with my head down." - Shirley Maisey, director of the Childers Neighbourhood Centre</p><p>IT's been 12 months since an early morning inferno took the lives of 15 young backpackers and left 69 others shivering on the street in little more than their underwear. But trauma still grips the little rural town of Childers as if the catastrophe happened only yesterday.</p><p>Like most of the town's 2200 residents, those first called out to confront the tragedy in the chaotic dark hours of June 23 last year cannot get the deaths out of their minds.</p><p>Their fears and frustrations, anger and misplaced guilt -- this was proudly the safest of communities, especially for the young -- centre on "the black hole", the burnt-out Palace Backpackers Hostel where death visited with frightening speed and no warning.</p><p>As far as is known since a coronial inquiry has been delayed, it was here about midnight that a fire began in a downstairs TV room, volatile, unburnt gases drifting up to accumulate beneath the roof where, inevitably, they "crowned" like a forest fire.</p><p>But the building remains much as it was when the last flames died out, rubble and soot and ash-filled; ugly, melted pipes bending at crazy angles over what was a temporary morgue.</p><p>It is an accusation, a gap in the fabric of life itself. More than 6000 cars and trucks a day drive past it through an avenue of leopard trees, a soft interlude in the Bruce Highway. Townspeople hurry by, looking elsewhere.</p><p>Oh, there is life all around it. As they have for generations, the great canefields which surround Childers show promise of a bumper crop in the next few months. Between them, the rich, red volcanic soil each week is being stripped of hundreds of thousands of tonnes of tomatoes, capsicums, avocados, zucchinis and snow peas.</p><p>It is this $100 million a year industry which for decades has lured foreign backpackers to Childers, to work brutally hard for up to $11 an hour as pickers and field hands for a few days or weeks then move on, pockets filled, to continue their adventurous travels.</p><p>Although few were to be found there this week, they are still coming. There will be an influx this week, hopefully a dozen or so of the 69 injured and perhaps a few relatives of the 15 dead according to mayor Bill Trevor, to attend next Saturday's commemorative service in the town's Cultural Centre.</p><p>There, accompanied by prayers and hymn singing, a few low-key speeches and a mixing of townsfolk, backpackers, emergency service personnel, volunteers from the churches and service organisations, tears long dried in all likelihood will flow again.</p><p>This should be closure, says Trevor, or at least a major step in the healing process. But across the road is the stark, haunting reminder of the past, the blackened facade of the Palace, empty windows like eye sockets in a skull, behind them nothing but blue sky.</p><p>After the fire, the council tried to buy the hostel, Trevor says. Along with grants of about $300,000, came $75,000 from the State Government towards costs. The British government gave $29,000 and $50,000 came from Canberra. But the previous owners sold privately to a Gold Coast developer, who in turn has been seeking interest-free government loans. Through letters hand delivered by Premier Peter Beattie to Prime Minister John Howard, Childers asked for a grant of $1.3 million to turn the hostel into a memorial.</p><p>Continued Page 28</p><p>A hole in the heart of Childers</p><p>From Page 27</p><p> Although by this week nothing had been heard, Trevor says that $700,000 now would be enough to buy the front of the building from the developer, turn the upstairs into an art gallery memorial and downstairs into an information bureau. A modern hostel, possibly with a memorial garden, would be constructed at the rear.</p><p> "We have come so far. What hurts is that in so many ways these kids were our kids. They tended to replace our own youngsters of about the same age who, like so many from country towns, move to the cities for education or jobs," Trevor says.</p><p>"We have stayed in touch with most of them, even to the point now of still paying for the counselling in places like England and Western Australia of those most affected. Some keep coming back . . . from Hawaii, New Zealand, Britain, wherever . . . They tell me they see Childers not so much as where the fire happened but as a second home.</p><p>"We have had the parents of the dead, trying desperately to come to terms with their loss. One mother said she made the journey to gain a vision not of where her son died but of the fields where he worked and the friends he made.</p><p>"The thing is we need a symbol as the focus for the love and respect we feel for the children we lost and it can only be as a replacement for that black building."</p><p>The Cultural Centre is where director of the Childers Neighbourhood Centre Shirley Maisey, psychologist Jenny Lloyd-Morgan and director of the Childers Information Centre Nancy Calder, turned up in the pre-dawn of that awful morning 12 months ago.</p><p>Each instinctively claimed or was assigned a key role in the immediate crisis management. They call themselves the "old fossils" but their far-from-old arms, around weeping kids or kids in deep shock, were not fossilised arms.</p><p>This week in the centre, as in so many other gatherings in Childers, their minds went back to the beginnings. As they talked it was obvious that their recall was disjointed, like the tragedy itself:</p><p>Maisey: "I lost a daughter when she was 28, so I know that you never really get over things like this. The awful reality was that in the blink of an eye 15 young people we like were gone and 69 others were lost in horror even as we cuddled them.</p><p>"My horror began when the phone rang at 4.30am and I think it was three days before I got home for a small rest. The mayor kept saying to helpers who were inundating us, 'if you need anything just see Shirley'.</p><p>"I am trained in crisis, thought I knew how to deal with it and get out. But it turns out that none of us knew.</p><p>"I know I will never be the same again. I don't think we will ever have closure. It is not guilt but we keep asking, 'Why us?' If the kids had all been from Childers it might have been different, but these were from around the world and suddenly we were surrogate mothers with arms around those special 69. All we could do was try to make things better."</p><p>Lloyd-Morgan: "I was put in charge of counselling but in those first days all you could do was settle the kids, comfort them and the emergency workers who were in as much stress, make sure the survivors felt safe and connect them with family. This was an entire community in shock."</p><p>Calder: "I kept looking around the room, my mind continually asking, 'who's missing?' The lists were a mess. There were seven kids who had lost their glasses and could not see. The rest had nothing -- no money, no credit cards. They were cold and wet and did not know where their friends were.</p><p>'WE HAD to find food for them, for the SES, the firemen and the police and the volunteers -- 1400 meals a day for 14 days. The Fruit and Vegetable Association did the meals at night, the Lions Club did breakfast.</p><p>"Food arrived by truck and car. Little old ladies walked in with cakes, farmers with their produce. It was sorted by the Red Cross, the CWA and the churches. It became a seamless flow.</p><p>"The shock began to go after the memorial service on the third day and I came back to find two boys kicking a football around in the hall and I thought 'Thank heavens something is normal. We are going to be all right'."</p><p>Calder: "Some have told me that they would leave us with memories of hard work, of heat, sweat, flies, cold beer and storms. But they have kept coming back. They have a bond with this little town, see it as a second home. It is going to be a difficult commemorative service."</p><p>Lloyd-Morgan: "Yes, we have come a long way, but that black hole is a barrier to integrating the life of the community so that we can go on. You see it and think that 15 people died there in the smoke and the rubble.</p><p>"It is not a memorial. We need something that is beautiful, not something dark and charred, not a stone or a plaque somewhere. It has to be something to help us remember who those children were, not how they died."</p><p>What these women do not say, but Trevor does, is that a memorial will not be the end of the ordeal.</p><p>There is the trial later this year of Robert Paul Long, 38, who has been charged with setting the fire and murdering two of the victims, 27-year-old West Australian twins Kelly and Stacey Slarke. He remains in custody contesting the right to have the trial held elsewhere.</p><p>The inquest into the disaster will follow, the Coroner having adjourned his inquiry to ensure that Long gets a fair trial.</p><p>Like most Australian towns, Childers is unused to tragedy on this scale. With luck and a little governmental generosity, the black hole in the town's heart soon will disappear. But full healing promises to be a long night.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4P0N-K0M0-TXN5-S1T2-00000-00Letters2004-08-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:50:12ZLexisNexisNEWSLettersPg. 12LettersLETTERS & OPINION

Portable problems

We read (The Age, 13/8) that $5 million is to be spent to provide 300 new portables (or 600 classrooms). In these modified sheds - "sweatboxes" - our state teachers are charged with the responsibility of imparting knowledge, morals and a love of learning to about 27,000 state school students.

Comparing this with the millions of dollars offered to wealthy schools to further existing excellent, sometimes lavish, facilities and accommodation (all to the good) must tell us something of the reasons parents often choose, at great personal expense, to send their children to private schools. It seems there is a paucity of thinking and lack of vision by those in government.

Owen Dingle, Rosanna

As shameless as Gareth

For some years, the back window of my car carried the message "But it's not our oil, Gareth". This sticker also showed a map of the Timor Gap. On the departure of Senator Evans, I substituted the still current message "Timor Gap . . . Oil Piracy".

Notwithstanding your editorial (The Age, 13/8), the sticker will remain affixed until Australia unequivocally releases to East Timor its just entitlements to the oil in its sea. Alexander Downer's condescending and grasping behaviour is as shameless as that demonstrated by Gareth Evans.

Jill O'Brien, Kew

Spurious concerns

As an ecologist, I found some of Tony Cutcliffe's comments (Opinion, 13/8) rather disturbing. We have not lost forever 20,000 hectares of alpine ash. Ash forests, like many others, have been burnt and regenerated for millenniums, and somehow, miraculously, managed to do so without our superior brand of management. We should not pretend that what is clearly a disaster for humans is somehow a disaster for nature.

If the Stretton Group is concerned with community safety, the quality of drinking water or the protection of timber resources, then it should simply say so, because these are indeed important considerations. But please don't hide behind spurious ecological concerns.

Arn Tolsma, Box Hill North

What will another inquiry achieve?

Re Tony Cutcliffe's article: how many inquiries do we need before The Eureka Project and the Stretton Group get the answers they want to hear?

The Council of Australian Government's report on bushfire mitigation and management is imminent, the Victorian Government has issued its report of the inquiry into the 2002-03 Victorian bushfires, the House of Representatives Select Committee has released its report, and the Victorian Auditor-General's report on fire prevention and preparedness became publicly available last year. Now we have calls for a coronial inquiry into the fires. But what will another inquiry achieve?

If their claims and demands are to be taken seriously, it is important that groups such as The Eureka Project and the Stretton Group are themselves subject to scrutiny. What are their agendas? What stakes do they have in the management of our public lands? Who is it that they represent? They could begin answering these questions by revealing their sources of funds.

Josh Whittaker, Caulfield

The real problem

The problems of Victoria's under-resourced forests and national parks have essentially been created by the ideological opposition of some to the use of trees for wood, and their creation of damaging public perceptions that are out of proportion to reality.

The closure of local timber industries dramatically impacts on forest fire management by removing the source of substantial non-government funding that has always paid for key activities such as fuel reduction burning and road and track maintenance.

It also removes from the forest, government and industry personnel who have traditionally been at the forefront of firefighting efforts.

A coronial inquiry into the 2003 bushfires will only benefit sensible forest and fire management if it results in a rigorous public examination of green, anti-forestry campaign messages, motives, and methods. Only this can stem the growth in misinformed community sentiment that makes it politically expedient for governments to further exclude wood production and create more national parks.

Mark Poynter, Doncaster East

Profiting on death

My wife died recently, and in the process of getting her affairs in order I telephoned Altitude (Westpac) and Qantas to transfer her frequent flyer points to me, only to discover that they are forfeited on her death. This is disgraceful. I am only talking some 50,000 points, so it's no big deal. Keep them by all means, but my gorgeous wife made a point of buying on her credit card to build up these points - and they profit on her death? They should be ashamed of themselves.

Cliff Ellen, Rye

So where's the justice?

I am a registered midwife and the mother of two children aged nine and four. Last year my husband endured months of chemotherapy to treat bowel cancer. He died in March this year.

I spent last year caring for the kids and my husband, working casual shifts, and searching for a non-shift-work job that would enable me to keep my family fed and clothed. During this time the Government, through Centrelink, paid my husband $4000 as a sickness benefit. I have recently been informed that I have to pay $2000 of this back to Centrelink.

Richard Butler is getting a payout of $650,000 after 10 months' work. Where is the justice in all of this?

Jennifer Carr, Ocean Grove

Don't forget Darfur

The Australian Government has responded generously to the plight of the people of Darfur in Sudan. It is equally critical that Australia takes a leading role to ensure, as the UN Security Council has demanded, that the Government of Sudan puts an immediate end to the human rights abuses being perpetrated by the Janjaweed militia. UN Security Council Resolution 1556 describes the situation in Sudan as constituting a threat to international peace and security and to stability in the region.

As a party to the Genocide Convention, Australia should exercise its diplomatic influence both directly with the Government of Sudan and with other governments to mobilise an appropriate international response. The Australian Government should provide whatever support is needed and requested by the African Union to maintain its international monitors and sustain protection forces if they are deployed.

As an election campaign approaches, it is possible that political and public interest in Darfur might dissipate, if not disappear. Australia should not be silent in the face of this unfolding catastrophe. We, through our elected representatives, must take what action we can to respond swiftly to limit what in Sudan may be characterised as genocide. This is an opportunity for Australia to re-establish itself as a country prepared to stand up for issues of human rights.

Associate Professor Mike Toole, centre for international health, Burnet Institute; Bebe Loff, human rights and bioethics unit, Monash University;

Professor Kim Mulholland, centre for international child health, Melbourne University; Associate Professor Peter Deutschmann, Australian International Health Institute, Melbourne University

Oil wars

Please, Mr Howard, when you're deciding which country to invade next, could you make sure you don't pick an oil supplier? At more than $1.20 a litre, petrol is fast becoming an unaffordable luxury for many of us. I don't think we could cope with the price rise if you and Mr Bush destabilise another oil-producing country.

Michelle Wood, Wagga Wagga, NSW

Medicare muddle

The Government's new policy to pay more to doctors when they bulk-bill health care (or concession) card-holders or children under 16 is doing so much harm to the general society. Now many doctors are refusing to bulk-bill people who do not have a health care (or concession) card.

The vast majority of middle-class, hard-working Australians fall into this category. It is the tax paid by these industrious people that supports the health-care facility. But, unfortunately, the new policy has deprived them of the one benefit they enjoyed before - access to medical benefits.

Rebecca Jacob, Oakleigh

A waste of public money

I'm recovering from a nasty "bug" that resulted in me taking two days off work to huddle in bed feeling horrible. Under my employment award, I must supply a medical certificate if I have more than one day off sick. The consequence is that, having almost recovered, and hence feeling near enough well enough to get out of bed and drive, I have no option but to visit a GP at the expense of the public purse and waste their time and mine for the sake of bureaucracy.

When I lived in the United Kingdom, there was no requirement for sick folk to worry about medical certificates unless they were off work for more than a week. There seemed to still be adequate systems in place to ensure workers weren't shamelessly rorting their employers.

I imagine some GPs value the system for the easy money it brings them. But don't we have a system stretched to the limit, with doctors unable to give patients the time they need?

My trip to the doctor yesterday felt like nothing more than a ridiculous charade, demeaning to both of us and a waste of public money. (Yes, I went to a bulk-billing practice).

Isn't it time to review this ridiculous policy?

Mark Allen, Bentleigh East

Misplaced priorities

John Howard is so terrified of gays and lesbians he has dropped anti-terrorist measures to pass his ban on gay marriage (The Age, 13/8). He seems to be frantic to get the election under way, perhaps even while the Olympics is on: that way, he thinks, the real campaign will be shorter, because everyone will be watching Thorpe and Klim and company. That means he would evade the full scrutiny that would expose his shortcomings.

But there are a whole load of bills Howard wants to get passed, just in case he loses. Must have something for his legacy. What's more important? Already he has amended the FTA to incorporate changes he thinks might invalidate the whole deal, giving the Opposition everything it wants. Now he's so panicked, he has dropped anti-terrorist legislation to make time to go queer-bashing. He thinks we are more of a threat than al-Qaeda!

He is willing - according to what he has said about his anti-terror measures - to leave Australia dangerously exposed, solely, but has the time to ban gay marriage.

Doug Pollard, Eltham North

Mocking marriage

"The proposed ban on homosexual nuptials promotes intolerance." This is just a sample of the absurd propositions put forward by those promoting the never-ending gay agenda. However, this is not a claim by radical gay advocates, it is an extract from The Age editorial (13/8).

Marriage, by design, was never intended for same-sex couples and no one has questioned this until recent developments overseas. The Federal Government, with the support of the Labor Opposition, is merely confirming what the vast majority of Australians have always understood marriage to be: the union of one man and one woman to the exclusion of all others. How this can be interpreted as "promoting intolerance" is beyond the understanding of rational thought, yet it seems today that the more ridiculous the proposition, the more plausible it becomes.

Besides, there is considerable division within the gay community on this matter, as those who want to be accepted as "queer" do not want to be in a relationship that mimics heterosexuals. This is a dilemma, which some gays fear exposes the many in their ranks who are "closet" heterosexuals.

To accept gay marriage is to mock marriage and make it meaningless.

Peter Coventry, Keilor Lodge

CARTOON BY PETTY

urn:contentItem:3TV8-HH60-0048-T0XK-00000-00<published>1998-10-12T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:50:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Features</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>PEOPLE AND PLACES</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">CAMBODIA TEACHERS</p><p nitf:lede="true">PHNOM PENH, Oct 11 Reuters - Cambodian primary school kids are having to cope with an unlikely gang of bullies - their teachers.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> A local newspaper reported today that some primary school children in the Cambodian capital have to go without their break-time sweets because teachers are demanding their pocket money in exchange for good marks.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The Chakraval newspaper said teachers at at least two city centre primary schools were extorting money from young students and the childrens' parents were up in arms.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> "I have to pay 400 riel (about 15 Australian cents) a day to my teacher, otherwise I'll have a big problem," one pupil told the Cambodian-language newspaper.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> "The money that mum and dad give me for a snack when I'm hungry, I have to share it with my teacher so I can join the class like everyone else," the unidentified pupil said.</p><p>"If you don't pay $ US10 ($ A16) to your teacher, don't expect to pass your tests," another pupil said.</p><p> The newspaper said teachers who did not get paid by the children would sometimes scare children in their classes, which can contain as many as 60 students. The paper did not say how the teachers frightened their pupils.</p><p>REUTERS</p><p> US ANNIVERSARY</p><p> MINNEAPOLIS, Oct 11 AP - Judy and Jesse Paluck celebrated their fifth wedding anniversary dressed in hospital gowns and surgical stockings, barely able to muster the strength to hold hands.</p><p> For the Palucks, the setting and the gift Judy offered - a kidney - couldn't have been more romantic: It proved they were a perfect match.</p><p> "I think we were meant for each other and were meant to go through this," Mrs Paluck, 29, said on Friday, a day after donating a kidney to her 32-year-old husband. "That it happened so close to our anniversary is a sign."</p><p> Doctors said the prognosis is good for Paluck, whose kidney was damaged by lupus, a disease that affects the body's immune system.</p><p> Experts say the fact the surgery took place at all is unusual given the difficulties involved in matching tissues and blood types. In 1997, fewer than 3 per cent of all kidney transplants in the United States were spouse-to-spouse.</p><p>AP</p><p> CHINA TEMPLE</p><p> SHANGHAI, Oct 11 Reuters - A Buddhist temple in south China has apparently concluded that prayer may not be sufficient to protect its interests and has registered its name as a trademark.</p><p> The Sanping Temple in Pinghe county of the south-eastern province of Fujian has registered a trademark for the merchandising of its goods and services, the Wen Hui daily said today.</p><p> The Sanping Temple is a popular tourist site and the trademark could be used for travel-related business.</p><p> Economic reforms have kindled the entrepreneurial spirit across the country while increased religious tolerance has sparked a revival of Buddhism and other faiths.</p><p>REUTERS</p><p> UK FAVOURITE</p><p> LONDON, Oct 11 PA - The reputation of Britons for being plain, unadventurous eaters seemed to be on the wane in recent years, but a new survey has plunged them back to the boring.</p><p> Students' favourite meal is baked beans on toast washed down with some beer, according to the survey.</p><p> The two items came out top in a survey where students were asked what they would most like a year's supply of.</p><p> Other favourites included pasta and pasta sauce, cheese, bread, milk, vodka and toilet rolls.</p><p> Plush luxuries and healthy greens were left on the shelf, as champagne, smoked salmon and fresh fruit and vegies were cast aside in favour of more practical items.</p><p>Tesco spokesman David Sawday explained: "As term starts again we want to give students a helping hand with the groceries. So we polled students to find out what they would most like a year's supply of.</p><p> "We were sure that beer would score well but were pleasantly surprised when beans won."</p><p> Students are being offered Stg7 ($ A19.60) worth of money off vouchers at Tesco stores and they will then be automatically entered into a competition to win a year's supply of beans on toast and beer.</p><p> The Tesco Top Ten items were:</p><p> 1. Baked Beans</p><p> 2. Beer</p><p> 3. Bread</p><p> 4. Cheese</p><p> 5. Pasta and pasta sauce</p><p> 6. Toilet rolls</p><p> 7. Milk</p><p> 8. Bacon</p><p> 9. Vodka</p><p> 10. Cigarettes</p><p> PA</p><p> US ASHES</p><p>BROOKINGS, Oregon, Oct 11 AP - Some of the ashes of the only Japanese pilot to drop a bomb on the US mainland during World War II have been scattered at the spot where he made his 1942 bombing run.</p><p> Flying a reconnaissance plane from a surfaced submarine off the West Coast, Nobuo Fujita dropped the bomb outside Brookings, in the north-western state of Oregon, with the intention of starting a huge forest fire and diverting US efforts to fight the war.</p><p> But typical Oregon coastal rain and fog limited the incendiary bomb to a tiny blaze that was easily controlled.</p><p> Fujita, who died on September 30, 1997, at age 85, spent the final decades of his life serving as a symbol of peace.</p><p> "He was so very sorry. He had very, very deep regrets," said Ernie Bowers, 61, a close friend who met Fujita in 1990 when the former pilot visited Brookings.</p><p> Fujita made four visits altogether, including a trip in 1992 to mark the 50th anniversary of the attack during which he planted a redwood tree at the bomb site.</p><p> Some of his ashes were scattered at the site on October 4 by family members and friends.</p><p>AP</p><p> UK FISH</p><p> LONDON, Oct 11 PA - Bubbles the goldfish was swimming around happily in his tank today after surviving a rare operation which would have tested the constitution of a shark.</p><p> The 10cm long pet is making a swimmingly good recovery after vet Liz Leaver removed a grape-sized tumour on his eyeball.</p><p> His worried owner, schoolgirl Joanna Cantwell, 13, of Swansea, sought expert help when she noticed that what had started as a small lump was getting bigger and bigger.</p><p> Vet Leaver agreed to examine seven-year-old Bubbles and decided a life-saving operation was worth a try.</p><p> She first put an anaesthetising powder into the fishbowl before lifting out Bubbles and placing him on wet paper towels.</p><p> After carefully removing the infected eye, Leaver returned Bubbles to his bowl, with extra oxygen pumped into the water to aid his recovery.</p><p> "Everything had to be done within a maximum of five minutes and it was an operation I had never done before. Using anaesthetics on fish is very difficult and the timing was crucial. We were absolutely delighted for Joanna that the operation was so successful," Leaver said.</p><p> PA</p><p> CANADA DOPE</p><p>WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Oct 11 Reuters - Two men, who were allegedly cultivating marijuana in their garage, found themselves in handcuffs last week after they summoned the Winnipeg fire department for help when their home-grown crop caught fire.</p><p> "When we opened the garage door there was a funny smell," said fire chief Lionel Gauthier.</p><p> The police arrived with the fire department to investigate the problem at the house. "They might not have known that police automatically go to the scene with us," said Gauthier.</p><p> Police seized 627 marijuana plants, 144kg of dried marijuana and growing equipment from the burned-out garage and the surrounding property.</p><p>REUTERS</p><p>GERMANY YETI</p><p> FRANKFURT, Oct 11 Reuters - A Tyrolean adventurer says he has destroyed the legend of the Yeti, the mythical creature that has terrified Tibetans for thousands of years.</p><p> Contrary to popular myth, the Yeti or Abominable Snowman is not a humanoid ape but a large bear and there are about 1,000 roaming Nepal and Tibet, usually at night, Reinhold Messner announced at the world's biggest book fair in Frankfurt last week.</p><p> Bearded, rugged-faced Messner, himself a mountaineering legend since he climbed Mount Everest without using artificial oxygen in 1978, has devoted his life to tracking the creature after a close and terrifying encounter in 1986.</p><p> Over the years, several researchers have suspected that the Yeti may be a bear.</p><p>German researcher Ernst Schaefer expounded the theory after he was commissioned by the Nazis to seek out the missing link between apes and humans in the 1930s. He even shot a few.</p><p> Messner's book Yeti, unveiled at the Frankfurt Book Fair, claims to confirm this with the help of photos taken during several encounters.</p><p>REUTERS</p><p>US TEACHER</p><p>CHARLOTTE, North Carolina, Oct 11 Reuters - A substitute teacher was fired for handing out bogus "sex-dollar" bills parodying US President Bill Clinton's affair with White House intern Monica Lewinsky, school officials said.</p><p> The bills were distributed by the teacher as "prizes" to students at the John Chavis Middle School in Gaston County, North Carolina, said school spokeswoman Bonnie Reidy.</p><p> "This was unacceptable behaviour and the substitute teacher has been dismissed. Obviously this material was inappropriate for students," she said.</p><p>REUTERS</p><p> US PACKAGE</p><p>ARNOLD AIR FORCE BASE, Tennessee, Oct 11 AP - A long-lost package is better late than never, right? Maybe, except when military officials get suspicious and decide to blow it up.</p><p> The package that bore a 1986 postmark and languished somewhere for 12 years aroused suspicion when it finally showed up this week at the Air Force's Arnold Engineering Development Centre</p><p> First, it lacked a return address.</p><p> "The package had wrong markings and just didn't look like any other package you'd receive in the mail," said agent Jack Angelo of the Air Force's Office of Special Investigations.</p><p> The headquarters building was cleared out while the Air Force called down a Kentucky army unit that disposes of explosives. X-rays failed to determine if it was a bomb, so the squad took the package outside the building and blew it up.</p><p> The contents finally were revealed: The package contained data tapes.</p><p>AP</p><p> QUOTE UNQUOTE</p><p> We have still got a strong leader - and granny's still around - Former British Prime Minister Baroness Margaret Thatcher's message to the Tory faithful at their recent conference.</p><p> ENDS BRITES</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1998</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3TV8-HH60-0048-T0XK-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-25</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="1669"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1998 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:4P6W-1DK0-TXN5-R2Y4-00000-00The thin red line2002-12-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:50:12ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESNews ReviewPg. 25The thin red lineAnne Davies

New planning laws designed to protect Sydney homes from bushfires are coming into force. But, writes Anne Davies, they will come as a shock to many householders.

IN THE next few weeks tens of thousands of Sydney residents will receive letters notifying them their homes are in a bushfire-prone area.

It will be a shock for many who believed that their patch of suburbia was safe from the ravages of bushfire.

Others, perched on the urban interface between the city and the bush, will be expecting the news.

We have been told for years that living in such close proximity to nature is fraught with danger. Since the 1994 fires, when lives were lost, the state government and councils have been working on plans to control building in the danger zone. Last year's fires increased the urgency for action.

Now the plans designed to create a last line of defence against this peculiarly Australian scourge of nature are here. But the haste of their preparation is already posing problems.

Two Sydney councils put their maps of bushfire-prone areas on exhibition this week. Residents are about to find out what this means for them and their property prices.

"The psychological impact of buying something that is `bushfire prone' will affect values," says Max Fragar, the vice-president of the Planning Institute and who works as a consultant in the Blue Mountains. "It will also mean increased costs of development, increased insurance."

The new "bushfire prone" designation will appear on the section 149 certificates issued by the council when a property is sold, just as it does if a home is on a floodplain or an area prone to subsidence.

Building on some blocks may be restricted altogether, depending on the terrain. On others, with slopes of up to 18 degrees, there are requirements for buildings to be set back as far as 70 metres from the bush. This will most likely affect property developers who had hoped to either subdivide rural areas or build medium-density units in areas such as North Turramurra.

But it may affect individual home owners too, who plan to build afresh.

The new rules are contained in Rural Fire Service guidelines "Planning for Bushfire Protection", which came into effect on August 1, and Australian Standard 3959, covering buildings. The maps of bushfire-prone areas are the mechanism that applies the laws to particular properties. As the bushfire season takes hold again, several Sydney councils are racing to get their maps into law. Four rural councils, including Blue Mountains, have already had their maps approved.

But with only a few months of experience of the new laws, the Planning Institute is warning that the system is too broad-brush and is inefficient. It has warned of wholesale sterilisation of land within and around Sydney because of the setback rules.

In built-up Sydney the new rules are more likely to manifest as higher building costs, limitations on the type of design and materials that can be used and delays while development applications are submitted to the Rural Fire Service.

"People buying bushland blocks and wanting to build an environmentally sensitive house are going to have to build heavier houses," said Pittwater Council's general manager, Angus Gordon.

One planning consultant, who asked not to be named, said a client had been refused a wooden deck around the pool even though it was well separated from the house. The client must now look at alternative materials that are non-combustible and more expensive.

Such stories are not unusual. The Rural Fire Service has already agreed to join a taskforce that will review the implementation of controversial new legislation.

But, according to PlanningNSW, the legislation itself is not up for grabs; only its administrative workings will be reviewed.

In the meantime, the exercise of identifying the individual properties which are subject to the new laws is well under way.

Ku-ring-gai Council will consider its map (reproduced on the cover of News Review) next week at an extraordinary general meeting. The map will then go on public exhibition for comment, but it is unclear whether the lines on the map are able to be altered unless the RFS agrees. An estimated 12,000 homes are affected one third of all houses in Ku-ring-gai municipality.

Predictably, the Ku-ring-gai map includes large parts of North Turramurra and other areas which abut the Ku-ring-gai National Park. But it also includes some surprising areas, such as the heavily treed "bush school" in suburban Wahroonga and the houses in a 100 metre buffer zone around the school.

Ku-ring-gai mayor Ian Cross, whose own property is designated bushfire prone, says he's supportive of the new rules (although he won't be voting next week because of a potential conflict of interest).

"What we are looking to do is still have the amenity of living close to the bush, but make it a safe amenity," he says.

But like all new laws with the best intent, problems are emerging.

Pittwater's Angus Gordon says his council one of the first to put an interim map in place is sending 50 development applications a month to the Terrey Hills office of the Rural Fire Service.

"They are good guys but they are being buried under the workload," Gordon says. More complex multiple-dwelling proposals have to go to the RFS head office in Rosehill.

Pittwater Council is facing a particularly interesting problem. It has already notified 12,800 residents that they are in a bushfire hazard area, based on an earlier map produced to plan for a bushfire emergency in Sydney's most northern peninsula. But the new bushfire-prone map, which brings into play the new design laws, covers a much smaller area.

Gordon says the new map eliminates large areas adjoining what he calls "suburban bushland", and retains only the areas which adjoin the larger areas of bush.

"Some protective measures would be useful for these suburban areas. We need lesser criteria for suburban areas which are not as heavily treed," he says.

Pittwater Council has notified the RFS that it intends to stick with the earlier map until the RFS can reassure it that council will not be liable for loss or damage in the areas which have been dropped from the new map.

It has also raised concerns about the apparent contradictions between the Threatened Species Act which protects habitat and the bushfire legislation.

"It leaves a lot of confusion for residents and planners," Gordon says.

Pittwater has gone as far as to suggest the State Government should have a land repurchase plan where it wants to realise the objectives of both acts. But such a move would cost millions in an area like Pittwater, where property land values alone often exceed $1million.

Sutherland Shire Council, which covers the southern perimeter of Sydney, has more experience than most in dealing with bushfires and protecting property. It has learnt the hard way, having lost houses and lives during the 1994 bushfires and again at the start of this bushfire season.

As a result it has developed its own planning and building codes for the urban interface.

"We have a grading system at the interface and it depends on how close to the perimeter the property is as to what is required," says John Brunton, the council's director of environmental services.

He says that the RFS approach relies too heavily on setbacks and that research by Sutherland in conjunction with the CSIRO has isolated "fairly precisely where setbacks won't work in the shire".

But the Rural Fire Service has asked the council to simplify the maps for the purposes of working out which properties will be subject to the state-wide rules and the RFS approval process.

"We would prefer it if the RFS recognised our own in-house expertise [rather than taking over the process]," Brunton says.

Sutherland is planning to lodge its maps with the Rural Fire Service before Christmas, and they should be on exhibition in the new year.

While there are downsides for residents, the new bushfire laws appear to have brought one win in Ku-ring-gai: a halt to the hated SEPP 5 developments, medium-density developments for the over 55s.

Following a massive community campaign, by the residents of North Turramurra and which received support from broadcaster Alan Jones, the Planning Minister, Andrew Refshauge, and the Rural Fire Service Commissioner, Phil Koperberg, visited to see what

the fuss was about.

Within hours the entire peninsula had been declared a SEPP-5 free zone because of the difficulties of evacuation if the surrounding bushland went up in flames.

The large blocks along Bobbin Head Road had been a favourite for these over-55 developments and angry developers are still contemplating whether they have any legal rights to compensation.

Although legislation is still to come, the Land and Environment Court has rejected several applications on bushfire safety grounds.

So far it is the councils with experience of bushfires who have raced ahead with their bushfire mapping. But as this week has proved, councils like Ryde, which include areas like the Field of Mars common, will need to consider similar exercises.

Meanwhile, for those would-be renovators in the bushland suburbs, a word of warning. Finding a planner who has time to give advice is a challenge in itself.

BUILDING IN THE BUSH

Construction in areas prone to bushfires must meet the following guidelines:

* Maximum distance between bush and house depends on the slope of the land. The steeper the slope, the faster and more ferocious a fire can be.

* Ridgetop sites and sites on steep slopes should be avoided, particularly if they have northerly to westerly aspects. Sites on slopes steeper than 18 degrees are considered too dangerous.

* Every home should be separated from the bush by at least an access road or reserve. It is not acceptable to expect a neighbouring landowner, such as the National Parks and Wildlife Service, to provide these asset protection zones.

* There should be two ways to access every home and the roads should be at least eight metres wide, with limited use of speed humps or chicanes.

* Concrete-slab construction should be used in preference to raised floors. Homes should be built near entrances to blocks, rather than set back.

* Battleaxe blocks and scattered subdivisions are not permitted.

* Wire screens may be required on all windows, to prevent ember attack if the windows smash during fire.

* Guttering must have leaf screens.

* Use of wood as a building material may be restricted, depending on site.

ILLUS: The battle front ... establishing a dividing line is proving the struggle. Photo: Nick Moir MAP: Bushfire-prone land. Bushfire map prepared for Ku-ring-gai Council. urn:contentItem:46PH-YDB0-015G-T033-00000-00<published>2002-09-08T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:50:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>SEPTEMBER 11, 2001 - ONE YEAR ON; Pg. N04</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>My deliverance from pure evil</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Greg Trevor, 38, worked as a press officer on the 68th floor of the World Trade Centre's North Tower. He thought September 11 would be a day like any other. He was wrong</p><p nitf:lede="true">My life was spared by 11 minutes. On September 11, I escaped from the North Tower at 10.18am. The building collapsed seconds before 10.29am.</p><p nitf:lede="true">I owe my life to three things: a tie; a Port Authority Police officer; and the architects who designed the World Trade Centre in such a way as to ensure it remained standing long enough to allow an estimated 25,000 people to escape.</p><p>When the first of two 767s hit the twin towers at 8.46am, I was at my desk on the 68th floor, in the public affairs department of the New York Port Authority.</p><p>I had been working for nearly two hours, and had just finished a phone call to a colleague at Newark International Airport.</p><p>I stood to stretch my legs and was nearly knocked to the floor by the impact of the first plane.</p><p>I heard a loud thud, followed by an explosion. The building felt like it swayed about 10 feet to the south. It shuddered back to the north, then shimmied back and forth.</p><p>Out the window I saw a parabola of flame fall towards the street, followed by a blizzard of paper and glass.</p><p>Then I heard two sounds: sirens on the street and phones ringing across the 68th floor - calls from reporters wondering what had happened.</p><p>I ran to the office of my department director, Kayla Bergeron.</p><p>Within a few minutes, we gathered the staff, threw files into our bags, and prepared to evacuate.</p><p>Ana Abelians, a member of our staff, said two media calls were holding. I replied: "You get one, I'll get the other one, we'll get rid of them and get the hell out of here."</p><p>I picked up the phone. "Greg Trevor here."</p><p>"Hi, I'm with NBC national news. If you could hold on for about five minutes, we're going to put you on for a live interview."</p><p>"I'm sorry, I can't. We're evacuating the building."</p><p>"But this will only take a minute."</p><p>"I'm sorry, you don't understand. We're leaving the building right now."</p><p>He seemed stunned. "But, but, this is NBC national news." (Apparently, I didn't have to risk my life for the local NBC affiliate, but no sacrifice was too great for the national news).</p><p>I said "I'm sorry" once more, then hung up.</p><p>For more than an hour, we joined thousands of other people who patiently descended the emergency stairwells.</p><p>All we knew was a plane had hit the building. It didn't make sense. How could a plane hit a 110-storey building on such a clear day?</p><p>I tried to call my wife, Allison, several times by cell phone, but couldn't get through.</p><p>Fortunately, I reached my colleague, Pasquale DiFulco, through my pager.</p><p>Pasquale, who was on vacation and was watching CNN, called Allison to let her know I was safe. He also used his pager to tell us what was really going on.</p><p>9:32am Pager message from Pasquale:</p><p>AA 676 from boston crashed into 1wtc. fbi reporting plane was hijacked moments before crash. saw second plane crash live on cnn into 2wtc. Bush just made announcement possible terrorist attck.</p><p>9:36am At least 1000 injuries - cnn.</p><p>9:41am Fire at the pentagon.</p><p>9:43am Message to Pasquale: Oh Christ.</p><p>9:43am Message from Pasquale: Pentagon and white house being evacuated.</p><p>9:46am Fire on mall in</p><p>washington.</p><p>9:49am Faa closes all flights nationwide.</p><p>9:52am Plane hit pentagon.</p><p>9:54am Capitol treasury also evacuated.</p><p>Despite this news, our long walk in search of safety remained calm and orderly.</p><p>Every few floors we would stop, move to the right of the stairwell and make room for injured people walking down - and firefighters and Port Authority Police officers running up.</p><p>Then we reached the fifth floor just before 10am. We heard a loud rumble. The building shook violently. I was thrown from one side of the stairwell to the other.</p><p>We didn't know it at the time, but the South Tower had just collapsed.</p><p>Our stairwell filled with smoke and concrete dust. Breathing became difficult. The lights died. A steady stream of water, about</p><p>four inches deep, began running down the stairs.</p><p>It was as if we were wading through a dark, rapid river - at night in the middle of a forest fire.</p><p>The smartest decision I made that day was to wear a tie. I put the blue tie over my nose and mouth to block the smoke and dust.</p><p>Someone yelled that we should put our right hand on the shoulder of the person in front of us and keep walking down.</p><p>We descended one more flight, to the fourth floor, when I heard someone say: "Oh s-, the door's blocked."</p><p>The force from the collapse of the South Tower had jammed the emergency exit. We were ordered to head back up, to see if we could transfer to another stairwell.</p><p>Now we were wading against the current of that dark, dirty river. Others were still trying to walk down. People were starting to panic.</p><p>For the first time, I was afraid we wouldn't make it. I whispered a quick prayer: "Lord, please let me see my family again."</p><p>I closed my eyes and made mental pictures of my family's faces: Allison's beautiful brown eyes; our five-year-old son Gabriel's deep blue eyes and dimples; our two-year-old son Lucas's blond ringlets.</p><p>I remember thinking: Their faces will keep me calm, and if I die, they will be the last thing on my mind.</p><p>During this ordeal, Pasquale sent me a series of frantic pager messages that did not get through.</p><p>10am Message from Pasquale: Please tel me u r ok Please respond. Another explosion at wtc.</p><p>10.02am Part of 2 wtc has</p><p>collapsed. Is evryone ok???</p><p>10:06am Plwesse repsond.</p><p>10:12am Where are you? 2 wtc just collapsed???</p><p>I don't know how many minutes it took for emergency workers to clear the exit.</p><p>But when they did, thank God police officer David Lim was there.</p><p>David is a K-9 officer whose partner, Sirius, was killed in the attacks. He was later trapped in the rubble for five hours.</p><p>David had the presence of mind to figure out a way to get us all turned around and headed back downstairs. Over and over, he shouted: "Down is good! Down is good!"</p><p>When I heard that, I shouted "Down is good!" up the stairwell. Like an echo, I heard others shout "Down is good!" up the line.</p><p>Now we darted down the stairs as quickly as possible.</p><p>The emergency exit led to the mezzanine level of the North Tower. We walked several hundred feet to a glass door that led outside.</p><p>The mezzanine was filled with concrete dust. It felt like we were walking through a huge, dirty snow globe that had just been shaken.</p><p>It was even worse when we walked outside.</p><p>The plaza was a minefield of twisted metal, covered by a layer of dust several inches thick. I am grateful for that dust, because it means I didn't see any bodies.</p><p>As we were leaving the building, my pager buzzed with a message from Al Frank, a reporter with the Newark Star-Ledger who has covered the Port Authority for years.</p><p>10.17am Message from Al Frank: are you okay?</p><p>I replied a minute later.</p><p>We're out of the building. Everyone is fine.</p><p>Relieved but fatigued, we sprinted up Church St and headed north.</p><p>I looked back. The upper third of the North Tower was on fire. There was so much dust, I couldn't tell the South Tower had collapsed.</p><p>It was then we heard an NYPD officer shout: "Run for your lives!"</p><p>We ran north for several blocks. We felt a deafening rumble, followed by a thick cloud of black smoke and brown dust.</p><p>When we finally out-raced the cloud, we had almost reached the Holland Tunnel. I was standing next to co-worker John Toth, who was limping with a bloody knee.</p><p>"John, are you all right?"</p><p>"They're gone, Greg."</p><p>"Who's gone, John?"</p><p>"Not who. Both towers, they're gone."</p><p>I didn't believe him. Then I looked back to where the twin towers should have been. All I saw was smoke and sky.</p><p>We walked the remaining blocks to the mouth of the Holland Tunnel. Military jets flew overhead.</p><p>Our clothes, hair and faces still covered with dust, we crammed into Port Authority Police cars, which took us to our temporary offices in Jersey City.</p><p>My personal recovery has been steady in the months that have followed.</p><p>Our department worked out of Jersey City for two months - at first, in rotating 12-hour shifts. As we mourn the loss of 75 friends and colleagues, we have answered the deluge of questions from media around the world - about security, the recovery and our own experiences.</p><p>I returned to Ground Zero four days after the attacks. The experience was unnerving and humbling. I looked up at the hole in the sky where our offices used to be and thought about how easily we could have been trapped up there.</p><p>I still feel waves of sadness, thinking about the loss and the suffering.</p><p>I think about the 37 Port Authority Police officers and commanders who died helping others escape - particularly Captain Kathy Mazza, the first woman Commandant of the Port Authority Police Academy.</p><p>She led a group of Police Academy instructors into the North Tower a few minutes after the first attack. Most didn't make it out.</p><p>Kathy, a former nurse and one of the finest people I've ever known, was the first female Port Authority Police officer in the department's 73-year history to be killed in the line of duty.</p><p>Sometimes when I'm walking down a street, I stop, take a deep breath of clean air and remember those frightful minutes when we were denied this pleasure.</p><p>My thighs ached for four days from the stairwell evacuation. My wife says my skin was dull gray for the first two days.</p><p>In mid-December, I was in bed for a week with pneumonia - a condition caused in part by the stress and exhaustion from September 11 and its aftermath.</p><p>Therapy has been very helpful. It has shown me that I am in the middle of a long journey. Some days I make a lot of progress; other days I stand still.</p><p>My goal is to get as far down the road as possible. But no matter how far I go, I know that there's no way I'll get back to September 10.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata
