urn:contentItem:49M5-J4T0-01S8-D42T-00000-00<published>1990-04-12T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:50:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>AFTER HOURS; Pg. 19</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Lowdown on a bad influence</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>BOLT A</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Bad Influence (M) Directed by Curtis Hanson. Stars Rob Lowe and James Spader Opens today at Hoyts cinemas ROB Lowe has complained that his private business should be just that. He was cranky about the huge fuss made over the videotape he shot of a sex session he had in 1988 with two women.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> But just when you feel sorry for the schmuck he comes out with a movie which features guess what?- the videotaping of the hero having sex, and a later (gratuitous) shot of Lowe in bed with two women.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> It makes you suspect that Lowe doesn't mind his private life being public entertainment, as long as there's something in it for him - like publicity.</p><p>Still, there's more to this movie than publicity. It's a thriller that starts easily, turns engrossingly nasty and then ends lamely.</p><p> Michael Boll (James Spader) is making a mint as a market analyst, and is attached to the standard blonde fiancee you know he won't end up marrying.She's one problem - the other is Patterson, a nasty rival at work.</p><p> Spader is just as annoyingly effective as he was in sex, lies and videotape in convincing you through his sighs and quick-dying smiles that this is a guy short of guts.</p><p> But one day he's rescued from a bar-room brawl by Alex (Rob Lowe), a sparkly-eyed nightclub sort who owns a naughty-boy smile.</p><p> He turns out to be a yuppie Mephistopheles to Boll's Faust. At first he just gives Boll spine to take the fight up to Patterson, and then helps him pick up a girl.</p><p> Then Alex's help gets more serious. Boll doesn't want to be married? - showing the fiancee's family a compromising video fixes that.Patterson? Alex fixes him up, too.</p><p> At first this sudden freedom - from the worry of pleasing people, from morality - intoxicates Boll.Alex has given Boll what he wants, with Boll barely questioning the shoddy means.</p><p> Then comes the horrible climax of the movie, a truly awful murder.But just when the movie gets down to bare knuckles, it starts to lose its punch.</p><p> From now on it's a hide-the-body kind of suspenser, with a conventional finish.</p><p> The earlier rotten behavior of superyuppie is excused, letting Boll off pretty lightly and leaving us only mildly satisfied.</p><p> Always (PGR) Directed by Steven Spielberg. Starring Richard Dreyfuss and Holly Hunter Opens today, Russell STEVEN Spielberg is probably as close to God as you can get in Hollywood. When you direct and/or produce seven of the top 20 grossing films of all time you won't find many people arguing with you.</p><p> Which may explain why his latest film as director, Always, has several miscalculations which make it less effective than it deserves to be. Has Spielberg got anyone who dares tell him when he's gone wrong?</p><p> But first the plot, borrowed from the Spencer Tracy war film A Guy Named Joe.</p><p> Pete (Richard Dreyfuss) is a pilot in a forest fire-fighting outfit.He's a daredevil, flying on instinct, which worries the heck out of his girlfriend, Dorinda (Holly Hunter).</p><p> But when it comes to telling Dorinda that he loves her, he's a coward. But wouldn't you know it, just when he's agreed to get a safer job and he's about to tell Dorinda he loves her, he gets called out to drop fire-retardant on another fire - and dies.</p><p> From then on he's an invisible spirit, charged with helping another - but goofier - fire-fighting flyer called Ted (Brad Johnson). When Pete speaks, his words pop into Ted's brain as if they were his own thoughts, his instinct. Trouble is, Ted is in love with Dorinda. He's the one that can break through her grief, but Pete the invisible spirit is having trouble letting his girl go. He can put ideas into Dorinda's mind, too, so being that close to the girl he loves drives him crazy.</p><p> It's sentimental, it's obvious. But it's good lump-in-the-throat stuff for all that.</p><p> This makes it even more frustrating when Spielberg makes some obvious miscalculations that ultimately make the film much weaker than it could have been.</p><p> For one, Brad Johnson, a tall and handsome rodeo cowboy, looks stunned by this chance to act in his first major film. This wooden Indian would never be able to fully take over Pete's role in Dorinda's life, which isn't the point of the movie at all.</p><p> Then there is Audrey Hepburn's appearance as a sort of angel who tells Pete to help his rival.The angel is called Hap, which sounds like Hep and only makes this angel seem like nothing so much as Audrey Hepburn herself, offering advice from the hereafter.</p><p> And lastly, there's a messy confusion in the plot, which has Ted determined to fly back to his unit to be with Dorinda, even though there's no way he could know she had just been signed up there.</p><p> Thanks to these flaws, you'll need just the one handkerchief.</p><p> The movie at least has some big effects which help make it better than, at heart, it is.</p><p> Nightbreed (M) Written and directed by Clive Barker. Stars David Cronenberg, Craig Sheffer, Anne Bobby Now showing at Hoyts CLIVE Barker has given us a horror story with a twist - it's the humans that give the shocks, and the beasties that turn out to be the victims.</p><p> Boone (Craig Sheffer) has nightmares of monsters at a place called Midian. He confesses them to his psychiatrist, Decker (David Cronenberg), who speaks in a weird monotone so that you know from the start he's up to no good. Decker convinces Boone (but not the audience by a long shot) that he is living out his sick fantasies by carving up the locals.</p><p> Eventually he manages to trick the police into killing the gullible Boone, but not until Decker has seen the monsters of his dreams.</p><p> Boone, of course, comes back to a form of life, and from then on he's in charge of protecting the monsters from the likes of Decker and a mad local police chief.</p><p> If you like a plot that sounds like this, you will like Nightbreed, because it's handsomely filmed and has an interesting parade of monsters. It also has a "message" - that if there's anything more frightening than a monster, it's what a human will do when he sees one.</p><p> The film finishes with a scene which quite clearly shows we are going to have to sit through another round of this.</p><p> Let's Get Lost (M) Directed and produced by Bruce Weber. Starring Chet Baker, his third wife and ex-girlfriends Now showing at the Kino THIS over-long black-and-white documentary started out as a tribute to one of the greatest jazz trumpeters, Chet Baker. Trouble is, as the film-makers follow the haggard wreck that was Chet Baker in 1987, the last year of his cruddy life, they find that the man is a liar, a wreck, a junkie, a ruined talent, a wife-beater, a sponger, and a father who turned his back on his children.</p><p> Baker's mother chats happily on camera about her son's huge talents, but she can barely stop from crying when she is asked if he is a disappointment to her.</p><p> At the end of the film, director Bruce Weber tells a spaced-out Baker on camera that seeing him has been a great disappointment to him, too. A year later Baker jumped out of a hotel window.</p><p> This mildly interesting film is less about Baker's life than it is about how a huge God-given talent can sometimes be stored in the ugliest of containers.</p><p> END OF STORY</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>Chet Baker, one of the great jazz trumpeters</p></caption></nitf:media></graphic></nitf:body.end></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:485D-J3G0-015G-V4HG-00000-00<published>2003-03-19T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:50:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>LETTERS; Pg. 16</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>GM rule should fit all</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">CAN someone please explain the following:</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Why does the Tasmanian Government's moratorium on the commercialisation of genetically modified crops exclude GM poppies and GM carnations?</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Isn't the moratorium designed to protect human health and the environment?</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Then why can these crops be grown and, in the case of GM poppy crops, have the processed end product (morphine) injected into people?</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The NSW Labor Government, if re-elected, will place a moratorium on the commercialisation of GM food crops.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Yet this moratorium excludes GM cotton.</p><p>Cotton seed is a significant source of edible oil for the Australian oil seeds industry.</p><p> Furthermore, cotton seed meal and hulls are a common ingredient in many of today's livestock rations.</p><p> What's stopping pollen from GM poppies, GM carnations and GM cotton from spreading to other non-GM crops of the same species?</p><p> And what about weeds?</p><p> How can these industries manage the issue of GM liability and insurance?</p><p> Why have these industries readily adopted GM technology if they are enslaving themselves to multinationals?</p><p> Could it be that cotton and poppy growers have realised the benefits of biotechnology and, as professional industries, have refused to allow GM debates within their industries to become hijacked by emotional and non-scientific rhetoric?</p><p>Peter Ebert,</p><p>Horsham</p><p>A dangerous experiment</p><p>THE West Wimmera Shire and the Network of Concerned Farmers hosted a meeting on GM technology in Horsham last week.</p><p> The evening rolled back some of the fog created by the peddlers of progress to supposedly improve the bottom line for canola growers.</p><p> The returns and potential liabilities associated with growing GM canola show the bottom line to be negative.</p><p> And, other questions need to be raised.</p><p> Is there an intention in government, some university faculties, corporations and career scientists to replace evolved plant life with irreversibly modified plants?</p><p> Can mankind be saved from becoming an experimental species in the test tube of scientists and corporations?</p><p> Can our bio-mass be protected from eco-terrorists?</p><p> Even the Nazis could never have envisaged the testing of genetically modified plant life on such a scale.</p><p> Once released into the environment, GM plants will never be successfully eradicated.</p><p>George Powell,</p><p>Horsham</p><p>Give consumers  a choice</p><p>CHICKEN farmers should label the eggs and meat they produce using genetically modified grain.</p><p> This might hurt their sales, but at least I could make a better choice at the shops.</p><p>David Lyons,</p><p>Strathmore</p><p>Fuel policy could cut  fire threat</p><p>I HAVE been a rural fire scientist for 41 years, working on many aspects of fire physics, fire chemistry, fire behaviour and human survival.</p><p> I have also conducted many investigations of bushfires, including the Linton tragedy.</p><p> It is essential that we arrive at a fuel management policy that yields both forest health and a safe environment.</p><p> Mark Stone (WT, March 5) seems not to understand the relationship between fuel and fire intensity -- but it is essential he does so.</p><p> In the simplest terms, the more fuel the more intense the fire.</p><p> In fact, if the fuel is halved then the fire intensity is decreased to a quarter.</p><p> Flame height and rate of spread depend on fire intensity. If the fuel is carefully managed, it could be expected to average less than a quarter of the neglected fuels we currently suffer.</p><p> That means the fire intensity would be about one-sixteenth and the flame heights and rate of spread would be much less damaging. These are facts of physics.</p><p> During the time we were developing prescribed burning from aircraft, I asked all the forest fire controllers in Australia what the minimum area that must be prescribed burnt to achieve a healthy forest.</p><p> The answers were between 10 and 20 per cent. The 1.05 per cent that was burnt would, as Mark Stone said, have made no difference.</p><p> The decision to token-burn is really a decision to replace frequent mild fire with an infrequent intense fire, with much different results.</p><p> We have been warned yet again by the Gippsland fires of what destruction to forest health, water supplies, the timber industry and rural production can result from this neglect of our dry, fire-loving forests.</p><p> I hope we do not have to wait until Melbourne's forests, population and water supplies are destroyed before we seek an effective forest fuel policy.</p><p>David Packham,</p><p>Traralgon</p><p>Sheer luck, not firebreaks</p><p>I HAVE seen for myself the massive devastation from the bushfires in the Omeo region and beyond.</p><p> I have watched video footage of the fires as they swooped through open grazing land; smelled the stench of the hundreds of stock and wildlife still waiting to be buried; stared at their exploded bodies from the intensity of the heat of the blaze.</p><p> How can Joan Webster (WT, Feb 26) even suggest 20m firebreaks prepared around haystacks?</p><p> These fires jumped 500m breaks and fence posts were burnt so completely that the hole was ready for a new post.</p><p> Some 87 bulldozers worked for three weeks, day and night, putting in firebreaks, yet each one of them was "jumped".</p><p> No matter how prepared you were, the only survival hope for this particular "red beast" was sheer luck.</p><p> Not many people had it.</p><p>Dianne Carroll,</p><p>Yarragon</p><p>Put a lid on all this silly talk</p><p>SO the Victorian Government is still serious about charging for the rain that falls on farmers' land that fills the dams they have paid for.</p><p> Farmers, tell them you don't want rain to fall on your land under those conditions.</p><p> Make them put a roof over you or drop this idiotic idea.</p><p>David Stuart,</p><p>Dromana</p><p>Windmill now a safer option</p><p>I WISH to reply to criticism of the windmill safety platform I built (WT, Feb 19).</p><p> First, the platform weighs about 145kg -- the same as a couple of average-sized men.</p><p> Mr Wallace (WT, Feb 26) is concerned that it should be able to support much more than that. However, the other consideration is wind load, as the platform is edge-on to the wind.</p><p> It has made things much easier and safer for me.</p><p> Mr Barkla (WT, Mar 12), however, has completely missed the point.</p><p> When I am working on the original working platform, I have the comforting knowledge that if I slip I will hit the safety platform, not the ground.</p><p> Two more points: first, the gap in the safety platform has a lid; secondly, the photo was taken on a perfectly still day and the person was only in it to show proportion.</p><p> Two years ago, a storm damaged the tail. I was able to remove the tail, lower it to the ground, repair it and replace it on the windmill without the aid of a set of rope blocks.</p><p> I did this job in about six hours by myself. I was 70 years old at the time.</p><p> Another advantage is that tools can be lifted without them getting tangled in the steelwork of the tower.</p><p> I can access the platform, either by the original steps on the mill post to the inside, or by an outside ladder concreted to the ground at its base.</p><p> Having a safety platform doesn't mean you can throw away your safety harness -- one complements the other.</p><p> With our windmill, which is a 3m Alston on a 10m tower, I was able to put the platform less than a metre below the original working platform.</p><p> As the safety platform is two metres square, the wheel size affects that distance.</p><p> My only experience in this field is with our own mill, which we erected 18 years ago.</p><p> I have no formal qualifications, but I have worked with steel most of my life and have absolute confidence in our mill.</p><p>Jim Bennett,</p><p>Yea</p><p>Rain dance hit a raw nerve</p><p>HEARTY congratulations to every woman who took time out to attend the Ouyen rain dance.</p><p> Thanks, too, to the Ouyen committee and those who helped make the event happen.</p><p> Thanks to Helen Healy, the event's manager, and to Lyn Healy, for uttering the first words that set the whole thing alight.</p><p>Deborah Pezet,</p><p>Wistow, SA</p><p>Separate the single desk</p><p>TWO things are clear following AWB Ltd's round of pre-AGM forums.</p><p> First, it is not prepared to entertain debate on Australia's grain marketing arrangements and, secondly, it will not relinquish the single desk.</p><p> AWB Ltd's hypocrisy during these meetings has been insulting to growers.</p><p> The examples I bring are:</p><p> Andrew Lindberg's claim that the commissioning parties of the Kronos and Accenture reports have a vested interest in changes to the single desk.</p><p> AWB Ltd's continued and tiresome repetition that these organisations seek the end of the single desk. (As if AWB Ltd doesn't have the strongest vested interest in maintaining the status quo!)</p><p> Can AWB Ltd point to any sentence of the Kronos report that calls for an end to single-desk arrangements?</p><p> It cannot, because it says nothing about it.</p><p> The Grain Growers Association, which commissioned the Accenture report, has also explicitly supported the single desk in its own documentation.</p><p> The reports instead recommend changes to improve grower returns -- again, AWB Ltd has not attempted to refute this.</p><p> An important step in achieving these changes is separating the single desk from AWB Ltd and any other commercial interests. There are valid models for an independent single desk. It is the key to improving grower returns and industry efficiency through greater competition.</p><p> If AWB Ltd is truly operating the supply chain at the lowest possible cost, an open market should hold no fears for it.</p><p> AWB Ltd's reluctance to even entertain debate on the proposal prompts the question: what does it have to fear from competing to provide services to an independent single desk?</p><p> Another question AWB Ltd needs to answer is that, if growers want an independent single desk, will AWB Ltd give it back to them?</p><p> AWB Ltd needs to be part of the debate rather than ignoring the fact that it is occurring all over Australia.</p><p>Sue Rana,</p><p>executive officer,</p><p>United Grower Holdings Ltd</p><p>Time to stop the rhetoric</p><p>RECENTLY, I attended one of the AWB Ltd grower meetings, at Young in NSW.</p><p> It did not take long for many of those in attendance to be reminded that, indeed, the old Australian Wheat Board is definitely dead and buried. Unfortunately, for those growers left in the wheat industry, in its place is the new corporate structure, AWB Ltd.</p><p> Had I known this meeting was to be the most staged, controlled propaganda event I have ever witnessed, I would have done what most other growers did and stayed at home.</p><p> Constructive debate with farmers angry over AWB Ltd's management of the single desk was not allowed.</p><p> Nor was the exploration of grower problems in the local area (as was advertised).</p><p> An interesting statement at the meeting from chief executive officer Andrew Lindberg was that the new corporate structure is possibly costing wheat growers $9.33 a tonne more than when the single desk was controlled by the Australian Wheat Board.</p><p> Saying that it's just the way it has to happen may be music to your ears if you are an AWB Ltd shareholder living in Toorak, but not so good if you are a pool participant living in the wheat belt.</p><p> If Andrew and AWB chairman Brendan Stewart are fair dinkum about increasing grower returns, they should stop the rhetoric and open up the supply chain to the national pool.</p><p> That way, pool services could be satisfied by the cheapest qualified supplier.</p><p>Grant Holland,</p><p>Grenfell, NSW</p><p>The cedars of Dartmoor</p><p>YOUR story on the Dartmoor tree sculptures (WT, Feb 19) called the trees western cypress.</p><p> In fact, they are not cypresses (family Cupressaceae), but true northern hemisphere cedars (family Pinaceae).</p><p> It's confusing: among the several genera of the Cupressaceae some are called cypresses and some cedars.</p><p> But none of the species of the genus Cedrus, true cedars, are ever called cypresses.</p><p> The trees at Dartmoor have the characteristic upright, barrel-shaped female cones of the genus Cedrus.</p><p> They are almost certainly either the deodar (Himalayan cedar), Cedrus deodara, or the Atlas cedar, Cedrus atlantica, of the north African coast.</p><p>Peter Tyler,</p><p>Illowa</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4P7G-XXT0-TXN5-S1R6-00000-00Welcome to Skid Row1992-12-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:50:12ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 14Welcome to Skid RowPaul Mansfield

Rough-and-ready Seattle is still famous for its beer and bars.

THE Biggest Steer in the World was an awesome sight, "25,500 lbs of walking hamburger!", said the sign outside the tent _ but expectations, frankly, were low. The Biggest Horse in the World had been no bigger than an English shire. And the Biggest Alligator was a submerged brown lump that could have been, and quite possibly was, dead. So far, the attractions at the Central Washington State Fair _ an odd mixture of carnival, fun fair and agricultural show _ had been distinctly underwhelming.

But then I pushed open the flap of the steer tent and found myself confronted by this enormous thing _ as big as a bus, with horns like trees. The steer was several metres high, and it towered over me. I felt like a character in a Disney fantasy gone wrong. The animal kept lunging its horns around, one massive hoof pawing the dirt. It was, naturally, a very small tent _ and the only way out was past the steer. I managed it in a single, heart-stopping lunge, bursting into the sunlight with relief. The ticket taker laughed as I reeled away.

I needed a drink, but this was hard to get. In the beer tent, a strange man with eyes many centimetres apart asked what I wanted.

"What beers do you have?" "Depends. What you want?" "Well, what have you got?" "Depends. What do you want?" Dear God, I thought, we're going to be here all day. I also thought: there's no getting away from it; that steer, this place, these people are weird.

For respite, we drove out of Seattle on the Cascade Loop, the scenic highway that circles Washington State _ the small, diverse pocket of land between California and Canada with microclimates that sustain snow-capped mountains and lush vineyards; semi-dessert, scrubland, even an equatorial rain forest.

Seattle, the capital, is also a mixture; a rough-and-ready port that has recently succumbed to (some) gentrification. It speaks volumes about Seattle that two of its most illustrious residents should be yuppie computer wunderkind Bill Gates and eccentric cartoonist Gary (`The Far Side') Larson. The place attracts odd characters of all kinds. Ferries honk and moan in mist-filled Puget Sound; Mount Ranier stands like a sentinel a few kilometres from town.

The term "Skid Row" was coined in Seattle, and the city is still famous for its beer and bars. Also for the inhabitants, bums included.

The downtown panhandlers approach you directly, requiring eye contact, demurring politely if money is refused.

Jimi Hendrix was another native of Seattle, and the city has some great music bars. At the Central Bar in Pioneer Square, a grossly overweight guitarist called Fat Jake was belting out `I Jus' Wanna Make Love To You', with maximum sleaze hanging on every word. Given Jake's appearance, I would have thought the song an unwise vehicle for his talents, but Jake, like his audience, evidently didn't give a damn. Seattle is that kind of place.

To the north east the road winds up into the Cascades, a dazzlingly pretty range of mountains, dotted with small lakes of milky glacial blue. We passed quintessential American small towns with names like Concrete and Marblemount; at Winthrop a hand-written sign next to the cash register read "No out-of-town checks." Just up the road was the Sun Valley Lodge, a resort with spectacular views over the mountains.

We took an outside jacuzzi, warm despite the howling gale, and rode mountain bikes down impossible gradients, yodelling.

Heading south down Route 97 the landscape underwent a costume change, becoming flatter, dustier and drier. Indeed, we could see a small forest fire in the distance, and then, almost unbelievably, we hit a sandstorm. The harsh beige particles whipped against the car windows, but the engine, mercifully, kept going. Ten minutes later we were back in bright blue sunshine again; and all this in the space of 50 kilometres.

We arrived in Yakima just as the State Fair was getting under way.

After my experiences with the steer, I needed some alternative entertainment, and I found it in the substantial form of country singer Wynona Judd, performing live to an open-air audience. Wynona is one of those rhinestone-clad Country women who Take No Nonsense from Men. Her band had an Aramani-clad guitarist, with whom Wynona flirted outrageously. "Life's too short", she told the audience, "to waste time working with ugly men." Cheers all around.

The next day was the day of the Yakima Sunfair parade.

These parades are really a celebration of American middle-class values, a ritual reassurance that all is still well in the Land of the Free. So first there's a riding display by the local motorcycle cops; followed by the appearance of the doe-eyed beauty queen and her acolytes; then floats from local businesses (Big Bob's Hardware Store _ You Can't buy Better!); finally a few civic dignitaries and the odd politician cadging votes. What's actually on "parade" is the town itself.

Heading north-west, we followed the fast-flowing Yakima river through kilometre after kilometre of bare basalt, grey like a moonscape. Not a house or a tree in sight _ and yet not far south they make excellent local wine. At Roslyn the rain came down in torrents, and we stopped for lunch at the Brick Tavern, the oldest working tavern in the state.

A good American bar is the best bar in the world. The Brick had an old mahogany counter imported from England in the 19th Century. There was a wide range of beer; pool tables; a shuffle board; three silent televisions tuned to the football game; and a good jukebox. Locals came in out of the rain, shaking themselves like dogs. We spent two hours in the Brick without realising it.

Outside it was still raining, and we toiled up towards Snoqualmie Pass through thickening mist. When we emerged on the other side, the rain let up long enough to show that this really was `Twin Peaks' country; a landscape of brooding, cloud-topped mountains; wooden houses; logging trucks; with a small railroad running next to the highway.

Finally we pulled off the Interstate and drove down a deserted country road into the town of North Bend _ `Twin Peaks' itself.

There's usually something corny about tracking down location sites, but not in this case. With or without the TV series, North Bend would be marvellous. Mount Si's eponymous twin peaks stand over the town, lost in cloud. North Bend itself is a tiny grid of one and two- storeyed houses. On Main Street, pick-up trucks stand parked outside hunting stores; men in checked shirts jump down from diesel trucks and dash indoors out of the rain. In North Bend there is only one place to dash into, and that's the Mar-T cafe _ also known to `Twin Peaks' aficionados as the "Double-R Diner".

The owner of the Double R (sorry, the Mar-T) is Pat Cokewell, a former head waitress there. One day in 1989 a location scout arrived on Pat's doorstep and announced that director David Lynch (of whom Pat had never heard) was considering using the town and her diner in his forthcoming TV series. Two weeks later the scout was back with good news, and Twin Peaks (sorry, North Bend) was never the same again.

Or so you might think. In fact, the remarkable thing is how little North Bend has changed. More than that, David Lynch actually drew on the character of the town itself _ improvising scripts to include the locals, switching locations at their suggestion, taking details from the town and adding them to his story. `Twin Peaks' grew out of North Bend, not the other way round.

The Mar-T still has the leatherette stools and strip lighting it has had for 30 years. A signed photo of Special Agent Dale Cooper, alias actor Kyle MacLachlan (himself a local boy, from Yakima) is the only evidence of the series. Pat, a friendly woman in her 40s, has had to increase her production of Agent Cooper's favorite cherry pie (another Mar-T original, co-opted into the `Twin Peaks' story by Lynch) 20 times over; and once a year the town hosts a `Twin Peaks' festival, with the first prize of dinner at the cafe.

Otherwise, she has made no concession to the diner's new-found fame.

In the town itself, too, the only sign of showbiz silliness is the `Twin Peaks log' on sale at the souvenir shop for a costly $US7.50 ($A11).

Over at the Double-R though (sorry, the Mar-T), Pat has refused to put up her prices. The diner's breakfast special, a gargantuan plate of eggs, hash browns, sausages and beans for a mere $US3.50 ($A5), must be one of the cheapest meals in Washington State. Coffee, naturally, is included. Oh; and it's damn fine coffee, too.

urn:contentItem:58Y8-BB01-JCM0-6361-00000-00The barbecue stopper: the chikungunya mutation threatening Australia2013-07-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:50:12ZLexisNexisBackground Briefing10:27 AM AESTThe barbecue stopper: the chikungunya mutation threatening Australia

Ian Townsend: In amongst mangroves next to the port of Brisbane, on the shores of Moreton Bay, the Federal Government's mosquito police are on patrol. Angus Sly is checking traps to see if he's caught a particularly aggressive intruder.

Angus Sly: This is one of our traps, so the mosquitoes at night will be attracted to the carbon dioxide, come in closer, be attracted to the light, and as they come in towards the light the fan will suck them into this holding container.

Ian Townsend: This trap is designed to mimic human breathing. It expels carbon dioxide, and the fan circulates the air. To a mosquito looking for a blood meal, this trap acts just like its prey, and that's us.

Angus Sly: As you can see, we got a few mosquitoes last night.

Ian Townsend: A hundred or so in there by the look of it. What sort of species do you think they might be, those ones?

Angus Sly: Having a quick look at them there's a few Aedes vigilax which is a salt marsh mosquito. It's a bit hard to see in the light.

Ian Townsend: No albopictus

Angus Sly: I hope not.

Ian Townsend: Aedes albopictus is also called the Asian tiger mosquito, and no one wants to see it in these traps. It's one of the world's most invasive pests, a vicious biter that researchers are calling 'the barbecue stopper'.

Â The Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has sentinel traps at 84 ports around Australia, and it's on high alert for the barbecue stopper. Angus Sly says once every couple of months one or two of these mozzies are caught flying around a port.

Angus Sly: Darwin has predominantly been the location where we've been getting most of our detections. Each year we seem to be getting at least one or two, sometimes up to four or five in Darwin alone, and our most recent exotic detection was in Cairns at the port there. That was in March this year.

Ian Townsend: Several arrived in Townsville in a cargo of tyres. Others were spotted in a greenhouse in Melbourne. The Asian tiger mosquito has been spreading through Africa, Europe, the Americas and the Pacific. Its next stop is Australia, and if it slips past this thin line of traps, it could soon be stopping barbecues here. It could also start spreading viruses. At the moment it's helping a nasty virus called chikungunya sweep across the arc of countries to Australia's north.

Hello, I'm Ian Townsend, and welcome to Background Briefing.

The chikungunya virus and the Asian tiger mosquito are a match made in hell, and they're knocking on our door. Increasingly, tourists returning from holidays in places like Bali and Malaysia are bringing the virus home with them. Barbara Rogers came home from Bali three months ago feeling very sick.

Barbara Rogers: And I had this bluish-red rash all over me. And it was on my legs and my body and my joints. My ankles were swollen, my wrists were swollen, my elbows, and at that time my hips. And it's like someone has thrown a hand grenade into a very healthy body and walked away to leave me to deal with it. It's bone shattering; that you feel like every bone in your body is broken. You can't take anything. I mean, every four hours I was on Panadol and Nurofen and it didn't even touch the surface of the pain. I mean, if there'd been a box I would have put myself in it at some stage.

Ian Townsend: Cases like this have become more common in the past six months. Barbara Rogers-or Barbie Rogers as she was known when co-host of the '70s TV quiz show, Great Temptation-is one of more than 70 people known to have brought chikungunya back since January.

There's no vaccine or cure for chikungunya. Looking for drugs to treat it is Andreas Suhrbier from the Queensland Institute of Medical Research.

Andreas Suhrbier: Chikungunya is a Makonde word, that's a native language of Tanzania. If you stand up and try to scrunch yourself into a foetal position with all your joints in your body bent forward, that's what it describes, 'he who is bent up' or 'that which is bent up'. That describes the posture of somebody with chikungunya disease. All their joints hurt so much they're tottering along with all their joints clenched up in a sort of foetal ball. So, yes, not at all pleasant.

Ian Townsend: Eight years ago this unpleasant disease from Africa met up with that aggressive mosquito from Asia on an island in the Indian Ocean. The chikungunya virus mutated inside the mosquito, and the pair has been on a rampage around the globe ever since.

At QIMR is Jonathan Darbro who studies mosquito biology.

Jonathan Darbro: One amino acid changed into another one, two carbon atoms to be precise, and now it spreads through this albopictus mosquito quite well. And it's a mosquito from south Asia that happened to be in Africa, and this duo then swept through Europe, and so it's globalisation at its finest. So viruses change and people are moving around more and so you're going to get all these new interactions of insects and viruses or just new viruses that you haven't seen before. So I think we'll probably see a few more surprises down the line.

Ian Townsend: Two years after that surprising mutation in 2005 there was an unprecedented outbreak in Italy. Chikungunya has infected millions of people across India and Asia, and there are now outbreaks in New Guinea and the Solomon Islands. Last week a state of calamity was declared in a town in the Philippines. The Philippines media is reporting spot fires of chikungunya across the country, mixed up with dengue. It's all a bit confusing because it's happening so fast. Dengue and chikungunya start out with similar symptoms; a rash, high fever, aches and pains. The same mosquito can spread them both at the same time. Dengue can kill, but chikungunya causes a debilitating arthritis that can linger for months.

In Papua New Guinea tens of thousands of people are infected. The PNG Institute of Medical Research is in the Highlands town of Goroka, and its head of environmental and emerging diseases is Paul Horwood.

Paul Horwood: The outbreak here started about three or four months ago towards the start of the year and we're still getting a lot of cases here at the moment. There's still a lot of people present at hospital because they're very concerned that these symptoms they feel, especially the arthritis can be very, very painful and people get very worried. And the hospital really was being overwhelmed by these cases of chikungunya.

Ian Townsend: What's it like at the moment?

Paul Horwood: We're still getting a lot of cases. At the moment we don't have enough data to be absolutely sure that we are seeing a decline in cases.

Ian Townsend: It's a growing health risk for travellers, but most people heading overseas have never heard of this virus.

The director of infectious disease at the Austin Hospital in Melbourne is Professor Lindsay Grayson.

Lindsay Grayson: Every second day now on the internet we have an alert system for any outbreaks around the world, and it's very clear that the sites where chikungunya is increasing is changing very quickly.

Ian Townsend: For years, Bali has been a popular holiday spot for Australians and this is where a lot of people are being bitten by mosquitoes and bringing viruses back. Cases of dengue have been rising, but chikungunya is accelerating.

Lindsay Grayson: We're looking at any of these diseases where they have a relatively short incubation time that fits in with the flight patterns of travellers, and so for things which have this sort of six to ten day incubation period or even a bit shorter, this is the perfect thing where someone's away for a week, they come back, they're home in six to eight hours from Bali for instance, and then they're presenting a week later with this illness. So it's an important consideration for everyone, particularly GPs, and they now have to think...when they've got a fever in a returned traveller from one of these areas, not only to think of malaria, because that's the thing that can kill you overnight, but also dengue and, to add to that now, chikungunya.

Ian Townsend: The trouble is, it's not on the radar of most Australian doctors.

Barbara Rogers got sick in Bali in March, and a doctor there diagnosed chikungunya. When she came back to Australia, the pain was so bad she went to hospital and told them she had chikungunya, but the doctors who treated her hadn't heard of the disease.

Barbara Rogers: I was in overnight and they did all these tests and they kept coming back to me and saying, 'We can't find anything, we can't find anything, so we'll give you painkillers, painkillers.' Then it got worse and four days later I collapsed paralysed down the left side, and they rushed me into emergency again. And I took a photocopy of the doctor's thing saying what it was. Anyhow, it was interesting because I would say nine out of the ten doctors that came to see me had never heard the word before. Now, wouldn't you have thought they would have either got in touch with Bali or the doctor in Bali or infectious diseases? But they didn't even attempt to do that. I was in for 11 days. And a couple doctors came back to me and they Googled it and they said, 'We've never heard of it before.'

Ian Townsend: Background Briefing contacted a number of people who've come back to Australia seriously ill with chikungunya, and they all have a similar story; their doctors hadn't heard of it.

Here's Lindsay Grayson from the Austin Hospital in Melbourne:

Lindsay Grayson: That's an important point because particularly if you think of the huge number of people that come back from Bali or Malaysia where chikungunya now is increasingly being reported, or India, there's an important lesson here because GPs previously, a patient who wasn't sick enough to go to hospital they would just do dengue serology. Well, of course that'll come back negative, so it's important that they think to order both tests.

Ian Townsend: Is there a chance that if it comes back negative for dengue, they're not quite sure what it is, the patient might be over their fever and rash, that they be sent home? Is there a chance that some cases aren't being diagnosed?

Lindsay Grayson: You know, I'm sure that's true, that some aren't being diagnosed. The question is does it really matter? Well, it does because it's always an important part of getting over these illnesses because usually these people are pretty sick by the time we see them in hospital. It's good for them to know, well, actually what you have is chikungunya.

Ian Townsend: Chikungunya rarely kills, but it can put people out of action for months. They can have trouble typing, sitting, lifting, driving, holding a phone. It can be an economic disaster for families and even entire communities. That's what's been happening overseas.

Professor Donald Shepard is a health economist at Brandeis University near Boston, and he's speaking via Skype.

Donald Shepard: We studied dengue in other poorer communities such as Cambodia where people, if they were sick they had to pay out of pocket for treatment, and the burden was quite substantial, pushing people in debt, forcing them to sell livestock and other major assets. And I would expect chikungunya particularly in a poorer community to have very similar devastating impacts.

Ian Townsend: That's what's happening in Papua New Guinea, as chikungunya spreads and a silent disaster unfolds.

Paul Horwood from the PNG Institute of Medical Research:

Paul Horwood: A lot of these people are really on the borderline of being very, very poor and being able to feed their families and put food on the table, and having something like this can really tip them over the edge.

Ian Townsend: Paul Horwood's based in the highlands town of Goroka, which has a daytime temperature of about 25 degrees all year round. It didn't have many mosquitoes and rarely saw mosquito-borne diseases, until the arrival of the Asian tiger mosquito. Now Paul Horwood is seeing people in the streets crippled with chikungunya.

Paul Horwood: It's quite amazing, these arthritic symptoms that you see. You see people that are only 25 years of age walking around on a stick and limping on a stick because they can't walk properly, and it really has had a very large impact, particularly in our workforce, people turning up to work and not being able to walk properly and things like that. So it certainly has had a large impact on the country and also the workforce.

Ian Townsend: The strain of chikungunya that mutated in 2005 spreads with alarming speed.

At the University of Queensland, Nigel Beebe studies mosquito evolution.

Nigel Beebe: And that virus, the chikungunya virus that actually moves through albopictus quite quickly, we call it quick chik, and it is actually now moving around the world, and this is what's moving through Papua New Guinea at the moment. So we again should be extremely aware of this because it's quite likely we'll be seeing it in the Torres Strait islands.

Ian Townsend: It's the speed of quick chik, combined with the aggressive daytime biting habits of Aedes albopictus, that's making health authorities in North Queensland very, very nervous.

When chikungunya broke out on Reunion Island in the Indian Ocean, 270,000 people-nearly a third of the population-got sick. There were 45,000 cases in just one week. Deaths from the virus are considered rare, but several hundred people died in that outbreak.

As we heard, the Asian tiger mosquito, Aedes albopictus, is already in Australia, in the Torres Strait, but hasn't yet established itself on the mainland. There's another good vector of chikungunya already in North Queensland, around Cairns. A cousin of albopictus called Aedes aegypti is responsible for a rolling outbreak of dengue.

Health authorities in Cairns have been on alert for chikungunya since two people with the virus came back from New Guinea in April. The concern isn't just for public health but what an outbreak might do to the local economy.

Chikungunya researcher Andreas Suhrbier:

Andreas Suhrbier: If we get an outbreak here, even a reasonably small one, the tourist cost could be very large indeed. We've seen with SARS in places like Hong Kong, the damage there was really not so much clinical; the damage was to the tourist industry. Foot and mouth disease outbreak in England, yes big damage to agriculture, but the cost to tourism turned out to be much, much larger. So yes, keeping on top of these things and being prepared and controlling them quickly and efficiently is very important for your economy.

Ian Townsend: It's not just a threat to Australia's top end. The Asian tiger mosquito would be right at home in Melbourne. It likes temperate climates and its eggs can survive frost.

In Brisbane there is already a colony of Aedes albopictus, but it's in a secure lab at Queensland Health. The entomologist studying the Asian tiger mosquito for Queensland Health is Andrew van den Hurk.

Andrew van den Hurk: You know, one of the things with Aedes albopictus is that it has this amazing capacity, once it gets into a given location it will just spread, you know, human assisted transport, and has the potential to go down as far south as Sydney and Melbourne. And we've been doing experiments with the actual mosquito itself in the Torres Strait; could it actually survive in Sydney or Melbourne? And our experiments suggest that it could.

Ian Townsend: Asian tiger mosquitoes were found flying around a greenhouse in Melbourne last year. They'd come in from China with lucky bamboo, an indoor plant that grows in jars of water, and had somehow survived three levels of treatment, including fumigation. The mosquito invades countries by stealth, and wherever it goes, from Chicago to Rome, it changes people's behaviour.

Greg Devine is the head of entomology at the Cairns Public Health Unit.

Greg Devine: Interestingly in my own experience in working with colleagues in Rome where they have had incursions of albopictus, and albopictus is now very well established in that city which is about a similar climate to Sydney, it has changed the way the people live their lives. I mean, obviously Italians are very used to an outdoor lifestyle, but it has actually changed the numbers of people going through the gates at the botanical gardens and the local cemetery, and all the places that they used to traditionally go on a Sunday are now far less visited because they just haven't had this kind of thing that comes and bites your hands and your face and annoys your kids at one o'clock in the afternoon, that's not a mosquito they've ever been exposed to before. So it really will change people's behaviour.

Ian Townsend: People talk about being chased by this aggressive mosquito. When she became sick with chikungunya, Topaz Conway was on holidays in Malaysia.

Topaz Conway: I do remember the culprit because I happened to walk into this part of the forest just in back of the huts where there was a pile of rubbish from the resort where I was staying, and I was standing near that looking at a particular flower on a tree I think it was and suddenly felt like I was getting attacked by an army of mosquitoes and I ran and they literally chased me back to my hut

Ian Townsend: Before she fell ill two months ago, author Laura Jean McKay recalls the biting mosquitoes in Bali.

Laura Jean McKay: Because I've lived in Southeast Asia a fair bit I'm fairly good with repellent, however I was bitten through clothes.

Ian Townsend: Do you think they might have got you through the clothes because you had plenty of repellent on exposed parts?

Laura Jean McKay: Yes, that's right, I usually put the DEET around my ankles and wrists and the exposed areas but I had a lot of...a few bites on my upper thigh through the sarong or the skirt I was wearing, so I think that's probably where it came from.

Ian Townsend: In the US, the Asian tiger mosquito has spread right up the east coast, and is well established in New Jersey. In summer this mosquito can hold people hostage inside their homes.

Studying the mosquito behaviour is health economist Donald Shepard from Brandeis University in Boston.

Donald Shepard: The kind of people that would enjoy having a barbecue or sitting in their backyard relaxing or playing with their children, it's limited by this mosquito. So even when there's not a disease that's transmitted by it, which is so far the case in this part of the USA, there's still a burden from this mosquito.

Ian Townsend: The more people complain about this annoying mosquito, the more money local governments have to spend trying to control it. Professor Shepard's been looking at the cost benefit of all that expensive spraying. He's asked people in New Jersey how much they're prepared to pay to have one mosquito-free hour back outside in the garden.

Donald Shepard: They valued those hours at $10.88 per hour. So when you do the math and extrapolate that up it amounted to $291 per person over one season, the monetary value that people would put on being free of this nuisance mosquito.

Ian Townsend: How did they come to that particular figure of $10.88?

Donald Shepard: We used a technique in economics called 'willingness to pay'. We asked people to hypothesise a price for one mosquito-free hour and asked if people would be willing to pay that much, and if they said yes, then through a kind of auction process the amount was raised until one reached statistically the maximum amount that somebody was willing to pay. And the average over this sample turned out to be $10.88 cents.

Ian Townsend: That's $10.88 that each household is willing to pay for one mosquito-free hour. If you think of a city with 100,000 people, that's a million dollars for one hour in the backyard. Mosquito control doesn't cost that much, so a fogging campaign in this case is considered value for money.

Professor Shepard says because the Asian tiger mosquito has such a high economic cost, both as a nuisance and a disease carrier, it's well worth planning ahead for its arrival, much as people might plan ahead for a bushfire season.

Donald Shepard: When we try to take precautions to reduce the risk of a forest fire knowing its devastating cost, in the same way by taking precautions on minimising the kind of environments that promote mosquitoes, we reduce the risk that we have an outbreak that, like a fire, can be costly in terms of monetary cost, in terms of human cost.

Ian Townsend: In Queensland, local councils already spend about $10 million a year to control nuisance mosquitoes. That doesn't include the costs of fighting dengue in Cairns, or combating the Asian tiger mosquito in the Torres Strait.

Greg Devine from the Cairns Public Health Unit:

Greg Devine: And so one of the things that we're looking at in the near future is to get a proper cost benefit analysis of the problem so we can at least then go to state and federal governments and the local councils and say, look, this is what it will actually cost if it becomes a major problem on the mainland. And with that kind of information behind us then it's much easier to go and then ask for further funding.

The other thing of course is the threat of an actual disease outbreak itself. At the moment albopictus in the Torres is a nuisance issue and not a public health one because so far it hasn't vectored any disease that we know of, but it's very likely that in the future it will, and of course as soon as you actually have a real public health problem then people's wallets tend to yawn open a little wider.

Ian Townsend: Outbreaks of chikungunya come with a high medical cost and lots of lost work hours, and there's a big social cost too.

The director of the World Health Organisation's collaborative centre for arbovirus research is John Aaskov, who's also a virologist at the Queensland University of Technology.

John Aaskov: I think even more than the economic side is the social side. The disease is most common in the sort of 20 to 45 age group and that's your childbearing age group. Now, if you're a mum and you're working part-time and you've got young kids and you can't open the fridge door and you can't turn a tap and you can't undo the Velcro on the shoes and all this sort of stuff, your life is slower, it's more painful and you've not got anything that you can show anybody to elicit sympathy, you know, you don't get big swollen joints or something. And you find that when you have sore joints you lose mobility and muscle tone, so then anything you do tires you more quickly, so then you stop doing things anyway. And so you get this spiral of loss of fitness and depression and whatever else, and, you know, it's really hard to put a value on some mum trying to manage her household tasks in semi-constant pain, I don't know how you put a dollar value on that.

Ian Townsend: As John Aaskov says, it's people in their prime who are the hardest hit; people like Laura Jean McKay, who's 35 years old.

Laura Jean McKay: I did meet up with my 91-year-old grandmother, who is doing very well, but she does have arthritis, and we met up yesterday for a cup of tea and we were both walking in a very similar way. She's 91, and we had the same gait as we walked along.

Ian Townsend: This is why it's important that chikungunya is accurately diagnosed. It can cause arthritic pain for months. People and their employers need to know why they're sick, and that they will eventually get better.

Laura Jean McKay is an author, and still has trouble typing. She developed a fever at a writers' festival in Bali in May and was told she had dengue. On the flight home she had a rash as bright as sunburn and swollen hands and feet.

Laura Jean McKay: So when I came back to Australia I went to a GP who again tested for dengue and it came up negative. And then I went to the infectious diseases ward in Melbourne and they proceeded to do a series of tests, again they diagnosed dengue, and I think that was really just so I could start treating it. But with a bit of Facebook research actually, other friends who'd lived in tropical countries suggested chikungunya, and eventually the infectious diseases unit also diagnosed it as that.

Ian Townsend: So a friend on Facebook recognised your full-body rash?

Laura Jean McKay: Yes, I put up a photograph of this amazing rash and a friend on Facebook said looks like a dengue rash but it also could be chikungunya, and that was the first time I'd ever heard of this, and also I think the first time my GP had ever heard of this. So it's not something that's widely known. In fact a lot of people refer to it as 'chicken dinner' because it's hard to pronounce.

Ian Townsend: Two days after being bitten and chased by mosquitoes in Malaysia, Topaz Conway came down with a high fever, a rash and aching joints. When she arrived in Brisbane she was so sick she went straight to hospital, where she was told it was probably flu and to go home. The next day she went to a GP.

Topaz Conway: I kept saying, 'But it's not the flu, I know it's not the flu, my joints hurt, there's something wrong here,' and he pretty much did the same thing; take two aspirin, go home, and if you're not better on Monday, come back. So by Sunday I Googled my symptoms and immediately what came up were three things: it was dengue, Ross River or this chikungunya, and it could have been any of the three. So Monday I took myself off to another doctor, asked her to test for dengue and Ross River, she wasn't going to, but then I insisted.

Ian Townsend: While waiting for the result, Topaz Conway's pain become so bad that she started asking around for a chikungunya test, and found Andreas Suhrbier at the Queensland Institute of Medical Research.

Topaz Conway: And he immediately said, 'You know, it sounds to me like it's chikungunya,' he said, 'In fact I'll bet you a bottle of whiskey it is.' And so I said, 'Okay, that's great, but what do I do?' And he told me where to go to get the test done and I did that, and sure enough that's what it came back to be.

Ian Townsend: Chikungunya is like a souped-up version of Ross River virus. They're both alphaviruses, and they both cause a rash, fever, and arthritis that can last many weeks or months. If you've ever had Ross River virus-and 4,000 to 5,000 Australians are diagnosed every year-you'll know how painful that can be. Chikungunya is worse.

And there's another local alphavirus that's had an unexplained jump in cases lately. There've been 3,000 cases of the Barmah Forest virus in the past six months. We've put some graphs on the Background Briefing website to show how the incidence of these mosquito-borne diseases has been rising lately.

All these alphaviruses make people sick in the same way. Andreas Suhrbier:

Andreas Suhrbier: There are a very few viruses that cause this kind of protracted disease dominated by these rheumatic symptoms. And why do they do that? Well, the answer is actually reasonably simple; the virus infects cells in the joints, and so the immune response tries to get rid of these infections, and that battle between the virus and the immune system causes inflammation and that causes the disease.

Ian Townsend: The painful arthritis lasted nine months for Topaz Conway. She describes what happened when her symptoms vanished briefly during a bout of food poisoning.

Topaz Conway: Suddenly I felt good and it didn't matter that I had salmonella and was vomiting my guts out, it was more I was absolutely ecstatic and almost giddy from not having the pain in the joints. So on day five when all the symptoms of salmonella went away, the pain came back and that's sort of when I lost the plot and told the doctor, 'You can cut off both my arms and legs because I just cannot live with this pain,' and I was dead serious at the time.

Ian Townsend: In Victoria, Laura Jean McKay still has arthritis two months after the infected mosquito bit her.

Laura Jean McKay: So yesterday I felt really arthritic and found it difficult to walk and I dropped a plate and smashed it on the floor because I couldn't hold it, and then today not so arthritic but my feet are peeling and I feel quite nauseous.

Ian Townsend: What do you mean, the skin's actually peeled off?

Laura Jean Mckay: The skin's falling off, yes the skin's peeling off, and that's the result of the rash.

Ian Townsend: Laura Jean McKay's in Melbourne, where so far there are no mosquitoes that could transmit chikungunya. If she lived in Cairns, as opposed to Melbourne, it'd be a different story. A cousin of the Asian tiger mosquito, Aedes aegypti, has already migrated to Cairns, established itself, and is now endemic in North Queensland. It's responsible for a dengue outbreak that Cairns can't seem to shake. And Aedes aegypti is also a really good vector for chikungunya.

Greg Devine is director of entomology at the Cairns Public Health Unit.

Greg Devine: Certainly in Queensland we need to be alarmed just because we know this is where the viruses do very well. Virus replication is all to do with temperature and it's in these parts of the tropics that the virus can really circulate quite fast. And one of the interesting things about chikungunya and albopictus is that it's a very, very fast replication, much faster than we're used to dealing with the old Aedes aegypti dengue model, so that makes our job much, much harder. So we need to be looking very seriously for new interventions and, as I say, they are on the horizon.

Ian Townsend: Australia has kept albopictus off the mainland for more than a decade, but it came to the Torres Strait in 2004. It was thought to have arrived from Papua New Guinea, but DNA testing showed this variant of the mosquito came somehow from Indonesia.

There are so many ways Aedes albopictus can get to the mainland that some researchers worry that it's already here.

At QIMR is mosquito biologist Jonathan Darbro:

Jonathan Darbro: I think about that actually, I think about that quite a bit. And one nice thing about albopictus is that if it was well established, we would know it. It's not shy.

Ian Townsend: People would be on the phone saying, 'What are these mosquitoes?'

Jonathan Darbro: That's right, and as soon as people complain, council guys will go check it out, and everyone in the business is aware of the threat. It might be that a couple...maybe some eggs got through somewhere and there's some larvae, whether or not that gets caught before it goes anywhere or if it becomes the point of establishment, there is no way of saying.

Ian Townsend: Another worry is that chikungunya could be spread in Australia even without Aedes albopictus or Aedes aegypti.

Andrew van den Hurk: The interesting thing about Aedes albopictus is they called the Asian tiger mosquito because it's got a lot of stripes and things like that on it, but the most distinctive one is this stripe that runs straight down the back.

Ian Townsend: But its main distinction for the public would be just the fact that when you go outside you're being more viciously attacked than you would normally...

Andrew van den Hurk: That's right, and particularly during the day, which you don't tend to get much in Brisbane. In North Queensland you would because they have Aedes aegypti. So it's very distinctive, you can see that white stripe...

Ian Townsend: Yes, you can see the...it's almost a silver stripe down the back.

Andrew van den Hurk: Yes, so it's quite a spectacular mosquito.

Ian Townsend: It is spectacular, isn't it? And there are blobs of silver on its body and at its joints.

Ian Townsend: Queensland Health recently took a close look at Australian native mosquitoes to see if any of those could be a vector for chikungunya. It turns out that one of the best vectors is a common mosquito called Aedes vigilax, the salt marsh mosquito which we heard about earlier, caught in a mosquito trap at the Port of Brisbane.

Queensland Health entomologist, Andrew van den Hurk:

Andrew van den Hurk: One of those is Aedes vigilax which is the main Ross River vector throughout coastal areas of Australia. Aedes vigilax comes from salt marshes. So there's times when you get above average high tides or above average rainfall and you'll get plagues of these mosquitoes, and people definitely notice them, and certain suburbs are more at risk. So yes, there are a number, and there's even another domestic species called Aedes notoscriptus, and this is the one that if you're working out in the garden in the late afternoon heading into dusk or you're out on the veranda having a drink after work, that's the mosquito that will probably be hassling you there.

Ian Townsend: Researchers also worry about what will happen if the Asian tiger mosquito starts biting marsupials, which are the natural hosts for our native alphaviruses.

Andrew van den Hurk: Marsupials are major hosts of Ross River virus, so the question is could they be also hosts of chikungunya, and in all reality we really at this stage don't know that. Having said that, humans are the hosts of chikungunya, so I think there's enough potential hosts here, that's for sure.

Ian Townsend: There's no vaccine and no cure for chikungunya, and no specific drug to treat it. Trying to make any new drug from scratch can cost a fortune and take years. Andreas Suhrbier is part of a team looking at treatments for rheumatoid arthritis that could also treat chikungunya in an outbreak.

Andreas Suhrbier: The dogma some years ago was; oh don't be stupid, they are really very different diseases, you know, one is an autoimmune disease and goes on forever, one is a self-resolving viral arthritis, you know, completely different, you'd be nuts to think that there'd be some kind of similarity there.

So we actually did the experiment, and we got together with Emory University in the USA and we actually did a study trying to work out what the inflammatory signatures in the two diseases are, and we were really surprised. In fact the inflammation in both those have a remarkable level of similarity, and that was an extremely surprising result for us. But it illustrates that at least some of these drugs (we don't know which ones yet) that are being developed for rheumatoid arthritis should also find application in the treatment for Ross River and Barmah Forest and chikungunya et cetera.

Ian Townsend: There's research into new ways of attacking the mosquito too. In Cairns, a trial of a bacteria called Wolbachia is helping slow the spread of the Aedes aegypti mosquito and its ability to transmit dengue. The bacteria could also work with chikungunya inside the Asian tiger mosquito, but that research is still some years away. There are also new insecticides that could better help control Aedes albopictus, but they haven't been registered in Australia yet.

How cost effective the mosquito controls we have at the moment will be in controlling any outbreak of chikungunya is a question that bothers virologist John Aaskov.

John Aaskov: And, you know, if we did get a big outbreak of chik in Cairns or something there would be an enormous political pressure to rush around and do all sorts of things, which in the long-term might not have very much effect at all. And so I think people need to maintain cool heads here. What's it going to cost us in terms of either morbidity or mortality, what's it going to cost us to prevent that, and is that a cost effective use of our health dollar? And so while this is fascinating to me, I'm not the health minister trying to balance a budget, and so we need to keep a sense of perspective in what we are doing.

Ian Townsend: From the perspective of someone who's had the disease, no price is too high to be able to treat chikungunya and kill the Asian tiger mosquito.

Topaz Conway:

Topaz Conway: If hundreds or tens of thousands of people got this it would mean people who couldn't work, couldn't lift their children. You can't lift things, and simple things like if a mother gets it and she can't lift her infant, or I would drop things because literally my wrists would give out. Even getting up off the floor, if I sat down on the floor for any reason, there were times when I had to sort of crawl over to a chair so I could somehow get myself up off the floor. So it isn't a trivial thing, if this were to break out in a major way.

Ian Townsend: Background Briefing's co-ordinating producer is Linda McGinness, research by Anna Whitfeld, technical production by Leila Shunnar,Â the executive producer is Chris Bullock, and I'm Ian Townsend.
