urn:contentItem:4NBY-TWB0-TX52-F30C-00000-00LETTERS TO THE EDITOR2007-03-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:50:12ZLexisNexisFEATURESPg. 15

MATP

LETTERS TO THE EDITOR

A kangaroo court, yes, but anything to escape a hellhole

MOST TALKED ABOUT

DAVID HICKS

DAVID Hicks pleaded guilty in a kangaroo court to a charge that didn't exist when he was arrested -- after two of his three lawyers were not allowed in the court to give him advice.

Who could blame him? He has been subject to torture and deprivation for over five years, and any way out would have to be better than to continue to endure such barbaric treatment from the US.

Vic Adams

Reid, ACT

SO, David Hicks has pleaded guilty to a long list of accusations. Gossip as you will about the mechanics and quality of his imprisonment and trial, then sentence him to life imprisonment.

His fundamental crime had been to show a world of misfits, deviates, potential terrorists and so on, the path to evil -- and that is it quite easy. He has encouraged the enemy within with great publicity. He is a traitor of the first order and the world has traditionally been hard on traitors.

Geoffrey Sherrington

Donvale, Vic

AS David Hicks faces his days in court tonight, I am saddened that he was unable defend himself in an unbiased setting.

But what worries me even more is that both John Howard and Philip Ruddock claim that this military commission system that permits statements obtained under torture, denies evidence to the defence and removes rights of appeal, is a fair court. This raises the horrifying prospect that they may wish to apply similarly unreasonable standards to terror cases in Australia.

I can only hope that none of us have to face this Government's rough justice at home or abroad.

Ben Corry

Crawley, WA

IF the US Government has to corrupt its legal and democratic processes to deal with David Hicks, terrorism has won another victory. These acts of corruption do more damage than any terrorist could do to another country. You can only corrupt your own heart and soul.

Michael Diehl Breen

Dalton, NSW

SURPRISE, surprise the David Hicks kangaroo court has thrown John Howard an excuse for his actions in allowing a completely inhuman situation to continue.

I have more faith in Australians than to think they would accept the guilty plea by Hicks as genuine. Rather, they will see it as a desperate act to free himself from a hellhole.

As George W. Bush, Tony Blair, and Howard are all on the bottom of the popularity polls, we will thankfully be free of all of them in a year or so.

Frank Crichlow

Carrara, Qld

NOW that David Hicks has pleaded guilty to a serious charge, can the red-faced cheer squad take a rest. He had access to extensive military and civilian legal advice and has chosen not to fight the charge. One must assume his advice was that he would not be acquitted.

He has embarrassed and made fools of many supporters, so it is understandable that some will continue to keep fighting shadows long after he has given up. To them I say, be more careful next time before tilting at windmills. Anyone caught next to a forest fire with a box of matches and a can of petrol in their hand usually has good reason to feel apprehensive.

John McLeod

Sunshine Coast, Qld

AS feared, the ''trial'' of David Hicks is proving to be an obscene abuse of justice. When a judge has no qualms about sacking defence lawyers but criticises a prisoner's dress sense, you know something is wrong.

John Byrne

Randwick, NSW

ONCE a certain element in our community gets over the shock of a tubby David Hicks, the spin doctors will be working full time to tell us that the poor man had nothing else to do with his time. I'm sure, though that the Left would have preferred a waif-like Hicks. It's all been about an image forced on us when it comes to Hicks: the sweet, smiling boy next door, not the mercenary.

Jessie Black

Elwood, Vic

IF David Hicks can be charged under US federal law for materially aiding terrorists, why are not thousands of US citizens also charged for aiding, supplying and financing the IRA?

Stan Yeaman

City Beach, WA

IF I was locked in a dog box, in solitary, for five years I would even promise to vote for John Howard to get out.

Kieran Foy

Flaxton, Qld

WHEN he returns home, no doubt David Hicks will be offered millions of dollars from TV networks, magazines and book contracts. Hicks should donate all this money to the Australian families of victims of terrorist attacks in New York, Bali and London.

Michael Burd

Toorak, Vic

NOT an awfully difficult choice: plead guilty and get five years and a few months. Plead not guilty and get 20 years.

Andrew Wyminga

Bicheno, Tas

Not every worker benefits from the Work Choices laws

AS a Liberal-leaning voter, I am not comfortable with aspects of Work Choices. If you are skilled, articulate, have clout and a fair boss, you can negotiate an AWA. If the terms are unacceptable and your skills transferable you can go elsewhere (possibly).

Even in the present favourable jobs market, this does not apply to everyone. If you are of a certain age (despite the push for older people to keep working), have family responsibilities, and/or live in a small rural town, your choices are limited or nonexistent.

This is fact, not fear. That dissatisfaction is only now beginning to filter through is because those most affected have the least clout. John Howard should take heed of this.

Roseanne Schneider

Yeronga, Qld

THE much trumpeted employment growth of 2.39 per cent since the introduction of Work Choices doesn't stack up against the 3.9 per cent growth recorded in the year after the introduction of Labor's unfair dismissal laws in the 1990s. Hard to see John Howard or Joe Hockey claiming this growth was the result of the ALP's legislation, so why would anyone take their spin on their IR laws seriously?

Mr Hockey keeps telling us that the Government is not for turning on its IR laws. Well here's a message for him and his boss -- this voter's not for conning.

James Wood

Wagga Wagga, NSW

DESPITE the scaremongering by unions there have not, as far as I know, been thousands of jobs lost. Wages and conditions have not been drastically reduced. The adjustments that have been made would appear to have been in keeping with the necessary adjustments to keep the economy running and increase overall employment.

The way the unions and the ALP are arguing suggests that no one should ever lose their job and that wages and conditions should only be adjusted upwards. It seems unlikely that the real world works like that and that those opposed to the legislation are more concerned about themselves than the majority of people who will eventually benefit from keeping jobs in a competitive Australia.

K.M. Gunn

Lower Mitcham, SA

THE support for Work Choices by Peter Hendy comes as no surprise (Opinion, 27/3). It was Mr Hendy, as chief of staff to Peter Reith, who prepared the first tranche of IR legislation back in 1996. The legislation was then defeated because John Howard lacked the numbers in the Senate.

The comments from Mr Hendy are typical of individuals who are welded to the Liberal Party, are interested in advancing their own interests and care nothing for employee working conditions. The Coalition's IR reforms are all about handing the employers the tools necessary to advance the cause of big business.

Richard Slater

Berowra Heights, NSW

IN his opinion piece on Work Choices, Peter Hendy used the words union bosses no fewer than 16 times. Was he trying to scare me?

Daryl Poore

Diamond Creek, Vic

The Left's lack of outrage

PETER Tatchell (Cut & Paste, 27/3) has merely scratched the surface of the Left's hypocrisy on human rights, an ingrained inconsistency that dates from the Bolshevik coup d'etat almost a century ago.

Tatchell's main point concerns the Left's lack of outrage over Robert Mugabe's treatment of the Zimbabwean people, but he could have included the Left's similar apathy toward a whole clutch of other African post-colonial regimes, as well as Burma. Tatchell's exposure of the Left's unwillingness to condemn Muslim repression, racism and sexism will be familiar to The Australian's readership because it echoes the outrage of courageous mavericks such as Pamela Bone and Janet Albrechtsen.

What Tatchell does not mention is the Left's ancient unwillingness to criticise communist governments, beginning with the Soviet Union, and including today China, Vietnam, Laos and Cuba. He refers to fascist Spain, but fails to point out that some of Franco's most strident enemies in the West were uncritical worshippers of the infinitely worse Stalin.

The most egregious contemporary example of the Left's silence in the face of denial of human rights is its lack of interest in North Korea, which is simply the world's worst case of totalitarianism.

Bill James

Bayswater, Vic

Europe's 50th birthday

JUDGING by your disparaging and unnecessary swipe at the EU (Editorial, 27/3), it seems that even the harmless clinking of a few champagne glasses in Berlin to celebrate 50 years of like-minded European commerce is enough to stir up paranoia about old enemies and, heaven forbid, threats to US world dominance.

Excuse me, but are US-led coalitions of the willing the only ones allowed? Are US-sponsored armies the only ones permitted to be raised? Are US-sanctioned decisions the only ones allowed to be reached? You say that ''a return to the Treaty of Rome's original principles'' is the way forward for Europe. And what would those principles be? Stick to matters of your town square, messieurs, and don't obstruct the star-spangled stranglehold on global political and military policy.

John Skaro

South Yarra, Vic

WHAT planet is Stuart Reid living on? His piece (Opinion, 27/3) on the EU is typical of European self-delusion. It's not a matter of being a Eurosceptic. It's a matter of objective fact. European populations are shrinking at a rapid rate and many will halve with every generation. Their population rates have gone past the point of no return. In failing to have babies, Europeans have committed suicide.

Whatever goods Europe has delivered, they are only temporary. The diving populations of European nations means that by mid-century most Europeans will be geriatrics and there will be more government handouts than taxes coming in. It won't take young people long to realise that they are paying for their parents' past excesses and exit to the US or Australia. All this makes European socialism unsustainable, and those goods are destined to be withdrawn one way or another. Thus it's not surprising they want to enlarge the EU. Someone has to pay for their largesse.

Celebrate your anniversary Europe -- enjoy it for what little time it will last.

Andrew S. Kulikovsky

Mawson Lakes, SA

Slave trade myths

THE notion that the Jacobins of revolutionary France abolished the transport of slaves in 1794, 13 years before the British (L.M. Salter-Duke, Letters, 27/3), is a left-wing myth.

The convention in Paris on February 4, 1794, declared the universal emancipation of slaves, but did not outlaw the trade. This meant no slaves could be held on French soil, a finding that Lord Mansfield had affirmed was true of Britain 22 years earlier.

The only effect the Jacobins had on the slave trade was the abolition of the bounty France once paid for the carriage of slaves.

However, in the Caribbean colony of Saint-Domingue, the Jacobins' revolutionary example sparked a bloody slave uprising. Hugh Thomas in The Slave Trade observes that this was a godsend for slave owners and transporters elsewhere who could point to the chaos and outrages attendant upon the French actions. They thereby helped stave off British reforms that would have otherwise occurred much sooner.

Keith Windschuttle

Paddington, NSW

Sympathy for drug abusers

THE treatment of AFL players and other sportspeople with drug abuse problems holds up a mirror to the worst of our community responses to the issue. It reflects the sad fact that, in Australia, there is still so much stigma attached to alcohol and drug addiction.

The stories we see reinforce a negative tragic perspective -- disgrace, annihilation, desperation. Yet, there are many people around the world whose addictions have been resolved. These people bear testimony to the fact that the mental and physical obsession that is addiction can be overcome.

Watching the media coverage, it is easy to see why people with an addiction feel they must hide, or deal with it behind closed doors. Anyone wrestling with drug dependence should not have to endure public shaming, punishment, ostracism and harassment. This only exacerbates the problem. What is useful in these situations is support, understanding and mentoring by people who have been through similar experiences. This media circus is neither helpful nor compassionate.

Andrea Travers

The Recovery Foundation

Belgrave Heights, Vic

FIRST BYTE

Iran may charge Brits as spies, according to your headline (26/3). That this would be a breach of the Geneva Convention is beyond dispute. So where are the howls of protest from the Western press? Where are the protests and condemnation from our self-appointed human rights organisations? Their silence condemns them. Hypocrites all.

Nathan Potaznik

Canterbury, Vic

Just a whiff of Greg Combet MP, and the Prime Minister trots out the union bogeyman. But with conflict of self-interest always possible between employer and employee, and the former considerably advantaged, worker solidarity through union membership is an essential counterweight.

Barrie Smillie

Duffy, ACT

The NSW Liberals will surely use the ABD test (anyone but Debnam) when choosing their next leader.

Kel Joaquin-Byrne

Randwick, NSW

Garry Trethewey (First Byte, 27/3) will have to change his lifestyle, sleep during the day and use his computer in the early hours of the morning. He'll connect in seconds then.

J. Barathy

Carrara, Qld

The most appalling euphemism of all: comfort women for sex slaves.

Paul Hunt

Engadine, NSW

Today, Cricket Australia is preparing for a money-making trip to Zimbabwe which will only line the pockets of the Australian cricketers and send a message of comfort to the oppressive regime of Robert Mugabe. Cancelling this tour will instead send a message of protest at the destruction of democracy in Zimbabwe.

Isidore Shifrin

Prahran, Vic

urn:contentItem:4MSJ-6PT0-TX52-F1X9-00000-00Letters to the Editor2007-01-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:50:12ZLexisNexisFEATURESLettersPg. 11

MATP

Letters to the Editor

She displays the arrogance and the insecurity of atheism

MOST TALKED ABOUT

PAMELA BONE

I DO believe our secular humanist brethren are becoming a little rattled, for their attacks on Christians seem to be growing in number and intensity of late. A Canberra fertility clinic claims victimhood at the hands of Catholic hospital owners who refuse it access to facilities to carry out procedures anathema to the Catholic Church (''Catholic hospital shuts out IVF'', 9/1). It would seem that only ''victims'' have rights. And in her opinion piece (''Let's have faith in society and keep God out of it'', 9/1), Pamela Bone positively drools at the prospect of reading more bile-filled books by God-haters such as Richard Dawkins and Christopher Hitchens. She virtually accuses us Christians of child abuse for teaching our children about the God in whom we believe. Pathetically and deceitfully, she paints opponents of cloning for embryonic stem cell research as monsters who care more for the rights of human embryos than for the rights of children with cancer.

We are all endowed with free will, and Bone has every right to reject belief in God. She does not, however, have any right to pontificate superciliously against sincere people who regard such dubious progressive achievements as abortion and euthanasia as sins against God and man. And, in so doing, she displays not only the arrogance but also the insecurity of atheism.

Richard Congram

Carindale, Qld

FIRST we had David Williamson's secular jihad, now we have Pamela Bone's. Is The Australian becoming the official media outlet for Australian atheists?

Bone tries to claim the anti-theists are not on a crusade, but any sensible reading of their writings shows they clearly are. The new militant secularists are clearly undertaking a holy war against religion, and they show every bit as much intolerance and bigotry as any religious person ever has.

Bill Muehlenberg

Heathmont, Vic

PAMELA Bone's argument is contradictory. We can only have faith in society if there is an objective order that explains our duty to each other. Religions are just an acknowledgment that there is a creator of that objective order.

John Smith

Farrer, ACT

I HOPE atheist Pamela Bone realises that most Australian theists support her position that religion must be neither suppressed nor promoted by the state. Religion reaches into the realm of the non-obvious, so there are inevitably many versions. On top of that, religious views are often adhered to with great conviction. Conclusion: it's downright dangerous to human welfare to give any denomination the clout of state authority.

This said, there is no democratic justification to invalidate the vote of an individual citizen or elected politician on the grounds that he or she believes in God. There is nothing intrinsically more legitimate about a preference based on another ideology -- or on nothing at all.

Philip O'Carroll

North Fitzroy, Vic

HEAR, hear, Pamela Bone: God believers do not have exclusive rights to goodness. However, Bone's conclusion that in relation to morals it's better to ''leave God out of it'', is self-defeating from a non-believer's viewpoint. Being a non-believer is a statement that there is no God. To then wonder whether God should or should not be included is irrelevant.

Brenton Jury

Paddington, Qld

HATS off to Pamela Bone for having the guts to stand up for the non-believers who are tired of the politicians who daren't say boo to the fear-laden faithful.

John Morgan

Paddington, NSW

PAMELA Bone makes the surprising statement that Christian evangelism has had a ''long and unimpeded run''. Well, back in the 1950s, Christians were labelled ''wowsers'' and ''Bible bashers'', and in later years Christian principles were rejected by the secular state. It seems to me that society is a much more dangerous place today than it was then, so where is the proof of Pamela's pudding?

Zillah Williams

Latham, ACT

PAMELA Bone, like many atheists, makes the mistake of lumping all religious faiths together in relegating them to the dustbin of history. Clearly, in this age of terrorism, some religious faiths such as Judaism and Christianity are more compatible with contemporary, democratic societies than others.

She appears to argue that modern technological societies no longer need the survival advantages that religion once conferred on the human species, and that now we know better we can move on and find good, human reasons for the decisions we make.

However, she does not acknowledge that the development of democracy, freedom and the rule of law arose in societies which practised the Judeo/Christian faiths. How long these principles will survive without the over-arching moral codes which engendered them is uncertain. Yet, if Bone has her wish, sooner or later humanity will find itself without a place to stand in the moral world, merely destined for Darwinian determinism whereby humans are relegated to the natural struggle for survival.

Jennifer Meister

Ivanhoe, Vic

Building costly firebreaks won't stop the big ones

VICTORIAN Water Minister John Thwaites's proposal to bulldoze hundreds of kilometres of permanent firebreaks around Melbourne's water catchment, in the Otway ranges and along the southern edge of fires now spreading in Gippsland is beyond belief (''Bracks buckles on firebreaks'', 6-7/1).

Has nobody told him that firebreaks don't stop big fires? They didn't stop them in 1982 and 1983. They didn't stop them in Canberra in 2003, when a fire tornado carried flames for kilometres across almost bare, eaten-out pasture. And they didn't stop the current Victorian fires that jumped over bulldozed easements for power lines.

Has nobody told the minister how bushfires behave and what can be done about them, or is he listening to the wrong people? Mr Thwaites must understand that forest fires are uncontrollable when they burn heavy fuel loads in hot windy weather and spew burning embers kilometres ahead. What is required is a network of permanent access roads through forests and national parks, built and maintained to standards that allow personnel to work safely and mount aggressive initial attacks on unplanned fires. These roads are also the only firebreak that is necessary to conduct low-intensity prescribed burns for effective fuel-load management across the landscape to minimise the risk of firestorms.

Mr Thwaites's proposal is hugely expensive and simply won't work. Furthermore, he must recognise that the number of permanent fire fighters in Victoria skilled in forest-fire management is woefully inadequate. His reliance on the goodwill of fire fighters from other states and countries will not stop firestorms happening.

Athol Hodgson

Parkdale, Vic

More to lose than mere face

ROBERT O'Neill (''Good intentions drain into the sand'', Opinion, 9/1) says that ''Bush had better think hard in the coming months'' about how to avoid total defeat in Iraq. Yes, indeed, and so too should the Democrats. As O'Neill points out, there is a lot more to lose in the Iraq war than merely face. Rather than using Iraq as a political point-scoring exercise, the Democrats should work with President Bush to ensure the best possible outcome, for the sake of both the West and the Middle East. If the West loses in Iraq, the ramifications will be felt throughout the world for many years to come.

A. Khat

Ryde, NSW

IT'S madness. George W. Bush is sending more troops to the Iraq war -- meaning more Iraqis killed and maimed, more young soldiers' lives lost and more billions wasted on destruction.

This is the same outfit that launched the biggest bombing campaign since the Vietnam War in a self-proclaimed attempt to ''shock and awe'' the Iraqi people into submission. And we are going along with it. When will we ever learn?

James Wolf

Summer Hill, NSW

Zero demerits for P-platersIN 2005, 30 per cent of drivers killed in Victoria were aged between 18 and 25 years. And yet this age group only represents 14 per cent of Victorian licence holders.

To obtain my licence three months ago, I was shocked to discover that I was required only to meander my way through slow and quiet residential streets for about 20 minutes. How is this a true examination of whether or not a young person has the necessary skills to survive on our roads? No wonder so many young people are involved in road accidents.

If Victorian state MPs were serious about reducing the road toll, they would legislate to make the licence test more rigorous. Why not make it necessary for young drivers to sit three or more 30-minute tests, each in different road traffic conditions, so that an examiner can truly gauge the skill of the driver? Or maybe make it compulsory for young drivers to have a minimum of five driving lessons before sitting for their test?

Legislation that aims to control the way young drivers behave on our roads can only do so much once a dangerously unskilled driver has his or her licence. One measure that would certainly change the attitude of every young driver would be zero demerit points for P-platers in their first year.

Nothing can be done about the fact that P-plate drivers are the most inexperienced drivers on our roads, but at least some things can be done to ensure that the licence test is sufficiently thorough to force young drivers to fully prepare themselves for their Ps.

Struan Jones

Hurstbridge, Vic

I SUGGEST that for one offence a P-plate driver be required to spend another year as such. For two offences, the licence is lost only to be obtained again by retraining under L-plate conditions requiring a specified period before re-testing is allowed.

Peter Williamson

Killara, NSW

Value in heritage spending

HOW heartening to read Ross Fitzgerald's ''in praise of heritage'' and his urgings that children gain an early sensitivity to its many-faceted value (''Hold your hammers, there's gold in them there walls,'' Opinion, 8/1). He also argues that we should see money directed to heritage projects as being well spent because it helps local economies attract tourist dollars.

I never cease to be amazed at how much restoration work was painstakingly carried out across Europe after the devastation of war and now the world flocks there to experience the delights of cities and landscape presented as they were before.

M.A. Tiainen

Holland Park West, Qld

THE good work of the NSW Heritage Office in negotiating a productive future for the Broken Hill former mine manager's residence is unfortunately the exception to the rule and is overshadowed by the damage caused by the heritage elitists who regularly victimise homeowners with threats of dubious heritage listing.

A case in point is the secret heritage hit-list of 1970s mediocre pre-fab brick veneer project homes which the Heritage Office and the Royal Australian Institute of Architects had prepared before it was exposed in the media. The heritage zealots behind this plot should realise that this kind of furtive behaviour prostitutes the whole concept of heritage.

They should also take note of the Productivity Commission's report on the matter which came out with the novel idea that the views and wishes of homeowners should be taken into account before listing is even contemplated.

Peter Sinclair

Killara, NSW

Adams v Marie Antoinette

I WASN'T sure whether to laugh or cry at Phillip Adams's latest offering (''Selfish excuses for doing nothing'', Opinion, 9/1). It's an excellent example of the shallowness that passes for intellectualism to a particular political bent.

In essence, Adams wants us to stop selling both uranium and coal to the subcontinent and China so that the rest of the world will follow our example and do the same.

Assuming that is successful, one is left wondering what around one third of the world's population is supposed to do for the energy they need to bring them into the 21st century?

Marie Antoinette was reputed to have said that the breadless plebs could eat cake, but I think Adams tops this rather well. His implicit response to more than two billion power-starved people would be, ''Let them have solar''.

Andrew Lake

Daw Park, SA

Waugh outclasses Ponting

WHILE I agree absolutely with Simon Wilde (''History puts Ponting's lot in its place'', 8/1) that Steve Waugh's team would beat that of Ricky Ponting, I believe Wilde misses the greatest point of difference between the two teams -- the leader. As a strategist and tactician, Waugh almost ranks alongside Clausewitz and Sun Tzu, as well as being a great leader of men.

Ponting's main claim to the captaincy is that he is a great batsman. His leadership career is littered with tactical blunders, the most costly of which was his decision to bowl at Edgbaston immediately following the injury to his bowling spearhead. A better decision at that crucial point and we would probably have merely retained the Ashes in 2006/07.

John Rayner

Indooroopilly, Qld

FIRST BYTE

letters@theaustralian.com.au

One of the silliest products of the tedious culture wars is the linkage between chardonnay and intellectual elites. The humble chardy is the most extensively planted variety in Australia and has been the popular choice of regional and aspirational suburban Australia for 20 years. The rise and rise of the suburban barista suggests it's also time to let go of the latte association too.

Robert King

Brookfield, Qld

If Shane Warne spent as much time talking to his ex-wife about a reconciliation as he does to the media, he may have a better chance of realising just that. Simone must shake her head in disbelief.

Ray Duncan

Smithfield Heights, Qld

No, Taffy Morgan (Letters, 6-7/1) the Queen of Australia will not be rewarding her Australian cricketers with imperial honours. They ceased to be awarded to Australian citizens from 1992, with the agreement of the then prime minister, all six state premiers and all seven Opposition leaders.

David Smith

Mawson, ACT

I really think that Lleyton Hewitt should team up with Pat Cash. They would make an excellent pair. Both carry on like petulant children and neither displays the Australian sporting ethos.

Karl Hartmann

Cayfield, Qld

While I acknowledge that The West Wing is very cleverly and convincingly acted, I'm defeated as to what on earth it's about other than a bunch of seemingly clever types all talking against each other. Does anyone out there have a clue about what is going on?

W. Scanlon

Clifton Beach, Qld

urn:contentItem:4MMP-V1F0-TX4S-M32H-00000-00FROM THE ASHES2006-12-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:50:12ZLexisNexisAPg. B01FROM THE ASHESThe Canberra Times

IT SEEMED appropriate that a smoke haze shrouded parts of Canberra on Tuesday morning as ACT Coroner Maria Doogan handed down her long-awaited report into the January 2003 bushfires.

The smoke drifting from a contained but still smouldering bushfire near Tumut to the west of Canberra added a dramatic edge to an already highly charged morning. It was a reminder that bushfires would always be a part of life in the ACT but was also eerily reminiscent of the days before the January 18 firestorm when smoke from distant fires was drifting over the city. It had some people wondering if such a disaster could happen again and what had changed in almost four years.

Courtroom No 10 in the Magistrates Court building was packed with lawyers, officials, residents and media on Tuesday as Doogan issued her two-volume, 800-page report.

There were few surprises in the document.

Doogan's main findings, including that the then ACT Emergency Services Bureau had failed to aggressively attack the fires when they ignited or warn the community of the growing fire danger, had been key themes right from the opening address of senior counsel assisting, Lex Lasry, to the inquiry in October 2003.

Former ACT and Commonwealth Ombudsman Ron McLeod had made similar findings in his inquiry into the operational response to the fires issued in August 2003.

The difference on Tuesday was that Doogan found that senior officials within the ESB and even members of the Cabinet knew there was a risk to the city days before the firestorm but did not warn the public. Those findings appeared to give the greatest satisfaction to the residents who were in the courtroom.

Finally, here in black and white, in the most uncompromising language, was confirmation of what they had always believed: that those meant to protect the territory had failed in their duty in the most spectacular way.

As Laurence Buchanan, whose house in Duffy was destroyed in the firestorm, said plainly, "I lost my home because of the gross failure of the Emergency Services Bureau to warn us."

The Government, led by Chief Minister Jon Stanhope, has categorically rejected Doogan's finding that Cabinet knew Canberra was at risk two days before the firestorm. He reiterated that it acted only according to advice from its emergency services personnel, those expert in bushfire management. But the Government has also steadfastly refused to take any action against those senior officers still working in emergency services.

Emergency Services Minister Simon Corbell said the officers did their best in trying circumstances. "I do not believe they are deficient in their duties," he said. "I believe they are very competent and professional officers. They have demonstrated that in their management before and after 2003 and we stand by them."

The Chief Minister told a media conference on Tuesday that on important aspects of the report "The coroner is simply wrong".

It is still chilling to consider the losses from the January 18 firestorm: four dead, 435 injured, 487 homes destroyed, a damage bill of at least $610million.

In a letter to Corbell reporting her conclusions, Doogan said the failure to warn the community despite senior personnel of the ESB having knowledge that the fires would burn into the suburbs was "a factor that exacerbated the property losses and resulted in panic and confusion throughout the affected suburbs on the day of the firestorm".

"Frankly, on the evidence before the inquiry, it is a miracle that no more than four people died," she wrote.

Doogan's final report had taken more than three years to complete.

She had hoped to have it out by the end of 2004 but the inquiry was plagued by stops and starts as witnesses sought legal representation at the last minute, two appeals were made to the Supreme Court, lawyers needed extra time to write submissions and an expert witness suffered a heart attack. When it did come, the report pulled no punches.

Doogan found senior officers of the ESB had been self-deluded and over-optimistic about their chances of stopping the fires, and had failed to issue direct warnings to the community as the fire risk grew and grew.

The coroner did not "question the integrity or honesty of any of the senior officers of the [ESB]" but rather highlighted "poor judgment, insufficient knowledge and experience, and an inadequate response to the fires".

She denied being engaged in the blame game but acknowledged it was "often impossible to learn from mistakes made without finding fault on the part of individuals".

Five of those individuals former ESB executive director Mike Castle, former chief bushfire control officer Peter Lucas-Smith, then ESB operations manager Tony Graham, then ESB planner Rick McRae and Stanhope himself were all heavily criticised in the report. Each was subject to a Section 55 notice, alerting them before the report was published that they had been the subject of adverse comment and giving them an opportunity to respond. Their explanations did little to temper Doogan's criticism.

She found there were 15 causes of the deadly firestorm, mostly sheeted home to the ESB.

The lack of warning, the failure to aggressively attack the three fires when they were ignited by lightning in Namadgi National Park on January 8, the absence of a plan even on January 17 on how to react if the fires did reach the suburbs, the failure to properly use resources from NSW, the failure to inform the Australian Federal Police of the fire risk all contributed to the disaster.

But there were also other factors which contributed to the ferocity of the firestorm: the extreme drought, overgrown fire trails, heavy fuel loads, limited manpower and resources.

The inquiry heard evidence from Lucas-Smith that three requests to the Government for additional funding for the ESB in 2002-03 had been refused and overall ESB funding had been reduced.

And then there was the speed and magnitude of the firestorm. The ESB authorities have always maintained no one predicted anything like that kind of conflagration hitting Canberra on January 18, including a tornado created by the fires with wind speeds of 200km/h.

Doogan did not accept that the severity of the firestorm could not have been foreseen, saying extreme fire events had been recorded in Australia since at least 1851 and modern-day experts had been warning of such a disaster, apparently to no effect.

Nevertheless, even CSIRO bushfire expert Phil Cheney, an expert witness to the inquiry, conceded that on January 18 there were times when the firestorm was moving at 20km an hour, "the fastest documented rate of spread of a forest fire anywhere to my knowledge".

ESB planner Rick McRae told the inquiry that about 1pm on January 18 there were indications the McIntyre's Hut fire had moved about 3km overnight. But the fire then "accelerated quite remarkably" to cover around 12km in the next two hours to hit Weston Creek just after 3pm.

Lucas-Smith said of the firestorm, "I had not experienced anything like that in my over 30 years' experience involved in bushfire fighting".

Then there was the role of the ACT.

The McIntyre's Hut fire, started also by lightning in the Brindabella National Park on January 8, was a major part of the firestorm. It burned for nine days in NSW before hitting Canberra on January 18. Many people were highly critical of the NSW authorities choosing not to directly attack the fire on the first night. But because Doogan is an ACT coroner, she could comment on the fire only once it had crossed the border, and she could make no findings or recommendations in relation to NSW.

She did find that "once the fire crossed the border into the Australian Capital Territory, its cause was the NSW authorities' inability to prevent the fire entering the ACT".

"Once the McIntyre's Hut fire in NSW gathered momentum, crossed the border and joined the fires burning in the ACT, it became inevitable that the resultant firestorm would deliver its fury to both rural and urban areas of the ACT, turning some areas into an inferno that firefighters had no way of controlling," she wrote.

Some remain dissatisfied that NSW's role in the fires has not been properly reviewed, suggesting civil action will eventually reveal more.

Doogan said the issue of warnings was the "most compelling and emotive" of the inquiry.

She was satisfied that on January 16, two days before the firestorm hit the suburbs, "the cabinet generally, including Mr Stanhope, knew a potential disaster was on Canberra's doorstep but did nothing to ensure that the Canberra community was warned promptly and effectively".

Stanhope maintained this week that nothing was said in the cabinet briefing that led him to believe the fires were not under control, that a threat to Canberra was imminent or that warnings should be issued.

That was despite evidence to the inquiry that Weston and Dunlop were noted as suburbs that would be affected if the fires turned on Canberra.

Provision for a state of emergency being declared had also been discussed, based on the possibility of fires affecting the Transgrid line in Namadgi and cutting most of the power supply to Canberra.

Then Emergency Services Minister Bill Wood was also in the cabinet meeting. He went on holidays the next day, January 17. He did not believe the fires would enter the urban areas. "Had the tone of the briefing been different, I would not have sought leave as I did," he said, in a statutory declaration.

Treasurer Ted Quinlan, who would have filled in for Wood as Emergency Services Minister, was also away on January 17, going to the Australian Open tennis championship in Melbourne after attending the cabinet briefing. As a result, Stanhope became acting Emergency Services Minister on January 17. Quinlan said he believed the message from the cabinet briefing was that "relatively serious problem [was] facing the territory", but one comparable to the impact of the December 2001 bushfires, and nothing like the firestorm that arrived two days later.

Wood, despite being the relevant minister for most of the bushfire campaign, was never called to give evidence at the inquiry. Stanhope said he took "political responsibility" for the fires but would not be resigning. He believed Doogan's report was "good" and "very strong" but not accurate when it came to his actions. "I am concerned at the focus on certain individuals, and the suggestion that they have to accept blame. I don't accept blame for myself," he told 666 ABC radio.

In her report, Doogan was also satisfied that, by the evening of January 17, the ESB senior officers Castle, Lucas-Smith, McRae and Graham "were in possession of information confirming what they already believed; namely, the fires posed a serious risk to the edge of Canberra, and the impact was likely to occur within the following 24 hours".

By early morning on January 18, the four men "all recognised the potential for fires to impinge on the urban edge at some time during the afternoon or evening". Yet there was no warning to the community.

The officers had "lulled themselves into a false sense of security" that because they had stopped fires on the urban edge in December 2001, they could do it again. "As a result of this self-delusion, they deliberately withheld information from the community in the belief that they would as they had in 2001 stop the fires in the grasslands, and they did not want to alarm the community," she wrote.

The officials involved told the inquiry there were genuine reasons for their actions their predictions of fire spreading to the urban edge discussed in meetings at the ESB were worst-case scenarios, they expected the most dangerous fire day to be Monday, January 20; there was an expectation the fires could be held in eaten-out grasslands; and they believed a forecast for milder weather on the evening of January 18 would aid the firefighting effort.

While the ESB took measures to warn rural residents on the evening of January 17 about the fires escaping containment lines and threatening property in the Tidbinbilla area, only half on a list of 96 lessees were contacted. Doogan found none of the residents of the Uriarra, Stromlo and Pierces Creek forestry settlements had been warned.

She was also satisfied a media statement issued by the ESB at 9.50pm on January 17 which warned urban residents only of increasing smoke the next day was "inadequate and misleading".

Lucas-Smith told the inquiry that by 7.30am on January 18 he knew in his "heart of hearts" it was inevitable the fires would burn into Canberra's suburbs. A planning meeting at 9.30am had also discussed the potential for the McIntyre's Hut fire to strike an area from Weston Creek to Greenway. ACT Forests manager Hilton Taylor, working in the planning section of the ESB, estimated on the morning of January 18 that the fires could hit the rural-urban interface from Hawker to Weston Creek by 3pm. Operations manager Tony Graham received that information but could not recall why he did not react.

Doogan was satisfied Taylor's prediction was "not acted on, nor was it used as the basis for an urgent warning to the community". The firestorm did hit at 3pm, just 20 minutes after the first emergency warning was broadcast.

Doogan found planner Rick McRae had used a system to trigger community warnings that was "seriously flawed and constitutes a dangerous way to operate in an emergency management environment".

She made 73 recommendations which the Government has pledged to respond to by February. The one that perhaps has it in the tightest bind is that emergency services be taken out of the Department of Justice and Community Safety and returned to being a stand-alone authority, answerable directly to the minister. The move would take out "unnecessary layers of bureaucracy" and reduce the chance of a bureaucrat usually "with no special knowledge or experience in emergency management" being in charge.

At the time of the bushfires, the ESB was part of the department but McLeod later recommended emergency services be run by an independent statutory authority, headed by a chief executive officer. The Government agreed: the authority was created and Peter Dunn was engaged as the commissioner in November, 2003. But in the June budget this year, the Government returned the services to the department, to save more than $2million in administration costs.

Dunn subsequently resigned.

Corbell guaranteed the emergency services would retain operational independence. Three of the four arms of emergency services in the ACT are not convinced. Volunteers in the Rural Fire Service and the State Emergency Service and employees of the Ambulance Service have supported Doogan's call for the return of an independent statutory authority. Only the Fire Brigade says the previous Dunn administration did not prove a success.

As another chapter closes in the bushfire tragedy, Doogan found a comment by Phil Cheney to the inquiry worth repeating in her letter to Simon Corbell .

Cheney said, "If similar weather and fuel conditions were to occur in the ACT, and historical accounts indicate this is possible, then a fire starting under extreme weather 40km north-west of Canberra could burn into the suburbs in two to three hours.

"It is therefore fanciful in the extreme to imagine that any emergency services organisation is going to stop fires and provide the total protection under these conditions".

Corbell says there has been a complete overhaul of emergency services since 2003: extra equipment, additional personnel, funding increased by 40 per cent to more than $60million, fuel-management strategies in place, a cross-border agreement signed with NSW, new communication and weather- monitoring systems installed.

Corbell was confident that if the Tumut fire earlier this month had threatened Canberra a range of mechanisms would have kicked in to alert residents.

"We would have seen a much more coordinated response than we did see in 2003," he said.

Stanhope, meanwhile, did apologise this week to the people of Canberra. "As the head of government I acknowledge that mistakes and errors of judgment were made in the fighting of the fire," he said. "As head of government I apologise for those mistakes and errors of judgment and feel immense sorrow at the consequence."

He believed the territory had learnt the lessons of those mistakes.

Phil Cheney can only hope history does not repeat: "In another 20 years, memories will dull.'

urn:contentItem:4MJC-4CY0-TX52-F24D-00000-00Letters to the Editor2006-12-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:50:12ZLexisNexisFEATURESLettersPg. 13

MATP

Letters to the Editor

It's doubtful whether any trial will get under way soon

MOST TALKED ABOUT

DAVID HICKS

CALLS for David Hicks's immediate return to Australia have been met by the familiar Australian Government response that it is anticipating he will soon be charged under the new US Military Commissions Act (''Ruddock pledges fair trial for Hicks'', 11/12).

Whilst the laying of charges will at least set in place a process by which Hicks will get his day in court, it is doubtful whether any trial will promptly get underway. Given questions over the constitutional validity of the Act, it's most likely there will be a repeat of the cycle of claim and counterclaim over the legitimacy of the process until the Supreme Court gives a ruling sometime in 2008 or 2009.

Between 2002 and July this year the Howard Government relied upon legal advice that the original military commissions established by President GeorgeW. Bush were valid. That advice was wrong and the US Supreme Court said so in July. Presumably, the Government has new legal advice saying that the new Military Commissions Act is valid, but what if that is again wrong? The advice needs to be made public so that it can be subject to full scrutiny lest an Australian government sits on its hands once again while an Australian citizen languishes.

Donald Rothwell

Professor of International Law

Australian National University, ACT

LEIGH Sales (''Why our Gitmo inmate matters'', Opinion, 11/12) omits a key reason why the complex issue of David Hicks does not resonate in middle Australia. Emotions aside, the problem with most arguments about Hicks, on both sides, is that they centre on false assumptions and profound ignorance of the international law applying.

Whether Hicks can or should be tried or not, by anyone, is a completely separate issue from the undoubted legitimacy of his detention as a captured combatant under that part of International Humanitarian Law known as the Laws of Armed Conflict (based on the Geneva and Hague Conventions).

However unfortunate for him, Hicks can continue to be legitimately detained until the relevant war ends or he is released earlier on captured combatant parole (like most Italian prisoners of war from 1943 onwards). Such a parole would involve him promising to take no further action as a belligerent, and this being guaranteed and enforced by some recognised international authority. Any violation or renunciation of the parole would mean renewed detention.

Resolving Hicks's situation really centres on three issues. First, we need to convince the US not to try him under US or international law. This is as much a political and strategic matter as it is a legal one.

Second, since the US is our ally in the same war, under the Third Geneva Convention we could then negotiate with the US as the detaining power, and the International Committee of the Red Cross as the protecting power, to detain Hicks as a captured combatant in Australia. Whether he can or cannot be tried for terrorism offences under Australian law would not affect this.

Third, we could negotiate with the US and ICRC about how any subsequent release on parole would be accepted and enforced. Hicks's Australian lawyers have apparently declared he would accept and abide by such a parole.

Consistent application of the law, not emotion or politics, must govern resolution of this complex issue. But, should the war continue, releasing Hicks on captured combatant parole also offers a political and strategic resolution, as well as a legal one.

Neil James

Executive director

Australia Defence Association

Canberra, ACT

LEIGH Sales says ''Australians, in the main, have never been particularly troubled by'' the the US assertion of its right to detain and try David Hicks under a legal process of its choosing. But nowhere in her article does she try to explain why this might be the case.

Could it be because Hicks was captured fighting for the enemy in Afghanistan in the months following the September 11 terror attacks? Or that Australians have more pressing concerns than the plight of a self-confessed anti-semite and terrorist sympathiser, to say the least? Hicks will get a fair trial one day, but let's not forget that he -- and he alone -- got himself into this situation.

Lidia Tsen

Chatswood, NSW

THE man turned his back on Australia and joined a terrorist organisation that has Australia as one of its targets. I think anybody who joins, supports or finances a terrorist organisation should be declared an outlaw and be deprived of all citizenship rights and protections, and all finances and assets held directly or indirectly be forfeited to the nation.

C. Morgan

Acacia Ridge, Qld

PERHAPS I'm naive, but as David Hicks's alleged offences occurred in Afghanistan, wouldn't it be logical and fair if it could be arranged for him to be tried in Kabul, under Afghani law? Would that satisfy the protagonists both here and in the US?

Peter Bell

Camberwell, Vic

I GUESS that if George W. Bush and John Howard can keep David Hicks in solitary confinement in Guantanamo Bay until he loses the balance of his mind, he will be unfit to stand trial and so it will be unnecessary to prove that he is guity of anything.

B.A. Welsh

Tea Gardens, NSW

Give public schools the freedom to hire and fire

KEVIN Rudd's vow to raise the standard of schooling is music to my ears (''Rudd puts teachers on notice'', 9-10/12). I have long believed that the greatest defect of our commonwealth is that low-income children are forced into low-achieving schools.

But can we believe Rudd? Can Labor defy its own unions? Will Rudd have the stomach to replace weak teachers with strong teachers? We are not talking here about merely sacking the few teachers who abuse children. We are talking about replacing teachers who are not confident in literacy, numeracy or effective classroom performance.

Furthermore, it's a fact of life that good teachers cannot be identified by qualifications alone, nor by any remote-control procedure operated by state education departments.

The only hope of raising teaching standards in poor suburbs is to give those schools the huge advantage that independent schools have long enjoyed -- self-government, which enables them to employ the best teachers they can get to meet their students' needs.

Philip O'Carroll

North Fitzroy, Vic

NSW can easily match Queensland when it comes to dumbing down science classes (''Pop songs are weird science'', 9-10/12). My Year 7 daughter may not be listening to pop lyrics just yet, but she and her friends are kept entertained during science classes with episodes of Futurama, the TV cartoon series by the creator of The Simpsons.

I'm impressed that the school managed to change her attitude towards science from fascination into boredom within the first term. How is this possible? Children are natural scientists -- they love exploring and experimenting. Good schools and a good curriculum channel this natural aptitude and make the natural world a fascinating place. Mediocre schools don't expect much from their students and find it easier to stick them in front of a TV screen to watch cartoons. I wonder how many of our potential organic chemists and medical researchers will wither under this inane teaching environment.

Peter Gibson

Medowie, NSW

IT'S high time a federal government demanded ''quality control'' from all education systems and not just public schools. A federal Labor government would of course see that this quality control is matched by a return to much-needed ''quality funding'' of public education by a federal government, will it not?

Narelle Grant

Dubbo, NSW

WILL the ALP's Baldrick please own up. Whose cunning plan was it for Kevin Rudd to curry favour with swinging voters by getting stuck into public education? I mean, if a bloke wanted to vote for a short-arsed, dorky-voiced, teacher-bashing, God-bothering right-winger, don't you think he'd choose the experienced one we've already got?

Clive Forster

Coromandel Valley, SA

Swan stays inside the tent

SO Wayne Swan remains as Opposition treasury spokesman (''Rudd in push to heal ALP'', 11/12). The same Wayne Swan who said the Government's $600 family benefit payment wasn't real and the same genius who recommended Labor oppose the 2005 budget's tax cuts? Perhaps Kevin Rudd thinks it better that Swan be inside the tent pissing out, than outside the tent pissing in.

Charles Shavitz

Brisbane City, Qld

A REAL opportunity has been missed by new Deputy Labor leader Julia Gillard not being prepared to challenge Deputy Liberal leader and federal Treasurer Peter Costello in a head-to-head contest on economic management issues.

This is most unfortunate, as voters would be greatly assisted by Gillard being really tested in the treasury portfolio responsibility, rather than industrial relations where the Government has for some time been polling poorly and the ACTU has undertaken most of the public campaigning against the Work Choices laws.

The next federal election will be largely determined by voters with large mortgages in marginal seats. Whilst Work Choices will attract some interest, the key issues will still be interest rates and economic management.

Peter Maskell

Carrum Downs, Vic

Let foresters, cattle return

THE Victorian high country bushfires of 2003 and now 2006 can be seen as the logical outcome of four decades of anti-forestry activism (''Fires spreading, fears of worse to come'', 11/12). By locking out the foresters and mountain cattlemen from much of our high country, successive governments have excluded those who have the skills to best care for this country. The ill-equipped National Parks Service does not have the knowledge nor the financial resources to properly maintain these areas. The end result of this community neglect is devastating and all-consuming bushfires that essentially wipe these areas clean of vegetation.

Given the season, it's akin to the conservation lobby making large purchases on the community credit card and not paying off the monthly interest (undergrowth and fuel). The result is an explosive burgeoning of debt for which the debt collectors (fire) will inevitably demand payment. The cost is born in particular by the communities in these areas and the fire fighters who give up their time to fight them. A more sustainable policy would be to invite the foresters and cattlemen back into these areas so that they can be better cared for.

Evan Evans

Lindisfarne, Tas

I'M at a complete loss to understand why the Australian authorities have not asked Canada for help in fighting the forest fires. In Canada, we have thousands of trained, experienced and skilled forest-fire fighters. Permit me to remind Australians that it's winter here. We are hip-deep in snow. So these folks, male and female, are available.

It's important to understand that there are effective techniques, developed over decades, for fighting forest fires. Our professionals know these techniques.

C. Alexander Brown

Ottawa, Canada

Not fair to full-time parents

OFFERING tax deductions for childcare is a ludicrous idea. People who choose to work and use childcare already enjoy a higher disposable income by doing so, compared to those who stay home and care for their children themselves. There is no justification for a tax cut on top of this. In fact, such a concession would actively discriminate against those parents who forgo income to stay home and tend to their children.

Cameron Martin

Mayfield, NSW

TAX breaks for childcare: the concession we have to have.

Kim Hillier

Cooktown, Qld

Iran's provocation to Jews

WHILE the Middle East rests on a knife's edge, the Iranian Government has sought to further destabilise the situation by hosting a Holocaust conference this week (''Holocaust denier in 'farcical' summit'', 11/12).

This conference has no serious research purpose but, rather, seeks to offend Israel, Jews worldwide and all civilised, decent people by mocking a tragedy that still lives on in the memories of survivors.

Iran's President Ahmadinejad has ensured the conference's outcome by prejudging the Holocaust as ''a myth'' on various occasions in the past. His agenda is further exposed by the failure to include one credible historian on the list of invited participants; instead, it boasts discredited Holocaust-deniers such as Australian Frederick Toben.

At a time when international tensions are already running high about escalating problems in the Middle East, including Iran's efforts to obtain nuclear weaponry, this conference can only be seen as an another act of provocation and brinksmanship. That it's so calculatedly insulting to the memory of the millions cruelly murdered in the Holocaust inflames matters even more.

Geoffrey Zygier

Executive director

Executive Council of Australian Jewry

South Caulfield, Vic

Dictatorial double standard

GOOD riddance to another butcher -- General Augusto Pinochet in Chile. Yet the US, which found it convenient to go to war against another dictator, Saddam Hussein, ostensibly to install democracy in Iraq, supported this monster who led a coup in 1973 against the democratically elected government of Salvador Allende.

Jim McDonald

South Caulfield, Vic

FIRST BYTE

letters@theaustralian.com.au

If anyone thinks the tourists can come back to level/win this Ashes series, I suggest history is against them. England has not secured consecutive victories away from home since 1805 and 1815 -- at Trafalgar and Waterloo respectively.

David Price

Camberwell, Vic

After witnessing the V8 Supercar race at Phillip Island on Sunday to decide the chamionship, it would appear that Ned and Dan weren't the only Kelly boys to get away with highway robbery.

Mal Cronk

Bracken Ridge, Qld

A more significant benefit than that suggested by Doug Osmond (First Byte, 8/12) would be for technology to provide a means by which the thousands of trolleys which litter our streets could automatically find their way back home.

David Durrant

Perth, WA

So Amanda Vanstone has approved the deportation of a 33-year-old Swedish-born resident who has lived here since he was 4weeks old (''Mum attacks Vanstone'', 9-10/12). Gives a whole new meaning to ''faulty, returned under warranty'', doesn't it?

Barbara Harris

Dianella, WA

Does Arthur Sinodinos know something we don't with his resignation after 11 years as John Howard's chief of staff?

Robert Pallister

Punchbowl, NSW

As the TV stations serve up their Christmas collection of repeats, perhaps The Australian might follow suit? Let's begin with a re-run of old pre-invasion letters from the letter writers who today claim with conviction that they always knew Iraq had no WMDs. Maybe First Byte could be renamed Hind Syte temporarily?

M. Cornell

Crows Nest, NSW

urn:contentItem:49MB-YGT0-01S8-G24P-00000-00<published>1990-03-24T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:50:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>DIVORCE WARS</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>DAVIS I</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">DIVORCE WARS Ivor Davis in Hollywood finds high-profile divorces getting bloodier and more expensive for those caught in the middle. THE Cold War may be over as peace breaks out all over the globe _ except in Hollywood where the celebrity Divorce Wars continue to rage like a forest fire. Last year there was the battle between Sondro Locke and her superstar lover Clint Eastwood _ and another battle between LA Law's handsome Harry Hamlin and his disenchanted spouse actress Laura Johnson. Now the latest celebrity free-for-all involves the ubiquitous and very rich Donald Trump, and the lady he dumped _ his wife of 13 years, the mother of his three children, Czech born ex-model Ivana. And if one thinks that that bitter-sweet hit movie The War of the Roses, which chronicled the savagery between Michael Douglas and Kathleen Turner as the feuding, fighting Roses in Danny DeVito's hit movie was an exaggeration, one should think again. Life is far worse in reality, say most lawyers who have to separate the warring couples. Author Warren Adler, the man who chanced upon the idea for his bestselling book after meeting a shellshocked, newly-divorced businessman at a Washington cocktail party, noted: ""Since the movie came out I have been bombarded with stories of couple whose savagery and bitterness exceeded even what happened to the Roses." Attorney Gloria Allred, who has handled some of Hollywood's biggest divorce, added: ""Recently, I got involved in a custody dispute over a Rolls-Royce . . . the husband returned the car with all the parts taken out and laid them out one by one on her front lawn."</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>Meanwhile, the wars rage unabated _ with millions at stake. Donald and Ivana are providing the latest grist for ravenous readers. It seems that the blonde Ivana signed a pre-nuptial agreement before they wed, and then updated it on December 24, 1987. In it the billionaire indicated he was willing to give her $25 million of his $1.7 billion fortune, plus the family's 45-room mansion in Greenwich, Connecticut, plus $350,000 a year for herself and $100,000 for each of the three children until they are 21. Ivana is being offered a free month at the family's Palm Beach mansion, and if she promises to leave the couple's Trump Tower apartment in New York, he will sweeten the deal with another $4 million. She _ through her bevy of high-priced lawyers _ contends the agreement isn't worth the paper it is written on. In fact, they say, the rules of the marital game have changed because Ivana was responsible for increasing her husband's fortune. The Trump Split is wilder than anything Dynasty or Dallas dreamed up. The twists come fast and furious: Donald has a mistress who is pregnant, the couple may kiss and make up, Ivana is a gold-digger, he is the villain, why, he even made off with some of her jewels. It's the juiciest divorce scandal to come along _ well, since the last one. Not long ago beautiful former Charlie's Angel Jaclyn Smith went to war with her British film-maker husband Tony Richmond. Richmond sought custody of the two children aged seven and three _ as well as support from his wealthy 43-year-old estranged wife. She claimed he was having an affair with a make-up artist. American talk-show host Johnny Carson's right-hand man Ed McMahon is embroiled in a particularly nasty fight with his ex-model wife Victoria. He is claiming she has been sharing her affections with a local cop _ as well as her tennis coach. And in Beverly Hills, LA Law's Harry Hamlin is feuding with his wife over his friendship with sexy actress Nicollette Sheridan. Not long ago, Barbra Streisand's former lover Elliott Gould filed to divorce his 37-year-old wife Jennifer Bogart. Their combat has been particularly brutal: they divorced each other after marrying in 1973 _ a union that lasted less than a year. They remarried three years later, had two children and are now apart. Other combatants going their separate ways include Chips TV star Erik Estrada who has dumped his wife of three years, Peggy Rowe; British heavy metal rocker Ozzy Osbourne who has been barred from contacting his wife Sharon after police charged him with threatening to kill her; and top singer John Cougar Mellencamp, 37, whose wife Vicky wants to end their eight-year marriage. Then there's Bruce Springsteen, who broke up with his actress wife. Tom Cruise and wife Mimi Rogers have split _ and so far, it seems to be amicable _ if there's such a thing. But with Cruise commanding $6 million a film, and the hottest property in Hollywood, there could be disputes when the property is divided. In many cases, couples announce there is no animosity _ but it doesn't take long for the accusations to turn vicious. In the end, no one really wins. The casualties are high, families are left emotionally shattered and the combatants spend millions of dollars to seek an uneasy peace. Last year Oscar-winning actor William Hurt and former dancer Sandra Jennings, the mother of his young son, laid their private lives on the line in a courtroom brawl. But unlike some of the more star-studded celebrity squabbles, Hurt and Jennings were not officially married _ although today couples need not be legally wed for war to flare up. Michelle Triola Marvin sued the late star Lee Marvin in what was the first ""palimony" case. Michelle, now married to actor Dick Van Dyke, won, but her award was merely a token amount. Then there was the case of Clint Eastwood and Sondra Locke, who are still locked in a no-win conflagration after more than a decade together. Eastwood has been through the battlefield before, following his divorce from his long-time wife Maggie. The settlement ran in excess of $25 million _ but Clint thought it was worth it so he could be with Locke, his ""great love". The accusations have calmed in one of the biggest cases involving Steven Spielberg and his beautiful actress wife Amy Irving, who have gone their separate ways. Reports are that Amy emerged with $100 million and is reportedly pregnant to her latest boyfriend, while Spielberg's companion Kate Capshaw _ star of his second Indiana Jones movie _ is expecting the director's child. The settlement didn't break Spielberg, who is worth at least $250 million. But unlike other savage legal battles, the director of ET kept the dispute private behind closed doors. And currently it's all quiet on the western front with Oscar winner Jane Fonda and politician husband Tom Hayden, who are still trying to sort out their financial affairs on the road to divorce. The divorce probably will be swift, but the settlement could take years and the Fonda-Hayden fortune _ reckoned to be around $200 million _ is in the big league. Yet despite the accusations and charges, celebrity divorcees seldom appear in court, even though the law in California says that when a couple splits, their accumulated estate should be split 50-50. Many skirmishes are fought on the sidelines, and can get quite hot and heavy. The Mike Tyson-Robin Givens split was such a case. Theirs was a brutal, no-punches-pulled brawl that got bloodier than some of Mike's championship bouts. It was played out mostly in the newspapers and on TV. Givens claimed she wasn't after the champion's money _ then a month later her lawyer Raoul Felder filed a $125 million libel suit against the champion for lambasting her and her mother in print. A few years ago when talk-show host Johnny Carson's third wife Joanna sued her husband, she asked for $220,000 in support . . . that wasn't $220,000 a year, it was $220,000 a month. The request included such essential expenses as $37,000 worth of jewels 12 times a year. When Joan Collins finally dumped her Swedish manager husband Peter Holm, he tried to grab a chunk of the Dynasty star's millions by demanding thousands in monthly alimony so he could live in the style to which he had become accustomed while married to TV's Alexis Carrington. That one went to court and Holm settled for considerably less. When Sly Stallone's long-suffering wife Sasha, who pre-Rocky had supported him when he was out of work, divorced him, she was understandably anxious to get enough to support herself and her two sons. She ended up with a relatively modest $25 million. Stallone's statuesque second wife Brigitte Nielsen then dumped him, and tried to make off with half of his fortune. She finally settled for a few million.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>PIC OF HEAD SHOT OF HAMLIN, SMITH, EASTWOOD, LOCKE AND</p></caption></nitf:media></graphic></nitf:body.end></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier
