urn:contentItem:4MH9-6YY0-TX52-F1XS-00000-00LETTERS TO THE EDITOR2006-12-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:50:12ZLexisNexisFEATURESLettersPg. 11

MATP

LETTERS TO THE EDITOR

Why does a small Pacific nation need an army, anyway?

MOST TALKED ABOUT

FIJI'S FOURTH COUP

AFTER four coups in nearly 20 years, you have to wonder if Fiji really needs a military (''Military chief in control of Fiji'', 6/12).

While very intimidating to an unarmed public and a disarmed police force, Fiji's soldiers would not offer much resistance to an invasion from a proper army. When civil government returns to Fiji, as it must, perhaps it should look at following Costa Rica's lead and disbanding the lot.

John Rice

Largs Bay, SA

YOUR reporter in Suva describes people wearing a blue ribbon to symbolise their backing for the deposed prime minister, Laisenia Qarase, following the latest coup in Fiji (''Qarase resigned to hopeless situation'', 6/12). Most people who are wearing the ribbon support parliamentary rule and democracy, rather than Mr Qarase.

The Blue Ribbon campaign was initiated after the 2000 coup, led by George Speight, when Mr Qarase served as interim prime minister in an unelected government. Women's organisations involved in the campaign have been at the forefront of criticising Mr Qarase's just-ousted government over corruption highlighted in the Agriculture Department scandal; Qarase's failed attempt to include amnesty clauses in the Reconciliation Tolerance and Unity Bill; his opportunistic electoral alliance with Fijian nationalists, some of whom have escaped any punishment for their role in the events of May 2000.

The revival of the blue ribbon -- the colour of Fiji's flag -- symbolises support for democratic rights, not for one or other politician. The tragedy of Fiji is that civil society groups in the Pacific need year-round support from Australia for their work to promote better governance -- instead, we wait until a crisis erupts and send troops and warships to sit off the coast in futile impotence.

Peter Burnett

Fitzroy, Vic

COMMODORE Bainimarama stages Fiji's fourth coup, basically because he was dissatisfied over the leniency with which the third coup plotters were being treated. And our Prime Minister pooh-poohs the very suggestion we should intervene militarily. Heavens above, as if Australia is the sort of country that goes around invading other countries! It's obviously the season for irony.

John O'Hara

Mount Waverley, Vic

THE military in Fiji launched a coup supposedly because the people who pulled the last coup may be pardoned. What sort of sense does that make?

It's only the manipulation of a democratically elected parliament by a tinpot wannabe dictator who can't get his own way. It's sad for the people of Fiji.

Greg Stubbs

Mooroobool, Qld

WITH the unrest in Fiji, East Timor, West Papua, Solomon Islands and Tonga, and in other regional nations presumably to come, Australia is going to become more involved, whether we want to or not, and our focus will inexorably move to this area. I trust our Government implicitly in the way it spends our taxes, but I'm struggling to work out how large, multi-million dollar Abrams battle tanks fit into this scheme of things.

Ian Pollock

Maleny, Qld

TWO questions regarding Fiji's latest coup and other Pacific island troubles.

First, why does Fiji have an army as well as a police force? There is no credible external threat to Fiji's territory or sovereignty and the financial burden of maintaining an army is surely better spent on more useful things. I suppose an argument is made that the army pays its own way by being hired out on various UN peace-keeping missions from time to time. There's an irony.

Second, what is it about Samoa that keeps it out of the headlines? The answer is that it's a nation of clever and considerate people who developed a system of governance that, for more than a century, has balanced Western structure and Polynesian culture. In his A Footnote to History: Eight Years of Trouble in Samoa, Robert Louis Stevenson chronicled the events and machinations by which Samoans dealt with not one, but three competing colonial powers, and their own internal divisions leading to the creation of a peaceful, law-abiding society.

The fundamental structures are still in place and perhaps explain why Samoa was the first Pacific island colony to achieve independence (in 1962), and why Samoans still live in peace with each other and their neighbours. Perhaps the Fijians should look to their Polynesian neighbours for guidance in these dark hours.

Mark Reid

Doncaster, Vic

JOHN Howard recently said that it was in Australia's interests to join the coalition of the willing in the invasion of Iraq, a distant country which had never posed a threat to us. He said on Tuesday it was not in our interests to become involved militarily in assisting Fiji, a friendly neighbour. He never mentioned the interests of the Iraqis or the Fijians? He disgraces us all.

D. Law

West Hobart, Tas

I WILL tell you the reason John Howard will not send Australian troops to Fiji: we have none left.

Bill Grieve

Enoggera, Qld

Flintoff can't handle pressure of the captaincy

I READ Andrew Ramsey's article (''Deficient line-up must be changed'', 6/12) suggesting changes that must be made to England's Test team if we are to have any chance of retaining the Ashes. Of course everyone, apart from the coach, Duncan Fletcher, knew this, even before the first Test in Brisbane, in the same way that we should have chosen the best ''stumper'' in England, Chris Read, rather than Fletcher's favourite, Geraint Jones.

But I will go further and pray that Michael Vaughan will be fit enough to play and relieve Andrew Flintoff of the pressure of the captaincy. Finally, I would invite Fletcher, who must have been behind England's craven display on Tuesday morning in Adelaide, to catch the next plane back to England. This would then make way for Geoffrey Boycott, if he could be persuaded to accept the challenge of winning the next three Tests by giving the team the benefit of his great experience.

As an aside, speaking as an umpire for the past 20 seasons, I would have cracked down on Shane Warne's negative bowling. In the Central Yorkshire Cricket League, a ball pitching 15cm outside leg stump is a wide.

Norman Hazell

Coldstream, Vic

(but normally Wakefield, West Yorkshire)

ENGLAND have repeated the mistakes of the West Indies (Brian Lara) and India (Sachin Tendulkar) by appointing their best player to the captaincy, regardless of their suitability for the role. Andrew Flintoff is clearly bereft of both ideas and inspiration, and is batting like a rabbit caught in the glare of the headlights.

John Christie

Oatley, NSW

RIGHT now I'd say the odds of Kevin and Julia regaining the treasury benches would be a shade better than those of Freddie&Co retaining that mystical little urn.

Max Vallis

Wembley, WA

AFTER Tuesday's performance, it's time for Amanda Vanstone to do what she does so well: terminate the England team's visas and send the players home. It is the only humane thing to do.

Anthony Alexander

North Sydney, NSW

WILL Her Majesty be as quick to congratulate and bestow honours on our Test team as she was when England won the Ashes last year? I doubt it, but then there is always our cricket tragic PM to come to the party, isn't there?

Mike Yalden

Kiama, NSW

I WILL never understand why republicans would want to cut ties with England. The boundless kindness shown through her sportsmen towards us in this colony is legendary. They always find a method of keeping up our spirits, boosting our egos and giving us all a jolly good chuckle.

Steve Atkins

Berowra Heights, NSW

Respect goes both ways

IT comes as no surprise that several boys from an Islamic school desecrated the Bible and are responsible for abuse of teachers, especially non-Muslims (''Muslim boys urinated on Bible'', 6/12). I spent three years working at an Islamic college and witnessed many cases of abuse both verbal and physical from students towards, in particular, non-Muslim female teachers.

Respect goes both ways, and while these schools receive government funding they should be more open to scrutiny.

Andrew Bullen

Bull Creek, WA

THE principal of the East Preston Islamic College doesn't believe the schoolboys who urinated and spat on a Bible before setting it alight realised the significance of their acts.

Really? Such acts of gross profanity were not conscious, deliberate defilement? Next thing, someone will suggest it was all a conspiracy on the part of infidels who ''set up'' the little darlings to discredit Islam. After all, one hardly expects anyone to bring a Bible on a Muslim school camping excursion, does one? And to think that we, the taxpayers, donate almost $4million a year to the school involved. Indeed, we really are quite mad.

Richard Congram

Carindale, Qld

WAS the adolescent stupidity of a couple of Muslim kids who urinated on a Bible really worthy of a front-page story with picture? As a school teacher, I see a lot of kids do dumb things every day -- none of which need to be on the front page of a national newspaper. In the context of recent race riots in Sydney and a genuine tension in the Muslim community, it's surely irresponsible of your newspaper to elevate such minor misdeeds to this level.

Brett Coelho

South Yarra, Vic

PISSING on a Bible is front-page news now? What a sad little country we are.

Chris Bond

West Perth, WA

Gillard: substance and style

LEAVE Julia Gillard alone. No comments on her hair or clothing, they're irrelevant. She's a smart woman and her marital status and personal life illustrate the modern women in politics who are great role models for the younger generation. Substance and style go hand in hand.

Pam Papadopoulos

Prahran, Vic

Where's the evidence?

I SHOULD be most grateful if Barry Cohen (''Let a sane leader get on with his job'', Opinion, 4/12) would produce the authoritative evidence to support his assertion that Dr H.V. Evatt was ''declared clinically insane''.

In all the years that I had the privilege to work for and be associated with Dr Evatt and the ALP, I never heard the expression ''a chip off the old Doc'', nor the incident in a Double Bay restaurant to which Cohen refers.

Cyril Wyndham

Charlestown, NSW

The system is not working

AS the drought continues, forests in our water catchments are parched. Fires are burning uncontrolled on both sides of the Great Dividing Range, some perilously close to the source of Melbourne's dwindling water supply. The Murray-Darling Basin Commission has confirmed from previous research that a major high-intensity fire decreases the water harvested from eucalyptus water catchments by almost half. Water flows do not return to normal for about 100 years.

Flows into the Murray and Snowy rivers are now starting to show the effect of the huge 2003 bushfires. Those fires were the result of inadequate fire suppression and environmental neglect that prevented sensible fuel management. Both those vital services were historically provided by foresters, the timber industry, hydro-electricity workers, graziers and, before them, indigenous people. Now, under a lock-up policy, there are very few people taking care of the catchments in our beautiful high country.

Victoria's forest-fire management system failed, not only in the 2003 bushfires, but also in 2005, when a 20ha prescribed fire was botched in Wilsons Promontory park, and again in January this year when fires devastated national parks and private property in the Grampians and Brisbane Ranges.

The Bracks Government has consistently manipulated due processes to avoid proper scrutiny of its policies and actions and acknowledge the bleeding obvious -- the system is not working.

The Stretton Group was formed to bring the burning truth of fire, fuel and management of public land to public attention through greater transparency of the public sector processes involved, no matter how uncomfortable this truth may be. If we want the right to live in this land, we must respect its ecology and the place of fire in it.

Stewart McArthur (Convenor)

Bill Middleton

Athol Hodgson

Dr Peter Attiwill

Simon Paton

David Packham

Colonialism does not work

GEORGEW. Bush is in denial over the disaster in Iraq. UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan has described the conflict as worse than civil war. Hardline US envoy to the UN John Bolton has been forced to quit because the new Democrat-controlled will not renew his tenure (''Bolton jumps before the big shove'', 6/12). Is it any wonder that the Middle East is in crisis? Surely, the entire world must now see that the failed policies of the US and its supporters are the reason. Imposing your will upon another people will never bring about the change you desire. Colonialism does not work, Iraq being the latest example. Israel has also failed in its sad attempt to subjugate the Palestinians. Peace will only ever come about with justice.

Moammar Mashni

Hawthorn, Vic

FIRST BYTE

If only Barry Jones was available for Tintin's front bench. He'd make an excellent Captain Haddock.

Peter Corcoran

Hackett, ACT

Kevin Gale (First Byte, 6/12) reckons it's OK for a prime minister to come from Queensland now because six have come from Victoria and five from NSW since the last Queenslander 61 years ago. But you're talking about a state that very nearly gave us a PM called Joh, Kev! One bloody awful fright is enough.

JohnR. Wilson

Daisy Dell, Tas

There may be one more task for Kim Beazley. What odds governor-general?

Chris Mangan

Bracken Ridge, Qld

In Britain, the Barmy Army is just a bunch of travelling cricket fans. In Fiji, it's now running the country.

Philip Machanick

Taringa, Qld

Well, Stephen Fox (First Byte, 6/12), so Fiji is off your holiday list. There's a lot of Australia you should consider first, including Tasmania, and New Zealand is just across the ditch. The Tropics, deserts, endless coastlines, forests and islands, all highly recommended. Fiji will wait.

David Moncrieff

Ngunnawal, ACT

Barbara Harris (First Byte, 6/12) thinks marriage is too high a price to pay for sex. But the price of shacking up and one-night stands -- in terms of the overall cost to the community of unstable families, disease, etc -- is far greater.

Roslyn Phillips

Tea Tree Gully, SA

Qantas announces a major profit upgrade. Good news for its shareholders but what about its long-suffering surcharge-paying customers?

David Crommelin

North Strathfield, NSW

urn:contentItem:4P84-VCK0-TXN5-R343-00000-00On the hop1998-10-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:50:12ZLexisNexisSUNDAY LIFEPg. 31On the hopTravelGary Walsh

A stopover on the way to Europe can be both enriching and relaxing. Gary Walsh considers some of the options.

So you're ready to head for Europe, and the thought of a day or so enclosed in a metal tube 10 kilometres above terra firma doesn't really appeal. You're in stopover mode. The tyranny of distance is something Australian travellers are well accustomed to - the stopover might have been invented with us in mind. A night or two in a pleasant hotel, some much-needed sleep, a little sightseeing and a head start in dealing with jetlag are all welcome. But where should you stop, and why? Here's a brief guide to the main stopover spots.

Bangkok

The seething Thai capital can be confronting even for experienced travellers. Unlike Singapore, where the impact of Asia is less than dramatic, Bangkok assaults the visitor with sights, sounds and smells, so that sensory overload is a real possibility. Take a deep breath and wade into the city's sweaty embrace - here, an immersion course is the only way to learn.

For: Cultural richness and some splendid sights. The Grand Palace is a collection of gilded, bejewelled temples and pavilions of extraordinary beauty, and there are other fine buildings around the city, such as the Jim Thompson House and the Vimanmek teak palace. The wide, languid Chao Phraya River splits the city in two, and should be enjoyed for the relative tranquillity it provides - you can catch a local ferry, a tourist boat or a roaring V8 longtail boat to see the river, the offshoot canals and the life

alongside them. The devaluation of the baht means that Bangkok is a cheap place to visit, and the shopping is excellent. Thai silk and clothes are the best value.

Against: Bangkok's dreadful traffic. If your airline's timing is bad, you can spend a ridiculously large proportion of your stopover on the road between Don Muang Airport and the city, which is why the airport hotels are almost always full. Expect the airport-city drive to take anything from 30 minutes to four hours, depending on the time of day/traffic conditions/weather and a range of imponderables. The road chaos also makes getting around town something of a trial, and Bangkok is very polluted. The honky tonk nightlife of girlie bars and massage parlours is, for some, a big attraction. For those horrified by the exploitation, avoiding the spectacle is simple, as the tourist sex trade is concentrated in three areas - Patpong, Nana Plaza and Soi Cowboy.

Kuala Lumpur

The Mahathir-Anwar battle - troops in the streets, riots, demonstrations, a general air of tension - isn't likely to enhance KL's reputation as a stopover city. And Kuala Lumpur struggles to come up with attractions at any time, so you can treat the city simply as a refreshment stop. There are some excellent hotels - the Regent, in particular, is among the world's finest - so you could spend a day or so in pleasant R&R by the pool, with occasional shopping forays and perhaps a brief city tour.

For: If you're into these things, you can check out the Petronas Towers: the rather phallic-looking twin skyscrapers are the world's tallest buildings. Although this is Malaysia, the Chinatown section of KL is the most interesting bit of town. At night, markets selling everything from cheap T-shirts to knock-off designer goods are set up along the streets of Chinatown. There is also good eating around here. KL has some splendid colonial architecture (note in particular the railway station), a good museum and a number of interesting Islamic buildings, including the central mosque.

Against: Try political instability for starters. The new airport is a long way from town, and decent public transport connections are a bit iffy. Traffic can be chaotic, although not on the Bangkok scale, and pollution high, especially if there is a repeat of the Indonesian forest fire fiasco. KL is light on must-see attractions. Consider making your stopover in Penang or another of Malaysia's islands instead, although it will mean tacking on a couple of domestic flights. If you're flying with Malaysia Airlines, inquire about stopover deals - free sidetrips are frequently offered, air fares included.

Singapore

It used to market itself as Instant Asia, which was a bit inaccurate as Singapore is more like Asia As Theme Park. There's an air of unreality about it when compared with Bangkok or Hong Kong, where life is lived more actively and traditionally on the streets. For a taste of what used to be, go to Chinatown in the early morning, when the food markets are in full swing, and the shophouses are busy with local customers. Get your name written in Chinese by a calligrapher or buy some paper offerings (ricepaper replicas of cars, videos, houses, even Bank of Hell traveller's cheques, all designed to be cremated with a deceased person to give them plenty of wherewithal in the afterlife).

For: It's clean, efficient and easy to manage, which makes it an unthreatening place for a day or two. Just don't expect to fall in love with the place. Chinatown, Little India (with its south Indian restaurants and temples) and Arab Street have real character. Sentosa Island is the nearest thing Singapore has to a resort. You can swim, play golf, explore the fortress war museum and the butterfly park, and feel at least a little divorced from the mobile phones, the traffic and the bustle of the city centre. Singapore Zoo is an outstanding open-range wildlife park, with a new night safari to enjoy, and Jurong Bird Park is another place to see the natural world in this unnatural city state.

Against: How can one be polite about this? Singapore can be pretty dull - for an Asian city it can seem strikingly un-Asian and sterile, although the government is trying to bring back some of the colour drained away by zealous redevelopment and sanitisation of raffish places like old Bugis Street. The very things that make it attractive to many - such as the neatness and orderliness - make it anathema to true Asiaphiles. You can't chew gum, spit or jaywalk for fear of substantial fines, which is probably no great loss. The strength of the Singapore dollar, which has been largely untouched by the Asian financial implosion, means shopping generally is poor value. You might consider making your Singapore stopover on Bintan Island - which is in Indonesia. It's just a 45-minute boat ride from Singapore, has fine beaches and resorts, and you have the lowly rupiah to deal with instead of the powerful Singapore dollar.

Hong Kong

Tourist numbers are down since the China handover, inexplicably, but Hong Kong remains a fine travel experience. The spectacle of the city rivals Sydney - a beautiful, busy harbour beneath the ramparts of Victoria Peak and the towers of the financial district. You realise quickly what a vertical city Hong Kong is. Like Manhattan, it heaves itself skywards, but there is much to discover at ground level.

For: Delve into some of the distinctive districts of Hong Kong Island (the HK Tourism Association produces excellent walking tour guides), such as Central and Western, where you'll still find traditional herbalists and snake shops amid the tower blocks. In parts, the streets are little more than stepladders, and the buildings keep the city below in constant shadow. Visit some of the city's Chinese temples and seek out the colonial vestiges of British rule. In reality, a year since the Brits departed, there have been few overt changes. Don't miss a ride on the world's best value public transport system (with the exception of the free Staten Island Ferry in New York), the Star Ferry across Hong Kong harbour. For a few cents you'll get a close-up view of the action on the water, and spectacular photos of Hong Kong Island to boot.

Against: Of the Asian alternatives, Hong Kong is the costliest city. Forget about trying to pick up duty free bargains when the HK dollar is pegged to the US currency, although there's still good value in electrical goods and made-to-measure clothing if you know where to head. And as the central city has the highest population density in the world, this is not the place for claustrophobics. The take-it-or-leave it attitude of Hong Kong's people can also be difficult to cope with - everyone from shopkeepers to taxi drivers will treat you with little respect, and forget about trying to win a bargaining battle with a trader.

Africa

Yes, it's possible to have a stopover in Africa on the way to Europe with South African Airways or Qantas/British Airways. For Africa, read Johannesburg and beyond. Few would want to spend more than a night in South Africa's biggest, baddest city, although a Soweto tour is fascinating. But just a few hours' drive (or a short flight) from Johannesburg is Kruger National Park, one of Africa's prime game-viewing destinations. There's also Sun City, for a kitschy, Las Vegas-style break, and a couple of hours away by aircraft, the spectacle of Victoria Falls.

For: It's quite simply the most intriguing of all the choices if you are prepared to wander a little way afield. The natural attractions are astonishing: Victoria Falls, which can be one of life's great experiences, and the sight of African animals in the wild. You don't need to stay at a luxury game lodge or join a 4WD tour to see Kruger park, much of which is accessible by conventional vehicle. Culturally, southern Africa is a fascinating, and sometimes confronting place, with Afrikaaner and English heritage bumping up against a variety of indigenous African societies. If you choose to stay in Jo'burg, don't miss Soweto, which may make you weep at the injustice of apartheid, but will also cause you to admire the resilience and achievements of its people. Tours are run by Sowetan people - try Jimmy's Face to Face Tours, which have been operating for more than a decade.

Against: You need more time than on an Asian stopover, and consequently it will be more expensive. You'll probably have to add an internal airfare or two, or the cost of car hire. If you just want to park your head on a pillow for a night or two, Johannesburg is not a very palatable option. Most hotels are in the Sandton district, well away from the danger zone of the central city, but you will still see armed guards on the streets between the major shopping centres, and feel the pervasive sense of menace. And it is a long way from Australia and from Europe. n

FOUR ILLUS: Singapore: clean and efficient but, er, rather dull. Hong Kong: Expensive but amazing. Bangkok: Traffic aplenty. Africa: pricey but exotic.

urn:contentItem:4NWX-T5F0-TX52-F2MT-00000-00Turn of the native2007-06-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:50:12ZLexisNexisFEATURESALR: The Australian Literary ReviewPg. 7

MATP

Turn of the nativeLIONEL SHRIVER

We need to talk about immigration

WHILE admittedly self-taught, I am an enthusiastic amateur demographer and read the World Population Data Sheet, produced by the Washington-based Population Reference Bureau, with the enjoyment most folk reserve for the sports pages.

A passion for population issues goes hand-in-hand with a fascination with immigration, for populations are not staying put. In countries such as Yemen or Nigeria that are busting at the seams, the biggest national export is people. Indeed, there may be no other contemporary issue that engages me more than the thorny, fraught and morally tortuous matter of accelerating mass migration from high birthrate poor countries to the wealthy, low birthrate West.

Given that obsession, what is striking is not how much I've written about the subject but how little. I may have tried my hand at a couple of essays, the odd opinion page piece, but have avoided taking on the material in a novel.

To the degree that I've entertained such a notion, I've put it off. I have a feeling that I could put off an immigration novel indefinitely, too. For I immediately envision a gory media aftermath in which I am smeared from San Francisco to Sydney for being a bigoted, xenophobic, right-wing kook.

Oh, you're safe as houses if you're keen to submit in print that to the US, Canada, Europe and Australia immigration is a net economic benefit and that Western countries desperately need new arrivals willing to do the jobs that ''natives don't want''. You're on solid ground extolling diversity, multiculturalism and tolerance. Preferably decry as nasty, mean-spirited and inhumane referendums such as the one passed in California -- later struck down by the US Supreme Court -- that would deny public services to illegal immigrants.

Lobby for amnesties and the rights of illegal immigrants to vote. Correction: never use the word illegal to describe people who are not supposed to be in your country to begin with. Prefer ''undocumented workers'', which makes their chancy status sound not like a consequence of law-breaking but like a bungling bureaucratic slip-up by your government.

If you're going to say anything negative about immigration -- which I do not advise -- make sure to couch your concerns entirely in terms of ''people traffickers'', whose cruel predation on the desperate it is acceptable to deplore.

In short, if you care about your reputation, not only as a writer but as decent human being, your safest bet is to champion today's historically unprecedented rates of immigration -- legal or illegal -- as the best thing to happen to the West since the invention of Post-it Notes.

Alas, I have a perverse streak a mile wide. In a world drowning in superfluous text, I have never seen the point in writing anything that duplicates the same watery tropes already sloshing about the internet in buckets. Moreover, I do not know what is good for me. I don't watch my back. When I think something I'm inclined to say it. From which you may correctly infer that I am a fool.

Accordingly, whenever I have speculated publicly about immigration, -- trying, naively, to observe something I haven't read hundreds of times before, -- I've got my fingers burned.

In May 2002, I wrote an opinion piece for The Wall Street Journal pegged on the disturbingly good showing by the extremist National Front in the 2002 French presidential election. Dutch politician Pim Fortuyn, widely disparaged as anti-immigrant, had just been assassinated in The Netherlands. Yet watching their backs and knowing what was good for them, neither of the centrist French candidates, Jacques Chirac and Lionel Jospin, had mentioned the word immigration anywhere in his election manifesto. Hence any French voter unhappy about French immigration and asylum policy had found nowhere to turn but the National Front's bigoted, anti-Semitic Jean-Marie Le Pen.

Mindful that the WSJ's official editorial policy was to support the unfettered flow of labour markets, I put forward what was, to me, a mild thesis: ''Even advocates of open borders should concede that all concerns about immigration policy are not inherently racist and xenophobic. Casting the debate in these terms means, in effect, that there is no debate. Anyone who objects to an influx of new arrivals is simply bad.

''Immigration is already so supercharged that responsible politicians need to develop a less judgmental vocabulary for its level-headed discussion, rather than heaping opportunistic calumny on immigration sceptics. Advocates of tighter border controls mustn't always be saddled with a reputation for derogating other races and harbouring a morbid horror of foreigners. Otherwise immigration will remain a no-go area for Western centrists, who thereby abdicate responsibility to the worst elements.''

In particular, I argued the modest linguistic case for European politicians not always slamming folk who were anti-immigration as anti-immigrant. The latter downgrades a policy position to a personal prejudice. Thus simply to argue for lower quotas is to invite not only political ostracism but character assassination. As I was soon to discover for myself.

Now, this was an article studiously neutral on the issue of immigration proper. Yet I feel free to lift from it here because it was never published. In a bitter irony, a WSJ editor had it spiked because it was -- I quote -- ''anti-immigrant''.

In The Guardian's weekend magazine in 2005, I hazarded a view at diametric odds with my new, and unwelcome, role in the British media as ''the anti-Mom'', with which I had been saddled purely for writing a novel about one mother-son relationship that went rather badly.

With cheerful hypocrisy (I have no children), I plumped for Western couples bearing more kids. Resistant to embracing an ahistorical individual happiness as the sole holy grail of a well-lived life, I commended the notion of continuing ''our own people, however we might choose to define them'', be that via lineage, ethnicity, religion or nation.

With great trepidation, I ventured: ''If I feel, oh -- a little wistful -- about the fact that my country of birth, the US, will within my lifetime no longer be peopled in majority by those of European extraction (I'm German-American on both sides), that passing dismay has never been considerable enough for me to inconvenience myself with giving lifts to football practice.

''Frankly, if I can't be arsed to replace myself with a reasonable facsimile, immigrants willing to nurse sick little boys through their fevers have truly earned the right to take my place.

''Of course, that wistfulness of mine is political dynamite. Yet maybe the multiculturalism debate is sufficiently matured for us to concede that white folks are people, too. We encourage minorities of every stripe to be proud of their heritage -- Jamaicans, Aborigines and Jews -- as well they should be. The long dominant populations in most of Europe are contracting, and maybe by the time they're minorities in their own countries they will have rights, too, among them, at least the right to feel a little sad.''

I worded that piece with great care and no little anxiety. So imagine my chagrin in April this year when Lynn Barber, interviewing me for Britain's Observer, parroted them back in the grotesque. ''As far as I could tell,'' said Lynn, tapping an ash mischievously, ''you were saying that we white people have to outpopulate the blacks.'' I blanched. She later claimed she was joking, just trying to get my goat (and she succeeded), but if so she had quite a poker face.

In any event, I feel sure she was accurately encapsulating what many traditionally liberal Guardian readers took those passages to mean. See, this is the peril of expressing a less than pompom-waving attitude towards immigration: bingo, you're a white supremacist.

A fascinating little postscript to that Guardian article: to fill it out, I conducted an email interview with another childless friend of mine, herself outspoken and a fellow writer whom I have always admired as intellectually courageous. In response to my query about how she felt about the consequences of her childlessness writ large, she originally wrote: ''Many Western cities will be largely black-Hispanic-Asian in 50 years' time. Does that bother me? Well, I vaguely regret the extinction of gene lines that in their various ways played a part in the establishment of Western civilisation. But the gene lines coming in from the developing world will have their own strengths, energies and qualities, I guess.''

Yet when she reviewed the article before I filed it, my friend rang up and insisted that I must at all costs edit out that final ''I guess''. I understood; articulating even the gentlest ambivalence about immigration was dangerous, though I gave her a pseudonym. The mere appendage of ''I guess'' risked her seeming anti-immigrant. So I obliged and cut the phrase. Yet the article was the poorer for its excision and less honest. That ''I guess'' was everything, packed with all the uneasiness, moral conflictedness and political self-consciousness that infuses this delicate subject matter. That deadly ''I guess'' is exactly the sort of unedited, mortifyingly forthright slip that I'm always afraid will escape me when interviewers have drawn me on this topic.

Whenever the word immigration arises while a digital tape recorder is switched on, I grow physically uncomfortable. I fidget; I break eye contact. Even if I've been on a lucid roll, suddenly my syntax is halting and full of pauses. I'm hyperaware that one poorly couched sentiment or injudiciously chosen adjective will damn me for all time as a bigot and I will be reading it -- probably misquoted and made more offensive still -- for years to come.

Making the blandest assertions on this subject -- say, proposing timidly that economically immigration is more complicated than being purely beneficial -- I am overwhelmed with the sensation of digging my own grave.

Fair enough, there certainly are nonfiction writers who argue boldly, and sometimes brutally, for more restrictive immigration policies. Pat Buchanan stuffed an unabashed immigration alarmism into his 2006 title, State of Emergency: The Third World Invasion and Conquest of America. But Buchanan would belong to the same American right-wing ghetto inhabited by the likes of Ann Coulter and Bill O'Reilly on Fox News, as well as countless rabid radio DJs.

Any writer keen to gain the broader acceptance of the cultural mainstream is better off arguing for immigrants' rights or, better still, avoiding this subject altogether.

It is in fiction that the immigration debate -- in so far as novels and short stories conduct debates, and they can, after a fashion -- has been skewed. Fiction's overwhelming one-sidedness does not hail from a craven toeing of the socially acceptable line alone. Rather, fiction tends to empathise with the immigrant experience -- as opposed to that of native populations undergoing sudden, dramatic ethnic shifts -- because of the nature of narrative and the instinctive gravitations of sympathy in Western readerships. However they may feel about the political issue of immigration in real life, readers side with the underdog in fiction. They may not approve of weakness of character, but their hearts go out to characters placed, through no fault of their own, in a weak position. Traditional heroes and heroines confront seemingly insurmountable obstacles and overcome adversity. Whatever their complex feelings about class, entitlement and death taxes in their own polity, readers tend to be old-fashioned work-ethic types. They admire industry, sacrifice and gains that are hard-earned while deploring the fruits of privilege that fall lazily to hand like apples from a tree.

Readers admire cunning, resourcefulness and ingenuity. Outside the newspaper, they are unlikely to get too fussed about niceties such as technically breaking the law, especially if doing so is in the interests of a character's survival and the protection of his family. Readers appreciate ambition, dedication to self-improvement and a refusal to accept the lottery ticket of nationality as a permanent, uncontestable limitation on one's fortunes.

They like characters with vision. They respect get-up-and-go, so naturally esteem folk who got up and went. American and Australian readers would have been raised on derring-do tales of the frontier, and for immigrants a new, often hostile country duplicates the hardships of the wild west or the outback.

Continued next page

From previous page

The immigrant narrative is inherently dynamic. Of necessity, it entails motion, a literal journey, leaving and arriving somewhere else, whereas a non-immigrant stays put. Thus ''stranger comes to town'' is said to be one of the three primary narratives on which all stories are a variation. The stranger is nearly always sympathetic. Think Kung Fu.

An immigrant's roller-coaster emotions make for intrinsically rich fictional material: the anguish of leaving home, the terror of the unknown, the relief of finding safe harbour. For that matter, I count myself as a classic Western reader in all these respects.

Whatever my broad concerns about rapid, unchecked immigration in the abstract, on an individual level my heart goes out to the immigrant (after all, as an American living in Britain, I am one). Especially to the illegal sort: living in fear of authorities, probably not speaking the language, often being taken advantage of by unscrupulous employers, barely scraping by yet still being expected to send any extra money back home.

Thus immigration fiction such as Amy Tan's best-selling The Joy Luck Club is par for the course. Addressing themselves to a variety of ethnicities, numerous novelists have told the tale of immigrant travails and final triumph in making a new home. I don't mean to denigrate these books, either. Immigrants give great story.

So is there another side, another story to tell? Clearly, but any characters in the host population who are anything but welcoming and helpful to guests of their nation -- not to put too fine a point on it -- are going to look like shit.

Any character's passing discomfort with the fact most of his kid's classmates don't speak English is going to come across as -- that's right -- racist and xenophobic. Should they be sympathetic, native citizens in a novel whose ethnic landscape has suddenly transformed had better like it. Any reservations whatsoever are going to mark that character as a bigot.

All of the emotions attached to an anti-immigration -- sorry, anti-immigrant -- character are unattractive: wariness, hostility, paranoia, suspicion, inhospitality. Conjure in your head a character who is, say, campaigning in Texas to have that infamous fence erected on the US-Mexican border and see if you don't immediately picture a satire victim from DBC Pierre's Vernon God Little: provincial, ignorant and mean.

Furthermore, any native-born character in the immigration drama starts off in a position of advantage. He may not be rich in the terms of his own country, but you can be sure that he is rich in the terms of the world; in an international context, he's spoiled. He speaks the language. He has a credit card and he's plugged into the system; he doesn't live in constant danger of being arrested simply for being where he lives. Advantage is fictional anathema.

I have read one novel -- one -- that vivifies the experiences of immigrants and their host citizenry in an even-handed, appropriately complex manner: T.C. Boyle's magnificent The Tortilla Curtain of 1995.

A desperate pair of Mexican newlyweds crosses the border and sets up camp in a Californian public park. While Boyle wrenchingly depicts their hardships, he also dramatises the crime, drug-running and sense of invasion and predation suffered by the white Californians who live near the border. Boyle maintains an impressive authorial neutrality through most of the book, which climaxes, through a cruelly hilarious sequence of events involving the cooking of a free Thanksgiving turkey, with the couple starting a raging forest fire. Yet ultimately, even in The Tortilla Curtain, it's the immigrants, not the Americans, who break your heart.

Nevertheless, when any community is abruptly inundated by the Other, whoever that Other may be, powerful, primitive feelings arise. (How did Native Americans feel when European settlers -- immigrants, really -- colonised their land? Ditto, the Australian Aborigines?)

Due to the social touchiness of this subject and the narrative difficulty of making those feelings sympathetic, they have gone under-examined in fiction and nonfiction alike. Like it or not, people are pack animals. Perhaps they should think of themselves as one big happy human family, but as an identity human is too abstract and our species naturally subdivides into groups.

Few would contest that modest levels of immigration are good for any country's soul. Difference creates vitality. A too-homogenous society is apt to be ingrown, myopic, boring and culturally static. But there may be a psychological tipping point at which even initially kind, broad-minded populations start to feel overrun. When a host country's people no longer feel visited but invaded, big, scary emotions come into play, emotions little different from those of a homeowner whose house is being burgled.

In 2005, The New York Times ran an article about an American family that has owned a ranch and farmland in New Mexico since 1918, running along 20km of an open border with Mexico. As many as 500 illegal immigrants cross their land every day. Fences are continually torn down, crops pilfered, pastures set on fire, cattle rustled and watering troughs used as toilets. Sure, many of these trespassers are simply trying for a better life, but some are drug smugglers, bandits and armed coyotes. Having been held up more than once, the ranchers are fearful every time they walk out the door, and have written off whole tracts of their own property as too dangerous to set foot on. Is this family's plight not sympathetic, just a little?

As firmly as I believe that immigration begs to be addressed in fiction in a nuanced, sensitive, intelligent fashion that does justice to both sides of the equation, I dread the self-destructive day that I decide to write such a book myself. Please, somebody stop me!

urn:contentItem:4P8H-NRC0-TXN5-S1KM-00000-00Is Asia in economic meltdown?1997-10-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:50:12ZLexisNexisNEWSInternational NewsPg. 23Is Asia in economic meltdown?Louise Williams with David Lague and Russell Skelton

"For us, the holiday is over," Indonesian economist Bennett Silalahi said flatly as talks began behind closed doors this week between officials of the International Monetary Fund and the Suharto Government over an economic rescue package for Indonesia.

In just over two months the rupiah has lost more than 30 per cent of its value. The nation's largest corporates have revealed dangerous exposure on as much as $US80 billion of foreign debt. And the rosy glow of long-term growth has fallen to doubt and insecurity about the political and social consequences of a serious economic contraction.

Indonesia is not alone with its problems. Thailand, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore and now Vietnam have all felt the chill wind of economic pain. The Thai baht has dropped by 40 per cent against the US dollar since it was floated on 2 July. The Philippine peso and Malaysia's ringgit have fared little better. This week Vietnam bowed to months of pressure on the dong by increasing the range in which it can trade either side of the official rate, from 5 to 10 per cent.

In little more than three months, the Asian miracle has looked more like a calamitous economic meltdown.

How did it happen, especially as none of the best-informed experts were predicting it?

While some experts still insist that the region's economic fundamentals are still strong, the reality would suggest otherwise. In Jakarta tens of thousands of workers on building sites are sitting around idle. Deliveries have stopped because bills have not been paid. For Australian companies in Indonesia, the story is much the same: exporters still waiting for debts due months ago, order books closing, clients ringing to cancel deals.

"The Thais will fall on to a cushion while we will fall on a hard floor," Mr Silalahi said of the consequences facing Indonesia.

"President Suharto has to make a very, very painful austerity program now," said Abdurrachman Wahid, the leader of the nation's largest Muslim organisation.

"Don't talk about today, because we are consuming the products we produced four months ago. Now people are stopping production because they can't calculate costs. Inflation will rise for sure. We need to realise that in the next 10 years our bleak economic prospects will place a large burden on our lives, including the political situation."

Only three months ago this warning would have seemed ludicrous. For two decades Indonesia enjoyed an average 7 per cent growth. The Suharto Government had dutifully followed the conservative economic advice of the World Bank and the mantra happily chanted by the local and international business community was that "Indonesia's economic fundamentals are strong".

Even when Thailand was facing the grim reality that it had drained its foreign reserves and still failed to save its currency, the crisis seemed remote. Many believed Indonesia was too strong to be pulled down by the domino effect of a crash in confidence in Asia's tigers.

But the dramatic decline in the rupiah revealed more what weakness Indonesia's economy had in common with other regional economies, rather than its unique strengths.

Simplistically put, corporate Indonesia followed the same path as the Thais. In an expanding economy flush with new developments, money was needed. Lots of it. Interest rates at home were high, about 15 to 18 per cent, so large sums - about $US80 billion - were borrowed overseas at more competitive US dollar rates.

This seemed a reasonable strategy given the certainty of rupiah exchange rates. The Central Bank managed the rupiah rate within trading bands, meaning costs could easily be calculated. In fact, this meant the rupiah was overvalued and the corporate sector lulled into a false sense of security.

When ripples from the Thai crisis started to shake Indonesia's money and stock markets, the Government began buying its currency to keep it high. After spending $US1.5 billion it said enough, it could not use up its $US20 billion foreign reserves to prop up the private sector. The trading bands were abandoned, interest rates soared and the currency began its spectacular crash. Suddenly there was a severe credit squeeze.

But the big corporations had short-term US dollars debts maturing - some economists estimate 61 per cent of private Indonesian debt is short term - so they tried to borrow more US dollars to pay last year's loans, sending the currency into a free-fall. Indonesia's problems are more than just US dollar debt. What the crisis exposed was an uncomfortable truth: the economic fundamentals were weak. For at least a year, various analysts had warned Jakarta that the financial sector was weak, there were too many banks and too many bad loans, many of them linked to the political elite. Deregulation of the economy has slowed, private debt was increasing rapidly and the economy was overly politicised. In short, the economy was distorted by patronage and favoritism, corruption was eroding efficiency and the bloated and inefficient bureaucracy was making politicised decisions about contracts.

The structure of the corporate sector, too, is part of the problem. About 180 conglomerates control the Indonesian economy, most with cosy ties to the ruling elite. Such a narrow business base means their debts can threaten the economy.

In much of the soul-searching this week one message was that Indonesia must expect a difficult time ahead. At best an IMF rescue package can prevent the collapse of the corporations. But money to pay unhedged debts is unproductive. It does not build, it does not employ. In Indonesia at least 38 per cent of the population is unemployed or underemployed.

The country is also in the grip of the worst drought for 50 years. Crops are failing and famine has already hit some isolated areas. One estimate said 7000 people a day were pouring into Jakarta off the land looking for jobs, just when the the construction sector was shedding unskilled labor. As in Thailand, the property sector is most vulnerable. Some big developments were begun on 100 per cent foreign loans. Under current circumstances they cannot be completed. The Association of Real Estate Developers estimates that 80 per cent of developers could go bankrupt within four months if there is no bail-out.

The Suharto Government has already announced a 25 per cent cut in its development budget. Prices are rising in markets across the country and a politically sensitive end to the fuel subsidy is expected soon, which will push up prices.

"Those who will suffer sacrifice most will be the poorest," said Emmy Hafild, executive director of a coalition of non-government organisations, WALHI. "But the business groups with vested interests will continue to receive special rights to exploit the nation's natural resources.

"Fuel subsidies will be stopped, Government expenditure reduced - we are afraid spending on hospitals, local clinics and schools will be cut."

Over the next few months, she said, the drought and forest fire crisis could lead to famine. Lay-offs in the construction and industrial centres will lead to unrest, she said.

For Indonesia, the economy is everything. For three decades President Suharto has justified tight political controls by arguing that stability is the essential foundation for growth. It is a model championed in other parts of the region, putting the nation's economic growth ahead of the rights and aspirations of the individual.

But without the carrot of steadily increasing material wealth, the Government is left merely holding a stick. Many analysts believe this crisis will be the most significant test to date of the Suharto Government, when the communications revolution has exposed tens of millions of Indonesians to new ideas about freedom.

"There is a proverb which say the stomach cannot wait," says a prominent Muslim leader, Amien Rais. "If the Indonesian economy is going down and inflation is higher and the price of gas and other essentials is increasing, the political situation will become critical."

Political analyst Dewi Fortuna Anwar said: "Economic problems will feed into political instability. Political stability is very much dependent on the country's economic solvency. If the economy takes a turn for the worse, then investors don't want to come here, we will be in a lot of political trouble."

Many commentators believe the IMF will demand reforms that will touch the sensitive link between control of the economy and the political elite. That process is likely to have a positive impact on future economic fundamentals.

At the same time growing demands for justice from workers and farmers, and even the middle class reeling from massive home interest rate rises, could produce pressure for positive political reforms and democratisation.

WHY THE TIGERS ARE NOT ROARING

Free Fall: Fears over high current account deficits and speculative trading have sent the currencies of Thailand, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines plunging by 20-40 per cent against the US dollar since July

View from Japan

Japan is closely monitoring Indonesia's currency crisis and its economy, but has shied from playing any unilateral role in the bail-out.

The Finance Minister, Mr Hiroshi Mitusuka, said this week his ministry was liaising closely with the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank on an action plan.

But Japan is wary of playing any direct unilateral role in the bail-out of any of South-East Asia's crashing currencies. As a major investor and aid donor in Indonesia, Japan is certain to be a willing participant in any regional rescue package.

Japan's banks have invested $38 billion in Indonesia since 1967 and for more than a decade Japan has been Indonesia's biggest foreign aid donor, handing over around $900 million a year. It is believed that Japan has already made it clear to Indonesia that it will provide assistance only through the IMF. - David Lague

View from China

The financial crisis now battering South-East Asian economies is causing unease in China where soaring bank debt is a serious threat to the country's economic growth.

Senior officials including the Premier, Mr Li Peng, and top managers at the People's Bank of China have warned that Beijing needed to learn from South-East Asia's troubles to prevent similar setbacks.

China's currency, the renminbi, is not fully convertible, which is a major barrier to sudden cash inflows or outflows but many economists, including experts at the World Bank, are deeply worried about the massive bad debts that state-owned enterprises have run up with the state banks.

The state-run media have been carrying reassuring articles lately that China can avoid a financial crisis, which analysts in Beijing believe is a strong indication that senior officials fear a banking collapse. - Russell Skelton

Four graphs: Thai Baht/$US; Malaysian Ringgit/$US; Philippine Peso/$US; Indonesian Rupiah/$US; Three photos: Philippines President Fidel Ramos; World Bank director for Indonesia, Mr Dennis de Tray; Indonesia's finance minister, Mr Mar'le Muhammad.

Included within Operating Earnings are the following Unusual Items: - Gain/Loss on Disposal of Affiliates in June 1999 relates to gains on the sale of the Chilean forestry operations ($66 million), the Island Cogeneration Project ($23 million) and the Taranaki Combined Cycle Plant ($23 million), a loss on sale of UK Paper ($11 million) and the release of provisions created on the disposal of affiliates in previous periods ($25 million). - Other Gains/Losses in June 1999 relates to an entitlement by Fletcher Challenge Canada Ltd to partial compensation ($86 million) in respect of production losses which occurred in the nine months ended April 1998, a gain on the sale of the Gold River newsprint machine ($49 million) and payments made relating to the settlement of the Kupuni Gas Price Arbitration ($17 million). - Restructuring Costs in June 1999 relates to Fletcher Challenge Canada Ltd ($44 million) and direct costs associated with the proposed merger of Fletcher Challenge Paper and its 50.8% owned subsidiary Fletcher Challenge Canada Ltd ($17 million). - Permanent Impairment in June 1999 relates to the carrying values of the investment in the Xinda Iron and Steel Operations in China ($49 million), the Tasman Eucalypt Forest Estate ($41 million) and non-forest estate assets ($14 million) and losses from the Chile forest fire ($30 million). Reconciliation of cash)                  901        1,220<br/> NON-CASH FINANCING AND INVESTING ACTIVITIES Details of financing and investing transactions which have had a material effect on consolidated assets and liabilities but did not involve cash flows are as follows. If an amount is quantified, show comparative amount. The Fletcher Challenge Group Investment in the Central North Island Forest Partnership was increased by $29 million with the issue of 46.65 million Fletcher Challenge Forests shares at 61.22 cents per share. During the year, the Fletcher Challenge Group Equity Interest in the Taranaki Combined Cycle Power Station was reduced to 33.3% with debt of $138 million deconsolidated. The Equity Interest in TCC was subsequently sold prior to 30/06/1999. During the year, the Fletcher Challenge Group Equity Interest in Xinda Iron and Steel was deconsolidated, including debt of $31 million. During the year, Fletcher Challenge and RII Chile completed a sale and purchase agreement whereby Fletcher Challenge Forests exited its 51% position in Forestal Bio Bio, with RII Chile moving to 100% ownership; and RII Chile exited its 49% share of Papeles Bio Bio, with Fletcher Challenge Paper moving to 100% ownership. urn:contentItem:49RS-VC20-015H-521P-00000-00<published>2003-10-11T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:50:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WEEKENDER; Pg. W14</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Freedom is within everyone's reach</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">ONCE you were free2b. You were a child and teenager during the late 1940s, '50s or '60s which makes you a baby boomer.</p><p nitf:lede="true">As a kid, you rose when it was still dark, did your chores, left home early and dawdled back at sunset, exhausted from laughing, learning, playing, daring and surviving another day of death defying adventures.</p><p nitf:lede="true">When your parents asked 'what did you do today?' you replied 'nothin', in accordance with the kid-to-parent information rule of 'what they don't know won't hurt them'.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Did not knowing hurt them? No way! Not knowing such things helped you and them to feel free. 21st century life is vastly different to the 1950s, '60s and '70s. In some ways better, and other ways not.</p><p>The biggest difference is that you no longer feel free. Why? You know too much about things that don't matter. You spend too much time watching, reading, listening and getting your guts in a knot about doom and gloom news and views - things you can't fix and which aren't your business.</p><p>Your uptightedness about useless information has numbed the neurons that make you laugh, have fun, imagine and be curious.</p><p>As a result you now suffer headaches, skin disorders, viruses and melancholic moods you never had before. Your obsession about things that don't really matter has made you forget how to be you. You've become oblivious to the reality of life and you are not hearing or feeling the cries from within your body.</p><p>You've become insensitive to your hunches, insight and 'gut feelings' and where is your desire to go out and do things?</p><p>You don't make time for self reflection, self nurturing and listening to your 'inner shrink' - powers that were integral to your once happy and successful life.</p><p>But don't despair. Millions of other baby boomers share the same condition. The problem is you've become too scared to be free.</p><p>And you've lost your way on the frenetic freeway of 21st century life.</p><p>Let's get a handle on what's so different between then and now.</p><p>You went places by yourself without asking or telling your parents. You played ball using rolled up newspapers tied with string.</p><p>You drank water from the garden hose but never bottled water from the shop. And you never heard of sunscreen or blockout.</p><p>You were taught how to use an axe before a cricket bat because work came before play and chopped wood was the source of heat for cooking, washing, bathing and warmth.</p><p>You were also responsible for keeping the household lawns tidy, which meant herding the family horse, cow, sheep, goat, ducks and chickens from the back to the front, and scooping the poo into large hessian bags for use as compost for the vegetable garden.</p><p>There were also after-school and weekend jobs such as chopping more wood, selling or home delivering newspapers, walking a couple of miles to and from the grocery shop; digging holes to bury household garbage and a stinking drum of 'poo and wee' from the outside backyard toilet.</p><p>Luckily you didn't have a swimming pool to clean, and washing the dogs was as easy as throwing them into the river, lake or dam.</p><p>Chores, Sunday school, roast lunch and a weekly bath made Sundays absolute hell, so a great deal of midweek strategic planning and 'Houdini rehearsing' was necessary. But your regular 'escapes' from all or part of 'Sunday hell' can be best described as creatively brilliant and ingeniously carried out.</p><p>You were obsessively curious, wondering, exploring and asking 300-plus questions during an average day. By age six, you learned that disobeying teacher meant a whacking and a screamed reminder: "That will teach you a lesson."</p><p>School discouraged individuality, imagination and fun, so you fantasised about the wonderful free life you would have after and away from school.</p><p>You tried out for school sports, but not everyone made the team. That taught you to deal with disappointment.</p><p>Some students who weren't as smart as others often failed a grade and were held back to repeat the same grade. Tests were never adjusted as a result of 'parental pressures'.</p><p>Your actions and performances were your own. And you copped the consequences, good and bad. You had no one to hide behind. Parent rescue, if you upset a teacher or broke a law, was impossible.</p><p>During 'school and home chores free' times, you would spend hours or days doing stuff with your friends. Your 'what they don't know won't hurt them' policy extinguished the chance for your parents to discover if there was truth in neighbourhood gossip about 'incidents' that might involve you.</p><p>You were brilliant at not being caught, but when you were, you copped your punishment (usually a thrashing) without fuss. Your loyalty to friends remained rock solid despite parental threats of unspeakable punishment for making the shit hit the fan so seriously and frequently when you and your friends were together.</p><p>You were fearless. You never wore a helmet while riding your bike. You rarely read newspapers or listened to the news, so what was there to be scared about?</p><p>Everyone had a nickname like Porky (overweight), Claws (lost two fingers playing with his dad's saw), Hoss (well endowed), Peep (wears thick spectacles), Donkey (great ass), Luscious (has a large mouth), Blue-Knob (red hair and freckled face), Bomber (continually farts), Pope (father a Baptist minister) and Sticks (skinny legs).</p><p>You built billy-carts from scrap and only during the first downhill road test did you realise the need to install brakes.</p><p>After crashing into trees and bushes a few times, you learned to solve the problem.</p><p>That was how you discovered the second meaning of 'trial and error', the first one being don't upset your schoolteacher.</p><p>You rode in cars with no seat belts or air bags. You hitchhiked and bummed rides from complete strangers.</p><p>You collected and swapped stamps, sports cards, marbles, bike wheels and comic books.</p><p>You'd walk into your friends' house without knocking, call their mum 'mum', help yourself to a drink from the ice chest and start talking as though it was your place.</p><p>Remember accidents? You were cut, broke bones and lost teeth, but didn't blame anyone except yourself.</p><p>Law suits didn't happen. Accidents were accidents and no one was to blame but you.</p><p>You were as resilient as a rubber ball. After being hurt, you intuitively bounced back often to the raucous ribbing and suppressed admiration and sympathy of your friends.</p><p>Your T-shirts became tourniquets and bandages and the bloodstains remained as a reminder for rainy day reminiscing.</p><p>To settle serious issues, you sometimes fought, occasionally belting the bejeezus out of each other, but afterwards you'd shake hands to signify the dispute had been resolved. Such outcomes were easier to achieve in those times because fights were with fists, not knives and guns.</p><p>You ate scones, cakes, fat chips and bread and butter; you dipped your fingers into thick, fresh cream and drank fizzy drinks, but you were never overweight.</p><p>Like how could you be overweight when your days were chock-a-block of running, playing, jumping, pretending, climbing, daring, swimming, surfing, wrestling, riding, walking, swinging, skating, sliding, swapping, teasing, pushing, shoving, laughing and joking?</p><p>You shared a warm drink from the same bottle with four or five friends, and remarkably, no one got germs and died. You had real and imaginary friends instead of personal computers, e-mails and Internet chat rooms. You told endless stories, true and made-up, and you loved listening to and reading other people's stories. You made up new games with sticks and tennis balls.</p><p>You ate worms and although your teachers and parents told you the worms would grow 50 feet long and live inside you forever, they didn't. You terrified grandmas and old aunties with your pet spiders, ants, moths, lizards, snakes and every sort of bug imaginable.</p><p>Intuitively you were super smart.</p><p>Your ability to sense danger gave you many lives. You built tree houses in the wilderness, often sleeping over and holding 'secret club' meetings in them. Your last-second slides under barbed wire fences frequently saved you from injury or death after you teased farmyard bulls and billy goats to the point of dementia.</p><p>You were like a frog, jumping, diving, skinny-dipping and belly whacking from rickety old wooden bridges into creeks and streams.</p><p>You tied old tyres and ropes to branches overhanging rivers and performed endless death defying feats. You built fabulous rafts and canoes from fallen trees, bark and junk, and in between creating your own versions of Treasure Island, Tom Sawyer and Huck Finn, your interpretations of the grand sea battles by Lord Nelson, Francis Drake and Long John Silver are legendary.</p><p>You explored old caves in the hills, often burying 'treasure', then creating cryptic treasure maps you tore into equal pieces to be held in custody by you and your closest friends.</p><p>You felt and heard ghosts during your spooky exploits, but you weren't scared because only sissies were scared of ghosts. You pretended to be like cave people, Tarzan, Jane, Al Capone, Davy Crocket or Daniel Boone.</p><p>There were always plenty of fresh field strawberries and blackberries to pick. Your home-made fishing rods and crab pots worked wonders and there were always plenty of field mushrooms and potatoes. Nearly all homes and farms had a vegetable garden so 'bandicooting' fresh carrots, peas and beans was simple.</p><p>You sent smoke signals from one hilltop to another, but it seems only the fire department could understand your message after it became necessary for them to extinguish your forest fire.</p><p>After finding specks of gold in rubble around disused goldmines, you staked your 'claims' and tried to dig for a mighty nugget. When unsuccessful, you found large rocks, painted them gold, buried them close to the surface and laughed till you were sick watching unsuspecting prospectors discover your 'fools gold nuggets'.</p><p>Your neighbourhood fun, games and adventures were at least on a par with those you shared with nature.</p><p>You glued coins to the footpath and laughed hysterically as the suckers tried to pick them up. You played other harmless pranks like throwing stones onto tin roofs of houses and put firecrackers in letterboxes as payback to mean and cranky wrinklies who complained that the noise of your laughter and fun was annoying.</p><p>You argued about and gambled on your predictions for future episodes of radio serials, but mainly you created your own cops and robbers, cowboys and Indians and used your own skills to challenge the feats of radio and comic heroes such as Superman, Hopalong Cassidy, Mandrake, Tarzan, Biggles and The Lone Ranger.</p><p>You were always on the lookout to score free samples from the baker, milkman, butcher, iceman and other suppliers who made home deliveries. As you rode, walked and ran throughout the neighbourhood, you said 'hello' to everyone even though many were terrified as to what your next prank might be.</p><p>No one was able to reach you all day. No mobile phones. Unthinkable. That was the life.</p><p>Your emergence into teenage status did nothing to quell your insatiable appetite for fun, adventure and trying new things. Sometimes you 'borrowed' cigarettes and beers from your parents or from secret stashes at the homes of your friends or relatives who never dobbed.</p><p>You joyfully boasted the arrival of each new pubic hair. You could roll off 100 of the world's crudest jokes and effortlessly produce guffaw laughter from your two-minute version or an embellished half hour rendition. You dawdled past sports clubs and bars from where you overheard and memorised scores of vulgar ditties and songs, which you 'personalised' and performed with gusto and good humour.</p><p>You were around to welcome a new form of music, the likes of which the world had never known. You voraciously embraced Elvis, Bill Haley, Little Richard and the global phenomenon called rock 'n' roll and, with it, countless other new styles of pop music, dancing, records, clothes, languages, lifestyles and superstars.</p><p>Rock 'n' roll was loud and brash yet soft and romantic. It had rhythm, energy, powerful new words and subliminal messages.</p><p>It inspired love and anti-establishment. It introduced you to new love songs, dance songs, wild songs, sexy songs and silly songs that you heard a hundred times a day on jukeboxes or on amazing rock music stations through a new type of radio set called transistors.</p><p>Rock 'n' roll was a call to you and other post-World War II babies to rebel. To be free to be who you are and whatever you want to be.</p><p>James Dean was a rebel for the cause of freedom. So was Martin Luther King, Suzi Quatro, JFK, Buddy Holly and The Big Bopper. Your life was like Happy Days and Grease.</p><p>You hung out at cool milk bars, hamburger joints and dance halls where you flirted, sang, danced, made plans and revelled at being a rebel.</p><p>Rock 'n' roll sent you messages, inspired you to question every aspect of the life your folks wanted you to live.</p><p>You converted old A-model Fords into hotrods and street dragged till you could no longer afford the petrol or the speeding fines.</p><p>You pioneered drive-in movie romance by pretending to watch new flicks while cuddling your newest love in the back seat of a car.</p><p>You were bodgies or widgies; you wore blue suede shoes, stovepipe purple pants, tangerine shirts, hooped petticoats, wide belts, white sports coats, blue jeans, white T-shirts or leather jackets.</p><p>You experimented with dry crew cuts, Brylcreemed long hair with a kiss curl in front, long sideburns, teasing, hair spray and fringes added enormously to the new rock gen.</p><p>You experienced freedom, failure, success and responsibility. Like most of your friends, you found a job you enjoyed and for which you were rewarded for your loyalty, creativity, trust, ethics, humour and handshake deals.</p><p>Your generation produced some of the greatest visionaries, risk-takers, deal-makers and ethical entrepreneurs ever. How did you do it? The answer is you felt free.</p><p>You thrived on laughter and fun; you used your imagination, you were full of curiosity and wonder; you took notice of your gut feelings; you were resilient, and you rarely tried to be anything other than your natural self.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier
