urn:contentItem:49NV-F4F0-01S8-H51J-00000-00<published>1995-12-13T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:50:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Humpty Dumpty fall guy sits for peaceful Tyson at playtime</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>HUGH MCILVANNEY</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">PHILADELPHIA: Talking with Mike Tyson, listening to that light, slightly lisping voice convey a sense of confidence bordering on serenity, makes it impossible to believe his next opponent can be anything but the merest punctuation mark in the story of the most lucrative comeback in boxing history.Buster Mathis Jr is unbeaten after 22 fights, but he is a heavyweight with a silhouette disturbingly similar to that of Humpty Dumpty's. Come Sunday afternoon (Australian time) at the Spectrum here, he will have much the same prospects of avoiding a fall. He may not break apart, but has every chance of sagging to the floor like a sack of marshmallows.How long that process takes will depend on the quality of his own spirit and the sharpness of Tyson's timing. But the limitations of Mathis's physique, and the technical shortcomings exposed by the abuses he suffered during an appalling session of sparring last week, suggest he will be lucky to survive more than a round or two.Mathis represents the softest of soft targets. If Tyson lingers over the easy task of demolition he will provide unexpected encouragement for Frank Bruno, who is due to defend the WBC title against the former undisputed champion on March 16.Big Frank should not hold his breath waiting for such a licence to be optimistic. While Mathis has been showing a pathetic vulnerability to his sparmates, Tyson has been brutal with the hired help in his training camp.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>The Sunday Times</p></bodyText></section><p>Reports that he has forced as many as 15 sparring partners to slink off in search of more congenial employment may contain as much hyperbole as is standard in the fight business.There is no need for his PR team to elaborate on the impression made by his appearance, however. The taut lines of his face, accentuated by a neat moustache and small beard, combine with the trim condition of his body to make acceptable the claims of a current weight around 99kg. That is exactly what he scaled for the 89-second destruction of the egregious Peter McNeeley last August, in the one ring engagement he has faced since completing three years for rape.And there was nothing stage-managed about the flurry of precisely-executed violence that hurled Nate Tubbs to the canvas, and curtailed a rare open-day in Tyson's training at a North Philadelphia (home turf of the Hollywood slugger Rocky) gym last week.In four impressive rounds with the 200cm, 128kg Tyrone Evans, Tyson had given no indication of protecting the right hand which caused the Mathis fight to be postponed from November 4 to next weekend. Fears he might be inhibited by that thumb fracture disappeared altogether as he started to pummel Tubbs, a 187cm 113kg giant from Cincinnati.In fact, it was a couple of rights - one to the body and another to the temple that first severely distressed Tubbs. Then, after permitting the bigger man a brief respite, Tyson unloaded a swift leftright-left combination of hooks to the head that blasted his victim sideways to the floor and into a state of confusion which took half a minute to clear.Having given that public demonstration of his aggressive well-being, and coped with a concentrated onslaught of media attention afterwards, he instantly reverted to the reclusive ways that have been the norm since he left prison.But there have been signs here in Pennsylvania his inaccessibility is less armour-plated than it was even a few weeks back. Some say this is because the necessity to sell this fight is more pressing than was the case with the first phase of the second coming against McNeeley (the Fox network television company are understood to be putting up only half of the $US10 million they were going to pay for the original November 4 date with Mathis).Other close observers conclude less cynically that, as Tyson slowly adjusts to the complex consequences of his release, he is gradually thawing towards a more relaxed attitude.There was certainly not a trace of tension or awkwardness in his manner when, on Friday evening, he responded to requests for a private conversation by making a telephone call to my hotel room.The unmistakable voice answered questions with an agreeableness and gentle courtesy which, in conjunction with the televised images of the dumping of Tubbs, created a faintly eerie effect.When he uses the term "Sir", as he did frequently, there is a tendency for the listener to touch the forelock."I am happy with the way things are going," he said. "Right now, at this stage of my life, I have no hang-ups. I'm not concerned with what people think about me. I am content to live my life for me and my children."People underestimate the strain, the pressures of coming back from where I have been to where I am now. Prison was a dismal experience and the horrific ordeal didn't end the moment I was freed."I had to deal with so many things, a different mentality, a different valuesystem. But I am pretty loose now. I am smiling more than I ever did. I'm in good shape and I'm having fun." The very relaxation he celebrates at 29 is seen as a powerful argument against believing he can ever again be the forest fire of aggression of nearly a decade ago, as he began the devastating surge which made him, at 20, the youngest-ever holder of a heavyweight championship and rapidly carried him on to total supremacy.He was, such critics justifiably emphasise, declining noticeably long before he was jailed.Given all the disparate influences at work on him since, from the eroding effects of four years' idleness to the spiritual impact of conversion to Islam, can he possibly rediscover the singleminded zeal for fighting he once had?"This is a job I take very seriously," was his direct, if less than comprehensive response. "Being the best out there is still extremely important to me. The money obviously matters a lot but ego and pride are vital elements, too. I always had a hunger to win and it is still there, intact. I can feel my powers coming back."The speed is back, the hooks, the combinations. In due time we will discover, in the ring, whether I am as good as I was, or better." "In due time" recurred in his conversation and had a special resonance when he talked of Riddick Bowe and Bowe's insistence that, in spite of holding nothing more meaningful than the WBO crown, he is the world's No.1.Both men are from Brownsville, a Brooklyn district that is one of the bleakest ghettos in America.There is an almost fraternal respect mixed with the hard implications when Tyson refers to the rival who may bring the ultimate career jackpot."A lot of people say they are going to do great things and then when the day of judgment comes they don't fare too well," he said mildly."But Riddick is a good fighter. He has earned his reputation. I have been away and he has been performing, so you can't say I am the best. He has put in his dues but there will be a day of judgment. In due time, we'll know who is the man." Officially, Bowe has only one blemish on his record (a loss to Evander Holyfield sandwiched between two victories over the old warrior).There should have been another in August 1994 when he battered Mathis Jr while Mathis was in a kneeling position during the fourth round of their meeting in Atlantic City.Expediency rather than justice produced a ruling of no-contest. Regardless of the blatant unfairness of that decision, the occasion supplied scant evidence that Mathis can hope to trouble Tyson.There seemed no point in wasting questions on the negligible problems presented by the imminent assignment.Mathis is only a fraction taller than the 181cm optimistically claimed by Tyson. Though the outsider has a substantial advantage in reach, he conspicuously lacks the superiority in physical scope that enabled really big opponents of reasonable talent to worry Tyson even in his prime.Bruno does have such troublesome dimensions, but it was the long list of the Londoner's deficiencies that clearly dominated Tyson's thinking when he was asked about the March rematch with a man he stopped in five rounds in 1989."No one has to tell me how Frank Bruno will fight," he said. "I know how he will fight. I know his strengths and his weaknesses."If somebody wants to make something of the fact that he landed a decent left hook early in our first fight, that's fine. He caught me off guard and the punch was solid enough, but I took it like it was nothing."What I know about Bruno tells me that if I do my work properly I will come out of this championship fight very successfully." Naturally, he does not harbour the slightest dread this weekend will damage career figures which stand at 42 wins and one defeat, with 36 stoppages.It was another Buster, James Douglas, who violently inflicted the one loss, in Japan nearly six years ago.Surely that spectre will not haunt the Spectrum, however. A more convincing omen appeared at the Joe Frazier Gym while 25-year-old Mathis was suffering on Thursday.The lanky figure of the retired Michael Spinks engaged in a training routine he insisted had no significance other than as a means of keeping fit.We were reminded of how Spinks, a magnificent light-heavyweight over many years, was annihilated by Tyson in half a round.The great Frazier himself was on hand to reminisce admiringly about Mathis's late father, who earned a living as a heavyweight in a more distinguished era."That Buster could fight," said Frazier, blinking in the hard sunlight that slanted in from rough streets. "He could go all right." Against Tyson, the younger one can be expected to go all wrong, and early. In seeking to explain the miseries of his sparring, Mathis and his handlers stressed that he was exhausted by a complicated transfer from New York which landed him here in the early hours on Thursday.If he had flown economy from Mars, it would scarcely have been an excuse for such a shambles.No reaction to what we had witnessed was more measured or more damning than that of George Benton, a famous local who has made the transition from outstanding fighter to venerated trainer."It will be a miracle if this kid can stay in there with Tyson," Benton said. "He doesn't have anything that can stave off Tyson. He is much the same height, his jab isn't much and he doesn't have muscular strength. The kid looks soft and he obviously doesn't hit very hard. His record shows only six wins inside the distance. How can he resist Tyson? Tyson comes at you with a lot of hands, hooking at you, hooking at you. I'd say Buster's chances are slim and none." And, as Don King jokes with tiresome regularity, Slim is out of town.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier identifierScheme="DOC-ID">THEAUS-AUS9512130022213182</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">THEAUSTRALIANLTD</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:49NV-F4F0-01S8-H51J-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">244777</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2020-06-21</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="1761"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>THE AUSTRALIAN</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1995 Nationwide News Pty Limited</copyright><publicationDate day="13" month="12" year="1995"><dateText>December 13, 1995 Wednesday 0 Edition</dateText></publicationDate><classification classificationScheme="publicationtype"><classificationItem><className>Newspapers</className></classificationItem></classification></publicationInfo><classification classificationScheme="language"><classificationItem classificationScheme="lang.english"><className>ENGLISH</className></classificationItem></classification><classificationGroup classificationScheme="indexing-terms"><classification classificationScheme="subject"><classificationItem score="77"><classCode>STX000202</classCode><className>BOXING</className></classificationItem><classificationItem score="77"><classCode>ST000D9GY</classCode><className>SPORTS INSTRUCTION</className></classificationItem><classificationItem score="73"><classCode>ST000DNVT</classCode><className>ABUSE & NEGLECT</className></classificationItem><classificationItem score="68"><classCode>ST000DRDX</classCode><className>NEGATIVE MISC NEWS</className></classificationItem></classification></classificationGroup></metadata></articleDoc></content></entry>

urn:contentItem:6FJF-HS63-RX5F-B361-00000-00Why you might see and smell smoke around Ballarat this weekend2025-04-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:50:12ZLexisNexisWhy you might see and smell smoke around Ballarat this weekendAdam Spencer

Burnoffs are being conducted this month.

Smoke will be visible around the Ballarat region this weekend as more planned burns are carried out.

Burns have already been completed in Ross Creek and Smythesdale, while a burn in Turpie Street in Ballarat East will be ignited over the weekend if weather conditions are suitable.

The burns are being conducted by Forest Fire Management Victoria and CFA firefighters.

Forest Fire Management Victoria said some planned burns can produce heavy smoke

"Smoke can travel long distances. It may also settle in valleys and other low-lying areas, especially overnight," an update from Planned Burns Victoria said

"Think about how smoke from this burn may affect you and what precautions to take to reduce your exposure.

"Avoid physical activity during smoky conditions.

"Remain inside, if possible. Close windows and doors to prevent smoke from entering buildings and vehicles."

More information on current and future planned burns can be found at plannedburns.ffm.vic.gov.au or by visiting the VicEmergency website or app.

More planned burns are being conducted around Ballarat in April, 2025. File picture by Lachlan Bence

urn:contentItem:4P8H-NVW0-TXN5-S13K-00000-00Hellfire - Can we ever stop the bush from burning?1997-12-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:50:12ZLexisNexisNEWS EXTRAPg. 1Hellfire - Can we ever stop the bush from burning?Peter Spinks

THE DEVASTATION wrought across vast tracts of north-western New South Wales last week is causing scientists to urgently consider the need to fight fire with firepower. Their high-tech armory includes satellite monitoring systems, to track the paths of fires, and computers - with enough power to perform billions of calculations every second - to predict the hitherto unpredictable: the start and spread of bushfires.

The cutting-edge technology has not yet reached the stage where bushfires may be readily monitored and controlled by firefighters as they assess how factors such as windspeed, landfall, habitation, temperature and humidity affect the progress and direction of a blaze.

For the moment at least, the experts' real weapon is neither modern nor particularly high-tech. To better understand the centuries-old problem of the burning bush, scientists from the CSIRO, and organisations like the Bushfires Council of the Northern Territory and the Cooperative Research Centre for Tropical Savannahs are turning to the past to find answers to the future.

The future, they believe, is in learning how to burn the bush in a deliberate and controlled way to prevent it from burning in an uncontrolled way, as it did last week between Coonabarabran and Nar-rabri, where more than more than 170,000 hectares of

bushland have been razed.

"Extensive wildfire is just as much a natural part of the Australian environment as the gum trees they burn," said Alan Andersen, the program leader of CSIRO's division of wildlife and ecology in Darwin.

"The mass burning of houses and other property can quite rightly be described as a social disaster. However, it is quite ridiculous to describe the extensive burning of native forests themselves as a disaster - unless we are talking about lost forestry production."

According to Dr Andersen, the fact that homes in Victoria and New South Wales are regularly threatened by bushfires can hardly be described as unexpected or surprising. "People like living in and around forests - there is always going to be a fire risk. There really is no excuse for people in fire-prone areas not to be prepared - no excuse other than the time-honored 'it won't happen to me' attitude."

Being prepared, however, does not just mean being ready to evacuate your premises if necessary. For fire management experts, it means regularly burning some of the shrubby undergrowth that fuels the fires and often keeps them raging.

As odd as it may sound, the solution lies in using fire to keep the fuel-rich understorey of forests under control, so that when fires do start they soon peter out or are at least directed to areas where they may do less harm.

But being prepared is not easy. Even in Australia's Top End, where fires have taken their toll for thousands of years and more than half of the country is burnt every year, pastoralists are still learning the hard way that being prepared means, ironically enough, to burn in order to protect. In short, Territorians are learning, albeit slowly, what the Aborigines have known and practised for millennia: the art of fighting fire with fire.

In the Northern Territory, where the tropical savannah landscapes of dense grass and scattered trees dominate the skyline, wet-season rains produce lush plant growth every year. At the season's end, the vegetation dries out quickly, providing wacking great amounts of fuel for dry-season fires.

One fire last year burnt over a region as large as Victoria, explained ecologist Dr Jeremy Russell-Smith, one of Australia's leading fire experts and a consultant to the Bushfires Council of the Northern Territory.

The way to keep those sorts of ferocious fires under control is to use fire as a management tool. "We use early dry-season fires in May and June to create fire breaks," Dr Russell-Smith said. "The breaks prevent the likelihood of more intense fires later in the dry season."

The breaks give the impression that huge swathes of the country have been systematically burnt, particularly near creeklines and other bodies of water.

"To many, it would appear something of paradox that such extensive burning activities might be considered as best conservation practice," said Dr Russell-Smith, whose unenviable task it is to develop a coordinated fire management and research program for northern Australia.

"Yet the stark evidence is there. In the absence of systematic burning undertaken from early in the dry season over the vast tracts of the Arnhem Plateau under contemporary patterns of human settlement, the potential for vast fires burning unchecked late in the dry season is realised

all too frequently, with catastrophic consequences for fire-sensitive communities and species like cypress pine and Leichhardt's grasshopper."

Recognition of the importance of fire management has led to the development of a fire project organised by the Cooperative Research Centre for Tropical Savannahs. Involving researchers and key groups from Western Australia, the Northern Territory and Queensland, the project aims to use remote-sensing satellites to monitor regions.

The idea is to obtain fire histories of regions and to assess the impacts of various burning regimes. "This will assist us to develop economically and ecologically sustainable fire management strategies for regions in northern Australia," Dr Russell-Smith said.

The ambitious task will be coordinated by the research centre, which spans such disciplines as ecology, biology, economics, information technology and social sciences.

"We try to develop practical management solutions with land owners and users," said John Childs, the centre's director. "It's very useful to get different bodies cooperating on fire management, because it affects so many different groups with different views - farmers, city people, conversationists, Aborigines and so on. The same broad principles should also apply throughout Australia."

Mr Childs believes public education is crucial. "The attitude of politicians, and the type of laws and management they apply to fire is often shaped by the ill-informed fears of many people - most of whom live in cities. If people knew more about fires, it would make life easier for the fire managers."

To find practical ways of managing fire, the research centre is working with pastoralists and Aboriginal land owners. "This is a tricky process," said Peter Jacklyn, the centre's communications coordinator. "Pastoralists are suspicious of the idea of biodiversity, which many consider a political tool of the green lobby, but some would like to use fire to control woody weeds."

Dr Jacklyn said Aboriginal land managers were often "alienated by scientists who can come across as arrogant and lacking in understanding of traditional culture".

None the less, the scientists' understanding is being improved by fire experiments and by satellite monitoring studies, which indicate that vast areas of the north and north-west of Australia are burnt annually - typically by intense wildfires late in the dry season.

"Ecological studies indicate that such fire regimes are having a catastrophic impact on fire-sensitive communities", said Dr Russell-Smith. "Conversely, on Cape York and over much of northern Australia, where pastoralism is developed on more arable lands, growing evidence indicates that the restricted application or absence of fire is likewise having profound ecological and economic consequences, particularly as a result of the encroachment of native and exotic woody species."

One of the world's largest fire experiments, in which detailed information was collected before and after fire, was conducted by the CSIRO from 1990 to 1994 at the Kapalga Research Station in Kakadu National Park. The experiment, involving students and researchers from various universities and government departments, covered more than 200 square kilometres and required nearly 500 kilometres of fire breaks.

Four different types of fire were tested: those lit early and late in the dry season, those lit progressively through the dry season, and no fires at all. The scientists collected data on soil nutrients, streams, trees, seed dynamics, insects, small mammals, birds, reptiles and amphibians, bandicoots, wallabies and dingoes.

The experiment sought to answer a raft of questions: Does fire increase soil erosion and the loss of plant nutrients? How do different fires affect different animals? Does frequent fire prevent seedlings from growing into trees? Does the smoke contribute significantly to the greenhouse effect?

Scientists, led by Dr Andersen, are still sifting through the mounds of data collected during the four years, and few firm answers are on the table just yet. But he is optimistic. "The results suggest that current fire management of early seasonal fires seems not to have any detrimental effect."

Elsewhere in Australia other scientists are also concentrating their minds on tackling the task of understanding fire in order, ultimately, to beat it.

In WA, for example, a six-year study, known as Project Vesta, is about to begin looking at how fires behave - particularly those ravaging bushland at the height of summer.

Building on existing knowledge of fire behavior, the project will develop a standard system for land managers around Australia to use to predict the spread and intensity of wildfires. It involves WA's Department of Conservation and Land Management and the CSIRO Forestry and Forest Products Division, and enjoys the backing of the Australasian Fire Authorities Council.

Knowledge gained will help determine the hazards in different types of fuel, and enable more accurate mapping of the threat of wildfires to towns and the environment. The Conservation Department's forest fire behavior tables, developed from more than 30 years of research, has proved invaluable in predicting fire behavior in low-to-moderate intensity fires.

In Adelaide, meanwhile, scientists at the University of South Australia are working on a computer system that will assist in predicting the start and eventual path of fires.

When a bushfire starts, the idea is to feed into the computer its current position. Then the "what if" game begins: what if the wind swings 40 degrees, what if the wind goes up 20 knots and so on. This helps to position the troops.

Wind speed and direction and the lay of the land all affect the course of bushfires. But until recently, this information could only be programmed into computers in sequence. Even with the most powerful computers in the world, number crunching at stupendous speeds, this would take weeks to obtain reasonably accurate data - by which time, of course, most fires would have run their course and taken their toll.

Working in what computer scientists call "real time" - that is time as it unfolds before you - the Adelaide scientists have developed a computer system that relies on innovative hardware rather than software to perform its feats.

And, while the hardware merchants keep hard at it, the climatologists are still scratching their heads to understand what happened to our climate that is making it fan the flames. Earth's climate has warmed by some half a degree in the past century, and the latest figures from the weather bureau reveal that the average temperature in Australia rose this year by 0.11 degrees Celsius from the average between 1961 and 1990.

"Most people are now aware that scientists are predicting overall changes in temperature, rainfall and sea levels," said Dr Andersen. "For many management purposes, it is not average changes that will be important but changes in variability, and particularly the frequency of extreme events.

"A small rise in average temperatures is not likely to have much of an effect on bushfire risk, but a higher incidence of extreme events - such as an extremely wet period followed by an extremely dry period with an extended hot spell - could have a major impact," Dr Andersen said.

Indeed, extreme events are likely to become more frequent now that scientists have discovered the first direct evidence that El Nino - the warm Pacific current flowing southwards along the west coast of South America - is affecting ocean currents off

Australia's top end.

But the concern is much wider than that. If El Nino, perhaps aided and abetted by the global warming, has contributed to the early ferocity of fires like those in New South Wales, then we could be in for a tough time of it.

Five photos: John Longstaff 1862-1941 Australia Gippsland, Sunday night, February 20th, 1898 1898 oil on canvas 196.2 x 143.5cm purchased, 1898 National Gallery of Victoria, Melbourne; Humbert River, 1933 and 1994. Top: Kapalga station. Pictures: CSIRO Wildlife and Ecology.

urn:contentItem:4P85-1250-TXN5-R384-00000-00STAY IN TOUCH1995-03-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:50:12ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESStay In TouchPg. 28STAY IN TOUCHEdited by DAVID DALE and MICHAEL SHARP

A FALL FROM SPACE

THINGS THAT MATTER

NO-ONE would have believed in the last years of the century that this world was being watched, keenly and closely, by intelligences greater than man and yet as mortal as his own. Across the gulf of space, minds that are to our minds as ours are to those of the beasts that perish - intellects vast, cool and unsympathetic - regarded this earth with envious eyes, and slowly and surely drew their plans against us. H. G. Wells, War of the Worlds.

LAST Tuesday the news room of The Sydney Morning Herald was galvanised by news that a meteorite had landed near Canberra and started a forest fire. It transpired that the fire had a different cause, but the story got us thinking. If the dinosaurs were wiped out by a meteor strike 65 million years ago, could it happen to us? What sort of early warning system do we have for such occurrences? We challenged the Herald's science writer Leigh Dayton to answer these questions ...

There's bad news for those who expect some spectacle with their meteor strikes. Rob McNaughton of the Anglo-Australian Observatory (AAO) in Siding Springs says there is "no authenticated evidence of a fire caused by a meteorite fall". True, the fabled objects can whiz in at between 11 and 20 kilometres per second. They can glow like fireballs as they rub against molecules in the upper atmosphere, and they get hot on the outside, but the inside is so cold after life in outer space - below zero degrees - that "falling stars" arrive cool as cucumbers. And anyway, fewer than 20 meteorites hit populous parts of the globe yearly. (NB: It's called a meteor in space and a meteorite on the ground.)

Asteroids are another matter. Dubbed "minor planets" by astronomers, they can be kilometres across. When they hit, they release massive amounts of energy. A one-kilometre-wide asteroid striking at 30 kilometres per second would release 2,000 times the energy of the biggest nuclear bomb ever detonated. In 1908 an asteroid or comet some 100 metres across blew up over Siberia and knocked the nearest person off his chair - 110 kilometres away.

Comets are dirty snowballs with a solid icy core surrounded by volatile material which glows when the comet passes near the sun. Comets present less risk than do asteroids, simply because only about 400 are known to cross the Earth's orbit. Astronomers estimate that there are 2,500 asteroids larger than a kilometre across and 150 million asteroids larger than 10 metres across - all waiting to land on a neighbourhood near you.

According to Ken Russell, an astronomer at the AAO, the chance of a catastrophic collision occurring within the next 50 years could be as high as one in 6,000. If that happened, he bets that "civilisation as we know it" would be on the way out. So isn't anybody watching? Yes and no. Yes, dozens of concerned astronomers around the world - including Dr Duncan Steel's team at AAO - have joined together in an informal group known as Spaceguard. They are scanning parts of the sky with rejigged telescopes and seeking funds for new ones. Their goal is to find "Earth-crossing" objects years before they are a menace. The US space agency NASA could then land thruster engines on the most threatening and gently "nudge" them out of harm's way.

But scientists can't look everywhere at once and these objects are hard to spot. A doomsday rock could still creep up without warning and devastate the planet - or just Canberra.

VISIONARIES

IN A moving ceremony at Central Station yesterday, Bruce Baird, NSW Transport Minister, climaxed a distinguished political career by announcing the winners of this column's contest to name the day and night XPTs between Sydney and Melbourne. Our photo shows him surrounded by, from left, John Brew, chief executive of the State Rail Authority, and several of our shortlisted contestants: David Catterall (who suggested The Archer) Chris Sim (The Yarra-Parra and the Beach Melba), June Strathmore and Maureen Hathaway (The Pacific Zipper) and Jay Govind (The Chang and The Southern Cross). They are holding the sign about to be affixed to the daytime XPT - The Olympic Spirit, a name suggested by Gary Cox, who was unable to be present yesterday to collect his medal and his tickets to ride the Tilt Train. But Jay Govind was there to collect his prize for naming the night train. We should note that several other people suggested The Southern Cross in their entries, but Govind's argument was judged the most convincing. And so this column's readers have now become part of the history of Australian rail.

After the ceremony, we begged Bruce Baird for permission to reveal a story he once told us in a confidential capacity about why he has a sentimental attachment to the old Southern Aurora, which was the predecessor to the XPT. But even this close to retirement, he refused to release us from our oath of secrecy. Perhaps one day ...

OPPORTUNITIES

WE REPORTED yesterday that there's a shocking injury rate among American zoo workers who treat elephants' feet, and that elephant restraints sell for $US100,000 each. But in Australia, what we need is a dog seatbelt.

About 5,000 Australian dogs were killed or injured last year after falling from moving cars. RSPCA president Hugh Wirth said the dogs mostly fell off utes or open-tray delivery trucks, but there were as many accidents in the city as in country areas. He said carrying an untethered dog on the back of a moving vehicle is dangerous not only for the dog but also for other motorists. Now all that's required is for someone to design a restraint that will fit every hound from a chihuahua to a great dane.

Footnote: Larry Vogelnest, a senior veterinarian at Taronga Zoo, told us the zoo does not use elephant restraints "because we don't actually handle our elephants". Vogelnest said there is debate among the world's zoos as to whether elephants in captivity should be trained so that they can be handled. Taronga's aren't. The problem, said Vogelnest, is that if zoo workers regularly handle elephants, "there is a risk that people will be killed occasionally". As for cleaning an elephant's foot, "fortunately we have not had a need to". Our pigmies must run faster.

GOSSIP

JOAN Kirner set the standard a few years ago by dressing in leather and singing I Love Rock 'n' Roll on ABC TV's Late Show. Now Jivin' Jeff Kennett has announced he will co-host a State reception for the Rolling Stones in Melbourne next week with the British consulate. The venue and date are being kept secret for security reasons (Kennett is consistently mobbed by groupies). Asked his favourite Stones song, Kennett said yesterday: "I think probably Satisfaction. I think it's because I can't get any from the Opposition at the moment and I try to do my best to keep the Parliament humming along." Hmmm. Opposition Leader John Brumby, distressed at not being invited to the party, also twisted a Stones lyric. "You can't always get what you want, but I think the Premier always gets what he wants," he said. This wasn't a bad line, but then Brumby asked why State receptions weren't held for recent rock visitors the Cranberries and U2. No wonder he wasn't invited.

STEPHEN Fry is back in England. The star of Blackadder and Jeeves and writer of A Bit of Fry and Laurie, stunned London's theatre world last month when he disappeared after only three performances of a new West End play. Fry wrote to the playwright, Simon Gray, saying he considered himself a failure as an actor. Fry's agent said yesterday that after spending last month in a French village, the actor/writer had returned to Britain and checked into a London clinic. She would not specify what the treatment was for.

OH, LORD, won't you buy me a Mercedes-Benz?/ My friends all drive Porsches, I must make amends./ Worked hard all my lifetime, No help from my friends./ So, Lord, won't you buy me a Mercedes-Benz. This satirical ditty, a surprise hit for Janis Joplin in 1970, is being used by Mercedes to sell their cars to the baby boomers who can now afford them. But not everyone is happy about Mercedes' purchase of the rights to the recording. "Some people will say this is another example of commercialism usurping the icons dear to us," said US marketing consultant Ross Goldstein. Others have warned the parody of prayer will alienate buyers in the Bible Belt. But the song's co-writer, Bob Neuwirth, said the song "was never meant to be taken seriously ... I wonder why it took them so long in a way". And Joplin's sister Laura, co-manager of Joplin's publishing company, said: "It does honour to the song as well as to the car. It juxtaposed them and was very much in keeping with her image and humour ... It's a hoot."

DESPITE yesterday's revelation that Australian rock star Michael Hutchence spent Sunday night at a Kent hotel with British TV presenter Paula Yates, Hutchence's girlfriend, supermodel Helena Christensen, has said there is nothing to worry about. "Michael and I love each other and, although we both have to travel a lot, we have a very steady relationship," she reportedly told a Danish newspaper. "My relationship with Michael is as steady as everybody else's," she added. "We miss each other terribly when we're not together. We have our ups and downs like any other couple."

WHAT'S HAPPENING

TODAY is March 23, the birthday of actor Joan Crawford (1904), runner Dr Roger Bannister (1929) and singer Glen Campbell (1936), and the deathday of actor Peter Lorre (1964).

CHIEF Archie Fire Lame Deer, a Native American medicine men who has supped with the Pope, swapped ideas with the Dalai Lama and ridden a Brahman bull for Elvis Presley, will speak at The Gazebo Hotel, Elizabeth Bay at 7.30 pm (tickets $20, phone 1 800 671 543).

A FORUM titled "Peace, Justice and the Environment: Whose Common Future" will feature Christine Milne, leader of the Greens in the Tasmanian Parliament, and Trish Caswell, executive director of the Australian Conservation Foundation, when it begins in Sydney University's Wallace Theatre at 6.30 pm.

BILL Stefaniak, the ACT Minister for Sport and Recreation, wants a rugby union Test to be played in Canberra in the near future. He will launch his campaign at the proposed venue, Bruce Stadium, at noon.

TWO CARTOONS: By Cathy Wilcox and Michael Leunig

urn:contentItem:4P7G-Y1W0-TXN5-S1WF-00000-00If you see a UFO, will anyone believe you?1993-05-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:50:12ZLexisNexisNEWSFeaturesPg. 15If you see a UFO, will anyone believe you?Barbara Hooks

Eighteen years ago an American named Travis Walton saw a UFO and was abducted by its occupants. So he says. Many don't believe him. The experience, and its aftermath, changed his life. BARBARA HOOKS spoke to him yesterday.

IN 1975, 22-year-old Travis Walton was reported missing, abducted by a UFO. But another ordeal awaited the Arizona woodcutter when he showed up five days later, telling of a frightening experience in a strange place amid alien beings. He was not believed. And one suspects that for this quietly spoken and conservatively dressed mill foreman, his earthly reception was more upsetting than any he might have suffered extra-terrestrially.

"What's worse, take your pick," he says. "Is he a liar; is he a druggie; is he a crazy? None of those is very appealing; to not be believed." Travis Walton was in Melbourne yesterday to promote `Fire In The Sky', a feature film based on his book about the disappearance 18 years ago.

With him are his wife, Dana, and brother-in-law Mike Rogers, one of the men who reported Walton missing. By any measure, the two men tell an extraordinary tale which began around 6pm on 5 November, 1975, in White Mountains, Arizona. They say they and five other contract loggers were returning from a day's work felling timber when they saw what they thought was a crashed plane or a forest fire.

Around the next bend in the track, crew leader Mike Rogers stopped the truck. Over the clearing ahead of them hovered a glowing, saucer- shaped craft. Ignoring the entreaties of his workmates, Travis Walton left the cabin and wandered into the clearing for a closer look.

Nothing happened at first. Then, as the others watched horrified, Walton was jolted by a vertical beam of light, as if by electric shock, and thrown several metres to the ground. In a panic, Mike Rogers accelerated down the track, but collected himself and returned a few minutes later, only to find that the mysterious object and Travis Walton had vanished.

A search party was mounted from the men's nearby town of Snowflake.

But few believed the story of the UFO. Most, including the police, suspected the loggers of murdering their companion, disposing of his body and concocting a cover-up story. All six took polygraph tests, and while they only prove that the subject believes what he or she is saying, five passed and one was deemed inconclusive.

Five days after his disappearance, Travis Walton turned up in a phone booth on a highway a few kilometres south of the clearing where he was last seen. Dehydrated and hungry but otherwise fit, he told of being held on a table in a humid room equipped with overhead lights. Three creatures with large eyes, domed heads and no hair or fingernails were standing around him. Travis Walton saw other rooms and other creatures, more human-looking than the first group. One put a mask over his face and he lost consciousness. When he came to on the roadside, he could see a small, disc-shaped object rising into the night sky.

No one has been able to disprove the story or explain away the supporting evidence; circumstantial and eye-witness. Blood and urine tests conducted by the county medical examiner showed Walton had ingested no drugs or alcohol. "A battery" of psychiatric tests indicated no "transitory psychosis" (hallucinations). His mother also took and passed a lie-detector test when it was suggested she had hidden him for the five days he was missing. Magnetic anomalies were found in the clearing, the loggers' hard-hats recorded a higher-than- normal level of radiation, and Walton's story allegedly matched an unpublicised account of a UFO encounter three months earlier, 100 kilometres away.

Meanwhile, six eye-witnesses have not changed their story in 17 years.

And according to one US report, Walton's account is believed in some respected scientific circles.

What is surprising is that Travis Walton, a man who so desperately wants to be believed, is promoting a film that seems to have taken more liberty than licence with his story. In his hotel room on the 44th floor of the Regent Hotel, he tackles the disparities. "Well, it's pretty good," he says of the film's fidelity. "You know, it's not a documentary. But it does leave one with the feelings we had at the time. There were certain differences, and I was against any at the start. But (the producers) persuaded me there were good reasons for them. For instance, you're taking a story that spans several years and telling it in an hour and 45 minutes so you've got to do some condensing and simplifying to make it intelligible.

"There were seven of us out there in the woods, not six. I had two brothers that were involved and they became one. And the head lawman was actually a composite of three different lawmen. It's very hard for an audience to be introduced to a huge cast of characters and be able to follow all these people. From the director's point of view, the function of the two brothers in the story was the same, so it made sense to combine them into one." Fair enough, but other changes and embellishments in the film weaken Walton's case. He did not see a half-decomposed (half-eaten?) human body hidden in a hive-like cell aboard the ship. The human-like creatures he says he did see were in charge of their faculties _ not dead. But they are not shown in the film at all. He also has no memory of the horrific medical tests depicted in the drama. And he was not found naked, as the film suggests.

"THE things I had more trouble with were departures from my experience aboard the craft," Walton says. "That was one I thought they could leave exactly as it was ... and I resisted those changes the most. But there were so many things happening to me; powerful, powerful intense emotions, but no way to really show the audience. So they contrived scenes that would generate the same emotions with people." In another scene, actor D.B. Sweeney, who plays Walton, has material rather like cling-film pulled over his face and body. "It's designed to invoke a certain emotion," Walton says. "I regained consciousness in a very enclosed space. It was dimly lit and the atmosphere was difficult to breathe. And I had this feeling of suffocation and claustrophobia that would be very hard to show visually. They showed the actor with this membrane over his face and I think it does a very good job of showing the intense feeling I had." For the same reason, Travis Walton justifies the depiction of the medical tests. "You know, a lot of the terror I felt in the aftermath of this was wondering what they had been doing to me. I woke up in the middle of (the procedure) and interrupted it, so I don't know what they were doing before I regained consciousness. Rather than trying to express the terror of wondering about those possibilities, of what had been going on, they just showed some things that didn't actually happen." Medical tests later showed that Walton had not been tampered with physically. "That was something that was extremely scary to me and I wondered about it. I was afraid of a variety of things; maybe I had acquired some bizarre infection, or maybe damage from breathing that strange atmosphere, or radiation sickness or something like that. The tests all came back negative and that was reassuring. Still, it's something I thought about .. I wanted to have kids." His four children (the eldest is 15) are fine.

At first, Travis Walton turned down the offer for the rights to make this film, just as he had done with the half-dozen or so that preceded it, and the many other requests to buy his story. From all accounts the Walton experience has not been unalloyed joy and he didn't want to make matters worse by selling his credibility.

At first, he was as keen as anyone to find an alternative explanation.

And had his disappearance not become an international story, over which he had no control, Walton says he would have maintained his silence. But after conducting "some reality testing of my own and connecting with the experiences of six other men" he dismissed any notion of self-delusion. In the past 17 years, Walton has lost friends and job opportunities because he stuck so doggedly to his story. He considered moving away from Snowflake altogether.

Instead, he cut off the phone for 10 years, banned discussion of the incident at home, and endured the slings and arrows of the sceptics, the doubters and the obnoxious disbelievers. So what persuaded him to become involved in this movie? He even has a cameo role _ in a town meeting called to demand the arrest of Mike Rogers and the others.

"I was kind of convinced they'd be true to the material." Which they weren't. "Yeah, well, the essence of the material. They could have made a movie that just focused on the lurid, sensational things, of aliens and space ships and laser battles and what have you. The fact that they did stick to the human side of the story, the way it affected me, the way it affected the community, and how the community reacted to it, that was a really important part of my life story.

That's what I mean when I say they stayed true to the essence." Is he happy with the result?

"YEAH, I had misgivings, wondering what's this going to do, stir up all the controversy again? But people's reactions have been good; their attitudes have improved." By that, he means people don't necessarily believe, but they are more open-minded, more objective about the details of the case.

"Although the documentation is not within the movie, the fact that people can go in and experience this and kind of live it for themselves has caused them to take a little more objective look at the evidence. A lot of the rumors and innuendo that were flying around back then have been disproven over the years." Travis Walton is not enjoying the publicity circuit. He and Dana are missing their kids. "I'm a private kind of a person; I guess I'll be relieved when it's over. There'll come a time again when I won't talk about it anymore, because it's not easy. The movie kind of renewed hopes for me that I could vindicate myself, speak to these issues and the controversy surrounding them and rebut the things that have been said." Even after all this time, it still hurts. "It does, you're talking about my character and my reputation." It came time to do some earth-bound shopping. With yesterday's public transport chaos in the city, they could have done with a flying anything to get from A to B. But you know how it is, there's never one around when you need one.

`Fire In The Sky' opens in Melbourne on 13 May at the Russell, Hoyts and Village cinemas.

urn:contentItem:7XJJ-C3C1-2RR2-D407-00000-00Burning the rule book2010-01-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:50:12ZLexisNexisGOOD WEEKENDPg. 14Burning the rule bookcover storyJohn van Tiggelen

On January 22, 2006, John van Tiggelen was invited into the control room of Victoria's Country Fire Authority. It was a day of extreme fire danger - the worst in three summers. The conditions spawned infernos around the state and seriously tested the CFA's "stay or leave early" policy, especially around Anakie, north of Geelong. Four years on, he explores why the policy proved so murderous on last year's Black Saturday, before returning to Anakie to hear five very different perspectives.

In the '60s, a canberra scientist named Alan McArthur completed the kind of life-saving experiment that, had it involved anything other than arson, might have seen him grace an Australian bank-note by now.

Time and again he set fire to the bush outside the capital and gave it a 40-minute start before letting a fire crew try to halt it. His aim was to determine the relative influences of temperature, wind speed and humidity. Further factoring in drought and fuel dryness, he arrived at a formula that he called the Forest Fire Danger Index (FDI). At very low scores, the fire might fizzle out by itself. At 12, the crew generally managed to extinguish it. Around 25, they were in trouble. And at 50, they had Buckley's.

The formula came to be widely used. Land managers applied it to determine the right, safe time for fuel reduction burn-offs, and still do. Meanwhile, CFA brigades used it to warn of the day's fire danger via rainbow-coloured signs by the sides of highways. An Extreme rating, coded red, meant the index had breached 50, the CFA's trigger for declaring a Total Fire Ban.

Problem was, Extreme didn't really mean extreme at all. McArthur's index didn't end at 50. The formula had been calibrated so that a score of 100 reflected the perfect-storm conditions of Black Friday, 1939, when 71 people died.

Three years ago, the authors of a joint CSIRO and Bureau of Meteorology study into the effects of climate change twigged to the fact that the CFA's warning system urgently needed updating. Weather forecasting had improved immeasurably since McArthur's day, and the public deserved to know what degree of fire danger to expect. So-called Extreme days would become more frequent and more severe, and it would no longer do to bundle your 100-plus Ash WedÂ­nesdays with your ho-hum TFBs (days of Total Fire Ban). The authors recommended that two new categories be added: Very Extreme, for days peaking between 75 and 99, and Catastrophic, for those exceeding 100.

State and federal authorities received the report in the winter of 2007. Nothing happened. Along came February 7, 2009. Five days in advance, the FDI had been tipped to top 150 in the ranges around Melbourne. Values greater than 100 are largely academic, much in the way that cyclone ratings stop at category five. But 150-plus was unprecedented. No one within the CFA could have failed to grasp its meaning: to get the hell out of the way. (It's no coincidence that not one firefighter was among the dead on Black Saturday.)

The figures were not conveyed to the public. No one had explained the fire danger index to us before, and no one was game to start doing so now. To be sure, Victorians were repeatedly warned by the Premier, John Brumby, that the weather would be "seriously bad" - hotter, windier and drier than 1983's Ash Wednesday. We were advised not to travel. We understood - we'd just endured a record run of 40-plus temperatures. Add 60kmh northerlies, and Saturday would definitely be a day to stay home. But we were also led to understand it was policy as usual: as nagged ad nauseam by authorities and their emergency broadcasters, Victorians were to "activate" their bushfire plans and "prepare to stay and defend, or leave early".

What we didn't know, but authorities did, was that the "stay or go" policy was never intended to cope with 100-plus conditions. Both the Australian Standard for Building in Bushfire-Prone Areas and the CFA's guide to individual bushfire survival plans were modelled on studies that assumed a worst-case fire danger index of 100. February 7 was, in fact, a day when the only bushfire plan worth "activating" was the second option: leave early. But we weren't told that.

At kilmore on black saturday, near the snapped powerline that ignited the day's deadliest fire, the FDI peaked at 189. Of the 173 people who died that day, 113 died in their homes.

Ahead of this summer, state governments belatedly agreed to split ExÂ­treme fire weather days, i.e., days of Total Fire Ban, into three new fire danger ratings. The "stay or go" policy has yielded accordingly: on a Severe day (50-74), you'll need a sound plan to defend your home; on an Extreme day (75-99), you'll need a sound house as well (i.e., compliant with fire safety standards), and on a 100-plus Catastrophic day - just go, as soon as you can.

But the policy remains shaky. It's a fine line - a degree in temperature, an extra puff in wind speed - that separates an Extreme day from a Catastrophic one. Besides, the intensity of any fire is at the mercy of fuel loads and topoÂ­graphy as well as weather conditions. In the barren north-west of Victoria, for instance, 100-plus days occur almost yearly, yet are unlikely to see a catastrophic fire, whereas in the hillier parts of south-eastern Australia, such a day almost invariably earns itself a black name.

When Good Weekend was invited to the CFA's control room four summers ago, the FDI reached the high 80s in southern Victoria, based on 43-degree temperatures, flailing northerlies and forests dry as kindling. "If the forecast were for a cyclone," I wrote, "it would be a category four - Cyclone Tracy strength." By mid-afternoon, bushfires were raging through the GramÂ­pians, the Latrobe Valley and the Brisbane Ranges, north of Geelong.

About 7pm, the deputy chief briefed staff that 18 houses had been lost around Anakie, at the base of the Brisbane Ranges. Whether there were fatalities, he didn't yet know, but his face was grave. An hour later, at a nearby emergency relief centre where some 200 people had gathered seeking refuge and information, the situation was no clearer. Said an anguished policeman, "We don't yet know if we'll find any deceased. Some of these homes are tucked right into the bush and we know there are people who stayed. Fact is, if they keep their properties clear, and they have a [bushfire] plan, we and the CFA encourage them to stay. That's the policy. As to whether it's wise ... I have to say that from where I stand now, it's a bit of a worry."

By midnight, residents were able to return. On the face of it, the "stay or go" policy had stood up well. All those who had stayed to defend their homes had managed to do so. Only abandoned houses had been lost. No one perished. But it transpired the local version of "stay or go" had been more like "wait and see". Most residents had delayed leaving, often to the last minutes. Several families who planned to defend ended up fleeing when members panicked at the sight of the front roaring towards them. In other cases, wives left and their husbands stayed on to fight solo and, in at least two instances, drunk. Writing in The New Yorker in October, Christine Kenneally contrasted our "stay or go" approach with that of Californians, who resort to mandatory evacuations in the face of bushfires. She put it down to "a streak of self-reliance in the Australian character", and went on to contemplate "the extent to which the deaths of Black Saturday were the result not just of the Australian landscape but of an entire mentality".

Doubtless, self-reliance took a knock on Black Saturday. In coming summers at least, before memories fade and lessons are unlearnt, more Australians will choose to leave in the face of fire. But when we returned to Anakie, four years on, we found support for "stay or go" resurgent. If anything, there was an attitude that the fire had been good for the area, in that it had exposed local complacency and the weaknesses in people's fire plans - without actually killing anyone.

They'll be ready next time, goes this line of thinking. Maybe they will. Then again, maybe the next fire will be worse.

farmer & CFA volunteer Peter Stray

Peter Stray, a stalwart of the Maude Rural Fire Brigade, lives alone on the flat open country south of the Brisbane Ranges, in a weatherboard farmhouse an hour's drive west of Melbourne. He doesn't have a fire plan. In the event of fire he'd be out with the crew, probably defending the homes of city escapees who, to his lasting puzzlement, insist on settling right in harm's way, in the bush up on the ridges, hankering for a view of properties like his.

Four years ago, Stray knew he was in for a rough weekend. On Saturday morning, the Department of Sustainability and Environment, which has responsibility for fire suppression on public land, called on local brigades to help contain a fire sparked by lightning in the Brisbane Ranges National Park. When Stray finally got home that night at 2am, he slept badly, fearing the rangers' containment lines wouldn't hold in the 40-plus temperatures and 40kmh-plus northerlies to come. They didn't. Late Sunday morning, as the FDI began climbing sharply, the fire spotted into fresh bushland. Forty more trucks and seven choppers were dispatched but it was too late. The tankers fell back to concentrate on saving Anakie township. The fire crowned in the trees atop the last escarpment and sent a storm of embers over the lowlands, sparking fears of grass fires that could run all the way to the coast. Fortunately, the paddocks were drought-barren and the fire was held at a road to the south.

"We were very lucky nobody got killed," says Stray. "There was a fair bit of community apathy here. Many people seemed to think that fire trucks would magically appear on their doorstep." In the preceding months, Stray had helped the CFA run its Community Fireguard program, which advises residents on how to survive fire. He was nervous to know how they had fared, especially those he'd helped plan to stay. "We don't tell people they should stay. But we do tell them that if they leave, they'll probably lose their house to ember attack.

"Problem is, people's fire plans vary greatly and even an excellent plan can't give you absolute protection. It might hold up on your average Total Fire Ban, but when the index is pushing 90, as it was that day, it's really going to test things."

At the same time, Stray wonders whether authorities have overestimated people's psychological capacity to rely on their fire plans. "We taught people to stay and defend or leave early. But would I do so myself? I can't answer that. I don't know how I'd handle it, if a wall of flame came over the rise and the sky turned dark and it started raining embers, the wind howling, heat and smoke everywhere ... I can understand why people would flee at the last minute."

On Black Saturday, Stray's brigade ended up in the Latrobe Valley. "It was chaos. We were held up in the staging area for hours, which was very frustrating. But on a day like that it's likely you go in after the fire and do what you can to save things. I never want to see weather like that again. If it had been like that during the Anakie fire, I would have ended up [stationed] in Geelong."

stayers and defenders

John and Carlene Baker

The Bakers live in a hidden gully in the far south-eastern corner of the Brisbane Ranges, hemmed in by forest. Not long after they moved here 12 years ago, a local brigade captain drove up their long, bumpy access track and knocked on the door. "He was shaking his head at us," recalls Carlene. "He warned us that if a fire came, we shouldn't expect a truck to come and save us. Then he asked us for a donation."

The Bakers decided to join the CFA, but a different brigade. They trained in firefighting and acquired fire-resistant clothes. They clad their dream cabin, made from recycled timber, in corrugated iron on three sides. They installed a water tank and fitted a pump to their four-wheeler. They also created two perimeters of "defendable space" around the house - an outer one, which they kept as clear of fuel as possible, and an inner circle of closely cropped lawn, which extended to the stables and barn.

"Our strategy was to save the outbuildings in a low-intensity fire, but if it was a high-intensity fire, we would retreat to saving just the house. And if that failed, we would save ourselves by keeping low and putting our hoses' fog nozzles over us."

Summers came and went. Then came January 22, 2006. "We sat here on the veranda pretty well all day waiting for the fire," says John Baker, who sports a pioneer's beard and makes dental prosthetics in Geelong. "We knew it would come. I wasn't at all nervous. We had five fire hoses and 60,000 litres of water. And I knew everyone would do what I told them to do."

The Bakers crowded their five cows, 22 sheep and one alpaca into the barn. They locked their two dogs, cat and chickens in the house. The pig was tethered on the veranda. Their son and daughter had been given the option of leaving, but they'd said no. Still, when embers the size of small birds began landing and igniting around them, Molly, then 13, lost her will for a moment. Says John: "I grabbed her and told her, 'This fire is going to be the worst thing you've ever seen. Just do your job and everything will be fine."

"The wind was coming from the north all day," says Carlene. "We never saw or smelt anything, as the fire was to our north-west. Then the change happened. Everything went dark and suddenly the wind started coming in from everywhere. Within a couple of minutes, there was fire all around us."

Gusts lifted the aviary and dashed it onto the ground. Branches thudded against their hard hats. The fire rumbled loud as a train. Carlene kept the hose on the stables. John sprayed the house. Unbeknown to him, embers were gusting in through the gaps between the roof iron and the roof cap to land on the beds upstairs. Inside, Molly, bucket in hand, was onto it.

Thoughts of doom flashed through their heads. "I kept thinking, 'What am

I doing with my kids here?"" recalls Carlene. At one stage John crouched down next to the house and had to steel himself. "I thought, 'Holy shit, we're in trouble here.'" He ordered Carlene to give up on protecting the stable; they could only hope to save the house. But she wouldn't hear of it.

The battle lasted four hours. About 11pm, they judged themselves saved. They tried to ring out, but the phone line was dead. "We just sat there on the veranda and looked out at the devastation. It felt like we were the last people on earth," says Carlene.

Even now, John can't suppress an air of victoriousness. "We were prepared for the worst - you have to be, because it's like going to war," he says. "I like the 'stay or go' policy. My feeling is that if you're going to live in the bush, you have to take some level of responsibility. But it's not for everybody. If you need to think about whether you can cope with staying, you should go."

left early

Nick and Bonnie Lanham

There have been three years of drought since the Anakie fire, and the Brisbane Ranges are struggling toÂ recover. On the ridges, many of the trees still standÂ black and naked, and the koalas, once abundant, have yet to return. Along the southernmost escarpment, De Motts Road winds through a subdivision of about 20 bush blocks with fine views. A third are for sale, including the Lanhams' rebuilt home.

In the lead-up to the fire, Nick and Bonnie Lanham were among the very few De Motts Road residents who chose to leave early. Of their three neighbours, one stayed to fight, one stayed until his wife panicked and the third left just as flames began licking at the Lanhams' house, tucked among the box gums and ironbarks.

"We bought our house just six months before the fire," says Nick. "We didn't have a bushfire plan, because we hadn't really considered fire. We were living in blissful ignorance on our dream bush block. The neighbours told us there hadn't been a fire in 40 years, so we figured we'd be right."

Nick and Bonnie had left the previous night to stay with friends on the coast and complete a fun run in the morning. "We grabbed the dogs, computer and photo albums, just in case," says Nick, a paramedic. "The morning was way too hot to run, so we pulled out. We kept an ear out for news of the fire in the ranges. We heard it had broken containment lines and I was thinking of returning to do a little fire preparation. But it was hard to know what was going on because there was very little information coming our way."

All afternoon, black smoke billowed over Geelong, and the Lanhams fervently hoped their possessions weren't going up with it. About 5pm, as Bonnie drove Nick to work, they heard on the car radio that De Motts Road was under attack. Shortly afterwards, Nick heard from his neighbour's wife. Her husband had rung her to say he was abandoning his house and that it looked like the Lanhams had lost theirs. "We got back the next day," says Bonnie. "We lost the garage, two bedrooms, the bathroom and the laundry. A helicopter drop saved the main part of the house. Actually, our belongings suffered more damage from water than they did from fire."

They decided to rebuild. It took Nick three years. He cleared trees and used fire-resistant materials where possible. "We didn't plan on selling," he reflects. "I completed a bushfire awareness course online and we had fire extinguishers, a dam, a water tank, a pump, a fire hose and gutter covers.

"In the event of a fire our plan was that we would stick around to fight spot fires, but if it loomed as a front we'd leave. We figured it's a good road out and we'd be out of danger in two minutes.

"Then came Black Saturday. It put everything into perspective. Our plan didn't allow for something like that. We'd have been dead."

Russell Rees

CFA Chief

At 2pm in the control room on January 22, 2006, Russ Rees, chief of Victoria's CFA, received a call from his regional commander that the Anakie blaze was scaring his men and could not be stopped. Someone produced a map and drew a teardrop, representing the likely fire path. "That's a dangerous spot," the chief said, leaning in. "If it gets in there" - he pricked his pen at a spray of little black squares along De Motts Road - "that's a lot of people under threat."

Unconfirmed reports of houses ablaze started coming in an hour later, but it would be another eight hours before anyone knew whether there were people in them. Meanwhile, another five large fires were demanding his attention. Scores of teardrop maps were drawn that day. Predictions were continually being updated or discarded. Outgoing warnings were mostly educated guesses. Nobody really knew what was happening on the ground - a situation Rees calls "the fog of war".

On Black Saturday, what was being predicted could happen had often as not already happened. The fires were moving so fiercely and spotting so far ahead that incident controllers on the ground could no longer tell (a) whose incident it was, and (b) whether it was one or several incidents. The confusion in the field turned to chaos in the control room. Incoming reports (there were 600 reported fires that day) made little sense on the map. People thought in terms of teardrops when, in fact, they should have joined the dots - there were rabid, roiling dobs of fire coursing down the map on the big screen.

For Rees, who is fond of military analogies, it was "like the Battle of Britain. You know the planes are coming, but you don't know where ... It was a total bombardment, this totally erratic fire behaviour. We didn't know how bad Marysville was. There was nothing, no communication, going in and out. It was beyond imagining."

Rees has been criticised for his insistence in the face of a communications debacle that he had more troops on the ground than ever before, and that he was satisfied every one of those did his or her best. Indeed, his reappointment a few months later for another two years met with some surprise. However, it's likely the Premier, John Brumby, retained Rees not for his policy brain but for his pastoral role within the CFA. The organisation is part emergency service, part club, and no one knows this better than Rees, who, as a boy from a battler family in the Latrobe Valley, found solace and strength in Moe's junior fire brigade after losing his eldest brother when he was eight and his father when he was 14. At present, firefighters are nursing deep sensitivities inflicted not only by Black Saturday but by the ongoing Royal Commission. The Government knows this is not the time to ditch Rees. There is too much healing yet to be done.

Rees himself is still seeing a psychologist. "Black Saturday is with me the rest of my life. It's like losing a child or getting divorced or your parents dying. It will never, ever go away." But he is deeply aggrieved, too, by the reports that he has failed to protect Victorians.

"You have bad days. Days when you sit there and say, 'I'm sick of this crap.' You learn to build a shield around yourself. I don't read the papers any more. I don't watch the news. I'll have someone ... tell me if there's something I should know. Because it's all just too overwhelming. It would have been easy to quit. But part of my job is to hold the team together."

Rees stands by the "stay or go" policy. "Last summer very few people had very good, complete plans. 'Stay or go' wasn't just about saving houses. But it became just about houses. The message went from 'prepare, stay and defend, or leave early' to 'stay or go'. It kept being dumbed down. One day it was quoted to me as 'fight or flight'. Now, that's a response driven by adrenalin, which is the last thing we want.

"I sometimes think fire safety is as complicated as road safety. Look at the number of road safety campaigns, yetÂ we're trying to distil fire safety to a simple message. What we are trying to get through to people is that you areÂ vulnerable, your plan has to be solid. It has to cope with 100-plus days, and on those days it might be a different plan."

Rees says all other measures - fuel reduction, community refuges, improved messaging, bunkers, fire-safe powerlines and better policing against arson - can only be a part of a solution. "What I see is that Australians want to be in a position to make their own choices, but they don't want to be in a position where they have to take responsibility for those.

"We're living in a way that is riskier than what we realise. This is drought-affected country and it is permanently changing. What we've learnt is that we've got to put a lot more effort into the way we plan for that. Clearly education is not enough. We need wholesale behavioural change, and it may need regulatory control to get us there." But forced evacuations, California-style, remain off the table. "There's an element in the Australian psyche that says, 'We're not going to run, we're going to fight this bastard.' It's deep-seated in our culture."

Kevin Tolhurst

Fire Behaviour Expert

On Black Saturday, Kevin Tolhurst was in the control room at CFA headquarters. The fury of the fires north of Melbourne caught him byÂ surprise as much as anyone. Tolhurst, who'd been studying andÂ predicting fire behaviour since 1998, had spent most of the day concentrating on a large fire threatening Victoria's power supply in the Latrobe Valley and, like others in the room, went home late that night not knowing whole towns had been lost. Later he was to tell the Royal Commission that the energy emitted in the fires that day amounted to 1500Â Hiroshima bombs.

Tolhurst is highly critical of current Australian building standards. Under theÂ Australian Standard for Building in a Bushfire-Prone Environment, for instance, the scorched towns of Marysville, Strathewen and Kinglake were not deemed fire-prone, because the standards consider only the vegetation within 100 metres of the home.

"Anyone with fire behaviour knowledge knows that fires are acting on aÂ much larger scale," says Tolhurst. "Really you need to look at a radius of 10 kilometres to see how much threat you're under."

Tolhurst points out that much of Australian fire science, safety and design is based on relatively predictable fires that move as a front. But there are fires and there are firestorms. Hilly topography and certain forest types will intensify a fire's heat, but so, too, may the size of the fire itself. Allowed a run-up of a few hours, a fire will form a convection column that sucks in the surrounding air and heat, not just from the fire-front, but also from the burning fuel behind it.

Says Tolhurst: "As we saw on February 7, a convection column can create windspeeds of up to 120, 140, 180 kilometres an hour. So if you are hit by fire relatively early, in the first hour or two, then your chance of defending your property is much greater than if the fire has been going for three hours, when it might have a footprint of five or 10 kilometres across, being held together by a convection column. A megafire becomes so hot it can come atÂ you from almost any direction. So your house really has to be able to withstand not only fire but also cyclonic winds."

Tolhurst advocates a new ratings system that assesses individual homes for their "defendability", based on their location in the landscape as well asÂ on their construction. The ratings would broadly reflect the weather conditions up to which a house could be defended against wildfire. As an example, Tolhurst (who accompanied Good Weekend to Anakie) rates the Bakers' home highly, believing its box-like construction, small windows and bare yard make it defendable in the worst possible conditions. He's less confident about the Lanhams' house, rating it as defendable in the event of "severe" fire weather conditions, i.e., a fire danger index of up to 75, pending further improvements.

"I think the 'prepare, stay and defend or leave early' policy is largely a good one, but if we are going to expect people to take more responsibility for their own welfare, then it's not fire trucks we've got to provide them with, it's actually good information, good intelligence.

"People in fire-prone areas need to know what they're capable of and what their property can withstand." ï¿¼
