Steven is very young and very</p><p nitf:lede="true">successful".</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Connery, in Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade, plays Dr Henry</p><p nitf:lede="true">Jones, Indy's father, a wonderfully eccentric medieval scholar</p><p nitf:lede="true">in the tradition of real-life Victorian adventurer, Sir Richard</p><p nitf:lede="true">Burton.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> It was a role he jumped at, as much because he relished the</p><p nitf:lede="true">idea of playing Indiana's father as for the chance of working</p><p nitf:lede="true">with Spielberg whom Connery says he has known for "some years".</p><p>Connery who has worked with some of the greatest film directors</p><p>of all time in his long and illustrious career that spans 48</p><p>movies and includes films with Alfred Hitchcock (Marnie) and</p><p>John Huston (The Man who would be King) says: "I thought it</p><p>was a marvellous idea to introduce the father of Indiana Jones</p><p>and to show the son, or rather the boy, Indy, and what gave</p><p>him all that zip.</p><p> "I had known Steven for a number of years and I am a great</p><p>admirer of his and the chance to work with him I knew would</p><p>be bundles of fun and afterwards this proved to be the case.</p><p>I enjoyed working with him tremendously."</p><p> Connery gets impatient with Hollywood's establishment and Spielberg's</p><p>peers continual refusal to give Spielberg true acclaim or hand</p><p>out an Oscar.</p><p> Spielberg missed out on Oscars for E.T., the Color Purple and</p><p>in a surprise this year, received no major nominations for the</p><p>year's big smash hit, the innovative Who Framed Roger Rabbit,</p><p>which for the first time ever, mixed animation and life action</p><p>creating a whole new process.</p><p> When the Academy Awards again snubbed Spielberg, who produced</p><p>Roger Rabbit, Disney's boss, Jeff Katzenberg who financed the</p><p>film exasperatedly said: "We had</p><p>a running joke that our chances suffered from the three Ss</p><p>success, special effects and Spielberg." Said Connery: "I think there</p><p>is</p><p>quite a bit of envy of Spielberg. "I remember when John Huston made the</p><p>Man who Would be King</p><p>there was a screening in Los Angeles at the Directors' Guild</p><p>and I went with Michael Caine. We were sitting at the back and</p><p>we had this showing to what were supposedly our peers and all</p><p>those people who are part of this business.</p><p> "It was not a nice experience. The atmosphere was quite antagonistic.</p><p>Half way through the film my toes were crunched up in my shoes</p><p>and I was perspiring quite a bit."HE added: "I turned to Michael Caine and said: 'Do you think</p><p>this is as bad as I think it is?' And he said: 'It's worse.</p><p>It's appalling.'</p><p> "And we went to this thing afterwards at the house of John</p><p>Foreman who was the producer, and Jack Nicholson came and Peter</p><p>Bogdanovich and Cybill Shepherd and Ryan O'Neal.</p><p> "Ryan came up to us and said: 'Hey, it went terrific' and</p><p>I said: 'You must be joking. I thought it was dreadful. The</p><p>response.'</p><p> "That's when Jack Nicholson laughed and said: 'Well, you've</p><p>got to remember they booed the Cuckoo's Nest.' "</p><p> Connery shakes his head. "What does that mean? To me it means</p><p>there is something very wrong in Hollywood. It's some kind of</p><p>envy or something. I don't think you should share your films</p><p>with people who want to be so disagreeable and show it so apparently.</p><p> "And as far as Steven Spielberg is concerned it is envy."</p><p> Connery believes instead of snubbing or ignoring Spielberg</p><p>or dismissing his films as "special effects kiddie comics"</p><p>Hollywood should be behind him and encouraging him.</p><p> "He is still very young and he is going to make other movies</p><p>and when he ventures into other fields, such as the Empire of</p><p>the Sun and the Color Purple, somehow there seems to be this</p><p>real need in Hollywood to hit him with a big stick because all</p><p>his other movies have made so much money. What's wrong with</p><p>money? Particularly in America? In America they love money,</p><p>I thought.</p><p> "Everyone seems to think being financially successful is terrific</p><p>except where Steven is concerned. But why shouldn't he be financially</p><p>successful? Hitchcock's films - apart from a very few, one of them being</p><p>mine - made a lot of money."</p><p> According to Connery, Spielberg is a "terrific director".</p><p> "He is very good with visuals and he is a wonderful storyteller.</p><p>I think technically Steven is not as assured in the composition</p><p>of things as Hitchcock, but Hitchcock began as an art director,</p><p>therefore he was a painter and a conceptualist before and he</p><p>had visualised before Steven was even born.</p><p> "But remember Hitchcock and Huston were both making movies</p><p>into their 70s and 80s and how old is Spielberg now? Just 42.</p><p>So you have to give him more time and what Hollywood should</p><p>really be doing is encouraging him.</p><p> "Steven is trying to do a lot of things and I think he has</p><p>got a way to go, still, and he's got to understand certain things</p><p>about actors too, and other stuff. But that is understandable.</p><p>I think he's tremendous."</p><p> Connery says critics of Spielberg overlook his professionalism. "He</p><p>has film storyboards that block everything from A to Z,"</p><p>says Connery. "He and George Lucas know exactly what they want</p><p>to get before the movie is shot and they know every sequence</p><p>. So when we get on the set we shoot that and then if they find</p><p>some bits of business by the actors or some invention they have</p><p>themselves, a bit of improvisation on top, they will shoot that</p><p>as well, but Steven is already prepared and because of this</p><p>is able to give himself alternatives that can be used when they</p><p>get into the cutting room."CONNERY adds: "Steven is much more prepared than most people</p><p>realise. Like all really good directors he has piercing observation</p><p>of what to start a scene from, which may be missed by the general</p><p>public, but it is there and has the same brilliance of a John</p><p>Ford, a John Huston or a Hitchcock.</p><p> "Steven Spielberg is much more professionally prepared than</p><p>this kid who shoots comic book impressions that has arisen."</p><p> Spielberg, who finished shooting Indiana Jones and the Last</p><p>Crusade last August and has since worked on the movie with post-production</p><p>and editing, is about to start work on his newest film and</p><p>first truy adult love story, Always. It will star Richard Dreyfuss</p><p>and Holly Hunter, and is a remake of the 1943 Spencer Tracy-Irene</p><p>Dunne classic, A Guy Named Joe.</p><p> "This is the only remake I would ever consider directing myself,"</p><p>Spielberg says. "It is a story that touched my soul when I</p><p>was 14 years old and saw it on television and it was the second</p><p>movie that ever made me cry that didn't have a deer in it. It's</p><p>a reassuring story. It's about life and saying that while you're</p><p>here, do it while you can."</p><p> In the original, Joe, played by Tracy, was a World War II pilot</p><p>who is killed, but returns to earth as an invisible but influential</p><p>presence. Spielberg's film will update the storyline and centre</p><p>around the firefighters of Montana and Wyoming and when his</p><p>hero, Dreyfuss dies, it is in a forest fire. Spielberg already has</p><p>spectacular fire footage. When Yellowstone</p><p>National Park went up in flames last November Spielberg was</p><p>there shooting for two weeks as the inferno raged.</p><p> While Spielberg's movies have always been about love - love</p><p>of a child, love for an alien, love of sisters, father and son</p><p>love (as in Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade), buddy love</p><p>and brotherly love, Always is his first bona fide adult love</p><p>story.</p><p> "Yep," he says with a grin, "and I don't want it to be a</p><p>mushy gushy lip-lock love story. I think the best love stories</p><p>are about people we perceive as being just like us."</p><p> Which is why he says he has cast Richard Dreyfuss (his star</p><p>in Jaws and Close Encounters of the Third Kind) because he believes</p><p>Dreyfuss is the personification of everyman and he has chosen</p><p>Broadcast News star, Holly Hunter, because he believes she is</p><p>everywoman "feisty, smart and extremely opinionated."</p><p> Spielberg is keen to make movies that don't necessarily bear</p><p>his distinctive stamp - a melodramatic fantastic vision - and</p><p>he says he admires A Guy Named Joe's director Victor Fleming.</p><p> "He made that movie and Captains Courageous and Gone with</p><p>the Wind and the Wizard of Oz, but there is no such thing as</p><p>a quintessential Victor Fleming movie. He could adapt to any</p><p>story, any period any premise."</p><p> Spielberg says he has matured and while once he could not have</p><p>imagined directing a film like Martin Scorsese's Raging Bull,</p><p>now he says he can imagine it.</p><p> A movie buff and scholar, Spielberg not only studies early</p><p>movies and the works of Fleming, Capra, Huston and Hitchcock,</p><p>but is aware of new directors and upcoming talents.HE gave hot new directors like Robert Zemeckis (Roger Rabbit,</p><p>Back to the Future I, II and III - the last two currently being</p><p>filmed) their breaks, has pushed the writer of Moonstruck, John</p><p>Patrick Shanley, into the director's chair with the movie Joe</p><p>Versus the Volcano with Tom Hanks, and keeps a careful eye on</p><p>all movies that release each year.</p><p> Of 1988, Steven Spielberg believes the best movie was Fred</p><p>Schepisi's A Cry in the Dark, based on the Lindy Chamberlain</p><p>story.</p><p> "It was an underrated movie with a new form of storytelling,"</p><p>he says.</p><p> Then he grins. "But I also saw Lawrence of Arabia at the end</p><p>of 1988 and that puts it all in perspective. That film in its</p><p>original form made me want to go back to film school."</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>2 photos: harrison ford, sean connery iin a scene fromindiana jones and the last crusade; steven spielberg; Steven Spielberg snubbe; Harrison Ford and Sean Connery inIndiana Jones and the Last Crusade criticism for directorSteven urn:contentItem:4P8H-NVV0-TXN5-S194-00000-00Old man Indonesia1997-12-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:50:12ZLexisNexisNEWS EXTRAPg. 6Old man IndonesiaSUCCEEDING SUHARTOLouise Williams

THE INFORMAL network of mobile phones was buzzing with rumors across the banking district of Jakarta as the rupiah plunged: President Suharto was seriously ill, troops were massing on the outskirts of the capital, a military coup was in the offing, bank accounts were about to be frozen and the country's biggest companies were on the brink of loan default.

Three decades of economic growth have rapidly been wiped off money and stockmarkets as confidence collapses, with drastic consequences for unemployment, inflation, stability and, probably, the political system itself. Official Government statements explain only that Suharto has been resting after suffering from "exhaustion" during an extended overseas tour. But diplomats and insiders believe the 76-year-old leader had suffered a slight stroke and continues to be plagued by kidney and blood-pressure problems.

There has been no coup attempt, the usually aloof armed forces felt compelled to announce, adding they were ready to handle any breakdown in social order that the deep economic crisis may trigger.

The rupiah and the stockmarket rallied moderately when Suharto made his first public appearance on Thursday morning to address new military graduates. His voice was slow and his speech short.

But already deep questions about Indonesia's future were being publicly posed.

The terms were vague and the debates carefully worded, as they usually are in a nation where such an ordinary act as forming a new political party can be punished as treason.

But the meaning was clear. The political and economic pyramid that Suharto has skilfully built, with himself at the apex, must be reformed for Indonesia to survive.

So personalised has power become under Suharto that the economic survival of a nation is linked to the health of one man, says an analyst of the rupiah's collapse.

Suharto has not anointed a successor, nor put into place reforms that would even begin to accommodate the growing pressures for democratisation and justice.

The process of politics in modern Indonesia is still played out behind the scenes, much as it was in the old fiefdoms of the Javanese kings. Like the Javanese shadow puppets, only the outlines of the characters can be seen as they battle their way through the minefield of intrigues in their quest for power in the royal courts.

What the financial markets fear in the long term is not the inevitable ill-health or death of an ageing leader, but the vacuum he would leave behind, which throws into question the viability of the political model.

"Good governance cannot be established upon one person's goodwill," says scholar Nurcholish Madjid.

He says Indonesia must abandon the model of state leadership under one man.

Muslim leader Abdurrahman Wahid, says: "There is a very deep change. People now see that the end of the President's rule is not a possibility, but an imperative."

The Petition of 50, a group of former senior officials of the Suharto Government, emerged to make a statement: "President Suharto took office promising democratic reforms. But in fact the people's sovereignty was ignored and the nation is ruled in an authoritarian way without effective political and social control."

In a nation that has regarded Suharto as unshakeable, a man of power beyond that of an ordinary politician, the possessor of the special protection of the "pulung", such criticism has been taboo.

But, on Thursday a group of university students in Yogyakarta symbolically circumvented the closed political system and called their own referendum: the question was simple. Should Suharto lead Indonesia into a seventh term when presidential elections are held next March?

"We have taken a quantum leap in uncertainty. There is not just disquiet, there is real anxiety," says one diplomat.

"Everything is hidden behind smoke screens and mirrors. There is now a direct relationship between the market and rumors . . .

"Look around the region, everywhere there is some kind of plan for the future and public debate over dealing with the economic crisis. In Indonesia, the future is just a black hole," says one economist.

Asia's economic crisis started in Thailand with the collapse of the Thai baht. One by one the nations around the region fell to the so-called contagion effect. Indonesia, much praised for its strong economic fundamentals, held on for a month by using its reserves to prop up the rupiah before it allowed the currency to slide.

Like Thailand, Indonesia's private sector had chalked up an overwhelming short-term United States dollar debt while riding on the crest of optimism after three decades of growth. The further the rupiah fell against the US dollar, the bigger that debt became in rupiah terms.

The more rupiah Indonesian corporates were forced to spend to buy US dollars to pay their debts, the faster the rupiah fell. The bigger the debt burden became, the more nervous foreign and domestic investors felt, and so the house of cards fell down. The Indonesian rupiah lost up to 58 per cent of its value in less than six months, becoming the worst performing currency in the world.

The market capitalisation of the Jakarta stockmarket was about $US100 billion ($A151 billion) in June this year, but had fallen to $US23 billion by last week, according to C. J. Koning, country manager of the ABN-AMR0 Bank.

Corporate Indonesia, he says, owes $US43 billion over the next year, or $US3.6 billion a month. Technically, the stockmarket is already bankrupt, its market capitalisation considerably less than its debt burden.

In October the International Monetary Fund announced a $US38 billion rescue package to help the Suharto Government arrest the slide and win back confidence. The IMF also came with demands for reform.

But those reforms challenged the dark side of Indonesia's economic growth. Under Suharto, political and economic power have become so entangled that the policy-makers in the Government are closely entwined with the business elite.

To attack corruption, nepotism and the lack of transparency in the Indonesian economy, Suharto must reign in an extensive network of his own relatives and allies who have gained considerable economic benefit under his leadership. Observers say he has clearly failed to do that.

"The Government hasn't even announced the details of the IMF package; it hasn't given the market any sense of commitment to reforms," says one diplomat.

"Indonesian markets have been going down faster than anywhere else; people are tearing down their economic forecasts."

Already, he says, Indonesia was facing a "corporate bloodbath" next year thanks to maturing debts, spiralling inflation, widespread lay-offs and a "real wage reduction" for those who manage to keep their jobs. This week Standard and Poor's revised its growth projections for Indonesia down to minus-5 per cent next year.

One economist recently estimated that the economic crisis could push the number of Indonesians living in abject poverty from 24 million to 42 million, and average annual family income from $US1200 to $US750.

In an ordinary year this would have been devastating enough. But this year, Indonesia has struggled through a drought and forest fire crisis wrought by the strong El Nino pattern. The planting of crops has been delayed, starvation is threatening isolated tribal communities and poor villagers have already sold their animals to pay for water.

These tragedies have taken on great significance to many who believe in the power of the pulung of Javanese mysticism. The 1000-year-old prophecy of Joyoboyo tells of five modern Javanese "kings", of which Suharto is says to the second.

The prophecy warns of terrible calamities if the morality of the nation is lost and corruption and greed gains the upper hand.

The five kings are all male, explained one mystic practitioner. Yet, Suharto has promoted his eldest daughter, Tutut, as a political leader, and some say he is trying to alter fate.

"To people who believe in this balance President Suharto has already committed the sin of challenging the cosmic process of Java and hence all the disasters."

For those who believe in the more pedestrian science of politics there are the three political foundations of Suharto's New Order: stability, growth, equity.

For decades Suharto has justified strict controls on political opposition in the name of economic development. One of the basic tenets, equity, was already seriously challenged in the high-growth years as the wealth gap widened alarmingly. As growth falters, stability is also likely to be threatened.

Under the tarpaulin of the sidewalk noodle stall, the air is thick and humid. The muddy ground is littered with trash. The steam from the soup vat mingles with fumes from passing cars, weaving their way through the factory belt on Jakarta's outskirts.

Across the road is a textile factory where 3000 workers demonstrated earlier this week, marching on the local Parliament to demand fairer wages. For a 13-hour day, says one worker perched on a wooden bench, they receive about 150,000 rupiah a fortnight (about $A44).

But prices are going up. The currency crisis and the impact of the drought are already being felt. Rice, say the soup stall customers, has gone up 30 per cent; cooking oil more than 100 per cent; chilli, 40 per cent. "We can't put up the prices of the soup because people can't pay, so we just earn less and less," says the vendor.

Around here, they say, at least four factories have already closed. In Jakarta alone two million casual workers in the construction sector have lost their jobs, 16,000 more in banks that have been closed, 30,000 in textile factories, 23,000 in the forestry industry and countless more in small businesses that escape the attention of the Manpower Ministry.

Angry workers, hungry villagers and a middle class that has seen its gains disappear into ballooning mortgages and spiralling prices makes for a volatile mix in a nation which has already seen two years of sporadic rioting.

Western embassies in Jakarta say they expect outbreaks of violence around factory closures as well as the expected non-payment of bonus for the Muslim new year, which falls in mid-January. But, decades of living within an authoritarian system under a Government that cannot be voted out of power has created myriad tensions below the surface.

The expansion of plantation developments controlled by the political elite, has, for example, forced tens of thousands of small farmers off the land. While the rich have won a five-star lifestyle of shiny new shopping malls, Mercedes and lavish weddings, the average Indonesian has made comparatively moderate gains under Suharto.

Social envy between the rich and poor is already brewing and only likely to intensify as the economic crisis bites.

Power, too, has corrupted the bureaucracy and the justice system. Bribes are routinely demanded for the most basic services, such as identity cards and school places, and the courts offer little justice to the ordinary citizen.

"My fear is that there will be an increasing demand for change, increasing economic hardship, and an elite which wants to hold on to power. Then there will be a real clash," says political analyst Dewi Fortuna Anwar.

"There is a desire for reform, but there is an unwillingness to face the fact that if you want reform you have to change the team leader. There is a fear of radical change here."

Many analysts have long argued that the memory of the trauma of the fall of President Sukarno in 1965 and the carnage that followed in which up to 500,000 people died serves as a break for social upheaval.

Wahid says: "There will be deepening militancy on the part of labor; everywhere there will be sporadic strikes, boycotts and protests. The harsh reality is that if the Government fails to end the economic crisis there will be violence from both sides - the people and the military.

"Violence now is unavoidable. We just have to try to limit the damage."

But he says the increasing scope of public protests means the military will be unable to defend the status quo and will be forced to negotiate with the people; at some time in the future, the process of democratisation in Indonesia must begin.

Photo: Lacking energy: President Suharto, now aged 76, has been largely out of public view recently, suffering from what Indonesian Government officials assert is exhaustion only. Picture: AP

urn:contentItem:5572-PP91-JD34-V4H1-00000-00How to survive on the Internet1996-08-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:50:12ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1How to survive on the InternetBeverley Head

The rush of business to the Internet gathers pace, but managements must quickly separate the hype from the hope, writes Beverley Head.

Big businesses will probably have to rip apart and rebuild their corporate structures to take full advantage of the Internet. That's the most recent advice of business analysts, who also warn that for every reward the Net promises, there is an associated risk.

Byram Johnson, vice-president of AT Kearney, says: "The Internet is hyped up significantly. We advise clients to advance with a level of caution."

He even says the Internet could be dangerous if companies race into it without considering its role in their overall corporate strategy.

Although McKinseys believes electronic commerce will become significant, it warns that businesses might have to cannibalise themselves to gain full advantage.

Early examples of this corporate cannibalism include The Wall Street Journal, which now offers an online version of the newspaper that costs less than the printed paper; the Australian Stock Exchange's live share quote feed, which can be accessed over the Internet free by anyone who uses OzEmail's access service; and News Corp oration and Fairfax , which have put their classified advertising - the "rivers of gold" - on the Net, where they can be read free of charge.

Although these exercises may appear self-defeating, they have been designed by management to expand the business by tapping new markets rather than damaging core ones.

There are probably as many views of the commercial benefits of the Internet as there are viewers. McKinseys, for example, believes electronic commerce will be the route into a new and dynamic market for many companies. AT Kearney views the Internet as a weapon to force overhauls of the supply chain. Bach Consulting believes it will liberate organisations from conventional industry structures. To the next crop of management consultants now in business school, the Internet will be just another scalpel for corporate surgery - in the right hands it will reform and enhance, but in the wrong hands will disfigure.

More than a third of Australia's chief executives have already used the Internet, according to a study released last week by The Executive Connection. Over the next year though, a full three-quarters of the CEO population expects to be online.

A quarter of the 265 CEOs who responded to the survey expected the Internet could improve their bottom line, and a fifth had already set up Web sites.

But analysts lament the lack of Internet strategic vision coming from Mahogany Row.

A slow burn for the first 20 years of its existence, in the past 12 months the Internet has become a forest fire, with protagonists predicting a billion people online by 2000.

Captains of industry are bombarded by a business media obsessed by the Net; they watch the competition race to establish Web sites; their technologists mutter darkly about internal intranets and virtual corporations; electronic commerce and digital cash is raised in polite conversation; and all the while the marketing department dreams up new products targeted at the embryonic cyber-marketplace.

There's no escape at home where teenagers are tuned in online.

As Fred Steingraber, chief executive of AT Kearney, puts it: "The Internet has a ways to go. But I don't think you can deny it is out there and working."

McKinseys believes electronic commerce, which will increasingly be underpinned by the Internet, will be important - but also demand corporate reorganisation.

In its latest quarterly the firm published a paper by Lorraine Harrington and Greg Reed from its Silicon Valley and Toronto offices respectively, which notes: "Success will involve piloting new approaches, mastering new technologies, challenging conventional market definitions, surviving an initial period of low revenues and perhaps cannibalising core businesses. But the potential rewards are great; a new platform and set of tools for competing in a new and dynamic marketplace."

The big question facing business is when will all these riches materialise? A company which cannibalises itself too soon may find itself without a leg to stand on.

Wayne Madsen wouldn't use his credit card on the Internet. He might not use his real name. He harbours serious concerns about net security and cyber stalkers.

But Wayne Madsen isn't just the consuming public, he's a leading expert on data security and the Internet, head scientist at Computer Sciences Corporation, and author of the Handbook of Personal Data Protection.

Wayne Madsen knows a cybertrick or two, but if even he won't risk doing much business on the Internet, who else will?

Certainly not purchasers of information, according to market research company Forrester Research, which has warned content publishers not to expect any return on the Internet until the turn of the century. In fact most stand to lose millions before they turn the corner, according to Forrester.

But as Madsen confirms: "The genie is out of the bottle." New security systems are being developed, communications carriers are expanding bandwidth, and the online population is growing fast. It is a rare corporation which is completely ignoring the Internet, even if it is only to create a Web site.

In Australia the most obvious manifestation of the corporate rush to the Internet is in the number of Web sites established in the .com.au domain. Such has been the demand for domains that the system now in place to issue them is fraying at the edges.

There are 7,300 domain names registered in the .com.au space, and a further 1,000 in the .net.au area, giving an inkling of the corporate demand for Web addresses.

Sanjay Kumar, president and chief operating officer of Computer Associates, considers the Web site frenzy as driven by "herd mentality". Chief executives were being subject to a "very compressed wave of hype" about the Internet, he says.

"Everywhere you're looking it's there, whether it's happening or not," according to Kumar, who believes that chief information officers are rushing to put Internet plans in place to satisfy management seduced by coverage of the Internet in newspapers

and glossy magazines.

But Fred Steingraber believes that the best current application for Internet technologies is not necessarily to set up a Web site - which some analysts describe as a billboard in the outback - but to integrate the Internet with the corporate supply chain. By tightening up the supply chain it might be possible to cut product lifecycles, eliminate middlemen and reduce risk, he argues, rather that than "pushing things out through the Internet and hoping people will buy".

Over time Steingraber believes more and more virtual companies will emerge, partly thanks to the integration which the Internet affords. And there would be more mass customisation - or "particle marketing" - such as that being offered through technology systems in the US where Levis offers every customer a made-to-measure jeans-making service.

Bach Consulting, a small firm established by a pair of ex-McKinsey analysts in North Sydney earlier this year, is focusing on providing business analysis for companies which are considering how they can leverage off the Internet.

Partner Julian Fairfield claims the arrival of Internet business will upset traditional business models where industry structures have tended to control business profits more than managerial capabilities.

He warns though that the "Internet will cause instability in many industries ... this will allow capable management to reposition industry structure and their relative position to improve profitability".

Dr Rony Attar, also a Bach partner, and a former chief information officer with the State Bank of NSW, confirms the Internet as "not just a delivery mode; it's a new way of doing business". But he laments that today's Internet strategies too rarely come from chief executive officers but are being driven by IT, product managers or marketing departments.

Summerfield agrees: "I don't know of any chief executive officers thinking strategically about this."

Again though, when to move?

"You can be two years too early or two years too late, and if you're two years too late then you're dead," according to Fairfield. One of the problems he envisages is overcoming the political barriers involved in cannibalising the current way of doing business.

Summerfield argues the case for "skunkworks": new teams of people set up solely to explore Internet opportunities, who worked independently of current business structures, were unfettered by emotional attachments to "the way we've always done it" and

reported only to the top brass.

As success stories emerge and Internet scepticism abates, skunkworks will be replaced by converted middle management who will be able to recognise how Internet levers can be used to grow or improve a business.

That could even be the case by the time the next generation of Australian management consultants emerges from the MBA course at the Australian Graduate School of Management.

This will be the first wave of dyed-in-the-wool Internet converts to enter the consulting community. In the past year the proportion of their research queries over the Internet has risen from noise level to a third. Two of the three final-year management projects are on the Internet.

By the time those graduates filter through to Mahogany Row, the Internet will be much more than a technological curiosity.

Today though the AGSM cautions that there are very few commercial successes on the Internet.

"Those that are (successful) have been around for a while and have spent a lot of money doing it well," said the AGSM's manager of computing and IT services, Dr Geoffrey Gordon.

Asked what companies ought to be doing today about the Internet, associate professor Simon Sheather, director of the MBA program, recommends the purchase of a crystal ball.

"It is just too early to say. If you are a multinational service where information is key then the Internet is a crucial part of your business," he said.

"In total quality management where you need to be close to your customers then you can use (Internet) feedback to improve your processes."

But there were no silver bullets.

In an increasingly global business community, where banks will have to compete with their US-based Internet-enabled peers, where small software houses are able to compete successfully with the giants of the business by selling online, and where content is available quickly and inexpensively, the challenge for big business to separate the hype from the hope is real.

WHAT'S IN - THE INTRANET

In the beginning was the Internet - a global network of computer networks, all hanging together using a communications standard called Internet protocol, which allowed information to be bounced from computer to computer.

Corporations also have computer networks - in some cases hundreds of different computer networks, often located in other regions, or other countries.

Smart information managers have recognised that if the Internet model worked for the public, then the technologies could also be harnessed to create a private network.

And so it was that the intranet developed.

The Australian Graduate School of Management's manager of computing and IT services, Dr Geoffrey Gordon, believes intranets potentially have more early benefits for business than the Internet.

Far less politically challenging to implement, intranets can provide a clear demonstration of the potential of the technology, while keeping core business intact.

It is a view shared by Computer Associate president Sanjay Kumar, who says that the medium-to-large business in North America which is not developing an intranet application is a rarity today as corporations seize on the economic benefits of the application.

Governments too: in Queensland the State is running a central Government Intranet pilot to gauge the benefits of the technology.

Forrester Research interviewed more than 60 per cent of the Fortune 1,000 recently and they said that traffic using Internet communications protocols within two years will eclipse all other traffic on local area networks.

Says Dr Gordon: "Intranets can be introduced in a subtle and inexpensive way," in contrast to Internet projects which increasingly tend to be large and expensive.

"The extension of that (intranet strategy) then to the Internet is almost transparent," he said.

AGSM Associate Professor Simon Sheather believes that one of the earliest useful applications for corporations which Internet technologies allow is in targeted database marketing - but again an application that falls back more onto intranets than to the Internet.

Over time though, the corporate databases could be enhanced through closer connection to the end customer, by creating an Internet link.

KPMG's global link-up - page 39

urn:contentItem:4580-9TW0-0197-51R2-00000-00<published>2000-01-08T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:50:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>REVIEW; Pg. R18</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Trans Siberia</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Colin Thubron</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Colin Thubron describes a segment of his landmark journey through the icy wastes of no-man's-land</p><p nitf:lede="true">ON either side of the railway to Omsk, the wheat fields shimmered in huge rectangles and fescue grass spread a pinkish sheen over the pasturelands. In this immense sameness, isolated things -- a duck pond, a well, a horse cart -- took on a lonely piquancy. I gazed with relief at terrain empty of coal or ruins, whose mounds were natural. A luxurious sense of freedom welled up. For the first time in Russia's history, a foreigner could wander Siberia at will. At any little town where I stopped, I might alight and disappear, nursing my business visa -- a scruffy paper inscribed with pro forma destinations -- against police intrusion.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The exhilaration of this freedom never quite left me. Whenever I pulled out my map and imagined entering the mountains abutting Mongolia or taking a ship up the Yenisei river to the Arctic, I would be hit by euphoria, then disbelief. Something or someone would surely prevent me. That was how Russia had always been. I had slipped through a transient gap in the country's age-old xenophobia.</p><p>The faintly clownish name of Omsk precedes the city with a light-hearted expectation. It lies where the railway crosses the Irtysh on a massive cantilever bridge and you see the curve of the river under a line of stooping derricks as it heads out among sandy islets and meadows, touching the city with an illusion of peace. But beyond, the suburbs bristle with petrochemical plants, textile combines and oil refineries, and the pollution is so thick that driving at night has sometimes been forbidden. They sprawl for kilometres above the river. Marx Prospect, Lenin Square, Partisan Street: the veteran names follow one another in relentless procession.</p><p> Yet the city keeps a modest distinction. Whereas World War II razed western Russian towns to the ground, in Siberia, untouched, they often attain a formal grandeur or rustic exuberance and seem older than they are. I wandered the streets in surprise. The municipal flowerbeds were all in bloom and fountains played between provincial ministries. Close above the river, 19th-century streets dipped and swung in icing-sugar facades. The air in the parks clattered with pop music. Clusters of miniskirted girls paraded their irregular beauty and children strolled with their parents in sleepy obedience; but their jeans and T-shirts were stamped with stars-and-stripes or Donald Duck. Every other pair of shoes or trousers sported a pirated Western logo. Fast-food restaurants had arrived, offering instant pelmeni -- the Siberian ravioli -- or anonymous steaks with stale mash, and a rash of small shops and kiosks had appeared, selling the same things.</p><p> Yet a feeling of boredom, or of waiting, pervaded the city. All style and music, the new paths of paradise seemed synthetic, borrowed. Real life remained on hold. The pop songs had the scuttling vitality of streams. The bus shelters and underpasses, stinking of urine, were rife with graffiti: "Pomponius Nautilus -- I love you! … Agatha Christie! Sepulchre! The Prodigy!" It took me time to realise that these were pop groups; other graffiti followed them, sometimes scrawled in English, the lingua franca of youth. "Jim Morrison lives! No!… I f...ed the bitch! … Communists are all buggers." Then, in Russian, enigmatically: "Why travel with a corpse? … The point of life is to ponder the cross on your grave."</p><p> Outside the big, unlovely cathedral, which in Stalin's day had been a cinema, I found a coach-load of pilgrims setting off for a rural monastery. They welcomed me on board. The monastic foundations were only just being laid, they said, and they were going to attend the blessing of its waters. In 1987 an excavator at the site -- near the state farm of Rechnoi -- had unearthed a mass grave and the place was revealed as a complex of labour camps, abandoned on Stalin's death. The inmates, mostly intelligentsia, had died of pneumonia and dysentery from working in the fields, and their graves still scattered its earth.</p><p> As our bus bowled through ramshackle villages, the pilgrims relayed the story with murmurs of motherly pity. They were elderly women for the most part, indestructible babushkas in flower-printed dresses and canvas shoes, whose gnarled hands were closed over prayer books and bead strings, and whose headscarves enshrined faces of genial toughness. When a fresh-faced cantor began chanting a hymn in the front of the bus, their voices rose in answer one after another, like old memories, reedy and melodious from their heavy bodies, until the whole bus was filled with their singing.</p><p> We reached a birch grove on the Rechnoi farm. It was one of those ordinary rural spots whose particular darkness you would never guess. As the women disembarked, still singing, the strains of other chanting echoed from a chapel beyond the trees. It was the first of four shrines that would one day stake out the corners of an immense compound. Inside, a white-veiled choir was lilting the sad divisions of the liturgy. As the pilgrims visited their favourite icons, a forest fire of votive candle-flames sprang up beneath the iconostasis, and two or three babushkas shuddered to their knees.</p><p> In the south transept, meshed in scaffolding, an unfinished fresco of the Deposition from the Cross loomed above us. It was almost complete but the flesh tints were still missing, as if the artist was afraid to touch too closely on divinity, and pots of pigment lined the scaffold.</p><p> So only the painted garments of the disciples semaphored their grief, while their hands and features were empty silhouettes in the plaster: here a face uplifted in dismay, there a blank caress on the unpainted body of Christ -- which remained a ghostly void, like something the onlookers had imagined.</p><p> Sometimes, whimsically, I felt as if this scene were echoed in the nave where I stood, where around the great silence left by God the worshippers lifted their heads and hands, crossed themselves and wept a little.</p><p> From outside came the squeal of bulldozers in a distant field. They were smoothing the earth of the labour camps into monastery foundations. I strained to catch the sounds, but our singing drowned them in the mournful decrescendos of the Russian rite. And out of the mouths of these ancient women -- whose sins, I imagined, could barely exceed a little malicious gossip -- rose the endless primal guilt, "O Lord forgive us!" -- over and over, as if from some deep recess in the national psyche, a need for helplessness.</p><p> The sanctuary curtains parted on an incense-clouded region inhabited by a small priest. His hair shimmered down in a phantasmal jumble, like a Restoration wig, and melted into a droop of violet-clad shoulders. Occasionally, feebly, one of his arms swung a censer; in the stillness between responses, its coals made a noise like suppressed laughter. As he intoned the prayers he constantly forgot or lost his place, until his chanting dithered into confusion and three deacons in raspberry robes prompted his responses with slips of paper. He would peer at these through enormous spectacles stranded in his hair like the eyes of a lemur and try again. But the cause of his panic was plain to see. Enthroned beside him, giant and motionless, sat Feodosy, Archbishop of Omsk.</p><p> Towards noon a procession unwound from the church and started across the pasturelands towards the unblessed waters. It moved with a shuffling, dislocated pomp. Behind its uplifted cross, whose gilded plaques wobbled unhinged, the archbishop advanced in a blaze of turquoise and crimson, his globular crown webbed in jewels. He marked off each stride with the stab of a dragon-headed stave and his chest glinted with purple and gold embossed frontlets, and a clash of enamelled crosses. He looked huge. Beside him went the quaint, dishevelled celebrant, and behind tripped a huddle of young priests in mauve and the trio of raspberry-silk deacons.</p><p> I fell in line with the pilgrims following. It was oddly comforting. An agnostic among believers, I felt close to them. I, too, wanted their waters blessed. I wanted that tormented earth quietened, the past acknowledged and shriven. I helped the old woman beside me carry her bottles. My feeling of hypocrisy, of masquerading in others' faith, evaporated. As I took her arm over the puddles and our procession stretched across the wet grass, Russia's atheist past seemed no more than an overcast day in the long Orthodox summer and the whole country appeared to be reverting instinctively, painlessly, to its old nature.</p><p> We reached a place where a silver pipe, propped on an old lorry tyre, was spilling warm water into a pool. A blond deacon like a Nordic Christ planted the processional cross on the far side and the archbishop, the priests, acolytes and pilgrims, the babushkas with their bags and bottles, a few war veterans and one mesmerised foreigner formed a wavering crescent round the water's rim.</p><p> The unkempt celebrant, clutching a jewelled cross, was ordered to wade in. From time to time he glanced up pathetically at Feodosy, who gave no signal for him to stop. Deeper and deeper he went, while his vestments fanned out over the surface, their mauve silk waterlogged to indigo, until he was spread below us like an outlandish bird over the pool. At last Feodosy lifted his finger. The priest floundered, gaped up at us -- or at the sky -- in momentary despair, recovered his balance and went motionless. Then, with a ghostly frown, he traced a trembling cross beneath the water.</p><p> A deep, collective sigh seemed to escape the pilgrims. Again the cavalcade unfurled around the pool while the archbishop, grasping a silver chalice, sprinkled the surface with its own water and the wobbly cross led the way back towards the noise of the bulldozers.</p><p> But the babushkas stayed put. As the procession glimmered and died through the darkness of the trees, and the archbishop went safely out of sight, a new excitement brewed up. They began to peel off their thick stockings and fling away their shoes. They were all ready. They tugged empty bottles labelled Fanta or Coca-Cola from their bags. Then they clambered and slid down the muddy banks and waded into the newly blessed water. At first they only scooped it from the shallows. It was mineral water, muddied and warm. They drank in deep gulps from their cupped hands and winched themselves back to stow the bottles on shore.</p><p> Then it all went to their heads. Six or seven old women flung off first their cardigans, then their kerchiefs and skirts, until at last, stripped down to flowery underpants and bras, they made headlong for the waters. All inhibition was lost. Their massive legs, welted in varicose veins, carried them juddering down the banks. Their thighs tapered to small, rather delicate feet. Little gold crosses were lost between their breasts. They plunged mountainously in. I stood above them in astonishment, wondering if I was meant to be here. But they were shouting and jubilant. They cradled the water in their hands and dashed it over their faces. Holiness had turned liquid, palpable. You could drink it, drown in it, bring it home like flowers for the sick.</p><p> Two of the boldest women -- cheery, barrel-chested ancients -- made for the gushing silver pipe and thrust their heads under it. They sloshed its torrent exultantly over one another, then submerged in it and drank it wholesale. They shouted at their friends still on land, until one or two of the young girls lifted their skirts and edged in. Bottle after bottle was filled and lugged to shore. But it was the young, not the old, who hesitated. The old were in high spirits. One of them shouted at me to join them, but I was caught between laughter and tears. These were women who had survived the Stalin years, the deprivation, the institutional suffering, into a life of widowhood and breadline pensions, and their exuberance struck me dumb. Perhaps in this sacred and chaotic waterhole the world seemed finally to make sense to them and all this aching, weary flesh at last found absolution.</p><p> The procession, meanwhile, had reached the open fields where the bulldozers worked. All the way to the future cathedral, which would stand in the compound's heart, the tarred pipes lay ready alongside their trenches, and the channel was blessed. I caught up with the remaining pilgrims clustered in the big meadows, beside the ghost cathedral. There Feodosy, above the lonely swing of a censer, blessed the site "where nameless thousands had laboured and died", and we stared across fields lacquered in blue and white flowers while the incense vanished over them.</p><p> When we arrived back at the chapel, we found a long table in the shade, laden with salads and jams. The babushkas had returned. Their hands were ready beside their soup plates in two ranks of sun-cracked knuckles and broken nails. The archbishop, presiding at the head, commanded me to sit beside him -- "We have a guest from England!" he boomed. "We must make him welcome!" -- and I looked down an avenue of nodding heads, which turned to gaze at me as one and murmured: "England … England." Their cheeks bunched into smiles, and faltering lines of teeth parted in welcome.</p><p> Feodosy pounded the table with a bottle. "This is for you!" he said. "It's our monastery water! It cures everything!" The babushkas crossed themselves and commended me to God. They looked deeply respectable. Nobody would have guessed that half an hour before they had been ducking one another half-naked in a waterhole. Yet under the benches their bags bulged with bottles of holy water and they were sitting becalmed, almost smug, in the warmth of their success.</p><p> This is an edited extract from In Siberia by Colin Thubron (Random House, $49.95 hbk). Courtesy of Random House, we have 10 copies to give away to readers. Put your name and address on the back of an envelope and send to: Siberia Giveaway, PO Box 293, Strawberry Hills, NSW 2013. The first 10 entries drawn at random will each win a copy.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4P84-PTW0-TXN5-S2DY-00000-00In the line of fire1996-03-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:50:12ZLexisNexisAGENDAPg. 3In the line of fireLarry Schwartz

As summer fades without a Black Friday or Ash Wednesday, the state's biggest volunteer body breathes easier. Larry Schwartz reports.

NOOJEE. The word means contentment to Aborigines, a disarmingly benign name for a town in the forests of towering mountain ash east of Melbourne's sprawl. Here Les Hubbard learnt to relish the bush life. And to be vigilant.

Then came Ash Wednesday.

Nothing he'd seen in decades of answering the call of the town's fire brigade prepared him for what lay ahead as he set out that day, in February 1983, at the wheel of a tanker carrying two tonnes of water.

The fires at Mount Macedon, Belgrave, Cockatoo, Upper Beaconsfield, Lorne, Anglesea, Trentham, Woodend, Warburton, Powelltown and Airey's Inlet claimed 46 lives and more than 1700 homes.

Those with memories of the pungent smell of burnt timber, of smoke, flame and confusion, know of the consuming helplessness when up against the most feared natural disaster in Australia.

Tall, bespectacled, with grey-white hair, Les Hubbard, 74, was then captain of the Noojee CFA brigade. He could not know that within hours he'd be standing within metres of the flames, the air thick with cinders and heat so intense it was "like opening a furnace door". That he'd be gasping for the little oxygen in the air, a wet handkerchief about his nose and mouth.

He had thought it was going to be a typical forest fire until, while out in the bush helping Forest Commission workers, he heard radio reports that Powelltown, to the west, had been evacuated and that two police were fighting the flames on the outskirts of Noojee. He headed back to town to help them.

Hours later, he was in one of two police vehicles near the town when fire swept across the road behind them and cut them off. They tried to radio back but got no response.

FOR a moment, he stood stunned by the extent of the conflagration about him, watching trees aflame, burning branches dropping to the ground, wondering if he would make it back alive.

"It's terrifying," he says. "It's not just a fire. You go out on some of these fires, half the time it's burned out by the time you get there.

"When you're in the front line of it you've got to think pretty clearly. You can't just rush into it. You've got to get yourself together and sort out what you're going to do.

How to get out of the bloody place." He laughs. "It sounds funny now but it wasn't at the time."

He told the police that their best option was to drive back in the direction of the fire. The safest path was through the already charred terrain. "The boys that were with me, they didn't like the idea of going back into it. But I said, `Well, you can do what you like but I'm off. I started walking'.

It wasn't long before they were right behind me."

They drove over blackened earth, using a chainsaw to clear the fallen trees that blocked their way. It took 10 hours - from 1am to 11am the next day - to cover the few kilometres back to town.

At one point, the firefighter remembered an Esky a local woman had given him. He shared the sandwiches and a bottle of hot beer. "It was warm but, I tell you what, it was thirst quenching," he says. "What water you've got you've got to try and hang on to. That little water might save your life.

" American author Stephen J. Pyne has written of the way in which fire in Australia has been "absorbed into the subconscious".

"Its smoke haunted memories. Its flames lit nightmares. The bushfire was part of indigenous Australia that would remain forever alien and unassimilable," he says in `Burning Bush', a recent history of fire in Australia.

About 75,000 Victorians freely give of their time, at considerable risk, as unpaid, voluntary members of the Country Fire Authority.

Like battles, the big fires are part of our lore: Black Thursday (1851). Red Tuesday (1926). Black Friday (1939). Ash Wednesday (1983).

Noojee horticulturalist, Tia van Horick, "70 going on 40", talks of a rush of adrenalin as the bright red tanker bounces along rough roads bearing its load of water to a fire. "It's not an enjoyable event but it is an enjoyable thing to go and do."

But whether they dwell on it or not, for thousands at 1226 rural and urban fire brigades who are on call 24 hours a day, 365 days a year, there's always a chance that each ride might be their last. Fifty firefighters have died "in the line of duty" since the CFA was founded in the mid-1940s to replace the old Country Fire Brigades Board. Thirteen of them were killed on Ash Wednesday.

Les Hubbard's successor as captain of the Noojee volunteer fire brigade, Terry Strickland, is a sturdily-built, bearded bear of a man. He drives a forklift at the sawmill. Strickland and a workmate have permission to leave work to fight fires and assist at road accidents, chemical spills and other emergencies.

At 45, Strickland is a fairly recent recruit. He was "sort of shamed into it," he says.

"There was a brigade full of women, I couldn't have that, " he concedes with a gruff laugh. Attracted by neither a sense of civic duty nor fear of fire, he says he responded to an appeal for help in a magazine put out every month or two by the CFA secretary, Liza Bennett, 62. "So I thought, `ah well, a bloke should do something about it. I just sort of showed up."

The original brass bell is partly for display these days.

But the station remains a rallying point in times of threat.

An unemployed secondary teacher, a horticulturalist, a theatrical engineer, a woman who runs a fabric shop and works part-time in the post office. Six locals in Strickland's charge have nick-named him "Mongrel".

Another member, Dawn Thomas, 57, is "the Wet One". "She's our mermaid," says Liza Bennett. "She always gets wet."

They meet on Sunday mornings for a couple of hours. "Sometimes its fair dinkum training and sometimes general maintenance and cleaning up around the station and so on," Bennett says.

"We try to keep it in good condition. We're in the fire brigade . . . We're proud of it and we like to keep it tidy.

" Though each brigade has a rank structure and Strickland has two lieutenants, the Noojee station is a far cry from the formality of military regimen during training at the CFA college at Fiskville near Ballan. It's a world away from the image that lingers in some quarters since mid-1970s claims on ABC TV by a United Firefighters Union official that the then CFA chairman, Dick Eason, was creating a paramilitary, right-wing organisation.

Perhaps it's partly that they are on their own, away from the watchful eye of professional CFA officers, but theirs is an easy camaraderie. "Especially when we can put the hose on Terry," The Wet One chips in.

"There's the work side but there's also the social bond, " says Gary Weir, one of 820 paid CFA staff and based at Warrigal, where he and a colleague co-ordinate 1800 volunteers at 51 fire brigades in CFA Region 9 in western South Gippsland.

"The brigades vary depending on the culture of the area and who the members are. Some have lots of parties and social dinners and teas and get-togethers. Others get together more informally, have barbecues. Some just come down on the Sunday so they can do some maintenance on the trucks and see their neighbors and talk."

For the volunteers, commitment to the CFA can be disruptive to domestic life.

Neil Bartlett, 35, is a benchman who cuts timber at a Noojee mill, says, "my missus is glad to get rid of me for a couple of hours". Strickland says his wife has told him to "make your tea down there". And Bennett's husband "thinks he's not looked after . . . especially when you get called out at meal times".

The CFA traces its origins to the bush "bucket brigades" of the last century. The Burwood headquarters is base for a powerful organisation that now has highly computerised monitoring systems, extensive radio connections, a 2000-strong fleet of trucks, 17 planes and helicopters.

As many as 2.5 million people live in the area for which the CFA is responsible: all of rural Victoria except state forests and national parks. Funded through fire insurance premiums and the State Government, its presence extends from the million or so residents of outer suburbs such as Frankston, Dandenong, Cranbourne, Melton and Werribee to the lone shed on some isolated, country back block.

"In a number of places, the CFA is the only thing left in the township," says Gary Weir. Noojee would be among the quietest stations in his region; the busiest are at Warrigal and Moe.

"Especially in a lot of the very small rural communities, they've closed down the primary school, a lot of the halls have fallen into disrepair and practically the only thing that signifies that there's a township there - or that it has a name representing a township - is the fire station. It's just sort of sitting there."

Noojee's seven firefighters have received 12 calls since last July. They might be needed to attend a fire or just a smouldering windrow. A car collision or a tree across the road. "A car that needs to be pulled back onto the road," says Liza Bennett, whose recent duties included handing out CFA educational leaflets in Captain Koala garb. "A car on fire on the trestle bridge. A tractor on fire. House fires . . ."

At which point, Strickland interjects: ". . . which was 12 kilometres up the road. By the time we got there, it was far too late."

After 20 years' service, Les Hubbard retired from the CFA two years ago and none of the seven volunteers lived there at the time of the 1983 fires.

In one hot spell, the CFA attended 180 separate fires around the state. "I was lying in the swimming pool at home," says Graeme Elliott, 47, an owner-driver for Boral Bricks. "I saw the smoke on the hill, thought, `Jesus this doesn't look good, maybe they needed my services.' He drove over to offer his services at the Belgrave South brigade and has been a volunteer firefighter since. HE now turns out at the Boronia CFA brigade on the outer eastern fringe of suburban Melbourne where Neil Parlby, a 46-year- old maintenance contractor and veteran of 19 years who followed in the footsteps of his volunteer firefighter father, Norm, is

first lieutenant.

Parlby, had knocked off from work early because of the heat and dropped in at the station on his way home at around 3.

30pm. Within 10 minutes or so, he found himself on a fire engine.

He remembers pulling into a street half an hour after the flames had passed through on Ash Wednesday. All that remained of some houses were stumps or holes in the ground. "I had been to a lot of bushfires but never anything with the intense heat of that fire," Parlby says.

The Boronia brigade is one of seven in the busy Knox Group that handles 2000 emergencies a year including factories, commercial and residential premises, grass and bushfires, industrial rescues and helps with severe vehicle collisions.

On the afternoon of our visit, volunteers Brian Cross, a 25-year-old transit police constable, and Bill Ireland, 49, a postman at Bayswater had been part of a six-man crew on a tanker to a suspected fire at a primary school in Ferntree Gully. It turned out to be nothing serious.

Bill Ireland has been in the CFA for 29 years. "During the really bad days I'm always looking over the hills," he says. "You're always keeping your eyes peeled. I turn out with the Ferntree Gully fire brigade too if I hear their siren I go. I'm just as close to them."

Ever mindful of the threat of fire since his recent arrival from Geelong, Noojee theatrical engineer Peter Brown, 36, says: "I feel that if I don't do it, I can't expect anybody else to. It's my way of putting something back into the community.

" The Noojee fire truck heads into the state forest. We stand on a mountain slope - the very place, explains Gary Weir, you wouldn't want to be when a bushfire was raging out of control.

This summer, the weather has been forgiving. But he knows that one day, after a long dry spell, the north wind will rise and there will be smoke on the horizon.

Photos Action stations: Bayswater postman Bill Ireland (right) with fellow volunteers; Historic hot spot: Members of the Noojee brigade at the disused railway trestle bridge and (inset) the clean-up at the same spot after the 1939 bush fires. Main picture: Sylvia Tuz
