urn:contentItem:490W-NDN0-015H-534S-00000-00<published>2003-07-05T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:50:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FOCUS; Pg. 82</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>LAUGH?;<br/>I ALMOST CROAKED MYSELF</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">MOST of us try to be professional but that doesn't mean we can't laugh at ourselves. Humour should be an occupational requirement, not an occupational hazard.</p><p nitf:lede="true">In that spirit, today the Gold Coast Bulletin launches its Jobs for Jokes series, for which we want you to send in your favourite jokes about the jobs we do.</p><p nitf:lede="true">For example, what do you have if there are 10,000 lawyers buried up to their necks in sand? Not enough sand.</p><p nitf:lede="true">What about teachers? Those who can, do. Those who can't, teach. Those who can't teach, teach physical education.</p><p>No occupation is sacrosanct and you can send in as many entries as you like. Here's a few to start things off and, to prove that journos do have a sense of humour, we'll begin with the members of the Fourth Estate.</p><p>JOURNALISTS</p><p>A PHOTOGRAPHER for a national magazine was assigned to get photos of a great forest fire. Smoke at the scene was too thick to get any good shots, so he frantically called his home office to hire a plane.</p><p>"It will be waiting for you at the airport," he was assured, and as soon as he got to the small, rural airport, sure enough, a plane was warming up near the runway. He jumped in and yelled: "Let's go!"</p><p>The pilot swung the plane into the wind and soon they were in the air. "Fly over the north side of the fire," said the photographer, "and make three or four low level passes."</p><p>"Why?" asked the pilot.</p><p>"Because I'm going to take pictures. I'm a photographer and photographers take pictures."</p><p>After a long pause the pilot said: "You mean you're not the instructor?"</p><p>AN editor, a photographer and a journalist are covering a political convention in Miami. They decide to walk up and down the beach during their lunch hour.</p><p>Halfway up the beach, they stumble upon a lamp. As they rub it a genie appears and says: "Normally I would grant you three wishes but, since there are three of you, I will grant you each one wish."</p><p>The photographer goes first. "I would like to spend the rest of my life living in a huge house in St Thomas with no money worries." The genie grants him his wish.</p><p>The journalist goes next. "I would like to spend the rest of my life living on a huge yacht cruising the Mediterranean with no money worries." The genie grants his wish.</p><p>Last but not least, it is the editor's turn. "And what would your wish be?" asks the genie.</p><p>"I want them both back after lunch," replies the editor, "the deadline for tomorrow's newspaper is in about 10 hours."</p><p>ENGINEERS</p><p>TO the optimist, the glass is half full. To the pessimist, the glass is half empty. To the engineer, the glass is twice as big as it needs to be.</p><p>WHAT is the difference between mechanical engineers and civil engineers?</p><p>Mechanical engineers build weapons. Civil engineers build targets.</p><p>AN engineer was crossing the road when a frog called out and said: "If you kiss me, I'll turn into a beautiful princess."</p><p>The engineer put the frog in his pocket. The frog spoke again: "If you kiss me and turn me into a beautiful princess, I will stay with you for one week."</p><p>The engineer took the frog out of his pocket, smiled, then put it back.</p><p>The frog cried out: "If you kiss me and turn me back into a beautiful princess, I'll stay with you and do anything you want."</p><p>Again, the engineer took out the frog, smiled, then put it back.</p><p>"What's the matter?" asked the frustrated frog. "I've told you I'm a beautiful princess and that I'll stay with you and do anything you want. Why won't you kiss me?"</p><p>"Look," said the engineer. "I'm an engineer. I don't have time for a girlfriend. But a talking frog, how cool is that?"</p><p>PSYCHIATRISTS</p><p>WELCOME to the Psychiatric Hotline.</p><p>If you are obsessive-compulsive, please press 1 repeatedly. If you are co-dependent, please ask someone to press 2. If you have multiple personalities, please press 3, 4, 5, and 6.</p><p>If you are paranoid, we know who you are and what you want. Just stay on the line so we can trace the call.</p><p>If you are schizophrenic, listen carefully and a little voice will tell you which number to press. If you are depressed, it doesn't matter which number you press. No one will answer.</p><p>If you are delusional and occasionally hallucinate, please be aware that the thing you are holding on the side of your head is alive and about to bite off your ear.</p><p>A MAN goes to a psychiatrist and says: "Doc, I've got a real problem. I can't stop thinking about sex."</p><p>Says the psychiatrist: "Well, let's see what we can find out." He pulls out his ink blots. "What is this a picture of?" he asks.</p><p>The man turns the picture upside down then turns it around and states: "That's a man and a woman on a bed making love."</p><p>The psychiatrist shows the next picture. The man looks and turns it in different directions and says: "That's a man and a woman on a bed making love."</p><p>The psychiatrist tries again with the third ink blot. The patient again turns it in all directions and replies: "That's a man and a woman on a bed making love."</p><p>"Yes, you do seem to be obsessed with sex," says the psychiatrist.</p><p>"Me?" says the patient. "You're the one who keeps showing me the dirty pictures."</p><p>DOCTORS</p><p>A MAN speaks frantically into the phone. "Doctor, my wife is pregnant and her contractions are only two minutes apart."</p><p>"Is this her first child?" asks the doctor.</p><p>"No, you idiot! This is her husband."</p><p>A DOCTOR and his wife were having a big argument at breakfast.</p><p>"You aren't so good in bed either!" he shouted and stormed off to work.</p><p>By mid-morning, he decided he'd better make amends and phoned home. After many rings, his wife picked up the phone.</p><p>"What took you so long to answer?" he asked.</p><p>"I was in bed," she replied.</p><p>"What were you doing in bed this late?"</p><p>"Getting a second opinion."</p><p>LAWYERS</p><p>A NEW client had just come in to see a famous lawyer. "Can you tell me how much you charge?" he asked.</p><p>"Of course," replied the lawyer. "I charge $200 to answer three questions."</p><p>"Well that's a bit steep, isn't it?"</p><p>"Yes it is," said the lawyer. "And what's your third question?"</p><p>"I'M beginning to think that my lawyer is too interested in making money."</p><p>"Why do you say that?"</p><p>"Listen to this from his bill: 'For waking up at night and thinking about your case, $25'."</p><p>THE lawyer's son wanted to follow in his father's footsteps, so he went to law school. He graduated with honours and then went home to join his father's firm.</p><p>At the end of his first day at work, he rushed into his father's office and said: "Father, father, in one day I broke the accident case that you've been working on for 10 years."</p><p>Responded his father: "You idiot, we could have lived on the funding of that case for another 10 years."</p><p>A LAWYER was talking to his son about entering college and said: "How did you get it into your head that you want to be a doctor instead of a lawyer?"</p><p>"Well, Dad," answered the son, "did you ever hear anybody get up in a croud and shout frantically 'Is there a lawyer in the house?'."</p><p>TEACHERS</p><p>A MUM and dad were worried about their son not wanting to learn mathematics at the school he was in, so they decided to send him to a Catholic school.</p><p>After the first day of school, their son came racing into the house, went straight into his room and slammed the door shut. His parents were a little worried about this and went to see if he was okay. They found him sitting at his desk doing his homework, a process he repeated for the rest of the year.</p><p>At the end of the year, the son brought home his report card and gave it to his parents. Looking at it, they saw he had scored an A-plus for maths.</p><p>"What changed your mind about learning maths?" they asked.</p><p>"Well, on the first day when I walked into the classroom, I saw a guy nailed to the plus sign at the back of the room behind the teacher's desk and I knew they meant business."</p><p>"DAD, can you write in the dark?"</p><p>"I think so. What is it you want me to write?"</p><p>"Your name on my report card."</p><p>ACCOUNTANTS</p><p>AN accountant visited the Natural History museum. While standing near the dinosaur he said to his neighbor: "This dinosaur is two billion years and 10 months old".</p><p>"Where did you get this exact information?"</p><p>"I was here 10 months ago, and the guide told me that the dinosaur is two billion years old."</p><p>AN accountant is having a hard time sleeping and goes to see his doctor. "Doctor, I just can't get to sleep at night."</p><p>"Have you tried counting sheep?"</p><p>"That's the problem - I make a mistake and then spend three hours trying to find it."</p><p>A PATIENT was at her doctor's office after undergoing a complete physical exam. The doctor said, "I have some very grave news for you. You only have six months to live."</p><p>The patient asked, "Oh doctor, what should I do?"</p><p>The doctor replied, "Marry an accountant."</p><p>"Will that make me live longer?" asked the patient.</p><p>"No," said the doctor, "but it will seem longer."</p><p>THERE once was a business owner who was interviewing people for a division manager position. He decided to select the individual that could answer the question 'how much is 2+2?'</p><p>The engineer pulled out his slide rule and shuffled it back and forth, and finally announced, "It lies between 3.98 and 4.02."</p><p>The mathematician said, "In two hours I can demonstrate it equals 4 with the following short proof."</p><p>The physicist declared, "It's in the magnitude of 1x101."</p><p>The logician paused for a long while and then said, "This problem is solvable."</p><p>The social worker said, "I don't know the answer, but I'm glad that we discussed this important question.</p><p>The attorney stated, "In the case of Svenson vs. the State, 2+2 was declared to be 4."</p><p>The trader asked, "Are you buying or selling?"</p><p>The accountant looked at the business owner, then got out of his chair, went to see if anyone was listening at the door and pulled the drapes. Then he returned to the business owner, leaned across the desk and said in a low voice, "What would you like it to be?"</p><p>JUDGES</p><p>THE local ranger in a small town western Queensland tow had arrested a man for killing and eating a kookaburra. The man went before a judge to plead his case. After pleading guilty, but with an explanation, the judge asked him why he did it.</p><p>"I was just trying to feed my hungry family," he told the judge, "and I've never done anything like that before."</p><p>The judge, being a family man himself, had a soft heart and agreed to let the man go free, since he was only trying to feed his starving family and it was his first and only offence.</p><p>"Before you go, though, I want to ask you a question," the judge quipped, "What does kookaburra taste like?"</p><p>"Well your honour," the man told him, "it's not as tender as platypus but it's better than koala."</p><p>AT the height of a political corruption trial, the prosecuting attorney attacked a witness.</p><p>"Isn't it true," he bellowed, "that you accepted $5000 to compromise this case?"</p><p>The witness stared out the window as though he hadn't heard the question.</p><p>"Isn't it true that you accepted $5000 to compromise this case?" the lawyer repeated.</p><p>The witness still did not respond.</p><p>Finally, the judge leaned over and said, "Sir, please answer the question."</p><p>"Oh," the startled witness said, "I thought he was talking to you."</p><p>A YOUNG lawyer was defending a wealthy businessman in a complicated lawsuit. Unfortunately, the evidence was against his client, and he feared the worst. So the lawyer asked the senior partner of the law firm if it would be appropriate to send the judge a box of Havana cigars.</p><p>The partner was horrified.</p><p>"The judge is an honorable man," the partner exclaimed.</p><p>"If you do that, I can guarantee you will lose the case!"</p><p>Weeks later the judge ruled in favor of the lawyer's client. The partner took him to lunch to congratulate him.</p><p>"Aren't you glad you didn't send those cigars to the judge?", the partner asked.</p><p>"But I did send them," replied the lawyer.</p><p>"I just enclosed the plaintiff's lawyer's business card!"</p><p>MUSICIANS</p><p>A RESEARCHER arrives in Borneo to gather data for his thesis. Accompanied by his trusty guide, he seeks out a very remote locale for researching the mating behaviour of the giant rat of Sumatra.</p><p>Around dusk of the first day, he's sitting by the campfire with his guide when in the distance, he hears tribal drums.</p><p>They get louder. The guide announces, "I don't like the sound of those drums."</p><p>The dusk turns evening. The drums get louder.</p><p>The guide says, "I really don't like the sound of those drums."</p><p>Evening turns to dead of night. The drums get louder and louder, until it is obvious that the drummers must be quite close.</p><p>The guide says again, "I really don't like the sound of those drums."</p><p>Suddenly the drums stop, and a voice from the darkness cries out, "Hey man, he's not our regular drummer!"</p><p>An anthropologist decides to investigate the natives of a far-flung tropical island. He flew there, found a guide with a canoe to take him up the river to the remote site where he would make his collections.</p><p>About noon on the second day of travel up the river they began to hear drums. Being a city boy by nature, the anthropologist was disturbed by this. He asked the guide, "What are those drums?"</p><p>The guide turned to him and said "Drums OK, but very bad when they stop."</p><p>Then, after some hours, the drums suddenly stopped!</p><p>This hit the anthropologist like a ton of bricks, and he yelled at the guide: "The Drums have stopped, what happens now?"</p><p>The guide crouched down, covered his head with his hands and said, "Bass Solo".</p><p>HOTELIER</p><p>A TRAVELLER pulls into a hotel around midnight and asks the clerk for a single room. As the clerk fills out the paperwork, the man looks around and sees a gorgeous blonde sitting in the lobby.</p><p>He tells the clerk to wait while he disappears into the lobby. After a minute he comes back, with the girl on his arm.</p><p>"Fancy meeting my wife here," he says to the clerk.</p><p>"Guess I'll need a double room for the night."</p><p>Next morning, he comes to settle his bill, and finds the amount to be over $3000.</p><p>"What's the meaning of this?" he yells at the clerk. "I've only been here one night!"</p><p>"Yes," says the clerk, "but your wife has been here for three weeks."</p><p>A MAN wrote a letter to a small hotel he planned to visit on his vacation: "I would very much like to bring my dog with me. He is well-groomed and very well behaved. Would you be willing to permit me to keep him in my room with me at night?"</p><p>An immediate reply came from the hotel owner, who said, "I've been operating this hotel for many years. In all that time, I've never had a dog steal towels, bedclothes, silverware or pictures off the walls. I've never had to evict a dog in the middle of the night for being drunk and disorderly. And I've never had a dog run out on a hotel bill. Yes, indeed, your dog is welcome at my hotel. And, if your dog will vouch for you, you're welcome to stay here, too."</p><p>* PUT your name and contact details on the back of an envelope and send your entries to Michael Jacobson, Jobs for Jokes, PO Box 5001, Gold Coast Mail Centre, 9726. Or email to <email normalizedValue="mailto:features@gcb.newsltd.com.au">features@gcb.newsltd.com.au</email></p><p>Staff and families of Gold Coast Publications, newsagents, subnewsagents and associated sponsors are ineligible to enter.</p><p>Contact details are required for the sole purpose of notifying the winners.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4P78-1640-TXN5-S333-00000-00The Chinese plague2003-05-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T15:50:12ZLexisNexisAGENDAPg. 6The Chinese plagueFeaturesChris Taylor

Is SARS "the big one"? Perhaps, perhaps not. Either way, Chris Taylor writes, it demonstrates how China's inability to tell the truth threatens us all.

IN MID-2001, a Hong Kong magazine ran a front-page story about how the world's next flu pandemic would hatch in southern China and infect the rest of the world via Hong Kong. The story espoused the theory that the Spanish Flu of 1918, which eventually claimed 20 million lives, had leapt from pigs to humans in southern China and travelled with Chinese labourers to the trenches of World War One. It was no more than a theory, but on two crucial counts the magazine was deadly accurate: the two other killer pandemics of the last century, which killed about two million people, sprang out of China and so will the next.

In February 2003, 18 months after the article appeared, shops in the southern Chinese city of Guangzhou experienced a run on vinegar. The traditional New Year celebrations had just begun, and most of China's 1.36 billion people were either en route to their hometowns or already with their families enjoying the longest and most anticipated holiday season of the year. Vinegar does not usually play a part in Chinese New Year. But it is a traditional fumigant used by Chinese in times of plague. If the world had been watching, alarm bells might have rung.

Instead, Spring Festival, as the Chinese call the lunar New Year, was celebrated as usual, with a massive countrywide exodus - more than 130 million trips by train, nearly nine million by air, a staggering 1.9 billion on the roads. For a deadly pathogen looking to hitch a ride, conditions were perfect. What's more, the Chinese authorities knew it.

On November 16, a businessman had checked into a hospital in Foshan, a city close to the Hong Kong border, with a mysterious strain of pneumonia. Two weeks later, in the drab, industrial city of Heyuan 200 kilometres away, staff at the Municipal Hospital began to get sick and die. On January 3, the Heyuan News ran a brief story denying the existence of an "epidemic virus", urging local residents not to panic. It was the first media reference, and the last for more than a month, to a disease that had appeared from nowhere in southern China. Two months later, it would reach Hong Kong, and the world would come to know it as Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome, or SARS.

As China unbuttoned for the New Year holidays, Liu Jianlun, a 64-year-old doctor, was working round the clock at Guangzhou's Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hospital. His problems had begun when a seafood salesman was wheeled into the hospital on February 1 with a high fever. He was barely able to breathe. Within two weeks nor could 45 other people in the hospital.

As they started dying, hospital staff began calling the salesman "Du Wang", the "Poison King". His coughs were like biological bombs, and the infection they spread was unlike any flu virus Liu had seen. He worried that he was witnessing the birth of a new epidemic, and that the authorities were turning a blind eye to it.

Concerned that news of the disease might cause panic and affect foreign investment and the tourism industry, a news blackout had been imposed. Like previous outbreaks of new strains of the flu, Chinese officials hoped this one would burn out and retreat to wherever it had come from before the world noticed.

If Liu Jianlun had been working at an Australian hospital and thought the government was ignoring the birth of a new life-threatening disease, he would probably have gone to the press. In China, such a move would have spelled the end of his career. It would also have been a waste of time.

The Chinese media were already aware of the emerging epidemic, but journalists could do nothing but watch until February 11, when Guangdong provincial health officials held a belated news conference. A disease called "atypical pneumonia" had sickened 305 people and killed five but was now under control, they said. Among the brief flurry of articles that appeared in the provincial press was an interview with a local academic who accused the government of incompetence. The result: a second media blackout that lasted until March.

Shortly after the February 11 press conference, Liu received a phone call from Hong Kong inviting him to a family wedding. He was feeling unwell, but he put it down to overwork. He'd taken precautions against catching atypical pneumonia, and didn't want to miss the wedding. Besides, a visit to Hong Kong would also allow him to consult with Hong Kong University specialists on emerging flu viruses in southern China.

Liu travelled by bus from Guangzhou to Hong Kong on February 21. The three-hour journey took him through a corner of the world that has changed more in the past two decades than anywhere else in the history of the planet.

The Pearl River Delta is home to almost 40 million people. In the decades since Deng Xiaoping told China that "to get rich is glorious", cities and factories have sprung from the delta's paddy fields. Densely packed tenements tower over sprawling pig and poultry farms. When medical experts talk about the next influenza pandemic, the Pearl River Delta is the place they worry about.

Virologists think China sneezed and gave the world the flu between 2000 and 3000 years ago, when ducks were first domesticated. The influenza virus lives harmlessly in the digestive systems of ducks, but when it jumps species, or a "zoonosis" occurs, it makes other mammals sick.

The most famous example of a zoonosis in history is the bubonic plague, which between 1347 and 1362 nearly halved the population of Europe. Like the flu, it started in China, when a virus found what scientists call a "vector" - in this case, fleas - that allowed it to jump species from rats to humans. By 1347 it had made its way to ports on the Black Sea, spreading to Sicily by trading ships. Like the Spanish Flu more than six centuries later, it was brutal. Boccaccio wrote at the time about people "eating lunch with their friends and dinner with their ancestors in paradise". It killed around 40 million people.

The plague, which still claims around 1600 lives a year, evokes fear because it emerges so rarely and kills so many (the last major outbreak was in western India in 1994). The flu, though, is always with us. It infects most of us many times in our lives because, like many common viruses, it is constantly mutating to fast-foot our defences. Scientists call these constant small changes "antigenic drift".

But every so often the virus "shifts", becoming almost unrecognisable to our bodies' defences. Perhaps a human strain recombines with an avian strain in a domesticated chicken and jumps. Such a biological event is rare, and when it does take place it usually burns out after infecting just a few people. But sometimes, as in 1918 and again in 1968, when the Hong Kong flu killed more than 700,000 people worldwide, the biological spark fans out like a forest fire through vast swathes of the healthy population.

This was precisely what experts had long been predicting would happen in the area Liu - now feverish and short of breath - drove through en-route to Hong Kong in late February.

The prediction was based on the unique conditions of the Pearl River Delta, where tens of millions of people live together with the world's largest populations of ducks, chickens and pigs. But unique conditions give rise to unique events. It was also possible - and this was something the experts did not talk about - that the next disease to emerge from the urban landscape of southern China would be something else. Something unexpected.

On February 21 Liu checked into Room 911 on the ninth floor of the Metropole, a sprawling three-star hotel complete with Chinese banquet restaurants and karaoke pubs in the heart of Kowloon, Hong Kong. The most densely populated slice of real estate on the planet, Kowloon is like an affluent version of crowded, push-and-shove Guangzhou, with wet markets and teeming housing blocks, their windows festooned with drying laundry.

Hotels in Kowloon are cheaper than on Hong Kong island, making them popular with Asian business travellers and package tourists. Kowloon also has the advantage of being more convenient to both China and the airport.

The next morning Liu was too sick to attend the wedding. It probably crossed his mind, after what he'd seen in Guangzhou's Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hospital, that he was too sick to be in Hong Kong. He left the hotel and walked five minutes down Waterloo Road to the Kwong Wah Hospital, where he told medical staff, "Lock me up. Don't touch me. I have contracted a very virulent disease".

It was too late, and Liu probably knew it. His disease had already spread mysteriously in the hospital he worked at. It had begun to spread at the Metropole Hotel, too. Somehow - perhaps in the lift, perhaps in the corridor, nobody knows - he infected seven other people staying on the same floor he was. They travelled to Canada, Singapore and Vietnam. Two of them were dead within three weeks.

The onset of SARS might be marked by a violent headache, or it might be marked by chills, diarrhoea and agonising pain in the joints. Within days liquid fills the lungs, making it impossible to breathe. Some patients' livers and kidneys start to malfunction and their blood stops clotting properly. Victims often lose consciousness for days and have to be kept alive on a respirator. The death rate may be as high as 10 per cent. Survivors are gaunt, enfeebled, some partially paralysed.

Kwong Wah medical staff knew none of this, however, and did not move Liu into isolation until his condition became life threatening. Within a month of his arrival, 70 medical staff and 17 medical students at the hospital were struck down. Liu died on March 4.

Eight days after his death, the World Health Organisation issued a global alert about atypical pneumonia. Three days after that, with infections in nine countries, the WHO was calling it Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome, and warning, in the words of director-general Gro Harlem Brundtland, "This syndrome is now a worldwide health threat".

The new pandemic experts feared would emerge from southern China's viral incubator was a new strain of the flu. But SARS was something altogether different, a whole new disease.

According to the WHO, around 30 new diseases have emerged over the past three decades. Almost all of them have failed the test of a truly successful virus, the ability to "amplify" in a host and then "shed" via a transmission method that infects large numbers of other hosts. The most frightening of the new diseases - Ebola, which kills 85 to 90 per cent of its victims by essentially liquefying their internal organs - consumes its hosts so rapidly and effectively it has so far never managed to spread beyond the five small

African communities in which it has erupted. The most well known of the new diseases, AIDS, requires such intimate contact to spread that it took from 1959, when it claimed its first proven casualty, until 1981 to infect 422 people in the US.

SARS, in other words, accomplished in the space of several months what it took AIDS, the 20th century plague, more than two decades to do.

If ever an example of the difference between Hong Kong and China were needed, their handling of the threat of disease is it. When 18 people contracted the bird flu in Hong Kong in 1997 and six of them died, the Government went straight to the source of the problem and slaughtered every chicken in the territory, all 1.4 million of them. When SARS broke out in Guangdong province, the Government chose to keep it quiet. It was a mistake that would not only endanger the world's health and economy, but also undermine the credibility of the Chinese Government itself.

Even in a country as closely kept under wraps as China, the truth has a way of coming out. On the evening of April 3, Jiang Yanyong, a 72-year-old semi-retired surgeon, was watching TV at his home in Beijing. That night the news featured a spot in which China's Health Minister, Zhang Wenkang, announced that China's capital had just 12 cases of SARS. Jiang couldn't believe his ears.

Jiang was a former head of surgery at Beijing's Military Hospital 301, and still did regular work there. How, he wondered, could the minister tell the world Beijing had only 12 cases of SARS when he knew for a fact there were 50 in his hospital alone? "I simply couldn't believe what I was seeing," he wrote in an email the next day to the state-run television station CCTV-4. "All the doctors and nurses who saw yesterday's news were furious."

The state TV channel's reaction was predictable: silence. But when the email made it to the hands of the foreign media, the allegations were soon circling the world. The WHO, which had bought the Government's line that the epidemic was under control, demanded access to Beijing's military hospitals. Within a fortnight, the Government upped its Beijing SARS statistics tenfold; three days later, the numbers were doubled again.

A tiny virus that hatched somewhere in Guangdong province had percolated 2000 kilometres north to the Chinese capital and infected close to 1000 people, rocking the central government. It had hitched rides to nearly every corner of the world, throwing the international airline industry into turmoil and snatching headlines from the US-led war on Iraq. And, while Beijing played cat and mouse with WHO inspection teams and foreign reporters, it was continuing its insidious assault on the Chinese population.

China's free-market reforms have made the country an economic miracle. But there are many victims of those reforms: tens of millions of workers laid-off from loss-making state-owned enterprises; tens of millions unemployed in the agricultural sector; and a public healthcare system that has been all but abandoned.

Guangdong, where SARS first emerged, is China's richest province, and has some of China's best hospitals. Rural China, on the other hand, has 70 per cent of the country's population but receives only 20 per cent of its public-health spending. In China's poor provinces - home to some 800 million people - hospitals turn away anyone who cannot afford to pay.

In educated, affluent Hong Kong, Singapore and Toronto, first-rate health-care systems have managed to prevent SARS from reaching epidemic proportions, but they have not been able to prevent panic. Despite widespread dissemination of information about the disease, it is still not known exactly how it spreads or even what causes it.

In uneducated, poor rural China, a ramshackle network of under-funded hospitals and clinics is the only thing standing between SARS and a vast population. In the days after Beijing upped its SARS count from 37 to nearly 900 the city descended into panic. Despite a ban on travel, first the student population fled and then the city's four million migrant workers from the poor provinces joined them. Businesses shut down. In less than a week, more than a million people left the city, taking disease and panic with them to the country's rural hinterland.

The Chinese Government's hold on power is guaranteed by its ability to deliver economic results. As panic spreads and business grinds to a standstill, that will be hard to do. In the meantime, its incompetence in dealing with the outbreak in Guangdong has allowed SARS to jet around the world.

Already epidemiologists are warning that if it is "the big one" - a fast-mutating virus that proves resistant to antibiotics - it will soon outstrip AIDS as a world health problem. Even if it is not, Guangdong's viral incubator has hatched a terrifying warning of the threat that China poses to the health of the world.

Last Monday, speaking at a press conference in Bangkok, David Heymann, the director-general of the WHO, admitted that "China will make or break this disease". The unanswered question - as outbreaks outside China are contained by efficient healthcare systems and the sharing of information - is not just whether this disease will make or break China, but if the big one will make or break the world as we know it.

Three photos: Transport hubs, a massive population and the proximity of animals and humans make southern China's conditions perfect for an epidemic. From top, travellers wear face masks at Shanghai Pudong International Airport; a crowded Guangzhou bus terminal; cats and rabbits crammed in cages at the Xin Yuan market in Guangzhou.

urn:contentItem:472J-J730-015G-S3BD-00000-00<published>2002-10-25T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:50:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FEATURES-TYPE- LETTER-COLUMN- LETTERSPHOTO; Pg. 30</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Letters to the Editor</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Safely under lock and key</p><p nitf:lede="true">That semi-automatic weapons were omitted from the gun buy-back in 1996 is curious in itself. In addition, it is</p><p nitf:lede="true">also curious that the death and injuries inflicted at Monash University this week by</p><p nitf:lede="true">a student using registered handguns has sparked much media comment about stopping illegal entry of guns.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The facts here are that these guns were registered and the student was a member of a gun club. These guns did not enter the country illegally -- so why is this issue being raised?</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The problem of handguns could be addressed by requiring that guns can only be owned by members of clubs and must be kept secured by a club on its premises at all times.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>MATP</p></bodyText></section><p>The argument put forward by owners of handguns is that the guns are required for use in a club. What then is the argument that leads to the conclusion that guns should be allowed to leave club premises?</p><p> Peter Martin, Bonython, ACT</p><p>Given the terrorist threat to Australia, why then would you want to disarm the only people in the community with the ability to train the defenders of this nation to shoot straight?</p><p>Switzerland was never attacked because its population was trained to defend the nation by virtue of firearms training. To this day, every reservist has a firearm and ammunition in the cupboard at home.</p><p> Perhaps we should be asking, why is it so that offences with firearms are so low in that country?</p><p> John Scott, Dora Creek</p><p>Offshore expertise</p><p>As Sydneysiders amused themselves watching HMS Nottingham being piggy-backed in preparation to return to Old Blighty, doesn't it worry anybody that we don't have the facility to repair this kind of ship in Sydney? Don't warships get damaged from time to time?</p><p> If we cannot fix the Nottingham, can we fix our own?</p><p> Riju C. Ramrakha, Balmain</p><p>Lost in translation</p><p>You need not be confused, William Hicks (To the point, October 24). The virgin birth of Jesus was as natural as any other birth of children.</p><p> In the early days of translations of the Holy Scripture from the Hebrew to the Greek, the Hebrew word "almah", meaning "a young woman", was translated into the Greek word meaning "The Virgin". And ever since the Niceno-Constantinopolitan Creed by the Council of Nicaea in 325 CE, the Christian church never bothered to rectify this mistake in the translation and kept on telling us that Jesus was the result of a "miraculous conception".</p><p> Karl Kilian, Lake Munmorah</p><p>Silent advisers</p><p>Whether Piers Akerman likes it or not, children were not thrown overboard ("Sinking ships and Labor's dirty tactics," Daily Telegraph, October 24). Several people in the Government and military were aware of this and were silent about it while John Howard ranted and raved about "these people" in part</p><p>of his pre-election propaganda campaign.</p><p> The choice is simple: Mr Howard is either a liar with</p><p>no ethics and utter contempt for the Australian people, who repeatedly lied to the Australian people, or he said what he believed to be true because no one who worked for him would tell him the truth -- which means he is incompetent in terms of running the Government he heads. It's that simple.</p><p> Adrian Bain, Pendle Hill</p><p>Dripping ignorance</p><p>In my daily walk this morning through the richest postcode in Australia, I came across no fewer</p><p>than five people using their hoses to rid the footpaths of a leaf, and passed another three wet tracts as evidence of more. When I searched their faces for arrogance, all I saw was a dull, ignorant boredom.</p><p> The real drought is one of morality. Under the lovely greenery, the water streaming across those pavements and down the drains seemed more to me like blood.</p><p> Sadly, it won't just be "user pays" when the restrictions kick in. Get those Save Water ads back on TV, Mr Carr, and fine the abusers.</p><p> Nigel Abbott, Edgecliff</p><p>A lot of Sydneysiders seem indifferent to the severe drought our state is in. Sydney Water deserves congratulations for its current campaign to educate the public on water conservation, but with the prospect of a scorching summer and bushfire problems, surely we need immediate water restrictions.</p><p> Those who continue to waste water on lawns and so on need to wake up to the dire situation our country cousins face. Apparently, the affluent are more indifferent to the water crisis.</p><p> I doubt that voluntary restrictions will change attitudes sufficiently.</p><p> Anne Mooney, Silverwater</p><p>Luke Kasper laments Sydneysiders' criticism of Melbourne's weather (Letters, October 24), but I can only say we are justified. Sydney does have a higher-than-average annual rainfall for two reasons -- one, Sydney is never and will never be just "average", and two, numbers can always be manipulated.</p><p> For example, of the 365 days that make up Mr Kasper's annual rate, Sydney may have 65 extremely rainy days and 300 with nothing but blissful sunshine. On the contrary, Melbourne would have 300 days with some degree of rain.</p><p> So next time I'm in Melbourne, I'll remember my umbrella and sun-</p><p>screen, T-shirt and overcoat. You can never be too prepared when you have four seasons in one day.</p><p> And as for Melbourne being the most liveable city in the world, perhaps Mr Kasper should once again check his facts -- I'm sure Vancouver and Vienna are still top of the tree.</p><p> Tom Matosevic, Jannali</p><p>Luke Kasper should be congratulated for defending his city from the constant barbs of Sydneysiders. He is indeed correct that Sydney has more rain than Melbourne.</p><p> However, according to the Bureau of Meteorology, Sydney also has more hours of sunshine per day, fewer rainy days and a warmer average temperature. I guess that's why Melbourne is the only city in Australia that needs a roof over its sporting facilities.</p><p> Luke, I'm afraid the facts paint a bleak picture of your city. Full marks for trying, though.</p><p> Tony Williams, Dee Why</p><p>Melbourne's weather may or not be worse than Sydney's, but the southern capital wins hands down when it comes to quality of life. Anyone who has been to Melbourne knows that.</p><p> Ron Garland, Petersham</p><p>True to its nature</p><p>I was appalled to read of a crocodile being slaughtered because someone decided to go for a swim in a billabong at night (Daily Telegraph, October 24). There are posted signs telling people not to swim in the these infested waters, so if you swim you risk your life -- and if you risk your life, why should we kill a crocodile because of it?</p><p> Crocodiles may not be cute and cuddly, but they don't deserve to be killed because humans are foolish.</p><p> Deborah Cooke, Carlingford</p><p>Champions do us proud</p><p>In response to Mike Gibson ("Are the Aussies killing cricket," Daily Telegraph, October 23), I would argue that there are in fact three types of people who watch Australian sport: those who enjoy seeing us beat everybody, those who prefer a good contest, and those who just love sport and will watch either way.</p><p> I am in the latter group.</p><p> When the Australian cricket team is losing, critics complain the players are too old and changes need to be made. When we are winning, critics complain the games are boring and that there is no real competition any more. What are they meant to do? Draw every game?</p><p> It was great to see them playing so well against Pakistan, especially in such extreme heat. We should be proud of these guys. They played exceptionally well and have reminded us all of how good they really are.</p><p> Erin McGarrigle, Toongabbie</p><p>Why workers must drive</p><p>Transport Minister Carl Scully's announcement of increased penalties for infringement of the state's traffic</p><p>laws (Daily Telegraph, October 24) should be condemned for its adverse impact on community safety in western Sydney. One only needs to sit in a magistrate's court for</p><p>a few hours to find working people, many middle-aged with young families, begging to keep their licences after minor infringements.</p><p> It is ironic that the main reason for the severe impact of licence loss on people</p><p>in western Sydney is Mr Scully's other portfolio responsibility, that of public transport. In many areas of western Sydney public transport is inadequate, if not totally non-existent. The situation in rural NSW is probably much worse.</p><p> Working people in this state rely upon their driver's licence to make their living. The effect of Mr Scully's announcement, for many offenders, will be to make the penalty for exceeding the speed limit by 31km/h the loss of the offender's livelihood.</p><p> If Mr Scully is serious about road safety he would impose a higher licensing standard for four-wheel-drive vehicles and introduce a driver training regime that included instruction on how to control a vehicle in an emergency. Providing drivers with some simple tuition in how to control a motor vehicle would undoubtedly save more lives than continuing along the current punitive path.</p><p> Darren Magennis,</p><p> Windsor Downs</p><p>One hat too many</p><p>The week after the Bali tragedy highlighted again how confused the role of Australia's head of state has become. The Queen sent a message of sympathy -- but then so did many other foreign heads of state. We don't expect her to do any more than that -- nobody would have expected her to go to Bali or come here to console those affected.</p><p> Her Australian representative flew out to Egypt and his absence from here and Bali was barely noticed until late</p><p>in the week.</p><p> The Prime Minister, as usual, assumed the role of head of state in addition to that of head of government. But in so doing, his attempts to console Australians in Bali were nullified when they criticised him for what they perceived as the failings of his Government in the identification and protection of the bodies of their loved ones.</p><p> When questioned on the absence of the Governor-General, Foreign Minister Alexander Downer summed up the Government's attitude to a head of state with: "I think the significant thing is the role of the Prime Minister in these situations."</p><p> The Prime Minister cannot wear both hats. We need an effective, apolitical head of state.</p><p> Mike O'Shaughnessy,</p><p> Spence, ACT</p><p>I commend the Prime Minister and the Governor-General on delaying their attendance at the Bali disaster. During a crisis we need executives to act, not legislators to talk. Action first, talking later.</p><p> Kow-towing to Mr Howard and Mr Hollingworth would have severely hindered the important work being done when it was needed.</p><p> Dieter Greulich, Noraville</p><p>Jan and Len Clark (Letters, October 23) would like our political leaders to call a national day of prayer, "asking God to intervene and halt such attacks".</p><p> They quote a passage from their holy book, which claims such prayers are effective.</p><p> If this is true, it means Jan and Len Clark did not, after the September 11 atrocities, ask their God to intervene and halt further attacks.</p><p> Rather than closing my eyes and talking to the Clarks' imaginary friend, I would spend this national day of prayer doing something useful, like planting trees.</p><p> Richard Lead, Kenthurst</p><p> To the point</p><p>Can somebody please explain to me why an innocent crocodile had to die because of the sheer stupidity of an incompetent tour guide who allowed his group to swim in a well-signposted area warning of the dangers from such creatures?</p><p> Ann-Maree Davis, Surry Hills</p><p>I am disgusted that a crocodile acting on instinct was murdered in its own habitat and then cut up and frozen for police investigations. Surely this Australian icon could have been tranquillised to retrieve the tourist's body?</p><p> Naomi van der Velden, Lilyfield</p><p>With all the trouble involved in identifying the Bali victims, I wonder if now is the time for thumbprints to be included on all passports, not only for quicker identification but also for security purposes.</p><p> N. Walsh, Greenacre</p><p>In search</p><p> AUBURN DISTRICT HOSPITAL</p><p>The ex-graduates association annual reunion dinner will be held on November 1, 2002, recreation room, ground-floor accommodation block at 7pm. Pre-dinner drinks followed by smorgasbord. All ex-graduates invited to attend, please RSVP promptly to 95639735 (Myra Martinenko or Viv Bullivant) or 98991170 (Pauline Kelly) for catering numbers.</p><p> PANANIA NORTH PUBLIC SCHOOL</p><p>Former 6th class students during the years 1958 to 1962 are invited to attend a reunion to be held on Saturday, March 29, 2003. The location is yet to be decided and will depend on numbers etc. Teachers from those years are also welcome. Please contact Denis Drummond on 96020703 (after 5.30pm or on weekends).</p><p> ROBIN ST ALBANS (MOLESWORTH)</p><p>Robin lived at 17 Hawkesbury Rd, Springwood; worked at NSW Teachers Credit Union about 15 years ago, born April 5, 1962. I have been looking for Robyn for many years. Any information or knowledge concerning Robin or her whereabouts please contact Lee on 99477206 (w).</p><p> PLUMPTON SCHOOL</p><p>Reunion 1982 -- Year 10 or Year 12, 1984, to be held on Saturday, November 2, 2002, at 1pm at the Imperial Hotel - Rooty Hill Rd, Rooty Hill. Please RSVP to let me know approx numbers. Contact Maria Leitch (Castle), 98645501 or 0401575527 or (w) 98311993, or <email normalizedValue="mailto:maria@clickprint.com.au">maria@clickprint.com.au</email>. </p><p> PETAH FIELDS</p><p>I am searching for an old school friend with whom I have lost contact. Her name is Petah Fields and I wish to invite her to my 21st birthday party this December. She has a baby daughter, Mikaylah, and attended East Sydney High School in 1997 with me. Elise Bentley. PO Box 640, Rozelle NSW 2039, phone 0415761486.</p><p> BARRY NELSON</p><p>Wish to make contact with</p><p>a Barry Nelson, who I have not seen</p><p>since 1966. His parents lived at Toongabbie and he had a sister and brother. Jacki, <email normalizedValue="mailto:070619434@msn.com.au">070619434@msn.com.au</email> or 43991552 (w). </p><p> BONDI JUNIORS RUGBY UNION CLUB</p><p>An ex-players reunion has been arranged for all surviving members of the above club, to be held at 12 noon, Friday, October 25, 2002, at the City of Sydney RSL Club, 565 George St, Sydney. Everybody welcome. Contact Ferris Ashton on 99055350, fax 99394444, e-mail <email normalizedValue="mailto:faapaal@bigpond.com.au">faapaal@bigpond.com.au</email>. </p><p> ANDREW ROBERTS PHOTOGRAPHY</p><p>I am trying to locate the photographer who took the photos of my son winning his riding class at the Sydney Royal Easter Show in 1982. M.J. Cook, 31 Spring St, Arncliffe. Phone 95994426 or 0401291880.</p><p> BELLMOUNT FOREST</p><p>A Back to Bellmount Forest Day is planned for November 2, 2002, from 10.30am at the Bellmount Forest Fire Shed. Lesley Johnson, 48451102.</p><p> LAKE BOGA RAAF BASE</p><p>I would like to contact any RAAF personnel who were stationed at Lake Boga (Catalina base), who worked in the electrical fitters shop from January 1, 1944, to September 30, 1944. Please contact A. McGuinness on 96356578.</p><p>  If you have a reunion or are seeking information, send the details to In Search, Letters Editor, PO Box 2808, GPO Sydney, NSW 2001 or email us at <email normalizedValue="mailto:letters@dailytelegraph.com.au">letters@dailytelegraph.com.au</email>. Include a contact name and phone number. Emails should not include attachments. </p><p>Word power</p><p>DITHYRAMB</p><p>We've already identified the British journalist and Conservative MP Boris Johnson as partial to a bit of Latin (Word power, October 9) but he's not averse to throwing in a Greek reference when the circumstances dictate it -- or even perhaps when they don't. In a column published in the London Daily Telegraph on October 3, he wrote: "I'm going to wring the withers of the Government, I told him, and before he could interrupt I outlined my dithyramb of recrimination." A dithyramb is a wildly ecstatic hymn of ancient Greece, especially one dedicated to the god Dionysus. Perhaps you had to be there.</p><p>Exchange</p><p> Q In May 1942 I joined the WAAF and came down to Sydney to do my rookies at Bradfield Park. As it was my first time in Sydney, I had no idea of the layout of the suburbs, except that we caught the train at Lindfield. I know the area will be all housing now but I am curious as to what streets constituted the boundaries of our camp in 1942. Can anyone help me?</p><p> N. Walsh, Greenacre</p><p>Bradfield Park is situated at West Lindfield. Three streets constitute the boundaries of the former camp -- Lady Game Drive, Moore Ave and Bradfield Rd. The area is now occupied by the CSIRO National Measurement Laboratory.</p><p> Bruce Sinclair, Allambie Heights</p><p>QUESTION</p><p>Can someone tell me how the Brewongle Stand at the Sydney Cricket Ground got its name and what does it mean?</p><p> Stephen Hutchinson, Sawtell</p><p>*  Is there a question to which you've always wanted to know the answer? urn:contentItem:49M1-RVB0-01S8-84MS-00000-00<published>1989-12-30T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T15:50:12Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>And now for the 90s</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>GEOFFREY KENIHAN</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">The 1980s. From midnight tomorrow they become simply 10 more years of human history. Are you glad or sad to see their departure? That was one of several questions put to a cross-section of South Australians by The Advertiser this week. Politicians, public servants, sports stars, farmers, artists and many more were asked for their judgments on these four questions:</p><p nitf:lede="true"> WHAT have been society's greatest achievements in the 1980s?</p><p nitf:lede="true"> WHAT has been your own greatest personal achievement?</p><p nitf:lede="true"> WHAT is your one regret for the dead decade?</p><p>WHAT is your greatest aspiration for the last 10 years of the 20th century?</p><p> The answers were as diverse as the people who gave them.</p><p> But one subject was cited frequently - the forest fire of democratic freedom burning through eastern Europe in the final weeks of the 80s.</p><p> Also looming large was society's recognition of environmental issues.</p><p> For South Australia's Education Minister, GREG CRAFTER, society's greatest achievement has been the progress towards a more peaceful world, and the improvement in East-West relations.</p><p> His greatest achievement? "To comprehend the education system and to bring to the attention of the community the importance of education, not just for young people but for the whole of the community."</p><p> His greatest regret? "That it is almost impossible to balance my time with my family, the electorate and my ministry."</p><p> He also regrets "the increasing lack of respect and understanding which the community has for politicians".</p><p> "My greatest aspiration is to see the reversal of the trend in Australia where we have more wealthy and more poor people and, in particular, to see greater opportunities for the disadvantaged to obtain comprehensive education." The Lord Mayor of Adelaide, STEVE CONDOUS, said society's greatest achievement in the 1980s had been the recent triumph of democracy in many European countries, marked most significantly by the collapse of the Berlin Wall.</p><p> His greatest personal achievement had been the adoption of his only daughter, Chilean-born Stacey.</p><p> "It was a long, painful wait for (my wife) Angela and I, but Stacy has given me more happiness in the past three years of my life than anything else," he said.</p><p> Mr Condous said his greatest aspiration for the 1990s was to continue fighting for the cause of street kids and the growing problem of poverty.</p><p> South Australian Tourism Minister BARBARA WIESE thought society's greatest achievement for the decade had been that people "realised that the earth's resources are finite and must be protected more for the future". She saw her own personal achievement as "placing tourism in this State in the position where we are able to realise our potential as a desirable international destination". Ms Wiese regrets that "South Australians still tend to be negative and lack the confidence to compete on the world stage".</p><p> For the next 10 years, her greatest aspiration is "the development of a society that is prepared to work together and constructively make South Australia an even better place to live".</p><p> GAY NAFFINE, a leading South Australian fashion designer, retailer and national marketer, said she believed society's great achievement of the decade had been a "more tolerant attitude and a breakdown of social barriers, culminating in the recent events in eastern Europe".</p><p> Her greatest achievement had been the overcoming of fear of taking risks.</p><p> Ms Naffine regrets that she didn't gain more formal training in the financial and commercial side of business, such as an accounting degree, "which would enable me to drive my own business in this area".</p><p> For the 1990s, she intends to "totally enjoy what I am doing", and develop the intellectual and philosophical side of fashion, in order to relate her business to "the cultural, social, political and psychological needs of our society".</p><p> The coach of the Port Adelaide football team, JOHN CAHILL, saw society's greatest achievements as "awareness of the environment and the fact that people were apathetic about it before the 80s".</p><p> His personal high point was being Port's coach this year when it became the first team to win both night and day premierships.</p><p> His greatest aspiration for the 1990s is "to see myself as someone who can win and lose with dignity - and that's something that is easier said than done".</p><p> MARINA PEARCE, a 25-year-old dual Olympic Games basketballer, thought society's greatest achievement in the 1980s was "the invention of the microwave oven".</p><p> Her own high point in the decade was "without a doubt playing in the 1984 Los Angeles and 1988 Seoul Olympic Games."</p><p> She regrets not winning a Women's National Basketball League title with the North Adelaide Rockets and, for the 1990s, wants the Australian women's team to qualify for the 1992 Olympics in Barcelona, and "to complete the extensions to our house".</p><p> Champion racehorse trainer COLIN HAYES said he hoped the opening of the Berlin Wall would play "a major part in bringing peace to the world".</p><p> He saw his greatest personal achievement as winning two Melbourne Cups, with Beldale Ball (1980) and At Talaq (1986), and the Cox Plate in October this year with Almaarad. "Winning Melbourne Cups is every trainer's dream and Almaarad's victory in my last season as a trainer is probably the most emotional I've been after a race."</p><p> Colin Hayes' greatest aspiration for the 1990s is to see his son, David, break all the training records he has established in recent years.</p><p> LYNEECE SCHMIDT, hotelier and society identity, rejoiced that in the 80s it became acceptable for women to drink in a hotel and that "old money" was no longer the criterion for social acceptance. Her triumph for the decade was having been accepted in business as a female, while her big regret was to have been picked up for drink-driving. In the 90s she hopes to have children.</p><p>Australian Airlines' promotions officer KARYN BAYLISS thought the breakthrough of the 80s was that men had come to want women on management teams. Her personal achievement was having a child and her impish regret was "not giving in to all those blue-eyed, brown-eyed and hazel-eyed men". During the 90s she's set herself the task of getting an MBA.</p><p> KARYN FOSTER, a vivacious public relations consultant, also hailed women's acceptance in the professional workforce as a major achievement of the 80s. Her own achievement as a dedicated working woman was not having children during that time. She had no regrets and has set her sights on retiring in the 90s.</p><p> ALAN OLDING, founder and president of the Australian Sherlock Holmes Society, believed that while society had little of which to be proud in the 80s, the Voyager journeys and the probing of outer space was a great scientific achievement. Of himself, he said maintaining a good lifestyle while keeping out of the hands of finance companies was a fair achievement, but he regretted that all the 80s had done was to make him 10 years older. He aspires to live through the 90s in similar style to the 80s.</p><p> LINDSAY THOMPSON, general manager of the State's biggest employer organisation, the South Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, saw the tearing down of the Berlin Wall and a move towards democracy right throughout Europe as the great achievement of the decade. His own high point was "to be part of a team comprising chamber members and public servants which has achieved the doubling of shipping coming into the Port of Adelaide from both Europe and Japan". He regrets that industrial restructuring of Australia "has been too slow and, as a consequence, our overall standard of living has fallen".</p><p> In the next 10 years, Mr Thompson wants to make people more aware of the need to become productive and competitive on international markets.</p><p> REX LEVERINGTON, a 5AN radio announcer, also cited the fall of the Berlin Wall as the greatest event of the 80s. Personally, he felt the 80s had been a phase of mellowing and maturing, and he hoped in the 90s to learn to relinquish anxieties and come to terms with life as it is. Regrets? "Ah," he said. "Regrets. I've had a few, but too few to mention."</p><p> The executive officer of the Australian Hotels Association's apprentice chef scheme, GLEN LAWRENCE, said: "At last we have begun to realise the damage we are doing to the atmosphere with chloroflurocarbons."</p><p> Any regrets? "That young people are faced with AIDS and drug problems, which we never encountered in our youth." Her personal aspiration for the 90s is to see her apprentice chefs recognised for improving the standard of hospitality in Australia. She hopes the 1990s will offer "employment for young people who would otherwise be on the dole".</p><p> MIKE RANN, South Australia's new Minister of Employment and Further Education, says his greatest personal achievement was "finally learning to question old assumptions, thinking through things that were absolutely sacred cows".</p><p> Society's greatest achievement was a "growing appreciation of the value of multiculturalism and greater realisation that, out of diversity, Australia will find its strength".</p><p> His regret is not having been able to spend more time with his family and his aspiration for the 90s is that they will encounter "renewed activism" after a decade which was "a time for taking stock and rearranging priorities".</p><p> Freeling farmer MICHAEL SHANAHAN, a former senior vice-president of the National Farmers Federation, former deputy chairman of the Australian Wheat Board and past president of the United Farmers and Stockowners of SA, said the greatest achievement of the decade had been "the almost universal commitment by society to introduce control measures to protect the environment from further degradation following irreparable damage caused to the ozone layer, the destruction of natural resources such as rain forests, and the frightening effects of Chernobyl".</p><p> He regretted the serious loss of political and market power by Australian grain growers, "who lack the resources to compete with government and economic bureacracies, marketing boards and private industry. This alarming change in the past five years is continuing and, if not arrested, will lead to a crisis in farmer influence in the Australian grain industry".</p><p> In the 1990s, Mr Shanahan wants to see the restoration of the balance of influence in the Australian grain industry so that graingrowers, through appropriate reorganisation, can have an effective say in how reform and restructing is implemented in their industry.</p><p> ALDO IACOBELLI is an emerging Adelaide artist of national significance who also saw society's greatest achievement in the 1980s as the Berlin Wall coming down.</p><p> "My greatest personal achievement has been supporting my family, mainly through my art," he said. Mr Iacobelli's aim is to "keep on working and hopefully I can do that without having an extra job to support my family. Artistically, I hope to be able to express myself in a most sincere way in my work, without being compromised in any way, and that includes the monetary one. That is the hardest thing to achieve."</p><p> ROB BROOKMAN, director of the 1992 Adelaide Festival, said: "You can't go past the peaceful democratisation of eastern Europe as the most significant development of the 1980s."</p><p> Mr Brookman's major regret is "the pragmatism that has led to the vandalisation of land that should have been returned to the green belt and that now houses some of the ugliest buildings in Adelaide, while making a mockery of the Adelaide Railway Station, the one fine building we had there - in short, the ASER development and all it represents in the pragmatic 1980s".</p><p> In the 1990s, he looks forward to "more money for the arts".</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>cartoon: the 80s; cartoon: eastern europe;
